Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, 9 May 2007

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Hon. David Hawker)

Speaker: NA
Text: took the chair at 9 am and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS'

Speaker: NA
Text: AFFAIRS LEGISLATION

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT (ONE-OFF PAYMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: AND OTHER 2007 BUDGET

Speaker: NA
Text: MEASURES) BILL 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and explanatory memorandum pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented by Mr Farmer, for Mr Brough.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr FARMER
Text: Macarthur-

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Education, Science and Training) (9.01

Speaker: NA
Text: am)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The measures in this bill are a further dem-

Speaker: NA
Text: onstration of the government's commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: to older Australians and carers. These

Speaker: NA
Text: changes ensure that the people of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: share in the economic prosperity that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have helped to create. In addition, several of

Speaker: NA
Text: the measures will enhance the quality of life

Speaker: NA
Text: for many ageing veterans, especially those

Speaker: NA
Text: with a disability, or their war widows or

Speaker: NA
Text: widowers.

Speaker: NA
Text: As with past bonus payments, these new

Speaker: NA
Text: payments will be paid in the majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: cases before the end of the financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: These payments are possible because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's record budget surpluses, which

Speaker: NA
Text: have delivered this capacity to give extra

Speaker: NA
Text: support to these members of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first payment provided by this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will go to older Australians. A 2007 one-off

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of $500 will be made to each per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son of age pension age who is qualified for

Speaker: NA
Text: utilities allowance or seniors concession al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance on 8 May 2007. Recipients at that

Speaker: NA
Text: date of mature age allowance, partner allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance or widow allowance will also attract the

Speaker: NA
Text: one-off payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Older Australians not actually receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: the stipulated payment on budget night will

Speaker: NA
Text: still get the bonus if they had made a claim

Speaker: NA
Text: by that date and subsequently have their

Speaker: NA
Text: payment backdated to cover that date.

Speaker: NA
Text: Self-funded retirees will not miss out on

Speaker: NA
Text: the bonus payment-they will receive $500

Speaker: NA
Text: per person if they are, on that same date,

Speaker: NA
Text: qualified for seniors concession allowance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Carers are the second group targeted by

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Carers receiving carer income support on

Speaker: NA
Text: 8 May 2007 in the form of a social security

Speaker: NA
Text: carer payment or carer service pension under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Veterans' Entitlements Act will be paid a

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,000 one-off payment. Carers who receive

Speaker: NA
Text: the non-means tested social security income

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement known as carer allowance in ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dition to either wife pension or a partner ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice pension under the Veterans' Entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments Act will also be paid a $1,000 one-off

Speaker: NA
Text: payment. Any carer receiving carer allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance will be paid a separate $600 one-off

Speaker: NA
Text: payment for each eligible care receiver. Car-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers who have claimed the targeted payments

Speaker: NA
Text: on or shortly before 8 May 2007 and are sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sequently granted those payments, with ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: fect from 8 May 2007 or earlier, will receive

Speaker: NA
Text: the one-off payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Carers whose children qualify for a carer

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance health care card only will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible for bonus payments of $600. Carers

Speaker: NA
Text: who claim carer allowance after 8 May 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: and whose payment is backdated due to the

Speaker: NA
Text: application of the carer allowance backdating

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions will not be eligible for the bonus

Speaker: NA
Text: payment, even though the backdated period

Speaker: NA
Text: will have included payment for 8 May 2007.

Speaker: NA
Text: Neither of the special one-off payments

Speaker: NA
Text: provided by this bill will be subject to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come tax, nor will either count as income for

Speaker: NA
Text: social security, veterans entitlements or fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily assistance purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third group assisted by the measures

Speaker: NA
Text: in this bill are veterans and war widows and

Speaker: NA
Text: widowers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill provides for a once-only compen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation payment to veteran and civilian pris-

Speaker: NA
Text: oners of war interned by enemy forces in

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe during World War II, or their surviv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing widows or widowers. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: has previously made once-only compensa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion payments to persons interned by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese and the North Koreans. Prisoners of

Speaker: NA
Text: war of enemy forces in Europe also experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: enced extreme brutality and starvation, and

Speaker: NA
Text: suffered from some of the same diseases that

Speaker: NA
Text: affected prisoners of war of the Japanese.

Speaker: NA
Text: These payments are in addition to the special

Speaker: NA
Text: level of benefits POWs and their widows

Speaker: NA
Text: already receive, including automatic eligibil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity for a gold card and eligibility to receive a

Speaker: NA
Text: war widow's pension.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also amend the Veterans' En-

Speaker: NA
Text: titlements Act 1986 to increase the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of funeral benefit payable from

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,000 to $2,000. By doubling the benefit we

Speaker: NA
Text: are making a greater contribution towards

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of funerals.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, the bill will increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of the intermediate rate disability

Speaker: NA
Text: rate paid under the Veterans' Entitlements

Speaker: NA
Text: Act by $25 per fortnight and the amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: special rate disability pension by $50 per

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight. More than 29,000 veterans with a

Speaker: NA
Text: disability who receive special and intermedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate rate pensions will benefit from increases

Speaker: NA
Text: to their fortnightly payments. The pension

Speaker: NA
Text: increase will provide a substantial boost to

Speaker: NA
Text: the ability of disability pension recipients to

Speaker: NA
Text: manage their day-to-day challenges.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, the bill will also extend the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum period for backdating of war

Speaker: NA
Text: widow or widower pension from three to six

Speaker: NA
Text: months in certain circumstances. For those

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible war widows and widowers who

Speaker: NA
Text: claim within six months of the death of their

Speaker: NA
Text: veteran partner, the war widow or widower

Speaker: NA
Text: pension will be backdated to the day after the

Speaker: NA
Text: date of death of the veteran. The extension of

Speaker: NA
Text: time to the permissible backdating period

Speaker: NA
Text: will allow those dependants of veterans who

Speaker: NA
Text: are not automatically eligible for the war

Speaker: NA
Text: widow or widower pension more time in

Speaker: NA
Text: which to lodge a claim for the pension and

Speaker: NA
Text: will ensure that they are not financially dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: advantaged during such a difficult time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Crean) ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: journed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the resumption of the debate

Speaker: NA
Text: be made an order of the day for a later hour

Speaker: NA
Text: this day.

Speaker: NA
Text: SUPERANNUATION LAWS

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT (2007 BUDGET CO-

Speaker: NA
Text: CONTRIBUTION MEASURE)

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and explanatory memorandum pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented by Mr Dutton.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Dickson-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Revenue and Assistant Treasurer) (9.09

Speaker: NA
Text: am)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: As announced in the 2007-08 budget, this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill will make amendments to the Superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuation (Government Co-contribution for

Speaker: NA
Text: Low Income Earners) Act 2003 to double the

Speaker: NA
Text: government co-contribution in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions made during the 2005-06 in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Take the example of a person who earned

Speaker: NA
Text: under $28,000 in 2005-06 and who boosted

Speaker: NA
Text: their retirement savings by contributing

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,000 to superannuation out of their take-

Speaker: NA
Text: home pay. Provided they met the other eligi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility criteria they would have already re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived a government co-contribution of

Speaker: NA
Text: This person will now receive an extra

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,500 government contribution.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have turned their initial $1,000 into

Speaker: NA
Text: $4,000, turbocharging their retirement sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings. This amount will remain invested in

Speaker: NA
Text: their superannuation account, growing over

Speaker: NA
Text: time until they are ready to retire.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the majority of cases the additional co-

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution will be paid to superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: funds before 30 June 2007. Remaining

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts will be paid in 2007-08.

Speaker: NA
Text: This measure will result in an extra $1.1

Speaker: NA
Text: billion being paid directly into the superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuation accounts of lowto middle-income

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. This is in addition to the $2 bil- Act 1990.

Speaker: NA
Text: lion of government co-contributions that

Speaker: NA
Text: have already been paid into superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: under this highly successful scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: This time last year the government an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced the most significant changes to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's superannuation system in decades,

Speaker: NA
Text: including extending the government

Speaker: NA
Text: co-contribution scheme to the self-employed.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, the income thresholds for the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution scheme will be indexed next

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year in line with growth in wages.

Speaker: NA
Text: These measures are made possible by this

Speaker: NA
Text: government's continuing strong record of

Speaker: NA
Text: sound economic management.

Speaker: NA
Text: Full details of the measures in this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in the explanatory memorandum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Crean) ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: journed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the resumption of the debate

Speaker: NA
Text: be made an order of the day for a later hour

Speaker: NA
Text: this day.

Speaker: NA
Text: DEFENCE FORCE (HOME LOANS

Speaker: NA
Text: ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and explanatory memorandum pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented by Mr Billson.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr BILSON
Text: Dunkley-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Defence) (9.12 am)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill seeks to further extend the operation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Defence HomeOwner Scheme (the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme), from 31 December 2007 to 30 June

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008. The legislative basis for the scheme is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance)

Speaker: NA
Text: Late last year parliament approved the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence Force (Home Loans Assistance)

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Act 2006, which extended the

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of the scheme from 31 December

Speaker: NA
Text: 2006 to 31 December 2007.

Speaker: NA
Text: The extension of the end date was re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired to enable Defence enough time to

Speaker: NA
Text: review the current scheme and develop a

Speaker: NA
Text: home ownership assistance scheme that is

Speaker: NA
Text: more contemporary to meet the needs of both

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence and ADF members.

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence has completed its review of home

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership assistance and the terrific results

Speaker: NA
Text: were announced last night by the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: are ment as part of the 2007-08 budget. In es-

Speaker: NA
Text: sence, the new scheme will have a value of

Speaker: NA
Text: $864 million over 10 years. It is important

Speaker: NA
Text: that this new scheme is supported as it pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides ADF members with assistance to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve home ownership, recognising the

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty members may have in purchasing a

Speaker: NA
Text: home due to the nature of their career. This

Speaker: NA
Text: will have a significant retention benefit to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ADF, as it is a targeted measure involving

Speaker: NA
Text: progressively higher loan subsidies for those

Speaker: NA
Text: who serve beyond critical separation points.

Speaker: NA
Text: In essence, the new scheme will replace

Speaker: NA
Text: the old home loans assistance scheme, which

Speaker: NA
Text: we are seeking to extend with this bill. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide contemporary and relevant home

Speaker: NA
Text: loan assistance pitched at a level that reflects House:

Speaker: NA
Text: current prices. It will also provide increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements as members serve beyond key

Speaker: NA
Text: exit points, based on a 37.5 per cent interest

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidy of a three-tiered loan subsidy limit:

Speaker: NA
Text: four years, up to $160,000-which translates

Speaker: NA
Text: to about $241 a month-eight years, up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $234,000-which is about $353 per month-

Speaker: NA
Text: and 12 years, up to $312,000, which is cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently about $470 per month. It will be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsive to changes in the housing market

Speaker: NA
Text: and it will provide flexibility and choice-

Speaker: NA
Text: giving the ADF member choice of mortgage

Speaker: NA
Text: providers instead of requiring a single pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vider, as was the case under the old scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The extension that I seek today will allow

Speaker: NA
Text: time for action consequent to the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's announcement to appropriately for-

Speaker: NA
Text: malise the introduction of the new scheme. I

Speaker: NA
Text: seek to further extend the end date of the

Speaker: NA
Text: current scheme from 31 December 2007 to

Speaker: NA
Text: The extension will provide the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Bank with continuance of its exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing rights as sole loan provider under the act

Speaker: NA
Text: until 30 June 2008, however, and more im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portantly, will ensure that ADF members'

Speaker: NA
Text: eligibility to home ownership assistance is

Speaker: NA
Text: preserved. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Crean) ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: journed.

Speaker: NA
Text: BROADCASTING LEGISLATION

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT (DIGITAL RADIO)

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Billson:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which Mr Albanese moved by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment:

Speaker: NA
Text: That all words after “That” be omitted with a

Speaker: NA
Text: view to substituting the following words: “whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: not declining to give the bill a second reading, the

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) that the Senate Committee inquiry into

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill did not allow interested parties

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient time to consider and draft

Speaker: NA
Text: submissions to the committee, this con-

Speaker: NA
Text: straint not allowing meaningful consul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation on the bill;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the lack of information as to how the

Speaker: NA
Text: omission of the Digital Radio Mondiale

Speaker: NA
Text: (DRM) platform from the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: will affect the roll-out of digital radio to

Speaker: NA
Text: rural and regional Australia and notes

Speaker: NA
Text: that this legislation only specifies the

Speaker: NA
Text: use of Digital Radio Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: (DAB); and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) that trials on DRM and compression

Speaker: NA
Text: standards are still being carried out;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) calls for debate on the bill to be deferred

Speaker: NA
Text: until meaningful consultation has occurred;

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) demands that the Government make every

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavour to ensure that standards are in

Speaker: NA
Text: place to enable the rollout of digital radio to

Speaker: NA
Text: remote, rural and regional Australia”.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Before the debate is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumed on this bill, I remind the House that it

Speaker: NA
Text: has been agreed that a general debate be al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowed covering this bill and the Radio Li-

Speaker: NA
Text: cence Fees Amendment Bill 2007.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: Hotham) (9.16 am)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Before the adjournment last night, I was

Speaker: NA
Text: making the point that we support our going

Speaker: NA
Text: digital but arguing for our amendment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: second reading motion for the Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Digitial Radio) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007 on the basis that the government does

Speaker: NA
Text: not have the framework right for us to do

Speaker: NA
Text: that. We see the need for the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: digital radio because it is an integral part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the digital media landscape. However, if we

Speaker: NA
Text: are to embrace it, it is essential that all Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians embrace it, not just those in the

Speaker: NA
Text: tal cities. Hence, the amendment we have

Speaker: NA
Text: moved seeks a deferral until we have estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished the means, technologies and frame-

Speaker: NA
Text: work for ensuring the coverage of this digital

Speaker: NA
Text: reach to the whole of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting that the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: ans' Affairs, in the second reading speech,

Speaker: NA
Text: mouthed the words that this will be a tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology and a platform available to the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: of the country. He talks about ‘equitable ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess to new services in broadcasting for peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple living in rural and remote' areas of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. However, the bill requires that digi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal be rolled out only for state capital cities

Speaker: NA
Text: and that this has to happen before 1 January

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009, but when it comes to the consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: of technology for the regions, that will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: completed until a review of appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: technologies by 2011-in other words, a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view up to three years later.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason we have moved the amend-

Speaker: ment, Mr SPEAKER
Text: and you would be aware

Speaker: NA
Text: of it because you represent a rural commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity-is that we want to ensure that the tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nologies and platforms that are developed

Speaker: NA
Text: are compatible, that they extend to all the

Speaker: NA
Text: regions, that regions do not miss out or that

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not end up having to purchase more

Speaker: NA
Text: costly equipment because, on the basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: what the capital cities have rolled out, tuners

Speaker: NA
Text: and receivers are equipped to receive only

Speaker: NA
Text: what is appropriate for them and their tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology but not what will subsequently be

Speaker: NA
Text: needed for the regions.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know from the bill's explanatory

Speaker: NA
Text: memorandum that the platform being talked

Speaker: NA
Text: of as being available for the cities is not ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: propriate for the regions. The bill establishes

Speaker: NA
Text: the problem; the explanatory memorandum

Speaker: NA
Text: confirms that the technology in question is

Speaker: NA
Text: not appropriate for the regions. That is why

Speaker: NA
Text: we do not quibble with the need to go digital;

Speaker: NA
Text: we are saying it has to be a digital reach for

Speaker: NA
Text: capi- the whole of the country, not just for the

Speaker: NA
Text: capital cities.

Speaker: NA
Text: I urge the regions and rural communities

Speaker: NA
Text: to agitate to ensure that they are not left be-

Speaker: NA
Text: hind. Quite frankly, this legislation can leave

Speaker: NA
Text: them behind. They should be aware of what

Speaker: NA
Text: Veteris inherently involved in this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: They should look seriously at the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment we have moved, which is asking for a

Speaker: NA
Text: deferral until such time as technologies are

Speaker: NA
Text: compatible, so that we can move forward for

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: I said at the outset that we support going

Speaker: NA
Text: digital and we do that because it will help us

Speaker: NA
Text: meet the real challenges of an increased au-

Speaker: NA
Text: dience expectation. Digital radio is more

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient than analog, AM-FM, and more

Speaker: NA
Text: stations can be broadcast within the same

Speaker: NA
Text: spectrum. What will that mean? It will mean

Speaker: NA
Text: greater diversity, greater choice and greater

Speaker: NA
Text: competition when it comes to news, current

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs and entertainment. It will expand lis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tener choices and this is critically important.

Speaker: NA
Text: As we all know, radio is the lifeblood of

Speaker: NA
Text: those who spend time in the regions. People

Speaker: NA
Text: spend a lot time in cars and at home. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: their connection, in many ways. It is about

Speaker: NA
Text: news and it is about connecting communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties.

Speaker: NA
Text: The digital approach also will provide bet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter services with minimal interference and

Speaker: NA
Text: signal fading, better quality, described as

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘compact disc quality sound' and much better

Speaker: NA
Text: reception. You will be able to tune into a ra-

Speaker: NA
Text: dio station using its name only. You will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to tune to programs on stronger fre-

Speaker: NA
Text: quencies when travelling. This is all terrific

Speaker: NA
Text: stuff. Whilst we welcome digital radio, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: essential that we get the framework for its

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction right. That means ensuring that

Speaker: NA
Text: people in capital cities and people in rural

Speaker: NA
Text: and regional Australia will have the same

Speaker: NA
Text: access.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have had experience already with the

Speaker: NA
Text: regions being left behind the capital cities,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that is when it comes to broadband. Who

Speaker: NA
Text: has stepped in to propose the policy alterna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive? Labor, with its Broadband Connect. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has taken the view, because we have read the

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence, quite frankly, that the regions that

Speaker: NA
Text: already have access to fast-speed broadband

Speaker: NA
Text: over the internet are the regions that are go-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing ahead. Those that do not have it are being

Speaker: NA
Text: left behind. Governments have to step in,

Speaker: NA
Text: either to address the market failure or by

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation, to ensure that the access and the

Speaker: NA
Text: platforms are available to them. This gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment has not done so in the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: broadband, and it is not doing so in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to the spread of digital.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill does not adequately address the

Speaker: NA
Text: roll-out of the enhanced radio services to

Speaker: NA
Text: people in regional Australia. I will remind

Speaker: NA
Text: the House again of what is contained in our

Speaker: NA
Text: second reading amendment. In particular, I

Speaker: NA
Text: remind those members on the other side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament who represent rural and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional Australians. We note in our second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading amendment that the Senate commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee inquiry into the bill did not allow inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ested parties time to consider and draft sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: missions to the committee, and that this con-

Speaker: NA
Text: straint did not allow for meaningful consulta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. So this is another rushed job-a rushed

Speaker: NA
Text: job that is so typical of the way in which this

Speaker: NA
Text: government has moved forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second reading amendment also notes

Speaker: NA
Text: that this has led to a lack of information as

Speaker: NA
Text: how the omission of the digital radio

Speaker: NA
Text: mondiale-DRM-platform from the legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation will affect the roll-out of digital radio

Speaker: NA
Text: to rural and regional Australia, and notes that

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation only specifies the use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: other platform, digital radio broadcasting, or

Speaker: NA
Text: DAB. So the legislation only specifies DAB.

Speaker: NA
Text: It does not talk about DRM. It defers that for

Speaker: NA
Text: later consideration. The government says it

Speaker: NA
Text: will look at that later, but why not look at it

Speaker: NA
Text: now? Why should we be taking precipitate

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions in the absence of knowledge about

Speaker: NA
Text: the technology and platforms that will enable

Speaker: NA
Text: us to take that regional opportunity?

Speaker: NA
Text: Our second reading amendment also de-

Speaker: NA
Text: mands that the government make every en-

Speaker: NA
Text: deavour to ensure that the standards are in

Speaker: NA
Text: place to enable the roll-out of digital radio to

Speaker: NA
Text: remote, rural and regional Australia. Many of

Speaker: NA
Text: these communities, as I said before, rely on

Speaker: NA
Text: radio, particularly the ABC. The bill's ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: planatory memorandum notes that the suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess of the introduction of digital radio will

Speaker: NA
Text: depend on the take-up of the system by

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasters and the public. We heard last

Speaker: NA
Text: night from the member for Moreton, who

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about radio broadcasters welcoming

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill. I notice he did not talk about what

Speaker: NA
Text: the ABC had to say about this. One would

Speaker: NA
Text: have thought, if we were talking about re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional and rural Australia, that we would

Speaker: NA
Text: take some notice of what the national broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: caster has to say-a national broadcaster

Speaker: NA
Text: whose reach is almost 100 per cent through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out the whole of Australia, and which does

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a service for the totality of the coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, not just for the capital cities of the coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remind the House what the ABC had to

Speaker: NA
Text: say about this matter. It made specific rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendations relating to the roll-out of digi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal radio to rural and regional Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: ABC has indicated that it believes the only

Speaker: NA
Text: to technology being referred to in the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, the digital radio broadcasting, otherwise

Speaker: NA
Text: known as the Eureka 147 platform, will not

Speaker: NA
Text: adequately service rural, regional and remote

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. That is not what the Labor Party has

Speaker: NA
Text: said; that is what the ABC has said, in its

Speaker: NA
Text: submission to the Senate committee inquiry,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet this legislation is proceeding and the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is ignoring that advice. The

Speaker: NA
Text: DAB standard, the standard that is provided

Speaker: NA
Text: for in this legislation, was prescribed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister in October 2005 as the primary plat-

Speaker: NA
Text: form, but at the time it was also recognised

Speaker: NA
Text: that additional standards such as DRM were

Speaker: NA
Text: required to address regional and remote area

Speaker: NA
Text: coverage. Even the minister understands the

Speaker: NA
Text: deficiency of the platform being prescribed

Speaker: NA
Text: in this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ABC went on to say that a wide-area

Speaker: NA
Text: digital radio standard should be determined

Speaker: NA
Text: before the provisions of the bill are put in

Speaker: NA
Text: place. In other words, the ABC is saying,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Defer this legislation until we get it right.'

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what Labor is saying; that is what our

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment is saying. The bill omits the digi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal radio mondiale platform. The bill ignores

Speaker: NA
Text: the warnings and recommendations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ABC. The ABC notes that, if DRM is ulti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately adopted as the wide-area digital radio

Speaker: NA
Text: standard, it will be necessary for receiver

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturers to produce multiformat de-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices that are able to receive both DAB and

Speaker: NA
Text: DRM, as well as AM and FM analog radio.

Speaker: NA
Text: But as the ABC notes, in the absence of a

Speaker: NA
Text: second digital radio standard for regional

Speaker: NA
Text: areas, there are no incentives for manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: turers to consider the need to develop multi-

Speaker: NA
Text: format receivers in their forward program-

Speaker: NA
Text: ming.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the result of that? It could be that,

Speaker: NA
Text: by the time a second digital radio standard is

Speaker: NA
Text: settled that can extend to the regions, digital

Speaker: NA
Text: tuners that are only able to receive DAB will

Speaker: NA
Text: be available for purchase. Where does that

Speaker: NA
Text: leave the people in the regions? Clearly, a

Speaker: NA
Text: better outcome all round would be for all

Speaker: NA
Text: digital tuners that are sold in Australia to be

Speaker: NA
Text: capable of receiving both standards. But this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation will not provide that direction,

Speaker: NA
Text: guidance and incentive. That is why we say

Speaker: NA
Text: this should be deferred.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are not trying to be prescriptive about

Speaker: NA
Text: the technologies the government should

Speaker: NA
Text: commit to, given that trials as to the best

Speaker: NA
Text: technology are being carried out; we are say-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing: ‘Let's get it right. Let's take the advice

Speaker: NA
Text: and let's consider all the information that is

Speaker: NA
Text: available to us.' But the government has to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that regional Australia does not miss

Speaker: NA
Text: out on this technology. Our fear is that rush-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in haste to introduce this legislation will

Speaker: NA
Text: see them missing out. Why is the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment rushing it? Why shouldn't it be prop-

Speaker: NA
Text: erly considering the submissions that are

Speaker: NA
Text: being made? There has not been enough con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sultation, not only in relation to the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: on rural and regional Australia. The report of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate Standing Committee on Environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, Communications, Information Tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology and the Arts identifies a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: other problem areas, and there has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient time for those making the submis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions to consider the department's response

Speaker: NA
Text: to them because the department's response to

Speaker: NA
Text: their concerns only came in last week. There

Speaker: NA
Text: were some 137 responses from the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, yet there has not been sufficient time

Speaker: NA
Text: to consider them at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe that all of Australia deserves

Speaker: NA
Text: the best available standards. We believe this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill is letting down regional Australia again.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not know where the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: stands these days, but if it is not standing up

Speaker: NA
Text: for regional Australia who does it represent?

Speaker: NA
Text: Why are they supporting the undue haste of

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation? I say to the National Party,

Speaker: NA
Text: to the members who represent rural and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional Australians: support Labor's amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment because we are looking after their in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terests and ensuring that the reach is avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to them. We want digital but we want it

Speaker: NA
Text: for all Australians, not just for the capital

Speaker: NA
Text: cities, and our amendment, our deferral, will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that we get it right. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr FARMER
Text: Macarthur-

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Education, Science and Training) (9.31

Speaker: NA
Text: am)-You will find, during what I have to

Speaker: NA
Text: say in summing up this debate, that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed a number of the concerns high-

Speaker: NA
Text: lighted by the opposition. The Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Digital Radio) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007 and the Radio Licence Fees Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Bill 2007 provide the Australian radio

Speaker: NA
Text: industry with a unique and important oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to commence digital radio services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Digitisation is a key strategic issue for radio,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the last significant broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: platform to remain analog only. The Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian radio industry has lobbied strongly for

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of digital radio to enable it

Speaker: NA
Text: to respond to the opportunities and chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenges that digital broadcasting presents.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that digital radio has the

Speaker: NA
Text: potential to enhance the already high-quality

Speaker: NA
Text: radio services enjoyed by Australian radio

Speaker: NA
Text: listeners every day.

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition would have us delay the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of the new technology, and

Speaker: NA
Text: thereby deny the radio-listening public the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity of new and innovative digital

Speaker: NA
Text: radio services, until further consultation has

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred; yet a comprehensive process of

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation has already occurred in the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment of this legislation with the full

Speaker: NA
Text: support and involvement of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: radio industry. In December 2004, the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment initiated an intensive process of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry consultation, research and policy de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment to examine the most appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: technology and framework for the introduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of digital radio in Australia. This proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ess culminated in the release by the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Communications, Information Technol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ogy and the Arts in October 2005 of a policy

Speaker: NA
Text: framework to guide the implementation of

Speaker: NA
Text: digital radio, which is now being imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mented through this legislation. The gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's policy development process had

Speaker: NA
Text: the strong support and involvement of indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, and the framework was warmly received

Speaker: NA
Text: by major stakeholder groups when it was

Speaker: NA
Text: announced. The stakeholders have been fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther involved in the development of legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to implement the framework through the

Speaker: NA
Text: release of an exposure draft of the bills prior

Speaker: NA
Text: to their introduction into parliament and

Speaker: NA
Text: through the inquiry of the Senate Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Environment, Communica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, Information Technology and the Arts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Underpinned by this exhaustive policy

Speaker: NA
Text: development process, these bills provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: measured approach to the introduction of

Speaker: NA
Text: digital radio in this country, one that bal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ances a range of complex objectives and

Speaker: NA
Text: constraints. Two of these are the scarcity of

Speaker: NA
Text: available spectrum for digital radio and the

Speaker: NA
Text: choice of digital radio technology. While

Speaker: NA
Text: there are a range of technology standards

Speaker: NA
Text: available for digital radio, it will be crucial

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia adopt a standard that is widely

Speaker: NA
Text: deployed and for which there are a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonably priced consumer receivers avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able. Equally importantly, this standard must

Speaker: NA
Text: be compatible with the radio frequency spec-

Speaker: NA
Text: trum available for digital radio broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. The bill provides for the intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of services using the digital audio

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasting, or DAB, standard. DAB is the

Speaker: NA
Text: most mature and developed of the terrestrial

Speaker: NA
Text: digital radio platforms, and its adoption in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has the full support of industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: These DAB based digital radio services

Speaker: NA
Text: will be introduced in a progressive manner,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the first services to commence in the

Speaker: NA
Text: state capital cities by 1 January 2009. This

Speaker: NA
Text: progressive approach to service introduction

Speaker: NA
Text: reflects the view, supported by the interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional experience with this technology, that

Speaker: NA
Text: digital radio will supplement existing analog

Speaker: NA
Text: radio services for a considerable period and

Speaker: NA
Text: may never be a complete replacement. Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trary to the suggestions of the opposition,

Speaker: NA
Text: listeners outside the state capitals have not

Speaker: NA
Text: been overlooked. The legislation provides

Speaker: NA
Text: that regional markets will have an opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity to commence DAB digital radio services

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent on the interest of relevant broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casters in providing services. The commer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial radio industry has publicly expressed

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable interest in providing DAB ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices in a number of large regional markets,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is therefore reasonable to expect that

Speaker: NA
Text: digital radio services may commence in a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of these areas some time after 2009.

Speaker: NA
Text: While DAB is the clear choice for the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plementation of digital radio in Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: larger markets, it is acknowledged that the

Speaker: NA
Text: platform may be unable to replicate the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tensive broadcast coverage of services in

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the regional markets, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: AM services. Consideration will need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: given to whether the other technologies such

Speaker: NA
Text: as digital radio mondiale, or DRM, are better

Speaker: NA
Text: placed to address the audience needs of some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the regional areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: While DRM has particular strengths in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of its capacity to provide a very wide

Speaker: NA
Text: coverage service, it remains an underdevel-

Speaker: NA
Text: oped technology, with affordable consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: sets only recently being produced in any

Speaker: NA
Text: meaningful numbers. There would be risks if

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia were to draft legislation to support

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of technology that is yet to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve significant commercial support in

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas markets. This consideration, to-

Speaker: NA
Text: gether with the view of digital radio as a

Speaker: NA
Text: supplementary technology, supports the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusion that it would be premature for Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia to develop a detailed regulatory

Speaker: NA
Text: framework for alternative digital radio tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nologies at this time.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, there would be a clear benefit in

Speaker: NA
Text: continuing the assessment of technology op-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions for regional digital radio. This is conbeen

Speaker: NA
Text: sistent with the government's stated com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment to ensuring equitable access to the

Speaker: NA
Text: new services in broadcasting for people liv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in rural, regional and remote Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: To this end, the legislation provides for a

Speaker: NA
Text: statutory review by 1 January 2011 of tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nologies for the transmission of digital radio

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasting services and restricted datacast-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing services in regional licence areas. This

Speaker: NA
Text: review will allow for the appropriate consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration of issues such as the availability of

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment for, and the coverage characteris-

Speaker: NA
Text: tics of, various digital radio technologies, as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as the types of services that could result

Speaker: NA
Text: from the use of those technologies in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional areas, and will thus allow for adjust-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to the regulatory framework if neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the first phase of the introduction

Speaker: NA
Text: of DAB digital radio, it will be important to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide the commercial radio industry with

Speaker: NA
Text: an appropriate measure of stability and cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainty as they roll out services. The legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion provides this with a six-year moratorium

Speaker: NA
Text: on the issue of new licence area planned

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial digital radio licences from the

Speaker: NA
Text: commencement of services in the respective

Speaker: NA
Text: markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the legislation also seeks to bal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance the stability provided to incumbent

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasters with the requirement that they

Speaker: NA
Text: fully utilise the new platform. Each incum-

Speaker: NA
Text: bent commercial radio broadcasting licensee

Speaker: NA
Text: will be obligated to commence a digital radio

Speaker: NA
Text: service and to continue to provide such a

Speaker: NA
Text: service for the duration of the moratorium.

Speaker: NA
Text: Failure by any licensee to meet this require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will result in the licensee forfeiting

Speaker: NA
Text: their rights in digital and will require the

Speaker: NA
Text: regulator to issue a new digital commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: radio licence for the area concerned. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: an important obligation on the commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasters-a point that seems to have

Speaker: NA
Text: missed by the opposition. It will ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the digital radio platform is fully utilised

Speaker: NA
Text: and allow appropriate commercial entry

Speaker: NA
Text: where an incumbent commercial broadcaster

Speaker: NA
Text: chooses not to provide a digital radio service.

Speaker: NA
Text: In terms of transmitter licensing, the legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation provides incumbent broadcasters with

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to own and operate the rele-

Speaker: NA
Text: vant licences, known as multiplex transmitter

Speaker: NA
Text: licences, that will provide their digital radio

Speaker: NA
Text: services. This is consistent with arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for analog radio and digital television

Speaker: NA
Text: where broadcasters manage the transmission

Speaker: NA
Text: of their services and control the associated

Speaker: NA
Text: spectrum.

Speaker: NA
Text: The community broadcaster's involve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in multiplex licensing and operations

Speaker: NA
Text: will be by way of a representative company

Speaker: NA
Text: formed and owned by community licensees

Speaker: NA
Text: in each market. This representative company

Speaker: NA
Text: will enable the relevant community broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casters in a licence area to manage their col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lective involvement in digital radio-as pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided for in the government's announced

Speaker: NA
Text: policy framework-on an equitable and

Speaker: NA
Text: transparent basis. The government's policy

Speaker: NA
Text: framework also provides the community sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor with guaranteed access to capacity on the

Speaker: NA
Text: multiplex transmitter licences that will also

Speaker: NA
Text: provide the guaranteed access for digital ra-

Speaker: NA
Text: dio services of the commercial broadcasters.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation establishes a multiplex ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess regime to ensure efficient, open and

Speaker: NA
Text: generally non-discriminatory access to digi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal radio multiplexes and, in particular, rights

Speaker: NA
Text: for incumbent broadcasters to access multi-

Speaker: NA
Text: plex capacity. In the case of the wide-

Speaker: NA
Text: coverage community radio broadcasting li-

Speaker: NA
Text: censees, the legislation reserves two-ninths

Speaker: NA
Text: of the capacity of every foundation multiplex

Speaker: NA
Text: transmitter licence for the community broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casters in a market to collectively use for

Speaker: NA
Text: digital radio. This provides the sector with an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to participate in digital radio

Speaker: NA
Text: from the commencement of the first services.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to note that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: has backed up this commitment to the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity sector with federal budget funding of

Speaker: NA
Text: over $10 million to help community broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casters establish digital radio infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has also committed to

Speaker: NA
Text: funding the roll-out of infrastructure to sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port the delivery of digital radio services by

Speaker: NA
Text: the national broadcasters-the ABC and the

Speaker: NA
Text: SBS. Together, these initiatives will enable

Speaker: NA
Text: the sectors to participate with the commer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial broadcasters in the commencement of

Speaker: NA
Text: digital radio services in the state capital cities

Speaker: NA
Text: on 1 January 2009. This is an excellent out-

Speaker: NA
Text: come for the introduction of digital radio in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and will support the successful es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tablishment of the new platform. The imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentation of digital radio overseas has high-

Speaker: NA
Text: lighted that consumer take-up depends on the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity for digital radio to offer more in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of choice and quality of radio services.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Australia, the national broadcasters play

Speaker: NA
Text: a vital role in the Australian radio market and

Speaker: NA
Text: are a critical source of service diversity, with

Speaker: NA
Text: their services highly valued by audiences

Speaker: NA
Text: across the country. Similarly, community

Speaker: NA
Text: radio is an established player in the radio

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasting landscape, making a valuable

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution to the diversity of radio ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices. This funding package will ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the roles of the respective sectors are carried

Speaker: NA
Text: forward in the digital environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In terms of digital radio services, the leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation permits each of these sectors to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide any combination of text or still visual

Speaker: NA
Text: images as part of digital radio content or

Speaker: NA
Text: content in a form determined by the minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: This mechanism will allow careful consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration of any additional types of radio con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tent, such as animation of moving image ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: terial, in the context of the broadcaster regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: latory framework for broadcasting services

Speaker: NA
Text: and the experience of digital radio in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia and internationally.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, the legislation permits broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casters to provide multiple digital radio ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices rather than a single stream of radio

Speaker: NA
Text: content, and there will be no requirement for

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasters to simulcast their existing ana-

Speaker: NA
Text: log services in digital-although some

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasters may choose to do so. These

Speaker: NA
Text: measures harness the potential of the DAB

Speaker: NA
Text: standard to expand the range of radio ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices in a spectrum-efficient manner, ena-

Speaker: NA
Text: bling broadcasters to provide a wide range of

Speaker: NA
Text: programming that is responsive to audience

Speaker: NA
Text: needs.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the member for Moreton indicated, this

Speaker: NA
Text: is enabling legislation. It provides a frame-

Speaker: NA
Text: work for the industry to take forward and

Speaker: NA
Text: make good use of. Taken as a whole, the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures contained in this legislation cement

Speaker: NA
Text: radio's important position in Australia's me-

Speaker: NA
Text: dia landscape, providing industry with the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to invest in innovative new digi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal content and provide listeners with a rich

Speaker: NA
Text: and more diverse radio offering.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Jen-

Speaker: NA
Text: kins)-The original question was that this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill be now read a second time. To this the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Grayndler has

Speaker: NA
Text: moved as an amendment that all words after

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘That' be omitted with a view to substituting

Speaker: NA
Text: other words. The immediate question is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the words proposed to be omitted stand part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the question.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Original question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Mr FARMER
Text: Macarthur-

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Education, Science and Training) (9.48

Speaker: NA
Text: am)-by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: RADIO LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 28 March, on mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by Mr Billson:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Mr FARMER
Text: Macarthur-

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Education, Science and Training) (9.49

Speaker: NA
Text: am)-by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT (2007

Speaker: NA
Text: MEASURES No. 2) BILL 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 29 March, on mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by Mr Dutton:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: Prospect) (9.50 am)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: Tax Laws Amendment (2007 Measures No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2) Bill 2007 is an omnibus bill which the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition will support. I will be moving a

Speaker: NA
Text: second reading amendment in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: venture capital provisions when I turn to

Speaker: NA
Text: them later in the proceedings. Schedule 1 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill deals with the effective life provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions of mining rights. The amendments in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluded in this bill clarify the law so that it

Speaker: NA
Text: reflects the original policy intent. The

Speaker: NA
Text: changes mean that a taxpayer acquiring a

Speaker: NA
Text: mining right from a prior holder will be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to estimate the remaining life, rather than the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole life, of the existing or proposed mine

Speaker: NA
Text: to which the right relates, as with other as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sets. The amendments provide that taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: can work out the effective life of their min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing right themselves by estimating the period

Speaker: NA
Text: until the end of the life of the mine, quarry or

Speaker: NA
Text: petroleum field. Taxpayers holding mining

Speaker: NA
Text: rights will have the choice of using either the

Speaker: NA
Text: prime cost or the diminishing value method

Speaker: NA
Text: in calculating the decline in value, as with

Speaker: NA
Text: other assets. Once the life of the mine has

Speaker: NA
Text: been estimated there will be no requirement

Speaker: NA
Text: for a yearly or periodic restoration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: effective life of the mining right. However, a

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer can reassess the effective life if

Speaker: NA
Text: original estimate is no longer accurate.

Speaker: NA
Text: These amendments apply from 1 July

Speaker: NA
Text: 2001. This is retrospective because the 2003

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments were also retrospective to 1

Speaker: NA
Text: July 2001. This will ensure that the policy

Speaker: NA
Text: intent is reflected in the law since the introforward

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of division 40 into the 1997 act. La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor supports this move to clarify the law and

Speaker: NA
Text: provide certainty to taxpayers. I do note that

Speaker: NA
Text: it has been some time in coming. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: regular refrain from me because it is a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mon problem. The government are very slow

Speaker: NA
Text: to correct drafting anomalies that are pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: out to them. I note, in passing, that last

Speaker: NA
Text: night's budget included a cut in the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of staff for Treasury. I certainly hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be the staff who are involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: drafting tax laws amendment bills, because I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that, if anything, that area needs

Speaker: NA
Text: more resources, not fewer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 2 of the bill proposes to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: deductions for boating expenses to taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: who do not use their boat for specific busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness activities. The current income tax law

Speaker: NA
Text: allows only people who are carrying on a

Speaker: NA
Text: business with their boat to claim deductions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The tax law denies deductions for taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: who use or hold their boats to earn ‘passive'

Speaker: NA
Text: income. For example, a boat owner who oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: casionally rents out their boat for income is

Speaker: NA
Text: assessed on that income but is not able to

Speaker: NA
Text: claim any deductions. As the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: agree that this is unfair, we support this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure. It is a fundamental principle, in my

Speaker: NA
Text: view, that if you are assessed on income you

Speaker: NA
Text: should be able to claim deductions relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: generating that income. The amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: will allow deductions for expenses relating

Speaker: NA
Text: to earning income from boats even where the

Speaker: NA
Text: owners are not carrying on a specified type

Speaker: NA
Text: of business.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed changes will allow taxpay-

Speaker: NA
Text: the ers who cannot demonstrate that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: carrying on a business using a boat to deduct

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure relating to their boating activity

Speaker: NA
Text: up to the level of income they generate in

Speaker: NA
Text: that year from the boating activity. They will

Speaker: NA
Text: also allow excess deductions to be carried

Speaker: NA
Text: and deducted against future boating

Speaker: NA
Text: income activities. A taxpayer will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: deduct the expenses to acquire a boat; retain

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership; acquire rights to use a boat; re-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain the rights to use a boat; use, operate,

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain or repair a boat in relation to any

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation associated with that boat or any

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation associated with the taxpayer's

Speaker: NA
Text: right to use that boat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Expenditure in relation to a fringe benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: will be exempt from the quarantining rule so

Speaker: NA
Text: that expenditure by an employer in providing

Speaker: NA
Text: a boat as a fringe benefit as part of a salary

Speaker: NA
Text: package is deductible to the employer re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gardless of the employee's boating income.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is consistent with the general treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: under income tax law of expenses in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to fringe benefits. Labor supports this meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure. The amendments should ensure that tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers who generate an income stream using

Speaker: NA
Text: their boat are not treated unfairly compared

Speaker: NA
Text: to other taxpayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 3 of the bill proposes amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to the tax law relating to research and

Speaker: NA
Text: development tax concessions. It makes 10

Speaker: NA
Text: technical amendments to clarify the law, re-

Speaker: NA
Text: move unintended consequences and ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: the law accurately reflects the original policy

Speaker: NA
Text: intent of the R&D provisions. The amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments proposed by this schedule include

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions so that companies will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: object to the amount of R&D tax offset al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowed by the tax commissioner if they are

Speaker: NA
Text: dissatisfied with the amount allowed. Cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently companies can only object to an as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessment when they owe money to the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: office. The bill will also allow companies

Speaker: NA
Text: who do not choose the R&D offset to amend

Speaker: NA
Text: their tax return to claim it by writing to the

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioner. Currently a company must

Speaker: NA
Text: choose the R&D offset instead of the deduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in the company's tax return for the year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Once it chooses the offset, it cannot claim

Speaker: NA
Text: the deduction for that year. For the acceler-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated deduction, expenses incurred in having

Speaker: NA
Text: an outside body perform R&D activities for

Speaker: NA
Text: the company are deductible at the acceler-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated rate. The $20,000 minimum spend

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold does not apply. This bill extends

Speaker: NA
Text: this to companies wishing to claim the R&D

Speaker: NA
Text: tax offset for the amount of the contracted

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The R&D tax offset provisions may not

Speaker: NA
Text: cover all companies in a group as it refers to

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘taxpayers', which is too narrow to cover

Speaker: NA
Text: certain companies that the original policy

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to cover. References to ‘taxpayers'

Speaker: NA
Text: will be replaced by references to ‘persons' to

Speaker: NA
Text: cover all companies in a group. This is im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant because, to reach the R&D expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture threshold of $20,000, eligibility applies

Speaker: NA
Text: to all R&D expenditure in a group of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies. Further, currently a group of compa-

Speaker: NA
Text: nies may be eligible for an amount of the

Speaker: NA
Text: premium deduction without any firm in the

Speaker: NA
Text: group being eligible for the allocation of that

Speaker: NA
Text: amount. This situation arises where a group

Speaker: NA
Text: of companies have collective R&D expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture greater than the rolling three-year aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: age of the group and are therefore entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: the deduction but no individual company has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased their R&D expenditure over the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous year's expenditure. This is because

Speaker: NA
Text: the premium deduction is only available for a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of a corporate group that must have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased its R&D expenditure above its

Speaker: NA
Text: three-year average. Also, at least one mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber in that group must have increased its

Speaker: NA
Text: R&D expenditure over the immediate previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous year. This was an anomaly in the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. We welcome its correction.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will eliminate the criterion that

Speaker: NA
Text: R&D group have at least one member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: group whose expenditure for the year is

Speaker: NA
Text: greater than its R&D expenditure in the prior

Speaker: NA
Text: income year to access the premium so that

Speaker: NA
Text: the R&D group will only have to have in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased its R&D expenditure above the aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: age for the past three years to be eligible for

Speaker: NA
Text: the premium deduction. Currently an entire

Speaker: NA
Text: group of companies becomes automatically

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible for the premium deduction if a newly

Speaker: NA
Text: acquired company can establish eligibility

Speaker: NA
Text: due to expenditure incurred prior to joining

Speaker: NA
Text: the group. This bill will restrict eligibility to

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure that is incurred during the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany's membership of the group so that a

Speaker: NA
Text: group will not be eligible for the premium

Speaker: NA
Text: concession based on expenditure incurred by

Speaker: NA
Text: a company when it was not a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: group.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a result of the method for calculating

Speaker: NA
Text: the 175 per cent premium concession, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: possible that the premium concession will be

Speaker: NA
Text: negative in certain circumstances. As this

Speaker: NA
Text: concession should only provide a benefit to

Speaker: NA
Text: companies, the calculation will be taken to

Speaker: NA
Text: be zero. We welcome these technical and

Speaker: NA
Text: detailed amendments to the R&D tax con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions. However, I make the point that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: time for more than technical amendments. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is time for root and branch amendments to

Speaker: NA
Text: the R&D tax concessions. It is time that this

Speaker: NA
Text: government re-examined its very short-

Speaker: NA
Text: sighted decision to slash R&D tax conces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions when it came to office in 1996.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since that decision we have seen the aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: age annual growth rate of real business in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment in R&D plummet from 11.4 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent in the period from 1986-87 to 1995-96

Speaker: NA
Text: to 5.1 per cent in a similar period 10 years

Speaker: NA
Text: later. For manufacturing the story is even

Speaker: NA
Text: worse, with the average annual growth rate

Speaker: NA
Text: slipping from 10.6 per cent to only 1.9 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. At 1.76 per cent-already half a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage point below the OECD average-

Speaker: NA
Text: an Australia's overall R&D effort is set to be

Speaker: NA
Text: overtaken by China's in the next few years

Speaker: NA
Text: unless urgent action is taken. Following the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's 1996 changes, R&D as a share

Speaker: NA
Text: of output plummeted from about 3.3 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: to only about 2.8 per cent. We can only

Speaker: NA
Text: speculate about what would be different to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day if the government had not taken its

Speaker: NA
Text: shortsighted decision back in 1996. We can

Speaker: NA
Text: only speculate as to what our R&D rates

Speaker: NA
Text: would be. We can only speculate as to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether we would have had over 50 con-

Speaker: NA
Text: secutive trade deficits. We can only speculate

Speaker: NA
Text: as to whether last night's budget would have

Speaker: NA
Text: still predicted that the current account deficit measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: would blow out to six per cent of GDP-as it

Speaker: NA
Text: did-one of the highest figures encountered

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia's history. We have 10 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: wasted R&D opportunities, 10 years of fail-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure to invest in the future. It is time for more

Speaker: NA
Text: than technical amendments; it is time for a

Speaker: NA
Text: complete re-examination of this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 4 of the bill amends the tax law

Speaker: NA
Text: to allow for a deduction for donations of

Speaker: NA
Text: small parcels of shares in listed public com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies to deductible gift recipients. The

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments will allow taxpayers a tax de-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction where they make a gift to a DGR of

Speaker: NA
Text: shares in a listed public company where

Speaker: NA
Text: those shares were acquired more than 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months before making the gift and are valued

Speaker: NA
Text: at less than $5,000. This is eminently sensi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble and it meets with our support.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also amends the Income Tax As-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessment Act 1997 to update the list of de-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductible gift recipients. Schedule 5 adds the

Speaker: NA
Text: American Australian Association Ltd and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bunbury Diocese Cathedral Rebuilding Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: to the list of specifically listed DGRs, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome this. The American Australian As-

Speaker: NA
Text: sociation do good work-and have done for

Speaker: NA
Text: many years-promoting good relations be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween our two great countries. They played

Speaker: NA
Text: an important role in having the American

Speaker: NA
Text: memorial erected here in Canberra and they

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to play an important role in the an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nual commemorations of the Battle of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Coral Sea, as well as doing much other good

Speaker: NA
Text: work. Tax deductibility for donations to this

Speaker: NA
Text: group is eminently sensible and supportable,

Speaker: NA
Text: as are those for the cathedral rebuilding fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 5 also extends the DGR listing un-

Speaker: NA
Text: til 27 August 2007 of the Finding Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Foundation-which of course does good

Speaker: NA
Text: work in trying to find that battleship and

Speaker: NA
Text: those who went down on her-and reflects

Speaker: NA
Text: the name change of a specifically listed

Speaker: NA
Text: DGR. Again, Labor supports each of these

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 6 extends eligibility for tax de-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductions for contributions to DGRs where

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a minor benefit in return for their

Speaker: NA
Text: donation. In other words, where a fundrais-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing function is held-a dinner, a ball or some

Speaker: NA
Text: other sort of function-and there is a minor

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit received in return, such as the dinner

Speaker: NA
Text: on the night or some other form of minor

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit for attending the function. Schedule 6

Speaker: NA
Text: proposes to relax the eligibility thresholds

Speaker: NA
Text: for minor benefits to allow deductions for

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions of more than $150-it is cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently $250-where the market value of the

Speaker: NA
Text: minor benefit is no more than that. We sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port this. Fundraising functions and dinners

Speaker: NA
Text: are very important parts of a charity's fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: raising activities. Just a couple of weeks ago

Speaker: NA
Text: I was delighted to host the Learning Links

Speaker: NA
Text: charity ball in Bossley Park, which raised

Speaker: NA
Text: almost $50,000 for Learning Links. I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that Learning Links and other charities ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: preciate this amendment, and, of course, we

Speaker: NA
Text: will be supporting it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 7 corrects a defect in the defini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of ‘exempt entity' by ensuring the defi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nition covers all entities exempt from tax

Speaker: NA
Text: under the tax law. This bill will change the

Speaker: NA
Text: definition of ‘exempt entity' in the Income

Speaker: NA
Text: Tax Assessment Act to include any entity if

Speaker: NA
Text: all of its income is exempted by any Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth legislation or if it is an untaxable

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth entity. This will ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: ancillary funds and prescribed private funds

Speaker: NA
Text: can donate to tax exempt state, territory and

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth bodies such as public ambu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lance services, research authorities and cul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural institutions. This was the original intent

Speaker: NA
Text: of TLAB (No. 3) of 2005, which made

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to public ancillary funds and pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed private funds. I note that various in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitutions, including the Opera House, made

Speaker: NA
Text: submissions to the Senate inquiry welcoming

Speaker: NA
Text: this, and of course we join them in that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now turn to the venture

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill. A healthy venture capital sector is

Speaker: NA
Text: vital to the strength of the Australian econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy. Venture capitalists take risks-they

Speaker: NA
Text: invest in things which may or may not pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce them a return-and the tax system rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ognises this. The OECD notes in its Eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic policy reforms: going for growth paper

Speaker: NA
Text: of last year that Australia's venture capital

Speaker: NA
Text: investment rate, as a percentage of GDP, is

Speaker: NA
Text: below the OECD average and is very signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantly below the rates for the United King-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom, Canada and the United States. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government enacted the Venture Capital Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2002 and the Taxation Laws Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Venture Capital) Bill 2002 to improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: tax treatment of venture capital. This has had

Speaker: NA
Text: a questionable impact. Only 15 VCLPs and

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 PDFs have been registered since that

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government then appointed the Wat-

Speaker: NA
Text: son review to look at the treatment of ven-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture capital in our taxation system. The gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment says that this bill adopts the recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations and meets the concerns of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Watson review, which it received in Decem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber 2005. I say: ‘That's great. I would rather

Speaker: NA
Text: come to that conclusion myself; I would

Speaker: NA
Text: rather make that decision for myself.' It

Speaker: NA
Text: would be helpful if I and other members

Speaker: NA
Text: could read the Watson review. It would be

Speaker: NA
Text: helpful if the government would actually

Speaker: NA
Text: release the review that they commissioned.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the Assistant Treasurer comes into the

Speaker: NA
Text: House to sum up this debate I ask him to

Speaker: NA
Text: enlighten the House as to why he, the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try minister and presumably other cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers are the only people in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to read the Watson review. Why has

Speaker: NA
Text: that privilege not been extended to members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the opposition or to any other person in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country so that Australia can make the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision and individuals can make the

Speaker: NA
Text: judgement about whether this government is

Speaker: NA
Text: adopting all the recommendations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: capital section of Watson review?

Speaker: NA
Text: I suspect the government are reluctant to

Speaker: NA
Text: release the Watson review because it shows

Speaker: NA
Text: that their previous reforms have been less

Speaker: NA
Text: than successful. When a government com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missions a report that finds that something

Speaker: NA
Text: they have done has been less than successful,

Speaker: NA
Text: they actually get points for fessing up, being

Speaker: NA
Text: honest about it and releasing the report. They

Speaker: NA
Text: get zero points for keeping it hidden and for

Speaker: NA
Text: refusing to release it. And they certainly get

Speaker: NA
Text: zero points for bringing in legislation which

Speaker: NA
Text: is meant to comply with the recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of the report and not giving the parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of this nation the chance to read the

Speaker: NA
Text: report to make that assessment for itself. So

Speaker: NA
Text: the Assistant Treasurer today has an oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to explain to the House why that re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port has not been released. Indeed, he has an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity today to release it so that this

Speaker: NA
Text: House can make that judgement.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also note that last night the budget an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced further changes to venture capital

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions. These changes were announced

Speaker: NA
Text: in last year's budget. The day after this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, we are finally debating them. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: meantime, more have been announced. This

Speaker: NA
Text: reinforces the point that the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: very good at making announcements on

Speaker: NA
Text: budget night but is very poor in implement-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think there are 10 separate measures that

Speaker: NA
Text: were announced in the 2006 budget which,

Speaker: NA
Text: the day after the 2007 budget, we are still to

Speaker: NA
Text: see introduced into this House. I hope for the

Speaker: NA
Text: sake of the Australian economy that some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the measures announced last night are intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced into this House a good deal quicker

Speaker: NA
Text: than that. For instance, I hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: change to the $100 million cap-which my

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessor, the previous shadow Assistant

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, moved an amendment in the Sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate to achieve two years ago, and which the

Speaker: NA
Text: government finally announced last night-is

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced a good deal more quickly than 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months down the track. My point is: what

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence do we have that these measures

Speaker: NA
Text: will achieve the government's objectives

Speaker: NA
Text: when, before they were even introduced into

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives, further meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures were announced last night?

Speaker: NA
