Text: Schedule 8 amends the venture capital

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions to relax the eligibility require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for the concessional treatment of for-

Speaker: NA
Text: eign residents investing in venture capital

Speaker: NA
Text: limited partnerships or VCLPs. It also intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duces a new investment vehicle-the ‘early

Speaker: NA
Text: stage venture capital limited partnership' or

Speaker: NA
Text: ESVCLP. The aim of the tax concessions is

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide equity capital for a relatively

Speaker: NA
Text: high-risk and expanding business that finds

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to attract investment through normal

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial mechanisms.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 8 relaxes the restrictions on

Speaker: NA
Text: VCLPs. It does that in the following ways. It

Speaker: NA
Text: removes restrictions on the investor's coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try of residence. People in this sector have

Speaker: NA
Text: been calling for this for some time and we

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome it. It allows the VCLPs to invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: unit trusts and convertible notes, whereas

Speaker: NA
Text: currently investments must be in the form of

Speaker: NA
Text: shares or options in companies. It reduces

Speaker: NA
Text: the minimum partnership capital required for

Speaker: NA
Text: registration from $20 million to $10 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: And it allows the appointment of auditors to

Speaker: NA
Text: be delayed until the end of the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: of the investment; currently an auditor is

Speaker: NA
Text: required on an ongoing basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 8 also relaxes the ‘Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: nexus' test, which currently requires that the

Speaker: NA
Text: investee entity-the company the VCLP in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vests in-be a company resident of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and that 50 per cent of the assets and em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployees of the investee entity be located in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia for 12 months following the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment. The changes allow some invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments-up to 20 per cent of the committed

Speaker: NA
Text: capital-to be in companies and unit trusts

Speaker: NA
Text: that are not in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, this bill maintains the restriction

Speaker: NA
Text: on VCLPs that target investees must have

Speaker: NA
Text: less than $250 million in assets-a restric-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion generally not imposed in other jurisdic-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. I will be dealing with this in my sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ond reading amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I indicated earlier, this bill also estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishes a new investment vehicle-the early

Speaker: NA
Text: stage venture capital vehicle-which will

Speaker: NA
Text: progressively replace the existing pooled

Speaker: NA
Text: development funds or PDFs, which were

Speaker: NA
Text: established in that 2002 legislation and

Speaker: NA
Text: which have had, at best, patchy success.

Speaker: NA
Text: These new vehicles will be flow-through tax

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicles, like VCLPs; however, the income

Speaker: NA
Text: and capital gains tax earned by these vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: it will be exempt from any Australian tax. This

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption will apply to both resident and

Speaker: NA
Text: non-resident investors.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the attractiveness of these con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions must be measured by the following

Speaker: NA
Text: restrictions that will apply to these vehicles.

Speaker: NA
Text: The maximum size of the fund administered

Speaker: NA
Text: by an ESVCLP is $100 million. They will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be able to invest in investee entities hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing total assets exceeding $50 million; this

Speaker: NA
Text: restriction already applies to PDFs. Losses

Speaker: NA
Text: from these new partnerships will not be de-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductible by the partners. And once the total

Speaker: NA
Text: assets of the entity invested in by an

Speaker: NA
Text: ESVCLP exceed $250 million, the vehicle

Speaker: NA
Text: year must divest itself of that entity.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That all words after “That” be omitted with a

Speaker: NA
Text: view to substituting the following words: “whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: not declining to give the bill a second reading, the

Speaker: NA
Text: House condemns the Government for its failure to

Speaker: NA
Text: promote the venture capital industry and calls on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) increase to $500 million the value of assets

Speaker: NA
Text: of an entity invested in by an Early Stage

Speaker: NA
Text: Venture Capital Limited Partnership

Speaker: NA
Text: (ESVCLP) beyond which ESVCLP must di-

Speaker: NA
Text: vest itself of an interest in the entity;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) increase the time allowed for a partnership to

Speaker: NA
Text: divest an investment from 9 months to 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) increase the value of assets target investees

Speaker: NA
Text: of Venture Capital Limited Partnership can

Speaker: NA
Text: have, to $500 million”.

Speaker: NA
Text: This amendment calls on the government to

Speaker: NA
Text: remove the significant requirement that

Speaker: NA
Text: ESVCLPs must divest themselves of an or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisation which has assets of more than

Speaker: NA
Text: $250 million. As a step in that direction, it

Speaker: NA
Text: calls on the government to change that

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold from $250 million to $500 million,

Speaker: NA
Text: and to increase the amount of time allowed

Speaker: NA
Text: for an ESVCLP to divest itself of that inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: est from six months-which can be extended

Speaker: NA
Text: by three months-to a flat 12 months.

Speaker: NA
Text: Increasing the threshold to $500 million

Speaker: NA
Text: would encourage more investment in early

Speaker: NA
Text: stage venture capital vehicles and more in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment in innovative businesses in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. This is something which has been raised

Speaker: NA
Text: with me consistently in my consultations

Speaker: NA
Text: with the venture capital industry on this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know the Assistant Treasurer likes to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about consultation but doesn't like to actu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally do much of it, whereas I have been to

Speaker: NA
Text: various capital cities of this nation and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sulted directly with venture capitalists about

Speaker: NA
Text: the implications of this bill, and this is a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern which has been raised with me directly.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not imagine that it has been raised di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rectly with the Assistant Treasurer, because I

Speaker: NA
Text: know he believes more in the rhetoric of

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation than in actually doing it.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a step that the Labor Party is call-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on the government to adopt today. I indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate that, should we be honoured with gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment later in the year, this is something

Speaker: NA
Text: we would be reviewing in office. We would

Speaker: NA
Text: be examining this threshold and the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of time that is given to ESVCLPs to divest

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves of those assets. We would be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: viewing those things and having a very close

Speaker: NA
Text: look at them. But, as we stand today, we

Speaker: NA
Text: think it would be a sensible measure for the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to lift this threshold, which does

Speaker: NA
Text: not apply in many other jurisdictions and

Speaker: NA
Text: which does not give these venture capital

Speaker: NA
Text: partnerships long, in real terms, to divest

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves of these assets. So, while I wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: come these reforms generally, I remain con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned about the restrictions on the assets

Speaker: NA
Text: that can be held by both investment vehicles:

Speaker: NA
Text: VCLPs and the new early stage vehicles.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have said, the government is making

Speaker: NA
Text: these changes because the venture capital

Speaker: NA
Text: regime it introduced in 2002 is not working

Speaker: NA
Text: properly and has failed to boost the venture

Speaker: NA
Text: capital industry by an acceptable amount.

Speaker: NA
Text: The removal of some of the restrictions on

Speaker: NA
Text: VCLPs and the new vehicles are positive and

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome. However, as I have said, they do

Speaker: NA
Text: not go far enough. I fear that, unless the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment adopts Labor's amendment today,

Speaker: NA
Text: we will be back here in one, two or three

Speaker: NA
Text: years time amending this legislation yet

Speaker: NA
Text: again. Just as we are today amending the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2002 legislation, just as the government last

Speaker: NA
Text: night announced further changes-which we

Speaker: NA
Text: will be amending sometime in the next 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months, I presume-we will be coming back

Speaker: NA
Text: again to amend this legislation because the

Speaker: NA
Text: government, through its lack of consultation,

Speaker: NA
Text: has failed to take it up.

Speaker: NA
Text: Generally, I support this bill. I note that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government of its own volition referred it

Speaker: NA
Text: to a Senate committee. I presume that is be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the farce that we saw last time with

Speaker: NA
Text: Tax Laws Amendment (2006 Measures No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 7) Bill 2007, where the government refused

Speaker: NA
Text: to refer it to a Senate committee, backflipped

Speaker: NA
Text: and accepted Labor's referral to a Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: committee and then finally had to accept the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation of Labor senators to amend

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill. I assume that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: thought, ‘We'll avoid all that rigmarole this

Speaker: NA
Text: time and just refer it straightaway to a Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: committee.' I welcome that. I do not think

Speaker: NA
Text: every tax laws amendment bill has to be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to a Senate committee-may I let the

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistant Treasurer know-only those which

Speaker: NA
Text: cause some concern. The measures in this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill are generally supported. I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill and the amendment to the House.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Jen-

Speaker: NA
Text: kins)-Is the amendment seconded?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tanner-I have much pleasure in

Speaker: NA
Text: seconding the amendment.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Mitchell) (10.16 am)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Tax Laws Amendment (2007 Measures

Speaker: NA
Text: No. 2) Bill 2007 contains multiple changes

Speaker: NA
Text: to the tax act. There are seven or eight effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive ones. Some are technical, but most of

Speaker: NA
Text: them deal with specific areas that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment has given attention to, either to sim-

Speaker: NA
Text: plify or to extend current provisions and

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions. They include the effective life

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions, the taxation of boating activities,

Speaker: NA
Text: certain expenditure on research and devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment activities, donations of listed shares

Speaker: NA
Text: to deductible gift recipients, deductible gift

Speaker: NA
Text: recipients, deductions of contributions re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated to fundraising events, technical

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments, and provisions relating to ven-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture capital, which were dealt with by the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous speaker. I will run through them

Speaker: NA
Text: briefly, spending some time on the taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: of boating activities and more time on the

Speaker: NA
Text: donations and deductions for deductible gift

Speaker: NA
Text: recipients.

Speaker: NA
Text: The boating provisions are very sensible.

Speaker: NA
Text: This area has been a problem for the boating

Speaker: NA
Text: industry for some time. I have examined the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes carefully. I am concerned that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a temptation for boat owners to mix busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness with pleasure. It is very difficult for the

Speaker: NA
Text: tax office to determine where the line be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the two should be. Under these provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions, there are changes to deductions and

Speaker: NA
Text: there are two exceptions. There is a general

Speaker: NA
Text: rule relating to the capping of deductions for

Speaker: NA
Text: income earned. Amounts attributable to a

Speaker: NA
Text: specific type of boating business or amounts

Speaker: NA
Text: incurred in providing fringe benefits are not

Speaker: NA
Text: quarantined. The quarantined amount is

Speaker: NA
Text: modified for taxpayers who have boating

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains, have profits from a boating

Speaker: NA
Text: business in an income year, derive exempt

Speaker: NA
Text: income and become exempt.

Speaker: NA
Text: For anybody involved in the boating in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry, I believe that the examples in the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: planatory memorandum are essential read-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, because it is only by looking at those

Speaker: NA
Text: specific examples that it is possible to delve

Speaker: NA
Text: behind the intention of the act. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: compliment the tax office for providing clear

Speaker: NA
Text: examples in this case. These include propos-

Speaker: NA
Text: als for using or holding a boat and what it

Speaker: NA
Text: can be used for. For instance, the advertising

Speaker: NA
Text: by a boat owner of his business on the side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the boat may or may not be deductible. It

Speaker: NA
Text: depends on the methods used by the boat

Speaker: NA
Text: owner for gaining income. If his income is

Speaker: NA
Text: derived solely from a business separate from

Speaker: NA
Text: the boat, of course the advertising itself on

Speaker: NA
Text: the boat may be deductible. But if the boat

Speaker: NA
Text: itself is used to raise funds and not just as a

Speaker: NA
Text: form of advertising but as a form of earning

Speaker: NA
Text: income, then of course a different arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment applies to taxation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The apportionment of the deductions that

Speaker: NA
Text: partly relate to using or holding a boat are

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined in further examples. There are ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceptions to the quarantining rule and there

Speaker: NA
Text: are modifications to the quarantining rule

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in the bill before the House. Part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the legislation covers the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: profits can be dealt with or the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: profits and losses can be carried forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another section of the legislation deals with

Speaker: NA
Text: owners who own multiple boats. Some may

Speaker: NA
Text: be solely related to fishing or business; oth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers may be for pleasure. The bill clearly sets

Speaker: NA
Text: out the conditions that apply. Interestingly,

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost to revenue of these measures is ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proximately $5 million or $6 million per an-

Speaker: NA
Text: num, and I believe they will be greatly bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficial to the boating industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is provision in the legislation for

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure on research and development

Speaker: NA
Text: activities. The new law is interesting and it

Speaker: NA
Text: provides a number of corrections. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: small changes to the existing concessions for

Speaker: NA
Text: research and development of any type, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation also provides some additional

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits, such as the offset in the year in

Speaker: NA
Text: which entitlement is made. Currently, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no provision for a company to choose the

Speaker: NA
Text: R&D tax offset by amending their original

Speaker: NA
Text: tax return. That has now changed in this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Currently the R&D concession has a general

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption to the $20,000 minimum spend

Speaker: NA
Text: rule for contracted expenditure to a regis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered research agency on behalf of a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany. This exception does not apply if the

Speaker: NA
Text: R&D tax offset is claimed. So that is a fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther change in this current legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The main area of particular interest to

Speaker: NA
Text: me-and, I believe, the public at large-is

Speaker: NA
Text: the encouragement that this bill offers for

Speaker: NA
Text: philanthropy. I think this is an area

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment needs to pay attention to. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that there have been considerable efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the government to have the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's Community Business Partnership

Speaker: NA
Text: group examine in particular the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: philanthropy can be encouraged. I believe it

Speaker: NA
Text: is an avenue that needs careful attention. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it can be easily extended to schools in

Speaker: NA
Text: general and to church and charity groups,

Speaker: NA
Text: which perform functions which are of a

Speaker: NA
Text: charitable nature. There should be an exten-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of the provisions of deductibility for

Speaker: NA
Text: gifts to charitable organisations of all types; I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not think the range is broad enough and I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe the community would benefit greatly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, the social welfare bill would be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced if we were to do this. I think charitable

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations generally are much more effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive at providing support and services to

Speaker: NA
Text: those in need than government mechanisms.

Speaker: NA
Text: This proposal does extend philanthropy. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that it needs further examination and

Speaker: NA
Text: that philanthropy needs to be greatly encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: aged.

Speaker: NA
Text: The context of these amendments is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the income tax law encourages philanthropy

Speaker: NA
Text: through a range of taxation measures cover-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the donation to deductible recipients of

Speaker: NA
Text: money or property valued at $2 or more.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those gifts are deductible. Currently, gifts of

Speaker: NA
Text: property to DGRs, the tax deductible gift

Speaker: NA
Text: recipient group, which can include shares,

Speaker: NA
Text: are tax deductible if the property is pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: chased during the 12 months before making

Speaker: NA
Text: the gift or is valued by the Commissioner of

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation at more than $5,000. Gifts of prop-

Speaker: NA
Text: erty, including shares, acquired at least 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months before making the donation and val-

Speaker: NA
Text: ued at $5,000 or less are currently not tax

Speaker: NA
Text: deductible. The new measure was announced

Speaker: NA
Text: in the 2006-07 budget and applies to gifts

Speaker: NA
Text: and contributions made in an income year

Speaker: NA
Text: commencing on or after royal assent. So it

Speaker: NA
Text: brings forward the capacity to make deduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: that govtions in the current income year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new law provides that taxpayers gift-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing shares deduct the market value of the

Speaker: NA
Text: shares on the day they make the gift, pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided that the shares were acquired at least

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months before making the gift, have a

Speaker: NA
Text: share value of $5,000 or less, were acquired

Speaker: NA
Text: in a listed public company and are listed for

Speaker: NA
Text: quotation on the official list of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Stock Exchange. So there is the protection

Speaker: NA
Text: for revenue: making sure the shares are ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired in a listed public company and mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing sure a full quotation is available. The

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains provisions are something that

Speaker: NA
Text: sneak in here, because it is obvious that the

Speaker: NA
Text: tax office would not like to see somebody

Speaker: NA
Text: make a capital gain and then avoid their re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility for paying by making a donation

Speaker: NA
Text: or a gift to a charitable organisation. Again,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have examples. I will read one briefly.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is example 4.2 in the explanatory

Speaker: NA
Text: memorandum:

Speaker: NA
Text: Mark wishes to gift $3,000 of shares in Red Ltd

Speaker: NA
Text: and $4,000 of shares in Blue Ltd, both

Speaker: NA
Text: lic companies, to a DGR. Both of these parcels of

Speaker: NA
Text: shares were purchased more than 12 months ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mark signs and submits two share ownership

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer forms.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although their combined value exceeds $5,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mark can still deduct the gifts of shares as they

Speaker: NA
Text: are treated as separate gifts each valued at $5,000

Speaker: NA
Text: or less.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a whole series of examples about

Speaker: NA
Text: the way in which this law may apply to gifts

Speaker: NA
Text: of shares. I think it is an excellent provision

Speaker: NA
Text: and one that needs to be promoted by chari-

Speaker: NA
Text: table institutions and organisations. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a ready source of income for these

Speaker: NA
Text: groups that they should be seeking out. I en-

Speaker: NA
Text: courage donors to actively consider whether

Speaker: NA
Text: or not a gift of shares is an appropriate way

Speaker: NA
Text: in which to make their support for an organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation known and recognised. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: need to cash things out. There is no need to

Speaker: NA
Text: go into all the problems of finding out what

Speaker: NA
Text: shares are worth and going through the sale

Speaker: NA
Text: process with its costs. A simple transfer is

Speaker: NA
Text: what is proposed by this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other interesting provision is the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision for tax deductibility for contributions

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to fundraising events. This tax de-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductibility provision is an interesting one. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will read schedule 6.1:

Speaker: NA
Text: The deduction is available where the value of the

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution is more than $150 (the current

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold is more than $250), and the minor bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fit received in return is no more than $150 (cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently $100) and 20 per cent (currently 10 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent) of the value of the contribution, whichever

Speaker: NA
Text: is the less.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means that, for fundraising events, all

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of things can be done to support a char-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity. Again, there is an example which illus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trates this. Example 6.1 says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Anthony pays $260 to attend a charity golf day,

Speaker: NA
Text: hosted by a DGR. The market value of an 18-hole

Speaker: NA
Text: golf game is $50. As the market value of the golf

Speaker: NA
Text: game is less than $150 and less than 20 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of the value of his contribution ($260), Anthony

Speaker: NA
Text: listed pub- can deduct $210 ($260 less $50).

Speaker: NA
Text: Without the amendments to the thresholds, An-

Speaker: NA
Text: thony would not be entitled to a deduction as the

Speaker: NA
Text: market value of the minor benefit, the golf game

Speaker: NA
Text: ($50), is more than 10 per cent of the value of his

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution ($260 × 10 per cent = $26).

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a great encouragement for charities of

Speaker: NA
Text: all sorts, for schools, for the Scouts and

Speaker: NA
Text: Guides, for people holding art shows and all

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of activities. It is a wonderful way of

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging people to make minor contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, whether they be football jumpers or

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever-a host of things can be contrib-

Speaker: NA
Text: uted to a charity. There is even the contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of attending a charity golf day, as illus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trated by the explanatory memorandum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly there are advantages to the taxpayer

Speaker: NA
Text: but particularly to the organisation, the DGR.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend this legislation to the House. It

Speaker: NA
Text: covers a wide range of important issues. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think they are good measures.

Speaker: Mr HAYES
Text: Werriwa) (10.30 am)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: know we are coming back from a break, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker, and we are all refreshed, but

Speaker: NA
Text: this week seems to be a week of amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. In addition to the Tax Laws Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment (2007 Measures No. 2) Bill 2007 that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have in front of us-not an uncommon

Speaker: NA
Text: form of legislative amendment, when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to this government-amendments are

Speaker: NA
Text: to come before the House in the form of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Building and Construction Industry Im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provement Amendment (OHS) Bill 2007.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is set down for debate tomorrow, I

Speaker: NA
Text: think. We also have the mother of all

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments-which the Prime Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: told us for the last year would not happen,

Speaker: NA
Text: out of fear that it would destroy the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: as we now know it-the amendments pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed to Work Choices. An effort is certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: being made by the government to draw to a

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion a number of things that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: hanging around for over 12 months.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will keep my comments brief and rele-

Speaker: NA
Text: vant to this tax bill. I will limit my comments

Speaker: NA
Text: to the issues of research and development.

Speaker: NA
Text: Research and development expenditure is

Speaker: NA
Text: critical for the performance and advancement

Speaker: NA
Text: of the economy. Certainly it is critical to im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proving the competitiveness of industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Business investment in research and devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment, however, is at 0.95 per cent of GDP.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is well below the average OECD con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribution to R&D, which is 1.53 per cent. As

Speaker: NA
Text: a consequence, that has this country sitting

Speaker: NA
Text: behind 14 other OECD nations. That is de-

Speaker: NA
Text: spite the fact that considerable advancements

Speaker: NA
Text: were made throughout the mid-1980s and the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990s in industry contributions to research

Speaker: NA
Text: and development.

Speaker: NA
Text: There must be many reasons for that per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formance, but the fact remains that business

Speaker: NA
Text: spending on research and development under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government has grown at less

Speaker: NA
Text: than half the rate that it grew at under the

Speaker: NA
Text: former Labor government. When the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister announced in 1996 his commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: to industry, he put it in these words:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... to improve Australia's international ranking

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of expenditure on business R&D, as a share

Speaker: NA
Text: of GDP.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have just cited the current figures, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: position could not be more different from

Speaker: NA
Text: that envisaged by the Prime Minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1996. It certainly has not lived up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: standard set by the former Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: with regard to encouraging industries to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vest in research and development in their

Speaker: NA
Text: sectors.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Howard government's main policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: cutting the research and development tax

Speaker: NA
Text: concession has produced a less than stellar

Speaker: NA
Text: performance. Policies that promote further

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in research and development are

Speaker: NA
Text: being actively pursued by many countries

Speaker: NA
Text: but this government only pays lip service to

Speaker: NA
Text: them. Let me take a moment to examine the

Speaker: NA
Text: targets set by other countries when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to R&D. China is committed to increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: research and development expenditure to 2.5

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of GDP by the year 2020. The Euro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pean Union as a whole is targeting expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture on R&D at three per cent of GDP by the

Speaker: NA
Text: year 2010.

Speaker: NA
Text: All around us, our Asian neighbours are

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing their research and development

Speaker: NA
Text: spending at an incredibly rapid pace. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: local member representing the seat of Wer-

Speaker: NA
Text: riwa, in the south-west of Sydney-an area I

Speaker: NA
Text: am very proud of-I point to the employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment statistics for the area to demonstrate the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect research and development will have on

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of our main industries. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the south-west of Sydney, we have nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: 50,000 people employed in manufacturing. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is welcome news that the manufacturing sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor is taking seriously its responsibility for

Speaker: NA
Text: R&D in the development of home products,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in Werriwa, my area. Currently,

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing accounts for 41 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's research and development. Manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturing businesses are also the most likely

Speaker: NA
Text: in to commit to innovation and further devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment and to invest in their futures.

Speaker: NA
Text: The manufacturing industry recognises the

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be the one that is setting the pace in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world, and not having it foisted upon it,

Speaker: NA
Text: simply being reactive to the position of other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. We need to stimulate growth in the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing sector. We need the sector to

Speaker: NA
Text: invest in its future. We are certainly seeing

Speaker: NA
Text: some encouraging signs. In my backyard, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the south-west of Sydney, various companies

Speaker: NA
Text: that I visit on a regular basis are now taking

Speaker: NA
Text: steps to invest in their future through re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search and development expenditure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments contained in this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will, I believe, help contribute to the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provement of Australia's research and devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment performance. They are vital and nec-

Speaker: NA
Text: essary. We do need to stimulate and encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: age expenditure in that area. To that extent

Speaker: NA
Text: support the provisions of the bill. Labor supneed

Speaker: NA
Text: ports the proposals in the bill, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposals relating to R&D. In saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that, however, it would be remiss of me not

Speaker: NA
Text: to note the time it has taken for this amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment bill to come before the House. The

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment bill was announced at the time of

Speaker: NA
Text: the last budget. I am talking about the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: handed down in May 2006, not last night's

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. It has taken more than a year for the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation to come before the House. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, this is not the longest delay that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen in amendments coming before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Research and development tax conces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions were introduced by the Labor govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in May 1986. Quite frankly, they have

Speaker: NA
Text: had a chequered history, particularly under

Speaker: NA
Text: the current government. In the 1992-93

Speaker: NA
Text: budget speech of the then Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: it was announced that the R&D concession

Speaker: NA
Text: would continue indefinitely. There was a

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment by a Labor government to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vest in the development of this country, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly in manufacturing, by continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: that concession indefinitely.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1996, upon the election of the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government, there was a slash and burn ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to budgetary measures and that char-

Speaker: NA
Text: acterised the government's first few budgets.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure members will remember the cuts

Speaker: NA
Text: that were made and the ones we are still pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for. There are fewer doctors, certainly on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Central Coast, and dentists. The Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government took it upon itself, among other

Speaker: NA
Text: things, to reduce the R&D maximum conces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion to 125 per cent. The government led the

Speaker: NA
Text: charge in discouraging people from investing

Speaker: NA
Text: in their futures. That is the legacy of this

Speaker: NA
Text: government. That is why it is scrambling

Speaker: NA
Text: now to redress those things. That is why we

Speaker: NA
Text: are falling behind other nations which have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken the positive approach of setting targets

Speaker: NA
Text: I for R&D into the future. That is why we

Speaker: NA
Text: to look forward and invest in ourselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is something we have advocated

Speaker: NA
Text: through successive Labor governments. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: good to see that the Howard government is

Speaker: NA
Text: now starting to take a leaf out of our book

Speaker: NA
Text: and at least return it to its former position

Speaker: NA
Text: prior to 1996.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2001, the government backflipped on

Speaker: NA
Text: its position when it produced a package

Speaker: NA
Text: called Backing Australia's Ability. In that

Speaker: NA
Text: package it introduced a premium rate of 175

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent for additional research and devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment activity and the research and devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment tax concession for small companies.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I say it has taken a long while for this

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment bill to come before the House,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I refer to last year's budget, the reality is

Speaker: NA
Text: that-and make no mistake about this-we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been waiting effectively since 2001 for

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation to come before the House and

Speaker: NA
Text: to be implemented in a way that will stimu-

Speaker: NA
Text: late the growth of R&D within the business

Speaker: NA
Text: sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that the government is now scram-

Speaker: NA
Text: bling to establish its credentials. I accept that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is an election year and the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: to do something about showing its sincerity

Speaker: NA
Text: in this regard. Last night when I went back to

Speaker: NA
Text: my rooms-as no doubt most members

Speaker: NA
Text: did-I started to go through the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: statements. Statement 1: Fiscal strategy and

Speaker: NA
Text: budget priorities, under the heading ‘Creat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing opportunities for industry', states:

Speaker: NA
Text: This commitment is outlined in the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: statement, Global Integration: Changing Mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: kets, New Opportunities, which includes-

Speaker: NA
Text: among other things-

Speaker: NA
Text: $200 million over four years to expand access

Speaker: NA
Text: the 175 per cent research and development

Speaker: NA
Text: (R&D) tax concession, to encourage multina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional enterprises to increase the amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: they perform in Australia ...

Speaker: NA
Text: That is welcomed, but I make the point that

Speaker: NA
Text: this highlights how the government is now

Speaker: NA
Text: scrambling to catch up and stimulate indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try to perform R&D, with a view to generat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing not only productivity but also employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in this country. One of the spin-offs of

Speaker: NA
Text: R&D is not simply the research and devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment that takes place but the all likelihood

Speaker: NA
Text: of the employment that it generates as a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sequence of undertaking R&D in this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that the provisions con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in schedule 3 of this bill will improve

Speaker: NA
Text: the research and development tax offset, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly by allowing companies more time

Speaker: NA
Text: to claim the offset. The amendment that al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lows all companies in a group to be covered

Speaker: NA
Text: by the research and development tax offset

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions will be welcomed not only by

Speaker: NA
Text: those businesses currently undertaking R&D

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia but also, more importantly, by

Speaker: NA
Text: those companies which are contemplating it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given the importance of research and devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment to the longevity of a number of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian businesses and industries and the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance of R&D in terms of building our

Speaker: NA
Text: productive capacity, while these changes are

Speaker: NA
Text: technical in nature, I agree they are welcome.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reality of our global economy is that,

Speaker: NA
Text: if we do not innovate, if we do not invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: our future, our businesses and our industries,

Speaker: NA
Text: we are not likely to survive in that competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive market. That is why it is more important

Speaker: NA
Text: than ever for government to come to the ta-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble with industry, to ensure that the arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in place are sufficient to maintain Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's competitive position in the world

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. While the amendments in this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: are welcome, when it comes to R&D, one

Speaker: NA
Text: to can only wonder whether they are enough.

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Text: Sydney) (10.45 am)-

Speaker: NA
Text: I rise to speak on the Tax Laws Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: R&D (2007 Measures No. 2) Bill 2007. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: focus my comments on schedules 5 and 6 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation. Schedule 5 will amend the

Speaker: NA
Text: list of deductible gift recipients in the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. Deductible gift recipient status

Speaker: NA
Text: will assist the listed organisations to attract

Speaker: NA
Text: public support for their activities. Schedule 6

Speaker: NA
Text: of the bill amends the tax legislation by ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tending the eligibility for tax deductions for

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions to deductible gift recipients

Speaker: NA
Text: where an associated minor benefit is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived with an eligible fundraising event.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government says that what they call

Speaker: NA
Text: the improvements to the taxation deductibil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity provisions provide further support to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: courage greater philanthropy in the commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity. Naturally, Labor support measures that

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage philanthropy in the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are pleased to see that this bill will lift

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the restrictions on the kinds of gifts

Speaker: NA
Text: which can be donated to organisations with

Speaker: NA
Text: deductible gift recipient status. Of course we

Speaker: NA
Text: support those changes.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to talk more broadly about deducti-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble gift recipient status and about charities

Speaker: NA
Text: more generally. We have a proud record in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia of giving to charities. The 2005

Speaker: NA
Text: report Giving Australia: research on philan-

Speaker: NA
Text: thropy in Australia estimated that the total

Speaker: NA
Text: giving of money, goods and services to non-

Speaker: NA
Text: profit organisations by individuals and busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesses was about $11 billion per year. I no-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticed just this week that new reports of giv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to charities put my own state, New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, at the top of the list per capita, having

Speaker: NA
Text: the most generous citizens when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: donating to charities.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. DJC

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerr)-We always say Sydney has a big

Speaker: NA
Text: heart!

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Text: We have a big heart,

Speaker: NA
Text: that is right. I know you are trying to pull my

Speaker: NA
Text: leg here, Mr Deputy Speaker, but as the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Sydney I see every day just how

Speaker: NA
Text: generous Australians are and just how gener-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous Sydneysiders are. My electorate of Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney, an inner city seat, is the location for a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot of charities and services-drug and alco-

Speaker: NA
Text: hol services and homeless services in par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular. We also have the head offices of a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of charities located in the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. Many church groups, welfare ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices, legal centres, environment groups,

Speaker: NA
Text: gambling services, family support services,

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbourhood centres and health services

Speaker: NA
Text: are located in my electorate. I see the first-

Speaker: NA
Text: class work they do. I also see the sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who rely on these charities every

Speaker: NA
Text: day-Australians who access homeless shel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters every night, young people in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: who are being helped to kick their drug and

Speaker: NA
Text: alcohol addiction or gambling habits, or

Speaker: NA
Text: women and children leaving violent partners

Speaker: NA
Text: and looking for a safe place to live. These

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations in my electorate support people

Speaker: NA
Text: living with HIV and AIDS, not only helping

Speaker: NA
Text: them with the usual domestic support and

Speaker: NA
Text: medical advice but also helping them to

Speaker: NA
Text: combat the social isolation which often goes

Speaker: NA
Text: with chronic illnesses such as HIV.

Speaker: NA
Text: I see a lot of people who are desperate for

Speaker: NA
Text: help accessing community legal services to

Speaker: NA
Text: try to get some protection for their rights,

Speaker: NA
Text: protection which they are likely to miss out

Speaker: NA
Text: on without advocacy on their behalf. Day

Speaker: NA
Text: after day I see the charities and other organisome

Speaker: NA
Text: sations supporting some of the most disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantaged and marginalised citizens in the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Many of the charities have deducti-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble gift recipient status. That means that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are allowed to receive donations which are

Speaker: NA
Text: tax deductible for the donor. The staff of

Speaker: NA
Text: these organisations are basically doing char-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity work also-they are certainly not being

Speaker: NA
Text: well recompensed. The deductible gift re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipient status provides for organisations to

Speaker: NA
Text: allow their staff to salary package. Some-

Speaker: NA
Text: times that is the only way people can make

Speaker: NA
Text: ends meet. Deductible gift recipient status

Speaker: NA
Text: allows organisations to receive money from

Speaker: NA
Text: philanthropic trusts and grants and to use that

Speaker: NA
Text: money for innovative new projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: The point that needs to be made here is

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australian society relies more and more

Speaker: NA
Text: on charities as the government has with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn from providing some of the most ba-

Speaker: NA
Text: sic services to Australian people. There are a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of examples in my electorate. An or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisation called the Luncheon Club AIDS

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Group started in my electorate in

Speaker: NA
Text: November 1993 and is a registered charity

Speaker: NA
Text: for taxation purposes. Every Monday the

Speaker: NA
Text: luncheon club offers lunch free of charge to

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are living with or affected by

Speaker: NA
Text: HIV or AIDS. Families, friends, partners,

Speaker: NA
Text: carers and children come along to support

Speaker: NA
Text: their loved one. HIV sufferers are able to

Speaker: NA
Text: support each other and to build a social net-

Speaker: NA
Text: work, and as well they get a nice lunch.

Speaker: NA
Text: Until recently, the luncheon club has also

Speaker: NA
Text: had a larder program, under which it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to provide food and other essential

Speaker: NA
Text: items free of charge, because people who are

Speaker: NA
Text: living on the disability pension find it very

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to pay for the medication they need

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to combat their HIV, as well as all of

Speaker: NA
Text: their other associated expenses. The lunch-

Speaker: NA
Text: eon club is really struggling at the moment. I

Speaker: NA
Text: met with the organisation recently to go over

Speaker: NA
Text: of the things we can do to improve its

Speaker: NA
Text: financial situation. But this is just one or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisation; there are literally hundreds that

Speaker: NA
Text: support people who live in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I support these measures that make

Speaker: NA
Text: it easier for Australians to donate to these

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations, I make the point that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last 12 months I have become increasingly

Speaker: NA
Text: worried about the number of organisations in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate that have lost their deductible

Speaker: NA
Text: gift recipient status. I know that a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations have been audited recently by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Taxation Office-some of

Speaker: NA
Text: them a number of times over a very short

Speaker: NA
Text: period-in order to establish that they meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the criteria for retaining DGR status. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are forced to go through what is really a very

Speaker: NA
Text: arduous process to prove that they are chari-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties-to itemise carefully all of their different

Speaker: NA
Text: functions and the varied work they do, in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to show that they meet the criteria.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apparently, the ATO has stepped up its

Speaker: NA
Text: auditing of non-profit organisations to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are entitled to the tax concessions

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are claiming. The ATO's compli-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance program priorities for 2005-06 include

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘testing the integrity of endorsed deductible

Speaker: NA
Text: gift recipient status organisations and tax

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions charities'. Losing DGR status

Speaker: NA
Text: results in substantial financial losses for

Speaker: NA
Text: these organisations. Their staff effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: lose money because they are no longer able

Speaker: NA
Text: to salary package a proportion of their wage.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have an increased tax burden. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: no longer able to accept donations and they

Speaker: NA
Text: can no longer apply for or receive philan-

Speaker: NA
Text: thropic grants.

Speaker: NA
Text: This move really began in 2003, when the

Speaker: NA
Text: government threatened to introduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: charities bill, which sought to remove chari-

Speaker: NA
Text: table status from organisations which en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaged in advocacy. In short, the government

Speaker: NA
Text: basically said, ‘If you help homeless people,

Speaker: NA
Text: that's all right, but if you say there shouldn't

Speaker: NA
Text: be so many homeless people, you become an

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate and you lose your funding.' It re-

Speaker: NA
Text: minded me of what Brazilian bishop Dom

Speaker: NA
Text: Helder Camara said:

Speaker: NA
Text: If I give food to the poor they call me a saint. If I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask why the poor have no food, they call me a

Speaker: NA
Text: communist.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important to note this threat of losing

Speaker: NA
Text: charitable status if you are advocating for the

Speaker: NA
Text: people that you are trying to help: instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: just giving them handouts, if you actually

Speaker: NA
Text: stick up for them, you are threatened with

Speaker: NA
Text: losing your charitable status. That is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: serious threat for these organisations.

Speaker: NA
Text: A great amount of work has been done by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australia Institute. One of their reports

Speaker: NA
Text: shows that 70 per cent of organisations re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port that the funding restricts their ability to

Speaker: NA
Text: comment on government policy and that 76

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of these organisations disagreed

Speaker: NA
Text: with the statement that current Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: political culture encourages public debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Firstly, these organisations fear that they will

Speaker: NA
Text: lose their public funding if they criticise the

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Secondly, if they get no fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, how does the government get to them? If

Speaker: NA
Text: they have no government funding, the way

Speaker: NA
Text: the government gets to them is by taking

Speaker: NA
Text: their charitable status away from them, mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing sure that they are too frightened to make

Speaker: NA
Text: public comments. So the deductible gift re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipient status audits are one way of intimi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dating some organisations. Losing their gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment funding is another. Another way, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, is the confidentiality agreements that

Speaker: NA
Text: charities are made to sign when they do a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dutton- Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order regarding relevance to the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: that is being debated at the moment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member made mention of sched-

Speaker: NA
Text: ule 5. Her contribution bears no relevance

Speaker: NA
Text: whatsoever to schedule 5 of the bill, which

Speaker: NA
Text: extends gift recipient status to two specific

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations. The nonsense and the hollow

Speaker: NA
Text: rhetoric cannot be of assistance to this de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot debate the matter under the guise of a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. I do understand the minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: comments but the chair has never been strict

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the rules in relation to relevance.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a broad relevance, so I permit the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate to continue.

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Text: Are you trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: shut down the debate in here as well? You

Speaker: NA
Text: don't like the charities telling the truth about

Speaker: NA
Text: this government; you don't like members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition telling the truth about this

Speaker: NA
Text: government either.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dutton-You're just a fraud, that's

Speaker: NA
Text: all. Stick to the facts.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! The

Speaker: NA
Text: minister should not interject or he will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to make his reply.

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Text: Throw him out. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about deductible gift recipient status,

Speaker: NA
Text: which, quite clearly, this legislation does

Speaker: NA
Text: cover, and I was talking about confidentiality

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements for these organisations. Because

Speaker: NA
Text: the government has pulled out of providing a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole lot of social services, it is asking the

Speaker: NA
Text: charities to provide those. Where the chari-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties do pick up the contracts, they are asked

Speaker: NA
Text: to sign a confidentiality agreement which,

Speaker: NA
Text: again, prevents them from commenting when

Speaker: NA
Text: they believe that government policy is

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: A study by Clive Hamilton and Sarah

Speaker: NA
Text: Maddison of the Australia Institute, which I

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned a moment ago, called Silencing

Speaker: NA
Text: dissent, shows that these organisations in

Speaker: NA
Text: many cases are clearly frightened of criticis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the government. One of the leaders in

Speaker: NA
Text: persecuting organisations that are advocates

Speaker: NA
Text: has been the Institute of Public Affairs, a

Speaker: NA
Text: conservative think tank which, incidentally,

Speaker: NA
Text: has charitable status and which has referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to these organisations as ‘cashed-up non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government organisations which are an un-

Speaker: NA
Text: representative dictatorship of the articulate'.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Institute of Public Affairs, inciden-

Speaker: NA
Text: tally, received $50,000 of government fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to audit non-government organisations to

Speaker: NA
Text: determine whether they were legitimate rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentatives of the people whom they claim

Speaker: NA
Text: as their clients. Incidentally, the Institute of

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Affairs, which received this $50,000

Speaker: NA
Text: in government funding, whilst it is a charita-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble organisation, does not disclose its donors,

Speaker: NA
Text: which of course is one of the criticisms that

Speaker: NA
Text: it makes of these other organisations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The churches, amongst other organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, have really been caught in this sand-

Speaker: NA
Text: wich. If they are working to relieve poverty

Speaker: NA
Text: once it is obvious in the community, that is

Speaker: NA
Text: okay; if they want to talk about why poverty

Speaker: NA
Text: exists in a country as wealthy as Australia, at

Speaker: NA
Text: a time when it is raining cash from the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources boom, then they have their charitable

Speaker: NA
Text: status threatened.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously, no government likes to be

Speaker: NA
Text: criticised-none of us take it well. But pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious governments have understood that, in a

Speaker: NA
Text: healthy and strong democracy, people who

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate for the most disadvantaged mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of our community should not be pun-

Speaker: NA
Text: ished for standing up for those people. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: vital for democracy, in fact, to have people

Speaker: NA
Text: standing up for the most disadvantaged

Speaker: NA
Text: members of our community, to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that their voices are represented when deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions are being made.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the 2001 inquiry into the definition

Speaker: NA
Text: of charities and related organisations, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed charities bill in 2003-the bill that

Speaker: NA
Text: lapsed-many organisations have argued for

Speaker: NA
Text: a rethink on laws and regulations relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: charities. At the end of last year Jobs Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia and ACOSS released a discussion paper

Speaker: NA
Text: floating an idea relating to the reform of

Speaker: NA
Text: charities, the definition of a charity, regula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions relating to charities and categorisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are calling for a more modern defini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of a charity. We are still working with a

Speaker: NA
Text: definition from 1891. It goes without saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that the role of these organisations has

Speaker: NA
Text: changed significantly since then. It may well

Speaker: NA
Text: be worth modernising and harmonising the

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation of various tax statuses so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: current confusions over whether an organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is a charity, a public benevolent instituing-of

Speaker: NA
Text: tion or a deductible gift recipient are re-

Speaker: NA
Text: moved.

Speaker: NA
Text: ACOSS has suggested that we consider

Speaker: NA
Text: the establishment of a charities commission,

Speaker: NA
Text: similar to the one in the UK. The commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion would act as a gatekeeper of charitable

Speaker: NA
Text: status at a federal level. It would mean that

Speaker: NA
Text: the regulation of many of these non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government organisations and their tax

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment would be at arm's length from the

Speaker: NA
Text: government. That would allow these organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sations to continue to play the important role

Speaker: NA
Text: they play in the community without fearing

Speaker: NA
Text: that, if they are too outspoken, they will

Speaker: NA
Text: their tax deductibility status. Advocates of a

Speaker: NA
Text: charities commission argue that it would

Speaker: NA
Text: streamline and improve the overall regula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of charities as well as harmonise the

Speaker: NA
Text: accountability requirements placed on chari-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties and deductible gift recipients by state

Speaker: NA
Text: and Commonwealth regulators and depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. I think that is well worth considering.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mentioned some research earlier by

Speaker: NA
Text: Sarah Maddison and Clive Hamilton from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australia Institute. There has been a great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal of very interesting research also under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by another academic, Joan Staples, that

Speaker: NA
Text: goes through just how the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: used its funding and tax deductibility status

Speaker: NA
Text: to prevent a number of these organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: from saying what it is that they truly believe

Speaker: NA
Text: about the way that the most vulnerable peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple in Australian society have been treated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Joan Staples's research in this area is very

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant as well. This whole argument about

Speaker: NA
Text: the shutting down of the defenders of the

Speaker: NA
Text: most vulnerable people in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community reminds me of what the founder

Speaker: NA
Text: of the St Vincent de Paul Society, Frederic

Speaker: NA
Text: Ozanam, said. He said, ‘Charity is the oil

Speaker: NA
Text: being poured on the wounded traveller, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: is the role of justice to prevent the attack.' I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that any system that helps pour the oil

Speaker: NA
Text: on the wounded traveller is worth support-

Speaker: NA
Text: course I support that. But any sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem that actually prevents advocacy for jus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice for those people has serious flaws.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. DJC

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerr)-I thank the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney. I apologise to the member for Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney for my intervention earlier in the debate,

Speaker: NA
Text: which led me to be less capable of adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tering admonishment to the minister when he

Speaker: NA
Text: later interjected.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Dickson-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Revenue and Assistant Treasurer) (11.05

Speaker: NA
Text: am)-I thank you at the outset, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, for acknowledging shortcomings,

Speaker: NA
Text: lose including your own. Can I say thank you

Speaker: NA
Text: very much to the members who have taken

Speaker: NA
Text: part in this debate on the Tax Laws Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment (2007 Measures No. 2) Bill 2007-

Speaker: NA
Text: except for the member for Sydney, I might

Speaker: NA
Text: say; that might have been the most painful

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 minutes of debate I have had to sit

Speaker: NA
Text: through in this parliament. It is a pity that

Speaker: NA
Text: she does not have the capacity to contribute

Speaker: NA
Text: along the same lines as perhaps the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Barton would have been able to-a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son who is able to contribute constructively

Speaker: NA
Text: and honestly to debate in this place. The con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribution by the member for Sydney was,

Speaker: NA
Text: frankly, nothing more than an attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: muddy the facts with the diatribe that she

Speaker: NA
Text: normally goes on with. It really is a sad re-

Speaker: NA
Text: flection on her contribution in this place. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think the House should record the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the contribution that was made by the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Sydney was not factual in any way.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nonetheless, I want to acknowledge in par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular the member for Mitchell, Mr Cadman,

Speaker: NA
Text: who I think provided an exceptional contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution to this debate. He obviously went

Speaker: NA
Text: through a very well-thought through process

Speaker: NA
Text: to compile his contribution. He should be

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised for that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also want to comment on some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: points that were made by the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Prospect and, again, to correct some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: confusion and lack of factual basis in some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the comments that he made. The first

Speaker: NA
Text: point I make is that it takes time to amend

Speaker: NA
Text: law and to consult on the amendments. The

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition are running around this place and

Speaker: NA
Text: in the business community, on one hand say-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that we do not consult enough with busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness and then, to a separate audience, saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that we take too long to implement changes

Speaker: NA
Text: and amendments to the law. The fact is that

Speaker: NA
Text: they cannot have it both ways. They cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: argue that we need a further process of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sultation and then argue at the same time that

Speaker: NA
Text: we should be making these decisions in a

Speaker: NA
Text: shorter period of time. It is like the other

Speaker: NA
Text: process that they are indulging in at the mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of telling one group that they can cut

Speaker: NA
Text: government expenditure, yet running into the

Speaker: NA
Text: next room and, in that speech, talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: further government largesse, about how they

Speaker: NA
Text: would be able to provide more money for

Speaker: NA
Text: them were they in government. It is hypo-

Speaker: NA
Text: critical, and it is a nonsense to suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: you can have one with the other. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: really showing their ignorance about the

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation process that is undertaken.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government remains very committed

Speaker: NA
Text: to conducting a timely consultation process.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, when we talk about tax law, we are talk-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing about complicated amendments to the

Speaker: NA
Text: law. They need to be properly thought

Speaker: NA
Text: through, and we need properly to be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: engage with people in the business commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity and with other stakeholders to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that we provide for best practice to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: economy going as well as it is in the current

Speaker: NA
Text: day.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also note the member for Prospect's

Speaker: NA
Text: claim that the government opposed referral

Speaker: NA
Text: of TLAB7 to a Senate committee. I encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: age the member, again, to get his facts

Speaker: NA
Text: straight on this issue, because it was the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment that initially sought to refer the bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor said that this was not needed, and then

Speaker: NA
Text: it was actually Labor which did the backflip

Speaker: NA
Text: to seek a referral of the bill. So that also

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be recorded, as part of my contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to this debate, to correct some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: non-factual contributions made by those op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posite.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 1 to this bill makes amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: to the capital allowance system to clarify

Speaker: NA
Text: how mining, quarrying and prospecting

Speaker: NA
Text: rights are depreciated. The changes align the

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment of these assets more closely with

Speaker: NA
Text: other depreciating assets and ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions operate as intended.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 2 to this bill improves the fair-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness of the taxation rules applying to income

Speaker: NA
Text: earned from certain boating activities, while

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that the tax system cannot be used

Speaker: NA
Text: to subsidise the private use of boats. This

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule implements the government's deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion to allow taxpayers to deduct expenses

Speaker: NA
Text: denied under the current rules, up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: that amount of boating income earned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 3 to this bill improves the opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the R&D tax offset for small and me-

Speaker: NA
Text: dium businesses, ensuring that the law re-

Speaker: NA
Text: flects the government's original policy intent

Speaker: NA
Text: for the offset. These amendments will ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that all companies in a group are covered by

Speaker: NA
Text: the R&D tax offset provisions and extend the

Speaker: NA
Text: time companies have to choose the offset.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments will also allow companies

Speaker: NA
Text: to object to decisions made by the Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner of Taxation regarding the allowable

Speaker: NA
Text: this amount of the offset. Further, the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments ensure that the existing exception to

Speaker: NA
Text: the minimum expenditure of $20,000 for

Speaker: NA
Text: contracted expenditure to a registered re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search agency applies to both R&D tax de-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductions and the R&D tax offset.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 4 delivers the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: 2006-07 budget announcement to extend the

Speaker: NA
Text: gift provisions to promote philanthropic giv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. The amendments will allow taxpayers to

Speaker: NA
Text: claim a tax deduction for the donation of

Speaker: NA
Text: certain publicly listed shares to deductable

Speaker: NA
Text: gift recipients. Schedule 5 to the bill further

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrates the government's support for

Speaker: NA
Text: philanthropy by amending the list of deduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: table gift recipients in the tax legislation to

Speaker: NA
Text: extend the current listing for the Finding

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney Foundation and to list the American

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Association Ltd and the Bunbury

Speaker: NA
Text: Diocese Cathedral Rebuilding Fund. Deduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: table gift recipient status will assist these

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations to attract public support for

Speaker: NA
Text: their activities. Further, schedule 6 to this

Speaker: NA
Text: extends the eligibility for tax deductions for

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions to deductable gift recipients

Speaker: NA
Text: where an associated minor benefit is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived with an eligible fundraising event.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 7 of this bill makes technical

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to ensure that the definition of

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘exempt entity' covers all entities exempt

Speaker: NA
Text: under the income tax law. Schedule 8 to this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill amends the venture capital regime to

Speaker: NA
Text: relax the eligibility requirements for foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: residents investing in venture capital limited

Speaker: NA
Text: partnerships and Australian venture capital

Speaker: NA
Text: funds. It introduces a new set of taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions for Australian residents and for-

Speaker: NA
Text: eign residents investing in early-stage ven-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture capital activities. This is achieved

Speaker: NA
Text: through a new investment vehicle called an

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘early-stage venture capital limited partner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship'.

Speaker: NA
Text: The $250 million divestment requirement

Speaker: NA
Text: is reasonable because the government is in-

Speaker: NA
Text: troducing generous tax concessions for early-

Speaker: NA
Text: stage vehicles. Given the emphasis on start-

Speaker: NA
Text: up and seed capital, the need for ongoing tax

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions once an entity reaches the size

Speaker: NA
Text: of $250 million diminishes. Moreover, if the

Speaker: NA
Text: partnership divests the entity into a venture

Speaker: NA
Text: capital limited partnership as it approaches

Speaker: NA
Text: the $250 million limit, it can continue to at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tract tax-free gains without any divestment

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement. The requirement to divest once

Speaker: NA
Text: an entity reaches $250 million applies for up

Speaker: NA
Text: to six months after the end of an income

Speaker: NA
Text: year, and this provides ample opportunity for

Speaker: NA
Text: divestment to occur. This measure further

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrates that the government's ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: support for new business continues, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: promotion of industry innovation will always

Speaker: NA
Text: be supported by this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank those members who have partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pated in this debate, and I commend the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. DJC

Speaker: NA
Text: bill Kerr)-The original question was that this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill be now read a second time. To this the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Prospect has moved

Speaker: NA
Text: as an amendment that all words after ‘That'

Speaker: NA
Text: be omitted with a view to substituting other

Speaker: NA
Text: words. The question now is that the words

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed to be omitted stand part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: question.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Original question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Message from the Governor-General rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommending appropriation announced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Dickson-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Revenue and Assistant Treasurer) (11.14

Speaker: NA
Text: am)-by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: FAMILIES, COMMUNITY SERVICES

Speaker: NA
Text: AND INDIGENOUS AFFAIRS

Speaker: NA
Text: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CHILD

Speaker: NA
Text: SUPPORT REFORM CONSOLIDATION

Speaker: NA
Text: AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 29 March, on mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by Mr Brough:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: Jagajaga) (11.15 am)-

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is the next legislative stage in the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's 2006 reforms to the child sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port system. The Families, Community Ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices and Indigenous Affairs Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Child Support Reform Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: solidation and Other Measures) Bill 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: contains a significant number of technical

Speaker: NA
Text: and consequential amendments following

Speaker: NA
Text: from the original two pieces of child support

Speaker: NA
Text: reform legislation considered by the parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment last year. Labor supported these previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous child support reform bills in the parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, after expressing our reservations that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government had failed to provide protec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for low-income families, who may lose

Speaker: NA
Text: income as a result of the changes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. Labor will support the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: before us today. However, we remain con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned about protection for low-income

Speaker: NA
Text: families, which has not to date been ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: quately resolved. I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That all words after “That” be omitted with a

Speaker: NA
Text: view to substituting the following words: “whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: not declining to give the bill a second reading,

Speaker: NA
Text: House expresses its serious concern that the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's child support reforms do not provide

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate protection against income reductions for

Speaker: NA
Text: low income households raising children”.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also incorporates relevant amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments relocated from the Child Support Leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation Amendment Bill 2004, which Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: was intending to support. We note that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is set to withdraw that bill from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Notice Paper and we are happy for that

Speaker: NA
Text: to occur. This amendment bill includes a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of non child support changes to vari-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous pensions and family payments, including

Speaker: NA
Text: the payment of the baby bonus in instalments

Speaker: NA
Text: to mothers aged under 18 years and the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tension of the pension assets test, from 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months to 24 months, following the sale of

Speaker: NA
Text: the principal home. Labor welcomes both of

Speaker: NA
Text: these initiatives. Not only are they good pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy; they are also suggestions that we put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward in the first place. If the government

Speaker: NA
Text: continues to run out of fresh ideas, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously keen to help.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Child Support Scheme was, as I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure everyone is aware, set up in 1988 by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke Labor government, and it has become

Speaker: NA
Text: an international model and the basis of a

Speaker: NA
Text: similar scheme established in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom. I do, however, acknowledge the

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine concerns about the scheme, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the fairness of the scheme, the assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment formula and, in particular, compliance.

Speaker: NA
Text: I reiterate that Labor acknowledges the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for reform of our child support system. The

Speaker: NA
Text: view we take to the reform challenge, how-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, is that fundamentally the interests and

Speaker: NA
Text: wellbeing of children must come first and

Speaker: NA
Text: that, as far as possible, child support policies

Speaker: NA
Text: should serve to support the child in secure

Speaker: NA
Text: and in economically acceptable conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: When it comes to child support, the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form process has been lengthy. The House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Family and Community Affairs report Every

Speaker: NA
Text: picture tells a story dealt with child support

Speaker: NA
Text: and other family separation issues and made

Speaker: NA
Text: 29 bipartisan recommendations. Among its

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations was the establishment of a

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerial task force to evaluate the Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Scheme, including establishing the

Speaker: NA
Text: costs of children's upbringing after parental

Speaker: NA
Text: separation, recognising the different income

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of households and reflecting the costs

Speaker: NA
Text: for both parents of maintaining meaningful

Speaker: NA
Text: contact with their children.

Speaker: NA
Text: The May 2005 report of the Ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: Taskforce on Child Support, otherwise

Speaker: NA
Text: known as the Parkinson report, was the first

Speaker: NA
Text: systematic evaluation of child support ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements. It recommended a new formula

Speaker: NA
Text: for child support assessment based on evi-

Speaker: NA
