Text: dence of the actual costs of raising children,

Speaker: NA
Text: the shared parental responsibility for those

Speaker: NA
Text: costs and recognition of each parent's level

Speaker: NA
Text: of care. The report examined the scheme,

Speaker: NA
Text: using sound principles, and it was generally

Speaker: NA
Text: well received. Labor believes that the report

Speaker: NA
Text: provides a constructive basis for moving

Speaker: NA
Text: forward on child support reform.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year the parliament passed two bills

Speaker: NA
Text: which implemented this new Child Support

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme, including a new payment formula.

Speaker: NA
Text: While not all the recommendations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parkinson report were adopted and the new

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme was not entirely to our satisfaction,

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor did support those bills. As I said, to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day's bill makes further amendments to the

Speaker: NA
Text: new Child Support Scheme. It is a lengthy

Speaker: NA
Text: bill, with 12 schedules and 178 pages, so I

Speaker: NA
Text: am not going to be able to cover all the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments. But I do want to touch on, in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, a number of issues which were

Speaker: NA
Text: raised in evidence given just last week at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate inquiry into this bill. The first issue is

Speaker: NA
Text: that these proposed amendments have not

Speaker: NA
Text: raised many new concerns-many of the

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns raised at the Senate inquiry were

Speaker: NA
Text: also raised when the original bill was de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bated. The second issue, which is perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: related to the first, is that the new Child

Speaker: NA
Text: port Scheme is still contentious and many of

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous concerns, especially with regard

Speaker: NA
Text: to the impact of the new regime, have not

Speaker: NA
Text: been fully addressed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Department of Families, Community

Speaker: NA
Text: Services and Indigenous Affairs, the agency

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for child support policy, told the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate inquiry that the implementation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: new regime is not progressing as smoothly as

Speaker: NA
Text: should be expected. The promised stake-

Speaker: NA
Text: holder reference group has met only once

Speaker: NA
Text: this year and there is still a lack of detailed

Speaker: NA
Text: information on the impact on families of the

Speaker: NA
Text: new formula and the new arrangements. Giv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing evidence at the recent Senate inquiry into

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill, Jaqueline Taylor, from the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of Single Mothers and their Chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: … calculating the financial impact on single

Speaker: NA
Text: mother families post July next year has actually

Speaker: NA
Text: been an incredibly difficult thing to do because

Speaker: NA
Text: there is nothing available to help us with that.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been no modelling done by the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment to actually calculate the impact that these

Speaker: NA
Text: changes will have on sole parent families and we

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot forget that this is also in conjunction with

Speaker: NA
Text: Welfare to Work and the loss of income from that.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I ask the government to make this issue a

Speaker: NA
Text: priority and do the necessary research to look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the impacts of the changes that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: enacted. We believe that the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: a responsibility to make sure that the wellbe-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of children is not compromised by the

Speaker: NA
Text: combined impact of these policy changes,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially the Welfare to Work changes. We

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge the concerns of many resident

Speaker: NA
Text: parents that they will receive lower child

Speaker: NA
Text: support payments under the new formula.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the request of the ministerial task force,

Speaker: NA
Text: NATSEM modelled some of the impacts of

Speaker: NA
Text: the new formula. That modelling showed

Speaker: NA
Text: resident parents on annual incomes of

Speaker: NA
Text: $26,000 or less will incur the biggest reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in child support payments. For exam-

Speaker: NA
Text: Sup- ple, where the non-resident parent earns

Speaker: NA
Text: $78,000, a resident parent with an income of

Speaker: NA
Text: $26,000 will be $50 a week worse off. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is certainly a lot of money for a parent earn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing $26,000 a year. These families are al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready amongst the most economically mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ginalised in the country. Ninety-one per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of these families, according to the Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Agency's own data, are headed by

Speaker: NA
Text: mothers. Only four per cent of these families

Speaker: NA
Text: have incomes over $50,000 a year and 75 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent raise their children on incomes below

Speaker: NA
Text: $20,000. We know that supporting parents

Speaker: NA
Text: who are getting by without paid work or are

Speaker: NA
Text: managing on low part-time wages are fre-

Speaker: NA
Text: quently surviving on incomes well below the

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty line. So more account certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be taken of these issues, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: look forward to the research being done by

Speaker: NA
Text: the department.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is also important that we look at these

Speaker: NA
Text: changes in the context of not only the new

Speaker: NA
Text: system that has been put in place but also the

Speaker: NA
Text: recent Welfare to Work changes that are hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a big impact on many of these families.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the one hand, we have family law and

Speaker: NA
Text: child support law encouraging shared parent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and an acknowledgement that between

Speaker: NA
Text: 35 per cent and 65 per cent of care is consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered to be shared. On the other hand, under

Speaker: NA
Text: the income support policies of this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's Welfare to Work changes only one

Speaker: NA
Text: parent can be given principal carer status,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the important concessions in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: activity requirements can leave the other

Speaker: NA
Text: parent and the children exceptionally vulner-

Speaker: NA
Text: able. I would like to quote Ms Taylor from

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Council of Single Mothers and

Speaker: NA
Text: their Children again. She said this about a

Speaker: NA
Text: case presented by the council to the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry:

Speaker: NA
Text: There is one in particular where a single mum in

Speaker: NA
Text: country Victoria has shared care of her toddler

Speaker: NA
Text: child, a very young child. She does not have prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipal carer status because her partner bullied her

Speaker: NA
Text: into making sure he got it. Centrelink assigned it

Speaker: NA
Text: to him. They have within the 10 per cent range of

Speaker: NA
Text: the fifty-fifty, so Centrelink have made their deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion against her in favour of him. So she is what

Speaker: NA
Text: is known as a generic job seeker where she is on

Speaker: NA
Text: Newstart with child rate but has full-time obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions to look for work and to do anything that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Job Network requires of her to accept full-time

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. She has none of the protections that

Speaker: NA
Text: you get with principal carer status such as part-

Speaker: NA
Text: time work, no suitable child care available, the

Speaker: NA
Text: 60-minute travel rule-hers is 90 minutes. She

Speaker: NA
Text: has no access to a pensioner concession card, so

Speaker: NA
Text: she is in a seriously disadvantaged situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor is closely monitoring the impact of the

Speaker: NA
Text: intersection of the Welfare to Work laws, the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of principal carer status, the

Speaker: NA
Text: promotion of shared care under family law

Speaker: NA
Text: and these child support changes to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that parents with largely shared caring re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility are not disadvantaged.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to turn to some other provisions in

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill. As far as the administrative review

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions are concerned, the bill makes

Speaker: NA
Text: technical changes to the process of adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: trative and judicial review of decisions in

Speaker: NA
Text: child support cases by the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Appeals Tribunal-the SSAT-or by the

Speaker: NA
Text: courts. One of these changes concerns ‘out

Speaker: NA
Text: of time' applications to the SSAT for a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view of a child support decision. Currently

Speaker: NA
Text: the executive director of the SSAT has 60

Speaker: NA
Text: days to make a decision about allowing such

Speaker: NA
Text: an application, and if the decision is not

Speaker: NA
Text: taken in the time frame the application is

Speaker: NA
Text: deemed to have been refused. This deeming

Speaker: NA
Text: provision will be removed by this bill and,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to the explanatory memorandum,

Speaker: NA
Text: the mechanism for ensuring timeliness in

Speaker: NA
Text: decision making will be left to ‘other mecha-

Speaker: NA
Text: nisms, such as the SSAT's reporting re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirements'. Clearly, the inflexibility of the

Speaker: NA
Text: deeming provisions could cause problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, relying on vague mechanisms such

Speaker: NA
Text: as ‘reporting requirements' does not neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sarily adequately address the issue of delays.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Law Council of Australia, in its submis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion to the Senate inquiry into the bill, ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed concern over item 64 of the bill's

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule 1. This provision gives the SSAT

Speaker: NA
Text: the power to make a determination about

Speaker: NA
Text: which documents are relevant to the review

Speaker: NA
Text: of its decision by the court conducting that

Speaker: NA
Text: review. The Law Council is ‘concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: about the appropriateness of this amendment'

Speaker: NA
Text: and believes it is preferable that the court be

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to review all documents to determine

Speaker: NA
Text: which are relevant in a decision on the mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter before it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also makes amendments to clarify

Speaker: NA
Text: situations when a court makes orders for the

Speaker: NA
Text: repayment of child support where payments

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made by a person who is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: parent of the child. Under these provisions a

Speaker: NA
Text: mere suspicion on the part of either parent

Speaker: NA
Text: that the payer was not the parent of the child

Speaker: NA
Text: is a factor relevant for the court to consider

Speaker: NA
Text: in making an order on possible repayment,

Speaker: NA
Text: even when this suspicion or knowledge falls

Speaker: NA
Text: short of a reasonable doubt about parentage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another proposed section goes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds for departure from the formula in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to stepchildren. The new regime al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lows for the child support formula to be de-

Speaker: NA
Text: parted from where the family cares for a

Speaker: NA
Text: stepchild. Any consideration of the appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ateness of a departure in these circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: requires consideration of the effects of such

Speaker: NA
Text: an order on the parents, the child support

Speaker: NA
Text: children and any other persons that the par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents have a duty to support. However, cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently the effect on a stepchild is not considposition

Speaker: NA
Text: ered. The amendments will include consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration of the effect on the stepchild.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 5 deals with changes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: maintenance income test provisions in the A

Speaker: NA
Text: New Tax System (Family Assistance) Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1999. These amendments will clarify the

Speaker: NA
Text: definitions of ‘amount received' and ‘amount

Speaker: NA
Text: payable' in the child support formula. They

Speaker: NA
Text: will also clarify that maintenance income

Speaker: NA
Text: received by a payee for one or more children

Speaker: NA
Text: will reduce the payee's amount of family tax

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit part A above the base rate for those

Speaker: NA
Text: children only.

Speaker: NA
Text: Currently ongoing child support can only

Speaker: NA
Text: be collected from employers if the payer is a

Speaker: NA
Text: wage or salary earner or they receive a Cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: trelink payment. This amendment in the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: today will broaden the agency's power to

Speaker: NA
Text: issue notices requiring the deduction of child

Speaker: NA
Text: support and the forwarding of that deduction

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Child Support Agency to include cases

Speaker: NA
Text: where the payer is under contract for service

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements that are, effectively, substitut-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for wages. This change effectively ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tends the reach of the ongoing collection

Speaker: NA
Text: system to independent contractors who are

Speaker: NA
Text: employees. Labor supports this change.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other aspects of the family payment system

Speaker: NA
Text: are also amended by the bill but, given the

Speaker: NA
Text: time available, I just want to indicate our

Speaker: NA
Text: support for those.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another significant change in this bill, un-

Speaker: NA
Text: related to child support, is to require that the

Speaker: NA
Text: baby bonus be paid in 13 instalments to par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents under the age of 18. There is an unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nate tendency for some to portray young

Speaker: NA
Text: mums in a negative fashion. I certainly do

Speaker: NA
Text: not support that sort of reporting. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: it has been noticed among some welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: groups and social workers that there have

Speaker: NA
Text: been disturbing occurrences of young moth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers being abused and exploited over their

Speaker: NA
Text: baby bonus payments. Young women are in a

Speaker: NA
Text: of special vulnerability when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to these issues. Some domestic vio-

Speaker: NA
Text: lence services have reported levels of abuse

Speaker: NA
Text: rising sharply around the time the bonus is

Speaker: NA
Text: paid. Unfortunately, it is true that women are

Speaker: NA
Text: handing over the money just to get rid of a

Speaker: NA
Text: violent partner. There are far too many sto-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries of young mothers being exploited for

Speaker: NA
Text: their baby bonus money. Governments have

Speaker: NA
Text: a responsibility to make sure that efforts to

Speaker: NA
Text: help families at a critical time are not misdi-

Speaker: NA
Text: rected by desperate or selfish people to have

Speaker: NA
Text: children they neither want nor care for.

Speaker: NA
Text: On this basis we support the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to fortnightly payments for young

Speaker: NA
Text: mothers-something we have been pressing

Speaker: NA
Text: for. We also support the common sense

Speaker: NA
Text: change in the name for the maternity pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to be officially known by what we all

Speaker: NA
Text: call it-the baby bonus. All family payments

Speaker: NA
Text: will now also be conditional on the registra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the birth. Some people might find this

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment surprising but such a change will

Speaker: NA
Text: be helpful.

Speaker: NA
Text: In their submission to the Senate inquiry,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Bureau of Statistics said that

Speaker: NA
Text: the registration requirement would improve

Speaker: NA
Text: the accuracy of Australia's demographic sta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tistical collections. They said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Births to mothers in their 30s are more likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: be registered promptly whereas births to younger

Speaker: NA
Text: mothers aged under 24 years were likely to be

Speaker: NA
Text: registered later. It is expected that the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement to have all births registered before

Speaker: NA
Text: applying for the baby bonus may result in a

Speaker: NA
Text: change in parents' behaviour.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hope that the change will be positive and

Speaker: NA
Text: that the tendency for late registration of

Speaker: NA
Text: births among those from very disadvantaged

Speaker: NA
Text: backgrounds will be reduced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of all births registered in Australia in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2005, 22 per cent of Indigenous births oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: curred in 2004 or earlier. So there is evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Indigenous community of the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: this change. For exnuptial births, where pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternity was not acknowledged or where a

Speaker: NA
Text: mother is not married and the father's details

Speaker: NA
Text: are not on the birth certificate, over 23 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of births registered in 2005 were for

Speaker: NA
Text: babies born in 2004 or earlier. This new re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirement must be implemented in such a

Speaker: NA
Text: way that those with particular vulnerabilities

Speaker: NA
Text: are not disadvantaged. We do not want them

Speaker: NA
Text: to be missing out on any payments and I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that those responsible will make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the parents who are vulnerable know the

Speaker: NA
Text: full implications of this change.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other Labor proposal that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is adopting in this bill is an amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to the Social Security Act and the Vet-

Speaker: NA
Text: erans' Entitlements Act to extend the pension

Speaker: NA
Text: assets test exemption period, from 12 months

Speaker: NA
Text: to 24 months, following the sale of the prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipal home. Labor proposed an amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Social Security Act in 2006 along

Speaker: NA
Text: similar lines to support pensioners who were

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to have their new home built during

Speaker: NA
Text: the 12-month period due to delays caused by

Speaker: NA
Text: the skills shortage. The 12-month rule was

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly affecting pensioners trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: build a new home and being delayed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: serious skills crisis that, frankly, is a respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility of this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the current arrangements, a person

Speaker: NA
Text: has 12 months to sell their existing home and

Speaker: NA
Text: construct a new home before the proceeds of

Speaker: NA
Text: the sale of their existing home become an

Speaker: NA
Text: assessable asset. Because of the huge skills

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage and therefore the delay in building

Speaker: NA
Text: completion dates, a number of pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: have been unable to get their home com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted within the 12-month time frame. Sto-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries of people waiting for tradespeople to

Speaker: NA
Text: turn up are very well known to everyone.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor was concerned about the impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners of the delays that forced them to

Speaker: NA
Text: be caught up in these assets test rules. It now

Speaker: NA
Text: appears that the government has caught up,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I am pleased to see this change in this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The changes to the remote area allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: are also welcome. The remote area allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance is a payment for income support recipi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents who receive no or little benefit from the

Speaker: NA
Text: income zone tax offset through the tax sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem. It is incomeand asset-test free and paid

Speaker: NA
Text: at single and couple rates, with an additional

Speaker: NA
Text: rate for each dependent child. The child sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port reforms that take effect from July 2008

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce the concept of a ‘regular care

Speaker: NA
Text: child'. That is a child who is cared for by a

Speaker: NA
Text: parent for at least 14 per cent and less than

Speaker: NA
Text: 35 per cent of the time. The bill provides for

Speaker: NA
Text: the rate of remote area allowance to be in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased by an additional allowance for each

Speaker: NA
Text: regular care child in a family in addition to

Speaker: NA
Text: each FTB child. So it does provide extra

Speaker: NA
Text: support to families, and it is welcomed by

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also support the changes to allow fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily tax benefits to continue to be paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Australian Defence Force

Speaker: NA
Text: and members of the Australian Federal Po-

Speaker: NA
Text: lice International Deployment Group who

Speaker: NA
Text: are deployed overseas. Normally FTB is only

Speaker: NA
Text: payable at the full rate to people temporarily

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas for up to 13 weeks. Discretion to

Speaker: NA
Text: extend that period exists where certain pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed events prevent or delay their return.

Speaker: NA
Text: Presently, ADF and AFP personnel on over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas deployment are not covered adequately

Speaker: NA
Text: by this discretion. This bill makes amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to rectify that deficiency.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, as I have indicated, Labor supports

Speaker: NA
Text: this lengthy amendment bill. However, I do

Speaker: NA
Text: want to reiterate our serious and ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns with the impact of the new Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Scheme on low-income families.

Speaker: NA
Text: The DEPUTY SPEAKER

Speaker: NA
Text: Secker)-Is the amendment seconded?

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms George-I second the amendment.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Throsby.

Speaker: Ms GEORGE
Text: Throsby) (11.38 am)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill before us for debate today-the

Speaker: NA
Text: Families, Community Services and Indige-

Speaker: NA
Text: nous Affairs Legislation Amendment (Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Reform Consolidation and Other

Speaker: NA
Text: Measures) Bill 2007-follows two substan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial pieces of legislation that were debated

Speaker: NA
Text: last year. Those bills arose in response to the

Speaker: NA
Text: bipartisan recommendations of the original

Speaker: NA
Text: report of the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Family and Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity Affairs, Every picture tells a story. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was pleased to be a member of that commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee, which worked very hard to try and insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tute some very fundamental changes both to

Speaker: NA
Text: family law and to the Child Support Scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: and the formula in particular. It was left to

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee chaired by Professor Parkin-

Speaker: NA
Text: son to come up with a range of detailed rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendations that go to the heart of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Child Support Scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government announced major

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the scheme in February last year,

Speaker: NA
Text: and, as I say, today is part of the ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: process of trying to give effect to the rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendations of both the House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives committee and the Parkinson task

Speaker: NA
Text: force.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill before us today contains a num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of significant technical and consequential

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments that flow from the original leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation. It also incorporates relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments relocated from the Child Sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port Legislation Amendment Bill 2004. The

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow minister has spoken at length on a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of the proposals contained in this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: and the proposed changes. I do not intend to

Speaker: NA
Text: elaborate on those in any greater detail, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr cause I want to focus my remarks specifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally on matters relating to child support.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the shadow minister, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Jagajaga, outlined to the House, the introduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the child support system back in 1988

Speaker: NA
Text: was a very important and innovative measure

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced by the Hawke Labor government.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was important at that time because it

Speaker: NA
Text: aimed to strike a fair balance between public

Speaker: NA
Text: and private forms of support for children

Speaker: NA
Text: where marriages had broken down, and to

Speaker: NA
Text: alleviate the poverty that we all know exists

Speaker: NA
Text: in sole parent families, particularly those

Speaker: NA
Text: struggling families with mum at the head of

Speaker: NA
Text: the family unit. We all know that sole parent

Speaker: NA
Text: families raising children are likely to be very

Speaker: NA
Text: much at the bottom of the income scale and

Speaker: NA
Text: at the bottom of the scale in terms of wellbe-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and living standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we on this side of the chamber have

Speaker: NA
Text: always had a view that any child support

Speaker: NA
Text: policy must put the interests of children first,

Speaker: NA
Text: must aim to reduce child poverty and must

Speaker: NA
Text: operate in a way that encourages both par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents, post separation, to continue to contrib-

Speaker: NA
Text: ute to their children's wellbeing. It must

Speaker: NA
Text: courage both parents to maintain ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: roles in their children's lives. We, as mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of parliament, know that hitherto that

Speaker: NA
Text: often has not been the case. So I do, in

Speaker: NA
Text: eral terms, welcome many of the long-

Speaker: NA
Text: overdue changes that will come with the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: troduction of the staged changes to the sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem and to the formula in particular. But, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Jagajaga made clear, our

Speaker: NA
Text: support for the package overall continues to

Speaker: NA
Text: be conditional on improved protection

Speaker: NA
Text: against income reductions for low-income

Speaker: NA
Text: households raising children. I will return to

Speaker: NA
Text: that point a little later.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it was regrettable that, as members

Speaker: NA
Text: of this House, we were not in a position to

Speaker: NA
Text: debate the changes to the Child Support

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme and the formula as a total package.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we had been able to, it would have been

Speaker: NA
Text: easier for all of us to assess the winners and

Speaker: NA
Text: the losers and to take into account the equity

Speaker: NA
Text: considerations of justice and fairness that

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be part of the eventual outcomes. As

Speaker: NA
Text: we know, these changes are coming in three

Speaker: NA
Text: tranches. Today we are debating some of

Speaker: NA
Text: those changes, but the final package of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: forms will only come into existence in July

Speaker: NA
Text: next year.

Speaker: NA
Text: You cannot argue against the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing formula has been the cause of a

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal of angst in the community. Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search undertaken by the Australian Institute

Speaker: NA
Text: of Family Studies found that more than 60

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of non-resident fathers and 45 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of resident mothers think the system is

Speaker: NA
Text: not working well. This was substantially

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmed in the evidence that came before

Speaker: NA
Text: us in the inquiry that led to the very impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant, ground-breaking report, Every picture

Speaker: NA
Text: tells a story. As I and all MPs know, many

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents who have come to see us have

Speaker: NA
Text: raised concerns about the application of a

Speaker: NA
Text: formula that they perceived to encompass

Speaker: NA
Text: many anomalies and that they believed

Speaker: NA
Text: enneeded to be rectified. So the changes that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have already seen are generally wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: comed and supported. I want to refer to some

Speaker: NA
Text: of these because they are matters that have

Speaker: NA
Text: gen- been the cause of complaint to me as the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Throsby.

Speaker: NA
Text: From July 2006, when the first major re-

Speaker: NA
Text: forms came into being, we recognised non-

Speaker: NA
Text: resident parents on income support who have

Speaker: NA
Text: contact with their children for at least one

Speaker: NA
Text: night a week by the payment of a higher al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance. We enabled parents who pay child

Speaker: NA
Text: support to spend a greater percentage of their

Speaker: NA
Text: payments directly on their children and to

Speaker: NA
Text: nominate the areas that they wanted those

Speaker: NA
Text: funds to be targeted at. So up to 30 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of child support payments can now in fact be

Speaker: NA
Text: directly attributed to the desire of the non-

Speaker: NA
Text: resident parent as to how that expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: should be met. We have certainly beefed up

Speaker: NA
Text: action to ensure child support is paid on time

Speaker: NA
Text: and in full. We all know cases where people

Speaker: NA
Text: have deliberately avoided their responsibili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties for payment of child support. We also

Speaker: NA
Text: know of the huge number of people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: system who were paying just the bare mini-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum of $5 a week. Compliance was a prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem, with only around half of all parents

Speaker: NA
Text: making their payments in full and on time,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I want to say a bit about that in a mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was some debate about the reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in the cap at the top level, where we saw

Speaker: NA
Text: the cap reduced from around $140,000 to

Speaker: NA
Text: $105,000. But I do believe that, in the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: text of the total package, this change will

Speaker: NA
Text: bring payments much more into line with the

Speaker: NA
Text: actual costs of raising children. We improved

Speaker: NA
Text: support for separating families through the

Speaker: NA
Text: family relationship centres. I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that we have one in Wollongong,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have visited, and I know the great

Speaker: NA
Text: job that it is performing in assisting local

Speaker: NA
Text: families. We increased minimum payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my view they are not sufficient, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: have gone up from $5 a week to just over $6

Speaker: NA
Text: and in future will be indexed to the CPI.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the second stage of the changes, operathe

Speaker: NA
Text: tive from January this year, there is now the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity for an independent review of Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Agency decisions through the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Appeals Tribunal. Many parents

Speaker: NA
Text: who have visited me have complained about

Speaker: NA
Text: the high legal costs in challenging decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: of the CSA when they have to go through a

Speaker: NA
Text: court process. I think it will remove the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: mense financial burden on people who are

Speaker: NA
Text: unhappy with outcomes as a result of deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions made by the agencies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Importantly, too, since January this year

Speaker: NA
Text: parents will be provided with more time to

Speaker: NA
Text: work out their parenting arrangements before

Speaker: NA
Text: their family payments are affected. Previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously, a separated parent was allowed only

Speaker: NA
Text: 28 days in which to take action to obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: child support payments before their family

Speaker: NA
Text: tax benefit A payments were affected. This

Speaker: NA
Text: time frame, as I know from personal experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence, often caused conflict between separat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing parents, often undermining their ability

Speaker: NA
Text: to reach agreement on parenting arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments or, in some cases, even to reconcile

Speaker: NA
Text: the differences which led to the breakdown

Speaker: NA
Text: in their marriage or relationship. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that, from January this year, the time

Speaker: NA
Text: limit will be extended from 28 days to 13

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Early indications of the impact of these

Speaker: NA
Text: legislative changes have in fact been very

Speaker: NA
Text: heartening. Recent data from the Child Sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port Agency showed that more separated or

Speaker: NA
Text: divorced couples are now embracing shared

Speaker: NA
Text: parenting arrangements-not as much as we

Speaker: NA
Text: would like, but it is heading in the right

Speaker: NA
Text: rection-and that an increasing number of

Speaker: NA
Text: fathers are taking on the role of primary

Speaker: NA
Text: carer. In 2006 about 21 per cent of new cases

Speaker: NA
Text: listed fathers as the primary care giver,

Speaker: NA
Text: pared with just 7½ per cent in 1997. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to see an increase in contact between

Speaker: NA
Text: non-custodial parents and their children, with

Speaker: NA
Text: number of those parents who see their

Speaker: NA
Text: children 30 per cent or more of nights a year

Speaker: NA
Text: doubling-from a low base but nevertheless

Speaker: NA
Text: doubling-in the recent period. I think these

Speaker: NA
Text: factors are a growing indication of changes

Speaker: NA
Text: in attitude in custody disputes, which is a

Speaker: NA
Text: good thing, especially for children in situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of marital breakdown.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am also pleased that the Child Support

Speaker: NA
Text: Agency and the tax office have been more

Speaker: NA
Text: proactive in putting the squeeze on what are

Speaker: NA
Text: described as child support cheats. We all

Speaker: NA
Text: know of cases where people deliberately

Speaker: NA
Text: minimise their assessable taxable income to

Speaker: NA
Text: avoid their obligations to their children. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was recently reported that more than 35,000

Speaker: NA
Text: divorced parents, mainly fathers, have been

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to pay $13 million in a major tax of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice crackdown on parents who do not file

Speaker: NA
Text: their tax returns in order to avoid paying

Speaker: NA
Text: their legal child support obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Ellison recently commented that

Speaker: NA
Text: this new program was expected to net some

Speaker: NA
Text: $460 million in child support payments over

Speaker: NA
Text: the next four years. We certainly hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: occurs, because there have been many sole

Speaker: NA
Text: parent families left in the lurch by people

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberately falsifying or minimising their

Speaker: NA
Text: assessable taxable income to avoid their ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: ligations of financial contribution to raising

Speaker: NA
Text: their children.

Speaker: NA
Text: From July next year we will see the final

Speaker: NA
Text: stage of the long-awaited changes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: formula for calculating child support-a new

Speaker: NA
Text: formula that will form the basis for the cal-

Speaker: NA
Text: culation of child support. For the first time

Speaker: NA
Text: diwe will have a formula which will be based

Speaker: NA
Text: on our own Australian research and provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: more objective and realistic assessment of

Speaker: NA
Text: the actual costs of raising children. The for-

Speaker: NA
Text: commula will treat the incomes and living costs

Speaker: NA
Text: of both parents more equitably and take into

Speaker: NA
Text: account the fact that older children cost more

Speaker: NA
Text: to raise. It will also ensure that children

Speaker: NA
Text: first and second families are treated more

Speaker: NA
Text: equitably. That has been a major cause of

Speaker: NA
Text: complaint from constituents who ask me

Speaker: NA
Text: why children of subsequent partnering and

Speaker: NA
Text: marriage are treated less favourably than

Speaker: NA
Text: children from the first marriage.

Speaker: NA
Text: These changes will see parents share in

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of supporting their children accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to their capacity to pay. The new propos-

Speaker: NA
Text: als and the new formula move away from the

Speaker: NA
Text: principle that the existing formula is based

Speaker: NA
Text: on-that is, the principle of continuity of

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure, which somehow tries to artifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cially maintain the intact family standard of

Speaker: NA
Text: living post separation. Something that has

Speaker: NA
Text: always baffled me and I have found hard to

Speaker: NA
Text: explain to my constituents is the basis of the

Speaker: NA
Text: percentages in the current formula and how

Speaker: NA
Text: they apply in a fair way. I think that for the

Speaker: NA
Text: first time, in moving towards an income-

Speaker: NA
Text: sharing approach, we will have a far more

Speaker: NA
Text: objective and scientific basis on which to

Speaker: NA
Text: respond to those issues. I think the new for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mula will better reflect the principle of

Speaker: NA
Text: shared parental responsibility and better re-

Speaker: NA
Text: flect the changes in workforce participation

Speaker: NA
Text: by women. It is proposed that in future the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of raising children will be based on the

Speaker: NA
Text: parents' combined income, with the costs

Speaker: NA
Text: distributed between the mother and the fa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther, or the resident and non-resident parent,

Speaker: NA
Text: in accordance with their respective share of

Speaker: NA
Text: that combined income and their level of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tact with their children. Both parents will

Speaker: NA
Text: now have a component for their self-support

Speaker: NA
Text: deducted from the income table.

Speaker: NA
Text: Very importantly, in moving away from

Speaker: NA
Text: the arbitrary percentages that we have had

Speaker: NA
Text: applied in the past, we will for the first time,

Speaker: NA
Text: courtesy of the fantastic work done by the

Speaker: NA
Text: University of Canberra's National Centre for

Speaker: NA
Text: Social and Economic Modelling, have a

Speaker: NA
Text: much more objective and realistic assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the actual cost of raising children. As

Speaker: NA
Text: from NATSEM themselves argue, the calculations

Speaker: NA
Text: can never be perfect; but they will be as

Speaker: NA
Text: close as researchers believe it is possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: be. For example, they have estimated that for

Speaker: NA
Text: a single child up to the age of four the aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: age cost of care is $91 per week in a two-

Speaker: NA
Text: parent family and $115 per week in a single-

Speaker: NA
Text: parent family. For a fiveto 12-year old, the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost rose to $95 per week in a two-income

Speaker: NA
Text: family and $119 per week in a single-parent

Speaker: NA
Text: family. I give those examples to make the

Speaker: NA
Text: point that it will be much easier to address

Speaker: NA
Text: the constant complaints and concerns when

Speaker: NA
Text: you can say to people who come to see you

Speaker: NA
Text: that at least, for the first time, we have the

Speaker: NA
Text: best calculations possible as to the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of raising children today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some people have argued with me that

Speaker: NA
Text: high-income earners appear to be favoured

Speaker: NA
Text: and advantaged by these changes and asked

Speaker: NA
Text: me whether I think that is fair. I guess that is

Speaker: NA
Text: a judgement people will come to in regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: their individual assessments, but I would

Speaker: NA
Text: note that a non-resident parent supporting

Speaker: NA
Text: two children under the age of 12 would still

Speaker: NA
Text: be making payments in the order of $472 per

Speaker: NA
Text: week at the top end and that those payments

Speaker: NA
Text: are in fact higher than the objective data that

Speaker: NA
Text: NATSEM has produced on the cost of raising

Speaker: NA
Text: children. So, even though initially it might

Speaker: NA
Text: appear that it skews the advantage to high-

Speaker: NA
Text: income earners, when you look at the reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in the cap against the actual costs I think

Speaker: NA
Text: you see that there is a measure of fairness in

Speaker: NA
Text: it. As I indicated earlier, the task force rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommended an increase in the self-support

Speaker: NA
Text: amount, that it should be the same for both

Speaker: NA
Text: parents and that children from first and sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ond families and partnerships ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: treated as equally as possible. The formula

Speaker: NA
Text: also recognises that regular face-to-face con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tact is an important component in assessing

Speaker: NA
Text: child support payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have some concerns about the with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawal rate for child support liability. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: been suggested that regular contact-that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: contact of at least five nights per fortnight-

Speaker: NA
Text: should entitle the non-resident parent to a 24

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent reduction in their child support li-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability. I would urge the government to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view that before the changes are introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: because I do feel that that rate of reduction is

Speaker: NA
Text: too high and, in fact, could have the unin-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended consequence of leaving too many sole

Speaker: NA
Text: parents-usually resident mums-in a more

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable position than they are in today. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think if we could revisit that 24 per cent re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction for the non-resident parent who has

Speaker: NA
Text: the child or children for at least five nights a

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight, we might get to a better and fairer

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome and address some of the very im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant issues that the member for Jagajaga

Speaker: NA
Text: raised in her contribution. We still have time

Speaker: NA
Text: to do that before the final legislative changes

Speaker: NA
Text: are enacted.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to talk about one example

Speaker: NA
Text: from evidence given to a Senate committee

Speaker: NA
Text: recently by Jaqueline Taylor from the Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Council of Single Mothers and their

Speaker: NA
Text: Children. She said:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... calculating the financial impact on single

Speaker: NA
Text: mother families post July next year has actually

Speaker: NA
Text: been an incredibly difficult thing to do because

Speaker: NA
Text: there is nothing available to help us with that.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been no modelling done by the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment to actually calculate the impact that

Speaker: NA
Text: changes will have on sole parent families and we

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot forget that this is also in conjunction with

Speaker: NA
Text: Welfare to Work and the loss of income from that.

Speaker: NA
Text: So it would be a great tragedy, in my view, if

Speaker: NA
Text: all the positive and innovative changes that

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise the anomalies and the difficulties

Speaker: NA
Text: inherent in the current formula were to falter

Speaker: NA
Text: on the rock of leaving some people, pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: dominantly sole parent mums, in a more pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: carious and vulnerable position than they are

Speaker: NA
Text: now in. It is important for the government to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the overall package is correlated

Speaker: NA
Text: very closely and carefully with welfare poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies and benefits to ensure that low-income

Speaker: NA
Text: households raising children are not left

Speaker: NA
Text: worse off than they are presently. I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be a terrible shame were child poverty

Speaker: NA
Text: levels to rise as an unintended consequence

Speaker: NA
Text: of the positive changes recommended by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parkinson report. I am very pleased that I

Speaker: NA
Text: had the opportunity to participate in the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view. I am very proud of the report we pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented and I am very encouraged by the leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islative changes that will shake up the family

Speaker: NA
Text: law system and child support in this country.

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Text: Moreton) (11.59

Speaker: NA
Text: am)-Before turning to the provisions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Families, Community Services and Indige-

Speaker: NA
Text: nous Affairs Legislation Amendment (Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Reform Consolidation and Other

Speaker: NA
Text: Measures) Bill 2007, I wish to delay the

Speaker: NA
Text: House for a moment to congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Throsby on her very carefully

Speaker: NA
Text: considered observations. I find virtually no

Speaker: NA
Text: fault with anything she has just said. I could

Speaker: NA
Text: leave my remarks there, to the relief of eve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ryone, and take my seat, but I shall not. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to contribute to the discussion.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Throsby has, to my mind,

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined some very real circumstances. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: optimistic that Minister Brough, because of

Speaker: NA
Text: his great capacity to listen, will look very

Speaker: NA
Text: closely at what the member for Throsby has

Speaker: NA
Text: just said about single parents, and particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: these larly single mothers, who may feel a sense of

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerability. We in our various electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: offices see that every day. I am optimistic

Speaker: NA
Text: that Minister Brough will look very closely

Speaker: NA
Text: at what the member for Throsby said. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: certain that over the next 12 months he will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that by 1 July next year we have some

Speaker: NA
Text: of those matters put to rest.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is absolutely important in this debate

Speaker: NA
Text: that we drive out any sense of victimhood.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Throsby is right to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: the minimum $5, now $6, contribution is not

Speaker: NA
Text: enough. That $5 contribution was not in

Speaker: NA
Text: place until the last decade-that minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: expectation of people, say, on a pension or

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit to make a contribution towards the

Speaker: NA
Text: raising of the child in the custody of the

Speaker: NA
Text: other parent. I do not think that $5 is any-

Speaker: NA
Text: where near enough. I do not want to see $6. I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to see $25. That might be a mark in the

Speaker: NA
Text: sand that I do not mind putting on the table.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing annoys me more as a local mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber than to hear the stories of a delinquent

Speaker: NA
Text: and absent parent who does not even bother,

Speaker: NA
Text: who does not even try, to contribute any

Speaker: NA
Text: money towards the upkeep of their child.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently I had in my office the case of a

Speaker: NA
Text: young woman with an ex-partner who, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the way the family law system

Speaker: NA
Text: works, has to have a phone number for ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess and who uses that phone number to ring

Speaker: NA
Text: her and abuse her. He screams at her over the

Speaker: NA
Text: phone.

Speaker: NA
Text: In saying that, I do not want to typecast

Speaker: NA
Text: the blokes as always being at fault. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: often not the case. There are circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: like those of another case I had, in which a

Speaker: NA
Text: man and a woman's relationship broke down,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I am sure everyone would see as an

Speaker: NA
Text: absolute tragedy. They had a child between

Speaker: NA
Text: them. They had reached agreement on a sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible parenting plan, as they were encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: aged to do, where essentially the wage struc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tures of both were the same. Even though

Speaker: NA
Text: one cashed out part of their wage to receive

Speaker: NA
Text: car from a state government department, ba-

Speaker: NA
Text: sically their incomes were exactly the same.

Speaker: NA
Text: They had one child between them and they

Speaker: NA
Text: had reached agreement on a parenting plan

Speaker: NA
Text: of 50 per cent each looking after the child.

Speaker: NA
Text: The child had access to both parents. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: woman involved-and good luck to her-

Speaker: NA
Text: found another man and got married. She rang

Speaker: NA
Text: her former husband and said: ‘I have to

Speaker: NA
Text: change the arrangements now. I am pregnant

Speaker: NA
Text: with another child, so I am going to retire

Speaker: NA
Text: from work and you are going to pay for me

Speaker: NA
Text: to have the baby.' This was because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: way the system used to operate. He was now

Speaker: NA
Text: culpable because he was going to be the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come earner. Under the way the system had

Speaker: NA
Text: operated in the past, he was the person who

Speaker: NA
Text: basically paid for his former wife to have a

Speaker: NA
Text: baby with someone else.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is one of the reasons why there are

Speaker: NA
Text: people in my electorate who are just hanging

Speaker: NA
Text: on for the changes, which the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Throsby and others no doubt will outline, at

Speaker: NA
Text: the start of next year, where we will see the

Speaker: NA
Text: more equitable treatment of both parents'

Speaker: NA
Text: incomes being taken into account. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: see a further decline in the situation where

Speaker: NA
Text: people use child support as a form of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: venge on the previous partner. They use it as

Speaker: NA
Text: a means of financially beating up or control-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling that person. So I applaud Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Brough for the continuation of his efforts. I

Speaker: NA
Text: saw the Minister for Defence here a moment

Speaker: NA
Text: ago-he has other duties. As the supreme

Speaker: NA
Text: commander of the south-west Pacific he has

Speaker: NA
Text: many duties, no doubt. When we came to

Speaker: NA
Text: office in 1996 we inherited this system of

Speaker: NA
Text: child support, which was more fledgling than

Speaker: NA
Text: it is today and needed a lot of work. A num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of us worked with then Minister Jocelyn

Speaker: NA
Text: Newman to effect some changes. It has taken

Speaker: NA
Text: a long time to drive them along. I remember

Speaker: NA
Text: that the member for Chifley in the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating government chaired an inquiry into

Speaker: NA
Text: a this, saying: ‘Mate, don't let it slip. You've

Speaker: NA
Text: got to ensure that there is better treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: this, that we see both parents' incomes being

Speaker: NA
Text: counted.'

Speaker: NA
Text: In hammering this point I am probably ru-

Speaker: NA
Text: ining your career, Member for Throsby, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: am saying that I think your contribution to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day was very good and I think it shows that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is some real concern and effort on both

Speaker: NA
Text: sides of the chamber on this matter. What we

Speaker: NA
Text: want to see, ideally, is families staying intact,

Speaker: NA
Text: but we accept that that is, unfortunately, not

Speaker: NA
Text: always the case. The children must come

Speaker: NA
Text: first in these circumstances. The welfare of

Speaker: NA
Text: the child must be paramount. I am also look-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing forward to work being done to remove

Speaker: NA
Text: this formula and to perhaps individualise

Speaker: NA
Text: better the circumstances and the costs of rais-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing children. As the parent of two teenagers,

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that they are far more expensive than

Speaker: NA
Text: when they were young kids. So I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased with, and enormously proud of, the

Speaker: NA
Text: work this government has been doing in this

Speaker: NA
Text: important area.

Speaker: NA
Text: But this bill is not just about child support

Speaker: NA
Text: reform. It contains a number of other meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures. We have spent a bit of time this morn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing talking about child support matters be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause they are important, but the other meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures are equally important. The bill deals

Speaker: NA
Text: with social security and veterans matters. It

Speaker: NA
Text: amends the veterans' entitlements legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: in regard to the sale of a principal home.

Speaker: NA
Text: These homes have been asset tax exempt if

Speaker: NA
Text: the person is likely to use the proceeds to

Speaker: NA
Text: buy another home. The previous provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: have applied within 12 months. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: listened, and we have recognised what is

Speaker: NA
Text: going on in the real world. It takes a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: longer for many people to build a home than

Speaker: NA
Text: maybe that 12-month period. They have to

Speaker: NA
Text: find another place to put that money and they

Speaker: NA
Text: do not see it as an unspent asset sitting in the

Speaker: NA
Text: bank. To give people 24 months, not 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months, is one of the measures in this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Equally, the bill makes amendments relating

Speaker: NA
Text: to income streams. A number of minor

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments are aimed at enhancing and im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proving the efficacy and the efficiency of

Speaker: NA
Text: various income-stream rules.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also makes changes to the pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the baby bonus. A few older people

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate have made their complaints

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious to me about the way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has been making payments of

Speaker: NA
Text: the baby bonus, the $4,000-‘One for you,

Speaker: NA
Text: one for your wife and one for the country,'

Speaker: NA
Text: said the Treasurer. Many people have been

Speaker: NA
Text: taking up the baby bonus. It does not meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the full cost of a child coming into the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is about encouraging people on the mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: gins in their decision to have a baby. If it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: financial reason that is stopping them-that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, if you can make these decisions and get

Speaker: NA
Text: the timing right-this $4,000 baby bonus

Speaker: NA
Text: helps people through that.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been genuine concern about

Speaker: NA
Text: many single parents, and I know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Families, Community Services

Speaker: NA
Text: and Indigenous Affairs has made it plain that

Speaker: NA
Text: in some Indigenous communities there have

Speaker: NA
Text: been real ramifications for young women in

Speaker: NA
Text: this regard. For under 18-year-olds we are

Speaker: NA
Text: now going to put in place a formal system of

Speaker: NA
Text: instalments. We are going to pay the baby

Speaker: NA
Text: bonus in 13 fortnightly instalments, require

Speaker: NA
Text: the registration of the birth by the relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: state or territory authority as a condition of

Speaker: NA
Text: eligibility and rename the maternity payment

Speaker: NA
Text: the ‘baby bonus'. The concept is very plain.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is about not allowing any sets of circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances whereby people see a profit out of

Speaker: NA
Text: pregnancy but realising that it is about assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the creation of a nurturing environment

Speaker: NA
Text: for the child.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know there will be a lot of older people

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate who will say: ‘In our day we

Speaker: NA
Text: never received this assistance from govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Why are you doing it now?' Fertility

Speaker: NA
Text: rates have declined, our population is going

Speaker: NA
Text: to decline and our standard of living is going

Speaker: NA
Text: to decline over the next 20 or 30 years if we

Speaker: NA
Text: do not keep our population growing in a

Speaker: NA
Text: positive way so that we have productive

Speaker: NA
Text: members of our community able to earn a

Speaker: NA
Text: wage and pay the taxes and create the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries and all of the things that people of past

Speaker: NA
Text: generations have done. We are the only

Speaker: NA
Text: country, as I understand it, in the Western

Speaker: NA
Text: world that has turned around its birth rate

Speaker: NA
Text: and, in fact, has increased its birth rate. That

Speaker: NA
Text: may be due to the fact that we have identi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied ways to assist people on the margins

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the financial aspect when making the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision to have a family. The situation is

Speaker: NA
Text: very positive in that regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Looking at the portability of family tax

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit, changes have been made to allow a

Speaker: NA
Text: portability period of 13 weeks for full pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. That is now being extended to mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Australian Defence Force and

Speaker: NA
Text: certain Australian Federal Police personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: of the International Deployment Group.

Speaker: NA
Text: When they are deployed overseas as part of

Speaker: NA
Text: their duty and, in fact, remain overseas for

Speaker: NA
Text: longer than 13 weeks, we do not want to see

Speaker: NA
Text: them losing that family payment. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: tidying up in that respect. With Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: now involved in 10 deployments-we have

Speaker: NA
Text: never had a greater number of deployments

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas in our entire history-there are

Speaker: NA
Text: many thousands of great Australians serving

Speaker: NA
Text: our country in uniform in all sorts of places

Speaker: NA
Text: who do not deserve the impost of a system

Speaker: NA
Text: denying them access to family tax benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, I am pleased to support this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure. When I was in the Middle East a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of weeks ago with the men and

Speaker: NA
Text: women of the HMAS Toowoomba and the

Speaker: NA
Text: men and women of the RAAF who were on

Speaker: NA
Text: flying missions in various parts in support

Speaker: NA
Text: our effort to ensure Iraq remains free and

Speaker: NA
Text: gains the strength in its economy which will

Speaker: NA
Text: underpin its democracy, there were many

Speaker: NA
Text: people there who have families in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: who will be advantaged by the efforts the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is introducing in this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are also amending the maintenance in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come test provisions in the A New Tax Sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem (Family Assistance) Act 1999 and clari-

Speaker: NA
Text: fying the meaning of the words ‘amount re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived' and ‘amount payable'. These techni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal amendments clarify that maintenance

Speaker: NA
Text: income received by a payee for one or more

Speaker: NA
Text: children would reduce the payee's amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: family tax benefit A above the base rate for

Speaker: NA
Text: those children only. Such technical amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments may seem to delay the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: from time to time but they have a critical

Speaker: NA
Text: public face and a highly personal reach each

Speaker: NA
Text: and every time we deal with these matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's announcement in yes-

Speaker: NA
Text: terday's budget to deliver more for Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian families-an additional $4.5 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: committed over five years-will support

Speaker: NA
Text: families and children, people with disabili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties, volunteers, Indigenous and older Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians. We are seeing the expenditure of $50.6

Speaker: NA
Text: billion a year across the portfolio adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered by Minister Brough and Minister Scul-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion. The enormous $2.1 billion childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: investment that was announced will see

Speaker: NA
Text: some very positive changes to the payment

Speaker: NA
Text: of the childcare tax rebate, which can now be

Speaker: NA
Text: brought forward and paid soon after the end

Speaker: NA
Text: of the financial year in which costs are in-

Speaker: NA
Text: curred, at a cost of some $1.4 billion over

Speaker: NA
Text: four years. This measure provides a very real

Speaker: NA
Text: dividend for people in my electorate where

Speaker: NA
Text: we have great childcare services and many

Speaker: NA
Text: people paying lots of money to them. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: now in a position to ensure that my constitu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents, and yours as well, Mr Deputy Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: are able to access more money-in fact, up

Speaker: NA
Text: to $8,000-over the next few months, de-

Speaker: NA
Text: of pending on their circumstances, to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: them in meeting the costs of child care. All

Speaker: NA
Text: of these massive amounts that are being ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pended by the government on behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia require the careful ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ministration that this government has

Speaker: NA
Text: brought to the task. The legislation before us

Speaker: NA
Text: has an even greater reach today than it would

Speaker: NA
Text: have had a week ago because of this major

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of additional assistance that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is giving child care, child support

Speaker: NA
Text: and family assistance-growing the cake,

Speaker: NA
Text: growing the circumstances, growing the

Speaker: NA
Text: sense of support that can be offered.

Speaker: NA
Text: The contrast will become very evident

Speaker: NA
Text: when we start to see the semblance of an

Speaker: NA
Text: address-in-reply and a contribution by those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite. The challenge to those opposite in

Speaker: NA
Text: the course of this debate-to follow the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample of the member for Throsby, for one-

Speaker: NA
Text: is to not send to vulnerable people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community the signal of victimisation being

Speaker: NA
Text: their way of life. In the whole area of family

Speaker: NA
Text: support, child care and indeed child support

Speaker: NA
Text: it is absolutely important that we encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: those people with a capacity to do for them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves to do so. The more we liberate people

Speaker: NA
Text: with the ability to do something for them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves first and foremost, and back those

Speaker: NA
Text: people, the more we can concentrate our ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: forts on those with no capacity to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. That is the simple difference

Speaker: NA
Text: between this side of the House and those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, who pretend they want to be in

Speaker: NA
Text: government later in the year and have no

Speaker: NA
Text: manifesto, no policies, no certainty-we

Speaker: NA
Text: would simply see a return to the way it used

Speaker: NA
Text: to be. One of the things that are very clear in

Speaker: NA
Text: any discussion about child support, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Throsby suggested, is the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that many families now have the challenge of

Speaker: NA
Text: balancing welfare to work, where many peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple on the margins are being encouraged-

Speaker: NA
Text: some might say ‘coerced'-to do for them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves first and foremost and not to wait for

Speaker: NA
Text: others to do it for them.

Speaker: NA
Text: People are making decisions on the mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: gins, putting their children through profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sional child care and giving them nurturing

Speaker: NA
Text: and an educative environment in formative

Speaker: NA
Text: years, using child care while they go off to

Speaker: NA
Text: earn a living. People are under a certain

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of pressure and expectation that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to help pay their way first and

Speaker: NA
Text: foremost. That is a big difference from those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite who had a view which said to peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple: ‘You're never going to achieve anything,

Speaker: NA
Text: you're never going to get anywhere. Park

Speaker: NA
Text: yourself in welfare. Not only that, we'll find

Speaker: NA
Text: new ways to park you in various aspects of

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare. We'll increase the ability of people

Speaker: NA
Text: to access disability pensions and we'll hide

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment by making more people tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nically disabled for the purposes of welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: but not disabled in reality.' They were more

Speaker: NA
Text: consumed with ensuring there were more

Speaker: NA
Text: victims in society, the theory being that, if

Speaker: NA
Text: there are more victims, more people are go-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to vote Labor.

Speaker: NA
Text: On this side, we have challenged people to

Speaker: NA
Text: get off their tail and go and do for them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. We have backed those who want to

Speaker: NA
Text: back themselves. The work we are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: through this legislation continues that jour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney and last night's budget announcements

Speaker: NA
Text: enhance that very much so. People who are

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to do for themselves are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: get great support from this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether it is child support-where the

Speaker: NA
Text: journey continues, with the efforts of the past

Speaker: NA
Text: decade now producing fruit and the promise

Speaker: NA
Text: of what will come over the years ahead-

Speaker: NA
Text: income streams or asset test exemption peri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ods, we are saying to people, ‘If you want to

Speaker: NA
Text: work hard, to achieve something for your-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves, to make a difference in our society

Speaker: NA
Text: and grow our economy along the way, we

Speaker: NA
Text: want to back you all the way.' I congratulate

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Brough on the success he managed

Speaker: NA
Text: to achieve for the people of Australia who

Speaker: NA
Text: rely on him, with $50 billion plus annual

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure through his portfolio secured by

Speaker: NA
Text: last night's budget announcements. I con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulate him and officers of his department

Speaker: NA
Text: on the close work they do to deliver the

Speaker: NA
Text: kinds of technical amendments we have be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore us today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I will end on a very special vote

Speaker: NA
Text: of thanks to members of the Child Support

Speaker: NA
Text: Agency-we have spent a bit of time talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about them. Today they are dealing with a set

Speaker: NA
Text: of circumstances which are different from a

Speaker: NA
Text: decade ago. I think they are now a lot more

Speaker: NA
Text: responsive than a decade ago to the ambi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of blokes when they get on the phone.

Speaker: NA
Text: When first elected in 1996, I heard com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plaints time and time again about officers of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Child Support Agency assuming that the

Speaker: NA
Text: blokes were at fault-no offence to officers

Speaker: NA
Text: but this is what people were saying to me.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now with more men involved in the process,

Speaker: NA
Text: that kind of discussion is defeated because

Speaker: NA
Text: there is an opportunity for greater action

Speaker: NA
Text: across genders and a greater sense of respect

Speaker: NA
Text: all round. We have moved things along

Speaker: NA
Text: enormously over the last decade but there is

Speaker: NA
Text: much more work to do, which is certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the reason we cannot go back to what

Speaker: NA
Text: we had pre 1996, to a government that is

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophically underpinned by the creation

Speaker: NA
Text: of more victims, telling people why they

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot do something instead of encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: them to do things for themselves. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophical difference between the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party and the government, between the coali-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and those who start from the position

Speaker: NA
Text: that people are going to fail. I commend this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill to the House and encourage others to

Speaker: NA
Text: follow the example of the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Throsby in her very good contribution earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: today.

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Text: Sydney) (12.18 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Families, Community Services and In-

Speaker: NA
Text: digenous Affairs Legislation Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Child Support Reform Consolidation and

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Measures) Bill 2007 is the third in a

Speaker: NA
Text: series of child support legislative reforms.

Speaker: NA
Text: represents the final part of the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: 2006 reforms to the child support system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor have largely supported these reforms

Speaker: NA
Text: and as a result we support this bill. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: debates on the previous two bills, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have expressed our concerns that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has failed to protect low-income

Speaker: NA
Text: families who may lose income as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: the changes to the Child Support Scheme. In

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking today on this bill, I note that our

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns have still not been adequately ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressed by the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Child Support Scheme was set up in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1988 by the Hawke Labor government and

Speaker: NA
Text: has become a model for other governments

Speaker: NA
Text: around the world. The principle that, after

Speaker: NA
Text: divorce, parents should continue to support

Speaker: NA
Text: their children is very sound. However, over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last five years a number of organisations,

Speaker: NA
Text: academics, experts, members of this House

Speaker: NA
Text: and others have expressed genuine concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: about the scheme. The scheme has not al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways operated fairly and equitably. The as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessment formula has not always produced

Speaker: NA
Text: good outcomes. There were particular issues

Speaker: NA
Text: with collection, arrears and compliance. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has not always been easy to get the money

Speaker: NA
Text: owed by non-custodial parents for the care of

Speaker: NA
Text: their children.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor have acknowledged the need for re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form to the system but say that reform

Speaker: NA
Text: should not come at a cost for the poorest and

Speaker: NA
Text: most vulnerable people, in particular the 1.1

Speaker: NA
Text: million children affected by child support

Speaker: NA
Text: and non-custodial parents who are often liv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in poverty in this country. In fact, custo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dial parents and their children are often

Speaker: NA
Text: among the poorest groups in our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are very vulnerable to changes which

Speaker: NA
Text: affect their income and we are very con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned that any changes in this area will not

Speaker: NA
Text: drive custodial parents and their children into

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reform process has been lengthy. In

Speaker: NA
Text: It 2003 the House of Representatives Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Family and Community Af-

Speaker: NA
Text: fairs tabled its report Every picture tells a

Speaker: NA
Text: story: inquiry into child custody arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in the event of family separation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: report dealt with child support and other

Speaker: NA
Text: family separation issues and made 29 bipar-

Speaker: NA
Text: tisan recommendations. Among its recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations was the establishment of a min-

Speaker: NA
Text: isterial task force to evaluate the Child Sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port Scheme, including establishing the costs

Speaker: NA
Text: of children's upbringing after parental sepa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ration, recognising different income levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: households and reflecting the costs for both

Speaker: NA
Text: parents of maintaining meaningful contact

Speaker: NA
Text: with their children.

Speaker: NA
Text: In May 2005, the report of the Ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: Taskforce on Child Support, known as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parkinson report, provided the first system-

Speaker: NA
Text: atic evaluation of the child support arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. It undertook a comprehensive analy-

Speaker: NA
Text: sis, relying on international research and

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioning modelling to come up with

Speaker: NA
Text: the best possible statistical information on

Speaker: NA
Text: the costs of children. It recommended an

Speaker: NA
Text: overhaul of the formula underlying the child

Speaker: NA
Text: support system that was based on evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: of the actual costs of raising children,

Speaker: NA
Text: parental responsibility for those costs and

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition of each parent's level of care.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year, we debated and passed two bills

Speaker: NA
Text: which enacted many of the recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Parkinson report. Those two bills im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plemented a new Child Support Scheme,

Speaker: NA
Text: including a new payment formula, changing

Speaker: NA
Text: the ‘capacity to earn' provisions, increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: the minimum payment and its indexation to

Speaker: NA
Text: the consumer price index, and increasing the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of child support payment that the

Speaker: NA
Text: non-resident parent can direct to specific

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly, not all of the recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Parkinson report were adopted. Cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly, the measures in those two earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: were not entirely to Labor's satisfaction, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I have made a number of criticisms in the

Speaker: NA
Text: past about aspects of that legislation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: principal concern raised by the reforms-and

Speaker: NA
Text: this remains my principal concern-is the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect of the new assessment formula on low-

Speaker: NA
Text: income resident parents, particularly those

Speaker: NA
Text: who have children under the age of 12. In all

Speaker: NA
Text: of these debates, we have tried to take a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: structive approach to the reforms. It is not

Speaker: NA
Text: my intention, and it is certainly not Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: intention, to politicise child support. We

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge that it is a very difficult area to

Speaker: NA
Text: get right. However, I remain concerned, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I know many of my colleagues do, about the

Speaker: NA
Text: interaction of taking money from low-

Speaker: NA
Text: income resident parents, particularly those

Speaker: NA
Text: with children under 12, at the same time as

Speaker: NA
Text: we are introducing Welfare to Work reforms

Speaker: NA
Text: and cutting the pay and conditions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: poorest and most vulnerable workers in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Those three things working together

Speaker: NA
Text: are set to penalise some of the poorest people

Speaker: NA
Text: in the country and those people who are busy

Speaker: NA
Text: raising the next generation. I am worried

Speaker: NA
Text: about that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week there was a Senate committee

Speaker: NA
