Text: inquiry into the bill. The inquiry highlighted

Speaker: NA
Text: shared the concerns about low-income custodial

Speaker: NA
Text: parents. The report shows that a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: the deleterious effects have not been ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressed by the government. The department

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for child support policy, FaCSIA,

Speaker: NA
Text: gave evidence that the implementation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms is not progressing as smoothly as we

Speaker: NA
Text: might hope. The department had agreed to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish a stakeholder reference group but

Speaker: NA
Text: that group apparently has met just once. The

Speaker: NA
Text: department has very little information about

Speaker: NA
Text: the impact of the new formula and new ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements on families.

Speaker: NA
Text: In debates on the child support bills last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, we called for transitional provisions in

Speaker: NA
Text: these bills to soften the blow for those low-

Speaker: NA
Text: bills income sole parent families. We certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: have not seen any of those transitional ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements in this legislation. If we put the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of children first and respect the

Speaker: NA
Text: original intent of the Child Support Scheme,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was to reduce child poverty, Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: would argue that there is a clear responsibil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity on the part of the government to amelio-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate the negative effect of the changes on

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the poorest families in the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today, again, we are debating these meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures. Again, we call on the government to

Speaker: NA
Text: ac- look to those most vulnerable parents and

Speaker: NA
Text: children and ensure that they are not penal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised, particularly during this transitional pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: riod. I note that the ministerial task force in

Speaker: NA
Text: its report urged the same thing. The ministe-

Speaker: NA
Text: rial task force, on page 261 of its report, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... the Government may wish to give considera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the position of those whose liability or

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlement will vary to a large extent as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of the recommendations, to avoid causing hard-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship in the short term.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly, that has not happened. These con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerns formed the basis of recommendation

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 of the Parkinson report, which said that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government needed to ‘comprensively

Speaker: NA
Text: consider the management of the transitional

Speaker: NA
Text: issues regarding the implementation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: new formula'. Unfortunately, our pleas re-

Speaker: NA
Text: garding some of the poorest families have

Speaker: NA
Text: fallen on deaf ears. No provision has been

Speaker: NA
Text: made to protect those families, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: the ones on very low incomes. That is why

Speaker: NA
Text: we have moved a second reading amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: in this regard. These are the same families

Speaker: NA
Text: who are, as I said, affected by Welfare to

Speaker: NA
Text: Work changes and the Work Choices legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. We will be watching very closely this

Speaker: NA
Text: interaction between the new child support

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, the Welfare to Work changes and

Speaker: NA
Text: Work Choices.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn to some of the measures that I am

Speaker: NA
Text: very pleased to see in this legislation. Cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently, ongoing child support can only be

Speaker: NA
Text: collected from employers if the payer is a

Speaker: NA
Text: wage or salary earner or they receive a Cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: trelink payment. This legislation will

Speaker: NA
Text: broaden the agency's power to issue notices

Speaker: NA
Text: requiring the deduction of child support and

Speaker: NA
Text: the forwarding of that deduction to the Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Agency to include cases where the

Speaker: NA
Text: payer is under contract for service arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that are effectively substituting for

Speaker: NA
Text: wages. We have heard a lot over recent years

Speaker: NA
Text: about the substantial increase in the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of employees who are employed as inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent contractors even when they are em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed to all intents and purposes as an em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployee. Extending the ability of the Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Agency to collect in those circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances is certainly a positive measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn briefly to the change to the payment

Speaker: NA
Text: of the baby bonus to under-18s. I am pleased

Speaker: NA
Text: to see that the government is paying the baby

Speaker: NA
Text: bonus in 13 instalments to parents under the

Speaker: NA
Text: age of 18. I am sure there are responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: parents out there who are under the age of

Speaker: NA
Text: 18, but I fear that the temptation of a $4,000

Speaker: NA
Text: lump sum may be too much for some of

Speaker: NA
Text: them. I think it is a more certain thing to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: people over a number of fortnights in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to avoid some of the worst effects that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard about in the payment of the baby

Speaker: NA
Text: bonus. Labor has said all along that, in cases

Speaker: NA
Text: where the money is likely not to be used in

Speaker: NA
Text: the best interests of the children, this should

Speaker: NA
Text: be something that we consider.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor supports the payment of the baby

Speaker: NA
Text: bonus generally as a good measure for help-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing parents when they encounter a lot of high

Speaker: NA
Text: costs around the time of the birth of the

Speaker: NA
Text: child. I am generally very sceptical when I

Speaker: NA
Text: hear stories about people living high on the

Speaker: NA
Text: hog on a few thousand dollars of government

Speaker: NA
Text: support at the time of the birth of a child, but

Speaker: NA
Text: there have been too many stories of concern

Speaker: NA
Text: in this area for us to ignore them completely.

Speaker: NA
Text: The stories that were brought to my attention

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to under-18s and the baby bonus,

Speaker: NA
Text: or more generally younger parents and the

Speaker: NA
Text: baby bonus, were not coming from the usual

Speaker: NA
Text: shock-jock sources; they were coming from

Speaker: NA
Text: youth workers, grandparents and community

Speaker: NA
Text: health nurses-people who have everyday

Speaker: NA
Text: contact with young parents and who want to

Speaker: NA
Text: support them, encourage them and teach

Speaker: NA
Text: them how to be good parents. They were not

Speaker: NA
Text: people who were interested in putting down

Speaker: NA
Text: young parents but people who were con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned that some of the money was not being

Speaker: NA
Text: spent in ways that were particularly useful

Speaker: NA
Text: for very young children. One woman told

Speaker: NA
Text: Today Tonight that her daughter was an ice

Speaker: NA
Text: addict who had seven children and that her

Speaker: NA
Text: daughter had told her, the grandmother, that

Speaker: NA
Text: she had had more children just to get the

Speaker: NA
Text: $4,000 baby bonus for each. On the same

Speaker: NA
Text: program, a 19-year-old mother of three said

Speaker: NA
Text: she had had her children just to get the baby

Speaker: NA
Text: bonus. I do not think this is widespread. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think many people are doing it; I think

Speaker: NA
Text: we are talking about tiny numbers. But it

Speaker: NA
Text: breaks my heart to think that any child would

Speaker: NA
Text: be brought into the world for such a reason.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is easy to discount these reports because

Speaker: NA
Text: we hear them from sensationalist sources

Speaker: NA
Text: that are interested in beating them up be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause they make good TV or are a good

Speaker: NA
Text: story, but we also have people like Father

Speaker: NA
Text: Chris Riley, who dedicates every day of his

Speaker: NA
Text: life to helping and supporting young people,

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that this payment has been causing

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘children to have children'. They are his

Speaker: NA
Text: words: ‘children to have children'. A West-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Sydney youth service reported directly to

Speaker: NA
Text: me that some of their clients saw the $4,000

Speaker: NA
Text: as a good way to buy a car or, in one case, a

Speaker: NA
Text: purebred dog. A Tasmanian youth worker

Speaker: NA
Text: told me that he knew of young men who

Speaker: NA
Text: were convincing their girlfriends to become

Speaker: NA
Text: pregnant, collecting the baby bonus when the

Speaker: NA
Text: baby was born and then shooting through.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sometimes they were not convincing their

Speaker: NA
Text: girlfriends to become pregnant but, if they

Speaker: NA
Text: became accidentally pregnant, were thinking,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Hang on a minute; I can get $4,000.' A

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawkesbury social worker told me of a

Speaker: NA
Text: young man who had systematically be-

Speaker: NA
Text: friended lonely pregnant girls, waited until

Speaker: NA
Text: they had given birth, convinced them to part

Speaker: NA
Text: with their baby bonus and then taken off. He

Speaker: NA
Text: boasted to this social worker that he had

Speaker: NA
Text: done this five times, and he was working on

Speaker: NA
Text: his sixth victim when the social worker

Speaker: NA
Text: chased him off. Again, I do not think we are

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about thousands of cases, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: tragedy of every one of these cases means

Speaker: NA
Text: that we need to take action, and Labor, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: said, has been calling for action in this area

Speaker: NA
Text: for some time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Domestic violence services report that

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of abuse rise about six weeks after the

Speaker: NA
Text: birth, just when the cheque comes in. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: women are handing over the money just to

Speaker: NA
Text: get rid of a violent partner. These are indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual stories, but we need to be aware,

Speaker: NA
Text: when we make these sorts of payments, of

Speaker: NA
Text: the social impact of the payments, even if

Speaker: NA
Text: that impact is on a small proportion of our

Speaker: NA
Text: population. I want to live in a society in

Speaker: NA
Text: which every child is wanted and every child

Speaker: NA
Text: is loved, and in which parents are emotion-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally ready to cope with this lifelong com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment, the most important job they can

Speaker: NA
Text: have.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand that it is difficult to design a

Speaker: NA
Text: system that takes into account the lengths

Speaker: NA
Text: that poorly motivated people will go to. You

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot design a perfect system that is able to

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent the human will to do wrong if that is

Speaker: NA
Text: a person's intention, but I think this is a posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive measure towards reducing this problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly, I think that more broadly in situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions where children are at risk of neglect the

Speaker: NA
Text: baby bonus could be paid fortnightly so that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is more likely to be spent on bills and other

Speaker: NA
Text: child-rearing expenses. A lot of organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: are already dealing with parents whose chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren are at risk of abuse and neglect and I

Speaker: NA
Text: think we could do more in that area. Taking

Speaker: NA
Text: the ‘jackpot' effect out of this payment is

Speaker: NA
Text: something positive that may prevent children

Speaker: NA
Text: from being born into really damaging cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances, so on that basis we support this

Speaker: NA
Text: change.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will finish by saying that it is important

Speaker: NA
Text: to remember that this payment was intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced with the purpose of increasing the

Speaker: NA
Text: birthrate. There has been a blip in the birth-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate, mostly because the cohort of women

Speaker: NA
Text: my age, who delayed childbearing because

Speaker: NA
Text: they were studying and getting a university

Speaker: NA
Text: education and doing all the rest of it, is now

Speaker: NA
Text: having children. Has it had an effect?

Speaker: NA
Text: Maybe. It is difficult to tell. We do know,

Speaker: NA
Text: though, what does work when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing the birthrate. If we look at coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries overseas with developed economies

Speaker: NA
Text: which have higher birthrates, it is because

Speaker: NA
Text: they have good supports for families. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have paid maternity leave or paid parental

Speaker: NA
Text: leave, they have better systems of child care

Speaker: NA
Text: than we have here and more affordable child

Speaker: NA
Text: care, and they have workplaces that recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nise that both parenting and paid work are

Speaker: NA
Text: essential roles. While of course Labor sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports this payment for new parents, we think

Speaker: NA
Text: we really need to address those other areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: support for families if we are serious about

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing the birthrate in Australia.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Text: Banks) (12.37 pm)-It is

Speaker: NA
Text: not my intention to go line by line through

Speaker: NA
Text: what is a very technical bill. However, there

Speaker: NA
Text: are some broad remarks I wish to make in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the Families, Community Services

Speaker: NA
Text: and Indigenous Affairs Legislation Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment (Child Support Reform Consolidation

Speaker: NA
Text: and Other Measures) Bill 2007. The issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: child support is one which affects every

Speaker: NA
Text: member of parliament. In my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Banks there are 2,465 persons who are liable

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay child support, 2,488 persons who are

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible to receive child support and a total of

Speaker: NA
Text: 4,037 children for whom support should be

Speaker: NA
Text: paid.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I first entered this place 17 years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago as a local member, the payment of child

Speaker: NA
Text: support was not an issue that my office dealt

Speaker: NA
Text: with on a regular basis. Indeed, the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion was not in place then. However, since

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation has been enacted, child sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port is constantly being dealt with in my of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice-and, I am sure, in every member's of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice. That is why the recent committee report

Speaker: NA
Text: into child support and custody, which I will

Speaker: NA
Text: come to later, came about. It is an issue that

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament has rightly confronted, legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated for and looked to improve and amend

Speaker: NA
Text: so as to give much deserved attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: community concerns.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to focus on the broad context of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill and the impact it will have on families.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that the issue of child sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port causes the most incredible heartache to

Speaker: NA
Text: parents and to children. This occurs follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, or as a part of, a relationship breakdown.

Speaker: NA
Text: In itself, the relationship breakdown causes

Speaker: NA
Text: significant distress to all the parties involved,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the issue of child support only multiplies

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect. Our constituents are usually in a

Speaker: NA
Text: state of grieving. As a local member I ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge that it is an extremely difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: issue to deal with in an equitable and fair

Speaker: NA
Text: manner. When they arrive at my office to

Speaker: NA
Text: discuss a child support matter, I know that it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be emotional and almost impossible to

Speaker: NA
Text: resolve.

Speaker: NA
Text: The original bill, the Child Support Legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation Amendment Bill 2004, was intended to

Speaker: NA
Text: create a new system for the assessment of

Speaker: NA
Text: child support payments. In the past, parents

Speaker: NA
Text: were quite reasonably concerned about the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that the previous formula was based on

Speaker: NA
Text: percentages and that those percentages did

Speaker: NA
Text: not always relate to the actual cost of raising

Speaker: NA
Text: a child. The new system is based on an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come share approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must acknowledge that this bill does

Speaker: NA
Text: little for low-income earners. The member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Jagajaga has moved a second reading

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to that effect and I fully support

Speaker: NA
Text: that amendment. Too often this government

Speaker: NA
Text: proposes legislation that gives little consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration to the impact on those earning not

Speaker: NA
Text: even middle-level incomes. Further, some

Speaker: NA
Text: primary caregivers-usually, but not always,

Speaker: NA
Text: mothers-will actually have their payments

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced under this new bill. It is not always

Speaker: NA
Text: possible to fully compensate for the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: raising children when the children are living

Speaker: NA
Text: in two separate homes-that of the primary

Speaker: NA
Text: caregiver and that of the access parent. Both

Speaker: NA
Text: the primary caregiver and the access parent

Speaker: NA
Text: incur real costs in raising their children.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note the concerns regarding proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 64 of schedule 1 that were raised by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Law Council of Australia in their submis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion to the Senate Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Community Affairs. Their argument is that

Speaker: NA
Text: this clause leaves the determination of which

Speaker: NA
Text: documents are relevant and which docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments should be given to the court in the

Speaker: NA
Text: hands of the Social Security Administration

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal. The Law Council believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: court should be entitled to review all docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to determine which are relevant in a

Speaker: NA
Text: decision on a matter before it.

Speaker: NA
Text: No legislation, however, can remove the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of those who act in bad faith. As leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islators our powers are limited in this regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: In reflecting on the remarks of my colleagues

Speaker: NA
Text: during the debate on the original bill, I was

Speaker: NA
Text: struck by the note of caution in their words.

Speaker: NA
Text: We might have an acceptable formula to es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tablish the costs of raising a child; however,

Speaker: NA
Text: no formula can determine the cost of the

Speaker: NA
Text: grief and the sense of injustice that many-

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, most-parents suffer while undergo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this process. With the best will in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world we cannot legislate that away, unfor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunately.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am reminded of a man who visited my

Speaker: NA
Text: office many years ago to discuss how unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: it was that he be expected to pay child sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port for his child. He was working in a rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonably well-paid job at the time. He an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced to me that he intended changing

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs and deliberately taking a lower paying

Speaker: NA
Text: job so that his child support payments would

Speaker: NA
Text: be reduced. Sadly, I believe that is not an

Speaker: NA
Text: uncommon practice amongst some members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the community. It is a wrong practice, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it is out there. There is no way that we as a

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament can legislate around bad faith. We

Speaker: NA
Text: can, however, ensure that the system in place

Speaker: NA
Text: is the most equitable it can be. As members

Speaker: NA
Text: of parliament there are ways we can work

Speaker: NA
Text: through issues which seem impossible. We

Speaker: NA
Text: can make a difference and we can offer the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for members of the community

Speaker: NA
Text: to articulate their concerns. We can work

Speaker: NA
Text: with the community and try to understand

Speaker: NA
Text: their concerns, even if we ourselves have not

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced similar circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: Constituents often ask what we do while

Speaker: NA
Text: we are in Canberra apart from debating legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation before the parliament. One of the most

Speaker: NA
Text: critical functions of a member of parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: is his or her participation in the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: process. This is a little understood yet vital

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the parliamentarian's day-to-day

Speaker: NA
Text: work. It is through the committee process

Speaker: NA
Text: that vital issues are identified and examined

Speaker: NA
Text: and the public are able to give input directly

Speaker: NA
Text: into the parliamentary process. Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the public are able to provide written sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: missions and may then be invited to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: directly to committee members. This is true

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy in action. It is fundamental to the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary process and to how we deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with important community issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason I raise this matter is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: heart of the bill we are dealing with today

Speaker: NA
Text: lies in a committee report. That report, Every

Speaker: NA
Text: picture tells a story: report on the inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: into child custody arrangements in the event

Speaker: NA
Text: of family separation, was produced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives Standing Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee on Family and Community Affairs. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: published in 2003 and made a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations about child custody and

Speaker: NA
Text: child support. The fundamental premise of

Speaker: NA
Text: that report, as stated in the terms of refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence, was:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) given that the best interests of the child are

Speaker: NA
Text: the paramount consideration ...

Speaker: NA
Text: This report involved thousands of hours of

Speaker: NA
Text: work and took as its operating premise that

Speaker: NA
Text: the best interests of the child are the para-

Speaker: NA
Text: mount consideration. This is how parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tarians can deal with incredibly difficult and

Speaker: NA
Text: emotive issues, this is how we work with and

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of the community and this is how

Speaker: NA
Text: we consider and work through those matters

Speaker: NA
Text: which are not black and white and involve

Speaker: NA
Text: many shades of grey. In her foreword to the

Speaker: NA
Text: report, the chair, the member for Riverina,

Speaker: NA
Text: said :

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the highlights of committee work for

Speaker: NA
Text: liamentarians is the people we meet. During this

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry our greatest delight was hearing from

Speaker: NA
Text: nine children and five young adults at our final

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting of the inquiry. These children and young

Speaker: NA
Text: adults were a microcosm of what this inquiry was

Speaker: NA
Text: all about.

Speaker: NA
Text: That report involved six months of work by

Speaker: NA
Text: not only the committee members but also the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee staff. Over 2,000 people contrib-

Speaker: NA
Text: uted to the inquiry through submissions, pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting evidence at hearings and participat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in committee visits to various family and

Speaker: NA
Text: mediation centres.

Speaker: NA
Text: This process is a core role of the parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I do know that the members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Family and Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity Affairs were dedicated and commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ted to an outcome that would ensure the

Speaker: NA
Text: rights of the children were the overriding

Speaker: NA
Text: factor in their considerations. The ultimate

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome of this report was a series of rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendations that formed the basis for the

Speaker: NA
Text: act that this bill is amending. As always, not

Speaker: NA
Text: everyone can be entirely satisfied with the

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes, but no-one can be in any doubt as

Speaker: NA
Text: to the effort put into trying to ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome was the best for the children in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved. Most importantly, the result was bi-

Speaker: NA
Text: partisan. The committee chair noted in her

Speaker: NA
Text: foreword that initially there had been diver-

Speaker: NA
Text: gent views. She concluded:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... I have never felt so proud of a group of

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of parliament who put political differences

Speaker: NA
Text: aside and worked together to ensure a united

Speaker: NA
Text: come.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a current member of several committees

Speaker: NA
Text: and a participant in the presentation of many

Speaker: NA
Text: reports to the parliament, it seems to me that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is an achievement we may all be proud

Speaker: NA
Text: of. It is the bipartisan approach to resolving

Speaker: NA
Text: important public matters that makes the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee process so valuable. I am a great

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate of the committee process and I am

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned that the significance and impact of

Speaker: NA
Text: par- that process is being watered down. I note

Speaker: NA
Text: with some disquiet that this bill was referred

Speaker: NA
Text: the to the Senate Standing Committee on Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity Affairs on 29 March 2007 with a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: porting date of 8 May 2007. There was only

Speaker: NA
Text: one day of public hearings actually sched-

Speaker: NA
Text: uled. Given that we are debating the bill to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day, it gives literally no time at all for those

Speaker: NA
Text: of us with an interest to consider the commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee's report.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have served on a number of committees

Speaker: NA
Text: in the 17 years I have been in this place. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe in the committee process and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: executive should pay respect to the parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Our committees should be functioning

Speaker: NA
Text: properly. The member for Chifley noted in a

Speaker: NA
Text: speech in this House on the tabling of a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port from the Standing Committee on Proce-

Speaker: NA
Text: dure on 12 December 2005:

Speaker: NA
Text: If we want to continue to exist as an institu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, if we want the parliament and parliamentari-

Speaker: NA
Text: ans to be held in higher esteem by the public, one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the key ways we will succeed is through hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a very vibrant and strong committee system.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that is true. I think it is also true that

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the reasons we succeed and do as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as we have is that we also have a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: dedicated and professional public servants

Speaker: NA
Text: who advise the government and the execu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive of the day. Indeed, in the six years we

Speaker: NA
Text: were in government in the time that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been here in parliament I was always im-

Speaker: NA
Text: mempressed with the quality of independent ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice that was provided by the Public Service

Speaker: NA
Text: outto each of the ministers that I had to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with. I have no doubt that that has not

Speaker: NA
Text: changed over the years and that that profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sional advice is still there in the public

Speaker: NA
Text: tor. We as a parliament need to recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: that. We need to nurture it and we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage that independent debate because,

Speaker: NA
Text: quite frankly, if the politicians were half as

Speaker: NA
Text: good as the public servants and the public

Speaker: NA
Text: servants who serve on the committees then

Speaker: NA
Text: we would be a lot better off. The problem

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have had in the past at times is that

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the politicians tend to think that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are a little bit better than they are and every-

Speaker: NA
Text: one else has got to clean up the damage that

Speaker: NA
Text: they do-they do not intentionally do it-

Speaker: NA
Text: with the egos that they have. I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: amending bill before the House to the par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament. I also commend the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: moved by the shadow minister for families

Speaker: NA
Text: and community services, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Jagajaga, to the House.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Parliamentary Sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: retary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs)

Speaker: NA
Text: (12.50 pm)-I rise on behalf of the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Families, Community Services and In-

Speaker: NA
Text: digenous Affairs to speak on the Families,

Speaker: NA
Text: Community Services and Indigenous Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Child Support Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form Consolidation and Other Measures) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007. The purpose of this follow-up bill is to

Speaker: NA
Text: complete consequential amendments and

Speaker: NA
Text: make minor refinements needed for the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plementation of the new child support for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mula on 1 July 2008. The bill consolidates

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's substantial 2006 legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: that restructured the Child Support Scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: in line with the recommendations of the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: isterial task force on child support chaired by

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Patrick Parkinson.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill makes a variety of other amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to Families, Community Services and

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Affairs portfolio legislation. This

Speaker: NA
Text: bill makes refinements to the major 2006

Speaker: NA
Text: child support legislation. A more fair treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of child support will be made where

Speaker: NA
Text: there are children of different ages in differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent households. Child support agreements

Speaker: NA
Text: sec- between parents are being better supported

Speaker: NA
Text: and strengthened and their interaction with

Speaker: NA
Text: family tax benefit clarified. Remote area al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance under the social security and vet-

Speaker: NA
Text: eran's entitlement legislation is being ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended, so parents with regular care of a

Speaker: NA
Text: child-that is, care of between 14 and 35 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent-will continue to receive the allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: after the 1 July 2008 changes to family tax

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the processes relating to the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view of child support decisions by the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Appeals Tribunal are being clarified

Speaker: NA
Text: and the changed arrangements with the

Speaker: NA
Text: courts refined. The bill relocates some provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions from the Child Support Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill 2004. While that bill has

Speaker: NA
Text: been overtaken by the reform of the Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Scheme, some measures are still

Speaker: NA
Text: required. The provisions move measures

Speaker: NA
Text: from the regulations into the primary child

Speaker: NA
Text: support legislation, allowing Australia to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet its international child support obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. Some refinements are also being made

Speaker: NA
Text: to the provisions after years of experience of

Speaker: NA
Text: their operation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 2004 bill measures include several

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to improve equity between the

Speaker: NA
Text: two parties to a child support case in access-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the court for review of any decision

Speaker: NA
Text: about whether one of the parties is a parent

Speaker: NA
Text: of the child in question. Some minor stream-

Speaker: NA
Text: lining refinements are also being made to the

Speaker: NA
Text: internal review system for child support de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cisions generally.

Speaker: NA
Text: The last of the 2004 bill measures are of a

Speaker: NA
Text: minor policy or technical nature and are gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erally to address anomalies in the current

Speaker: NA
Text: system or to improve aspects of child support

Speaker: NA
Text: administration-for example, amendments to

Speaker: NA
Text: broaden the ways in which an application for

Speaker: NA
Text: an extension of time to lodge an internal re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view application, known as an ‘objection',

Speaker: NA
Text: can be made. The new bill also includes sev-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral family assistance amendments-for ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample, the maintenance income test provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions for family tax benefit are being refined.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is partly to reflect the new treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: under the child support reforms for child

Speaker: NA
Text: support agreements and lump sum child sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port.

Speaker: NA
Text: Refinements are also being made to cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain elements of the formula used to work

Speaker: NA
Text: out the notional amount of maintenance in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come an individual is taken to have received

Speaker: NA
Text: under a child support agreement or court

Speaker: NA
Text: order where there is an underpayment of

Speaker: NA
Text: child support registered for collection by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Child Support Agency. It is also being clari-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied that maintenance income received by a

Speaker: NA
Text: payee for one or more children would reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the payee's amount of family tax benefit part

Speaker: NA
Text: A above the base rate for those children only.

Speaker: NA
Text: Separate amendments to the baby bonus

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions will formally rename the payment

Speaker: NA
Text: the ‘baby bonus', rather than the ‘maternity

Speaker: NA
Text: payment', in line with most people's under-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing. Under-18-year-old claimants will

Speaker: NA
Text: be paid the baby bonus in 13 instalments,

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than in a lump sum, and registration of

Speaker: NA
Text: birth as a condition of eligibility for the

Speaker: NA
Text: bonus will be introduced. Under this bill, the

Speaker: NA
Text: usual 13-week period for full payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: family tax benefit while temporarily outside

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia will be extended for members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Defence Force and certain

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Federal Police personnel in the

Speaker: NA
Text: International Deployment Group who are

Speaker: NA
Text: deployed overseas as part of their duties and,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result, remain overseas for longer than

Speaker: NA
Text: 13 weeks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cyclone Larry has shown that a year may

Speaker: NA
Text: not be long enough where the rebuilding ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: forts of a disaster-affected community are

Speaker: NA
Text: stretched. The bill will extend the current 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months principal home temporary absence

Speaker: NA
Text: rules for absences of up to 24 months for

Speaker: NA
Text: people who have suffered loss or damage to

Speaker: NA
Text: their homes due to a disaster. The bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: also assist people who cannot purchase or

Speaker: NA
Text: build a new home within 12 months due to

Speaker: NA
Text: factors beyond their control by extending the

Speaker: NA
Text: asset test exemption of principal home sale

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeds from 12 months up to 24 months.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another measure ensures the claim rules for

Speaker: NA
Text: the new Australian government disaster re-

Speaker: NA
Text: covery payment work correctly for non-

Speaker: NA
Text: resident Australian citizens. Lastly, the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will make minor refinements to the operation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the income streams provisions of the so-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial security and veterans' means tests.

Speaker: NA
Text: On behalf of the minister, I thank all of

Speaker: NA
Text: those officials and community members in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in the consultation for and prepara-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of this bill. I also thank the speakers on

Speaker: NA
Text: both sides of the House. I am delighted to

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the Families, Community Services

Speaker: NA
Text: and Indigenous Affairs Legislation Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment (Child Support Reform Consolidation

Speaker: NA
Text: and Other Measures) Bill 2007 to the House.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Hat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton)-The original question was that this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: be now read a second time. To this the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Jagajaga has moved as

Speaker: NA
Text: baby an amendment that all words after ‘That' be

Speaker: NA
Text: omitted with a view to substituting other

Speaker: NA
Text: words. The question now is that the words

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed to be omitted stand part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: question.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Original question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Message from the Governor-General rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommending appropriation announced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Parliamentary Sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: retary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs)

Speaker: NA
Text: (12.58 pm)-by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE

Speaker: NA
Text: PARK AMENDMENT BILL 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 28 March, on mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by Mr Turnbull:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr GARRETT
Text: Kingsford Smith) (12.59

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-The Great Barrier Reef is Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest natural asset, an economic power-

Speaker: NA
Text: house and an extraordinary ambassador for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The reef draws people to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and it draws Australians to Northern Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland. It captures the imagination like no

Speaker: NA
Text: other Australian icon. It is a place that offers

Speaker: NA
Text: serenity and stability, beauty and pleasure. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is, as the Great Barrier Reef Foundation have

Speaker: NA
Text: noted, ‘The largest, most pristine continuous

Speaker: NA
Text: coral reef archipelago on earth', a natural

Speaker: NA
Text: icon that links to our national identity. We in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia are so fortunate to be able to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that we come from the home of the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef. But the truth is that our greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: natural asset is crook-really crook. I often

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder whether the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: cares at all about the fate of the reef. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2007 is remarkable for what it does not

Speaker: NA
Text: do. It does not offer a plan to maintain a

Speaker: NA
Text: healthy reef into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill before the House seeks to imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment recommendations of a 2006 review of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1975. I want to pick up on the key aspects of

Speaker: NA
Text: that review and this bill. But, before I do, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is important to set the scene. The Great Bar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rier Reef is an extraordinary natural wonder.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the world's largest World Heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: area-2,000 kilometres of World Heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder. It is the world's most extensive coral

Speaker: NA
Text: reef system. It has the world's richest diver-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity of faunal species. There are some 2,800

Speaker: NA
Text: individual reefs, 1,500 fish species, 175 bird

Speaker: NA
Text: species, some 4,000 species of mollusc-an

Speaker: NA
Text: incredible figure-1,500 species of sponge,

Speaker: NA
Text: 500 species of seaweed and more than 30

Speaker: NA
Text: species of marine mammals.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Text: That's a lot of diversity.

Speaker: Mr GARRETT
Text: There is an extraordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nary range of marine biodiversity and spe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies diversity on the reef. There are 940 is-

Speaker: NA
Text: lands. The GBR is the jewel in the crown.

Speaker: NA
Text: The northern part of the reef is believed to be

Speaker: NA
Text: 18 million years old and the southern part is

Speaker: NA
Text: believed to be two million years old. These

Speaker: NA
Text: are staggering statistics. The reef is a place

Speaker: NA
Text: of staggering beauty. This is our inheritance

Speaker: NA
Text: and we have a responsibility to protect it for

Speaker: NA
Text: future generations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, we do not just have a responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility to maintain the ecological integrity of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Great Barrier Reef; we also have a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility to maintain the jobs and the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional towns that are dependent on a healthy

Speaker: NA
Text: reef. Around 200,000 jobs are directly de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent on a healthy Great Barrier Reef, a

Speaker: NA
Text: reef that generates about $4.3 billion for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy. That is a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment that the Great Barrier Reef

Speaker: NA
Text: makes, not only in terms of its environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: heritage and richness but also in terms of its

Speaker: NA
Text: economic productivity.

Speaker: NA
Text: But there are real threats to the future of

Speaker: NA
Text: the reef. The science is very clear. The unre-

Speaker: NA
Text: leased Australian chapter of the United Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions Intergovernmental Panel on Climate

Speaker: NA
Text: Change report Climate change 2007: climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change impacts, adaptation and vulnerability

Speaker: NA
Text: lays out a bleak future for the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef. It says that, by 2020, 60 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef could be regularly

Speaker: NA
Text: bleached; by 2050, 97 per cent of the reef

Speaker: NA
Text: could be bleached each year; and by 2080

Speaker: NA
Text: there could be ‘catastrophic mortality of

Speaker: NA
Text: coral species annually' and a 95 per cent de-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in distribution of Great Barrier Reef

Speaker: NA
Text: species. There could be a loss of 65 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of Great Barrier Reef species in the Cairns

Speaker: NA
Text: region alone.

Speaker: NA
Text: An international team of scientists work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on the Great Barrier Reef has found a

Speaker: NA
Text: clear link between coral disease and warmer

Speaker: NA
Text: ocean temperatures. World-first research at

Speaker: NA
Text: 48 reefs spread along 1,500 kilometres of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef, combined with six years

Speaker: NA
Text: of satellite data on sea temperatures, has re-

Speaker: NA
Text: vealed ‘a highly significant relationship' be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween ocean warming and the emergence of

Speaker: NA
Text: a disease known as white syndrome. And of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, ocean warming is a consequence of

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change. White syndrome is one of a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of unexplained coral diseases which

Speaker: NA
Text: scientists have observed to be on the increase

Speaker: NA
Text: globally in recent years. This is enough to

Speaker: NA
Text: make you weep. The Great Barrier Reef is

Speaker: NA
Text: dying before our very eyes and, frankly, it

Speaker: NA
Text: does not seem as if the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: gives a damn.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government cannot say it was not

Speaker: NA
Text: warned. It has received report after report for

Speaker: NA
Text: almost a decade about climate change and its

Speaker: NA
Text: likely impacts-similar warnings, growing in

Speaker: NA
Text: strength with each report. The truth is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's in-tray is littered with re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports warning of the threat of climate change

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Great Barrier Reef but his out-tray is

Speaker: NA
Text: filled with cobwebs. Look at the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's own March 2005 Climate change risk

Speaker: NA
Text: and vulnerability report. That report identi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fies the reef as one of ‘a handful of highly

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable regions [that] can be identified

Speaker: NA
Text: that should be given priority for further adap-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation planning and response'. The report

Speaker: NA
Text: goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Cairns and the Great Barrier Reef are expected

Speaker: NA
Text: to see multiple dimensions of change. The Reef

Speaker: NA
Text: itself is likely to suffer from coral bleaching

Speaker: NA
Text: events, which have long recovery times and flow

Speaker: NA
Text: on effects for the whole ecosystem. Climate

Speaker: NA
Text: model projections suggest that within 40 years

Speaker: NA
Text: water temperatures could be above the survival

Speaker: NA
Text: limit of corals.

Speaker: NA
Text: And 40 years is within the lifetimes of many

Speaker: NA
Text: people in our country. You have to ask: what

Speaker: NA
Text: action has the Howard government under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taken in response to this stark warning? This

Speaker: NA
Text: is not just an environmental question. A 2005

Speaker: NA
Text: Access Economics study found that tourism

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with the Great Barrier Reef gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erated over $4.48 billion in the 12-month

Speaker: NA
Text: period 2004-05 and provided employment

Speaker: NA
Text: for about 63,000 people. The marine tourism

Speaker: NA
Text: industry is a major contributor to the local

Speaker: NA
Text: and Australian economy. These employment

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics are significant, and the contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: that the reef makes to local, regional and

Speaker: NA
Text: national economies is substantial. In 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: there are approximately 820 operators and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,500 vessels and aircraft permitted to oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tourism attracts approximately 1.9 million

Speaker: NA
Text: visitors each year. That is an extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people who come to enjoy the

Speaker: NA
Text: beauty, amenity and qualities that the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef' has to offer. The reef is simply

Speaker: NA
Text: the lifeblood of regional and local econo-

Speaker: NA
Text: mies. That is why the Howard government's

Speaker: NA
Text: line-a calculated line-that Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: have to choose between a healthy economy

Speaker: NA
Text: and a healthy environment is so wrong. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef's extraordinary environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental values and its profound contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: to our national economy go hand in hand and

Speaker: NA
Text: provide the clearest rebuttal that Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: could ever seek of the false choices that are

Speaker: NA
Text: put forward by the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: when the Prime Minister and others put the

Speaker: NA
Text: line that we have to maintain protection of

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs at the expense of looking after the envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronment. Nothing could be further from the

Speaker: NA
Text: truth.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Great Barrier Reef brings billions of

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars into the Australian economy and is

Speaker: NA
Text: directly responsible for the employment of

Speaker: NA
Text: tens of thousands of Australians. So the

Speaker: NA
Text: question is this: how much new money do

Speaker: NA
Text: you reckon the government allocated in last

Speaker: NA
Text: night's budget to deliver a healthy reef? The

Speaker: NA
Text: answer is that at last night's budget, the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, $30 million over four years-some

Speaker: NA
Text: $7 million or so a year-was allocated to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef in new funding. That,

Speaker: NA
Text: frankly, is pitiful. The government has an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced $15.9 million over four years for

Speaker: NA
Text: field management. Labor would like to see

Speaker: NA
Text: the details of the field management, but that

Speaker: NA
Text: is something which we broadly support. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government has also announced $14.2 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion for the continuation of the water quality

Speaker: NA
Text: monitoring program and that that money will

Speaker: NA
Text: come from the Natural Heritage Trust. So we

Speaker: NA
Text: will wait to see whether that is new money,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it is a program that we would welcome.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are small initiatives by any reckon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, made by a government that does not

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the huge climate change chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenges facing Australia. A forward looking

Speaker: NA
Text: government would have used a federal

Speaker: NA
Text: budget to develop and implement an action

Speaker: NA
Text: plan to help protect the Great Barrier Reef

Speaker: NA
Text: from the effects of coral bleaching and to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect Australian jobs and industries de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent on a healthy reef. A forward looking

Speaker: NA
Text: government would have used a federal

Speaker: NA
Text: budget to implement a national climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change strategy that would include ratifying

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kyoto protocol, cutting Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: greenhouse pollution by 60 per cent by 2050,

Speaker: NA
Text: establishing a national emissions trading

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme and seriously investing in renewable

Speaker: NA
Text: energy and clean coal.

Speaker: NA
Text: A forward looking government would

Speaker: NA
Text: have announced serious long-term measures

Speaker: NA
Text: to cut Australia's soaring greenhouse pollu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. But that is not what we got in last

Speaker: NA
Text: night's federal budget. Climate change is a

Speaker: NA
Text: massive challenge for Australia but the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government is simply trying to slay

Speaker: NA
Text: the dragon with a feather. The federal budget

Speaker: NA
Text: will not stop Australia's greenhouse gas pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lution from soaring by 27 per cent by 2020.

Speaker: NA
Text: The federal budget will not build a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian clean energy industry. The federal

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007 budget will not create new Australian clean

Speaker: NA
Text: coal jobs. The federal budget failed the cli-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate change test. That is what happened last

Speaker: NA
Text: night when the Treasurer brought down his

Speaker: NA
Text: budget: the government failed the climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change test.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other thing a forward looking gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment would do is to cherish Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: past-to recognise that our natural and cul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural heritage is the cornerstone of our mod-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern society. That is why I find it staggering

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government still has not placed the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef on Australia's Natural

Speaker: NA
Text: Heritage List. A Natural Heritage List with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out the Great Barrier Reef is like a cricket

Speaker: NA
Text: hall of fame without Sir Donald Bradman-

Speaker: NA
Text: but that is precisely what we have. The Natu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ral Heritage List came into force in January

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004; it is now 2007. It beggars belief that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government has not got around to putting

Speaker: NA
Text: the reef on the Natural Heritage List. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to ask ourselves whether it is incom-

Speaker: NA
Text: petence, tardiness or forgetfulness, or

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Howard government is just tak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Great Barrier Reef for granted. Is it

Speaker: NA
Text: taking the people who depend on a healthy

Speaker: NA
Text: reef for granted, as well? The government

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to have given up on the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef, our greatest national natural treasure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Previously the government took a very

Speaker: NA
Text: courageous step when it announced it was

Speaker: NA
Text: protecting 33 per cent of the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef from fishing and other extractive indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries. I want to take this opportunity in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House to pay tribute to the then environment

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, David Kemp, who will always be

Speaker: NA
Text: remembered for that initiative-one which

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor supported. But what has the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment done since then? It announced a struc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural adjustment package for the fishing in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry. Initially, the structural adjustment

Speaker: NA
Text: package was worth $31 million. Now it has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased threefold, flowing out to more than

Speaker: NA
Text: $87 million-an extraordinary miscalcula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Fishermen and land based businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: that rely on reef derived income are entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: to compensation for economic loss caused

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Representative Areas Program,

Speaker: NA
Text: which increased the reef green zones. They

Speaker: NA
Text: deserve compensation; they do not deserve

Speaker: NA
Text: the mess that is the compensation package.

Speaker: NA
Text: The National Party and some of the more

Speaker: NA
Text: conservative elements of the Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: have worked hard in the past to destroy Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Kemp's legacy. Strong campaigns have been

Speaker: NA
Text: launched against the Great Barrier Reef Ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: rine Park Authority and the zoning plan. On

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 March 2005, the then National Party sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor-elect Barnaby Joyce was quoted in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Courier Mail as opposing the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park Authority's existence as an

Speaker: NA
Text: independent agency. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: GBRMPA is out of control ...We are having too

Speaker: NA
Text: many problems and we should bring it totally

Speaker: NA
Text: under government control and baby-sit it for a

Speaker: NA
Text: while.

Speaker: NA
Text: On 26 October 2004, the member for Daw-

Speaker: NA
Text: son said:

Speaker: NA
Text: What we've had is a statutory body in GBRMPA

Speaker: NA
Text: that is out of control that has put, I think,

Speaker: NA
Text: scientific basis for the arguments they've put for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward.

Speaker: NA
Text: It must never be forgotten that the Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland Nationals did a preference deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Fishing Party at the last election on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis that GBRMPA's powers be moved into

Speaker: NA
Text: the department where the minister would

Speaker: NA
Text: have control of all decisions. This helped get

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Joyce elected.

Speaker: NA
Text: The National Party always saw the review

Speaker: NA
Text: of GBRMPA as the vehicle for destroying

Speaker: NA
Text: GBRMPA and rolling back the protection of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Great Barrier Reef. On 25 March 2006,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Courier Mail reported that the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government was planning to reduce the ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: rine protection boundaries of the Representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive Areas Program and to abolish the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority as an

Speaker: NA
Text: independent agency. I am pleased to say nei-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther of those two things happened. I am also

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that GBRMPA remains a statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: authority. I want to pay tribute to the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Grayndler, who was my predecessor as

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow minister for the environment, to

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Jan MCLucas and to Labor's candi-

Speaker: NA
Text: date for Leichhardt, Jim Turnour, for their

Speaker: NA
Text: hard yakka and dedication to the protection

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Great Barrier Reef.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor prevented the destruction of

Speaker: NA
Text: GBRMPA, but there are still aspects of this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill that are concerning. The bill replaces the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef Consultative Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: with a non-statutory advisory board and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: moves the requirement for specific represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation from the Queensland government or

Speaker: NA
Text: the interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait

Speaker: NA
Text: Islanders. Labor is concerned that the part-

Speaker: NA
Text: nership with the Queensland government,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been such a hallmark of the work

Speaker: NA
Text: of GBRMPA, has in effect been shredded.

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition is also concerned that there

Speaker: NA
Text: may not be the opportunity for proper repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentation from Indigenous communities,

Speaker: NA
Text: no real which ought to be a feature of the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: new arrangements. Labor is also concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: that other interests, including the tourism

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, may not be adequately represented

Speaker: NA
Text: on GBRMPA or the advisory board. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter the government ought to give full

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration to. I call on the environment

Speaker: NA
Text: minister to make a commitment to a genuine

Speaker: NA
Text: partnership with the Queensland govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, to a genuine engagement with Abo-

Speaker: NA
Text: riginal and Torres Strait Islander communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties and to a real and genuine engagement

Speaker: NA
Text: with all the industries that are dependent on a

Speaker: NA
Text: healthy reef. A place must be found for eve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ryone at the table.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased-and Labor welcomes-that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government is establishing a five-yearly

Speaker: NA
Text: outlook report for the Great Barrier Reef.

Speaker: NA
Text: The environment minister has stated that a

Speaker: NA
Text: regular and reliable means of assessing the

Speaker: NA
Text: protection of the Great Barrier Reef will be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided through a formal outlook report

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be tabled in parliament every five

Speaker: NA
Text: years and that this report will cover the

Speaker: NA
Text: agement of the marine park, the overall con-

Speaker: NA
Text: dition of the ecosystem and the longer term

Speaker: NA
Text: outlook for the Great Barrier Reef. This re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port clearly is an important measure and it

Speaker: NA
Text: has Labor's support. This report will be peer

Speaker: NA
Text: reviewed by an appropriately qualified panel

Speaker: NA
Text: of experts appointed by the minister. Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: welcomes those measures but seeks confir-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation from the minister that the peer report

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a public document, as this is not prodrilling

Speaker: NA
Text: vided for in the bill before us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor notes that the minister will be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible for any future decision to amend

Speaker: NA
Text: the zoning plan and that any such decision

Speaker: NA
Text: will be based on the outlook report and ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice from the authority. Labor also notes the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister's commitment that engagement with

Speaker: NA
Text: stakeholders on the development of a new

Speaker: NA
Text: zoning plan will be improved and the process

Speaker: NA
Text: made more transparent-that is clearly nec-

Speaker: NA
Text: essary-with comprehensive information

Speaker: NA
Text: being made publicly available throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: process that will include the rationale for

Speaker: NA
Text: amending the zoning plan, the principles on

Speaker: NA
Text: which the development of the zoning plan

Speaker: NA
Text: will be based, socioeconomic information,

Speaker: NA
Text: and a report on the final zoning plan and its

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes. In addition, each of the two public

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation periods will be increased from

Speaker: NA
Text: one month to three months. We welcome the

Speaker: NA
Text: extension of the public consultation period.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important there is integrity in the

Speaker: NA
Text: process, and it is important there are ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments to better protecting the health

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Great Barrier Reef. That is why I call

Speaker: NA
Text: on the government to join Labor in opposing

Speaker: NA
Text: oil drilling and exploration near the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef. I foreshadow now that I will

Speaker: NA
Text: move consideration-in-detail amendments to

Speaker: NA
Text: extend the boundary of the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park region to the Exclusive

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic Zone, and I call on the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to support those amendments.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am deeply concerned that the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: manment's agenda is to proceed with the oil ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ploration and drilling near the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef. Just last year, Geoscience Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: published a map which indicated the poten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial for exploration and drilling in this region.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1975, any oil drilling or prospecting in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Great Barrier Reef region is prohibited.

Speaker: NA
Text: My consideration in detail stage amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: will seek to extend the region so that oil

Speaker: NA
Text: and prospecting in the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef region, the region east of the boundary

Speaker: NA
Text: of the current marine park to the Exclusive

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic Zone, will be prohibited.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst it is the case that the governance

Speaker: NA
Text: and associated measures contained in this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill are supported by the opposition, it re-

Speaker: NA
Text: mains a fact that the government's abysmal

Speaker: NA
Text: record in seriously addressing climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change is a significant impediment to ensur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing protection of the great natural treasure

Speaker: NA
Text: that is the Great Barrier Reef into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hereby move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That all words after “That” be omitted with a

Speaker: NA
Text: view to substituting the following words: “whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: not declining to give the bill a second reading, the

Speaker: NA
Text: House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) affirms the object of the Principal Act - the

Speaker: NA
Text: protection of the Great Barrier Reef - but

Speaker: NA
Text: notes that the future of the reef is threatened

Speaker: NA
Text: by both short term and longer term factors,

Speaker: NA
Text: including climate change;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) notes that the United Nations Intergovern-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental Panel on Climate Change stated in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007 that by 2050, 97% of the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef could be bleached every year as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of climate change;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) condemns the Government's incompetent

Speaker: NA
Text: handling of the structural adjustment pack-

Speaker: NA
Text: age for the Great Barrier Reef Representative

Speaker: NA
Text: Areas Plan, which has seen the budget blow

Speaker: NA
Text: out from $31 million to more than

Speaker: NA
Text: $87 million;

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) calls on the Government to develop and im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plement an action plan to help protect the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef from the effects of coral

Speaker: NA
Text: bleaching and protect Australian jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries dependent on a healthy reef as part

Speaker: NA
Text: of a national climate change strategy; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) calls on the Government to prohibit mineral,

Speaker: NA
Text: oil and gas exploration in Australian waters

Speaker: NA
Text: adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef Marine

Speaker: NA
Text: Park”.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Hat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton)-Is the amendment seconded?

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Text: I second the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr ENTSCH
Text: Leichhardt) (1.21 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: sat here with an element of disbelief as I

Speaker: NA
Text: heard the member for Kingsford Smith put-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting forth his vision for the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef. I could not help but think that a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: the problems, misconceptions, scare tactics

Speaker: NA
Text: and emotional claptrap that continues to be

Speaker: NA
Text: driven about this comes from his background

Speaker: NA
Text: in the cradle of the extreme greens. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no science in these arguments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Garrett interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Hat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton)-Member for Kingsford Smith, you had

Speaker: NA
Text: your go.

Speaker: Mr ENTSCH
Text: He stands up in his place

Speaker: NA
Text: and talks about a whole range of issues here.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the figures that I picked up here,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is basically one of the lies that was

Speaker: NA
Text: projected through the whole of the represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tative areas debate, is that 33 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef is now being protected. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is not 33 per cent of the Great Barrier Reef

Speaker: NA
Text: that is currently protected; it is 33 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, which

Speaker: NA
Text: goes way outside the Great Barrier Reef. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, over 70 per cent of the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef is protected.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is where the issues started to come

Speaker: NA
Text: in. You have those like the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker-coming from the ‘extreme green'

Speaker: NA
Text: angle-who believe that people have no

Speaker: NA
Text: place in the environment. They believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the only way you can manage these places is

Speaker: NA
Text: and inby shutting them down completely and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: moving people out of them-they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know what the word ‘sustainability' means-

Speaker: NA
Text: and, in doing so, destroying people's liveli-

Speaker: NA
Text: hoods unnecessarily. That is what happened

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the management of the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef Marine Park.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am certainly pleased to have the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to speak here on the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill 2007,

Speaker: NA
Text: because these are very important amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. They emanate from a review of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was completed last year. The review

Speaker: NA
Text: and its report delivered on a promise made

Speaker: NA
Text: by this government in 2004 after the travesty

Speaker: NA
Text: known as the Representative Areas Program.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation has been born out of a need

Speaker: NA
Text: and a desire of all government members to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that this type of event does not ever

Speaker: NA
Text: happen again. We cannot turn back the clock;

Speaker: NA
Text: we must learn from the experience, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be repeating the sins of the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: When these amendments come into force

Speaker: NA
Text: on 1 July this year, they will ensure the au-

Speaker: NA
Text: thority of future management decisions will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be exclusively within the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park Authority but that the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pacts will be considered back here. The

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments will provide a seven-year mora-

Speaker: NA
Text: torium for the future adjustments to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: stability-and this is absolutely necessary-

Speaker: NA
Text: and certainty for businesses and communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties, which have suffered so unnecessarily in

Speaker: NA
Text: the years since the current zoning plan was

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed. They will also provide a regular

Speaker: NA
Text: and reliable means of accountability, assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the protection of the marine park through

Speaker: NA
Text: a report that will be tabled in the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: every five years, and this will be peer re-

Speaker: NA
Text: viewed by a panel of experts appointed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister. That will ultimately mean that it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be the minister's responsibility for future

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions about opening the zoning plan for

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment. Importantly, the process of en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaging with stakeholders on future

Speaker: NA
Text: changes-and this is the area that was

Speaker: NA
Text: missed out significantly during the last proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ess-will be improved and formalised, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding extending each of the two public

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation periods from one month to three

Speaker: NA
Text: months. These are, in my view, very positive

Speaker: NA
Text: but very necessary changes.

Speaker: NA
Text: If there is a reservation, it is the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately these changes have come a

Speaker: NA
Text: little too late for many of my constituents

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been impacted by these agendas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Anybody who has any doubts about the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tent of the misery and the financial ruination

Speaker: NA
Text: wreaked by those ideological zealots who

Speaker: NA
Text: were in charge of this process through the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority

Speaker: NA
Text: need only speak to people-good, honest,

Speaker: NA
Text: hardworking people-whose businesses and

Speaker: NA
Text: livelihoods have been destroyed, absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: devastated, by this process; unfortunately, in

Speaker: NA
Text: many cases, totally unnecessarily.

Speaker: NA
Text: I first expressed concerns about the rezon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in 2002 when it was first mooted, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: was reassured by the senior executive of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority

Speaker: NA
Text: that the whole process would be based on

Speaker: NA
Text: science. On that basis, I accepted it. I ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cepted that advice in good faith. I spoke to

Speaker: NA
Text: the recreational fishing people, commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing people and tourism industry people.

Speaker: NA
Text: They all agreed that, if science were applied

Speaker: NA
Text: to this and the science said that any activ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity-irrespective of what it was, whether it

Speaker: NA
Text: was swimming on the reef, fishing on the

Speaker: NA
Text: reef or a commercial activity-was deemed

Speaker: NA
Text: to be unsustainable, any such activity had to

Speaker: NA
Text: stop immediately. Every one of them was

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to give up their livelihoods on that

Speaker: NA
Text: basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, that was the first lie. When

Speaker: NA
Text: the first round of plans came out and was

Speaker: NA
Text: presented to the stakeholders, everybody was

Speaker: NA
Text: quite pleasantly surprised. They believed that

Speaker: NA
Text: everything was okay, that it was quite rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonable. Even though the ‘extreme greens'

Speaker: NA
Text: were promoting the idea that only three per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the reef was protected-a bit like the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kingsford Smith's little slip with

Speaker: NA
Text: the words in his contribution-in fact it was

Speaker: NA
Text: three per cent of the marine park. So about

Speaker: NA
Text: that 22 or 23 per cent of the reef was protected at

Speaker: NA
Text: that point in time. We were assured by the

Speaker: NA
Text: authority that they were looking at 25 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the reef. They were looking at biore-

Speaker: NA
Text: gions. At the end of the day, they ended up

Speaker: NA
Text: with over 70 per cent. You can imagine the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact that that has had on users of those

Speaker: NA
Text: reefs.

Speaker: NA
Text: They presented those maps, and the maps

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared to be okay. They seemed to have a

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum impact, as we were assured by the

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucracy. But the interesting thing was

Speaker: NA
Text: that the bureaucracy then invited the reef

Speaker: NA
Text: users, the marine park users, to mark the ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: eas that they could never afford to lose, so

Speaker: NA
Text: that they could be taken into consideration in

Speaker: NA
Text: the final determination. The coordinates of

Speaker: NA
Text: those areas were very specifically marked on

Speaker: NA
Text: the map. When the next draft came out,

Speaker: NA
Text: every single area that had been marked by

Speaker: NA
Text: those reef users as an area they could not

Speaker: NA
Text: afford to lose was marked in either green or

Speaker: NA
Text: yellow, excluding them. And that set the tone

Speaker: NA
Text: for the treatment.

Speaker: NA
Text: We had a coastal trawl industry which had

Speaker: NA
Text: been assessed by the Great Barrier Reef Ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: rine Park Authority and by Environment

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia as the first ecologically sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: coastal trawl fishery in the world-they were

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting on certification-but the changes to

Speaker: NA
Text: those maps, taking those areas out, totally

Speaker: NA
Text: wiped them out. There was clearly an intent

Speaker: NA
Text: within the senior bureaucracy of the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to get rid

Speaker: NA
Text: of reef and marine park users. They did this

Speaker: NA
Text: with the marine collectors, the commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: trawling industry, the line fishermen and the

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational fishing industry. They drove a

Speaker: NA
Text: wedge between each of the user groups, cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ating conflict, and they used that opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to go in and amend the maps accordingly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Make no bones about it, every one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people affected by that was committed to

Speaker: NA
Text: stepping aside-losing their business if nec-

Speaker: NA
Text: essary-if it was deemed to be unsustain-

Speaker: NA
Text: able. But it was no longer an issue. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: driving the same agenda, the same mantra,

Speaker: NA
Text: that was pushed by the member for Kings-

Speaker: NA
Text: ford Smith in his previous interests as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the extreme greens and influ-

Speaker: NA
Text: enced very strongly by some members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: senior bureaucracy within the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park Authority.

Speaker: NA
Text: I said to Minister Kemp that this would

Speaker: NA
Text: have a devastating effect on industry. I sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gested to him that it could have as much as

Speaker: NA
Text: $2 million worth of impact on our industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister said to me: ‘That can't be pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible, because the Great Barrier Reef Marine

Speaker: NA
Text: Park Authority has advised me that the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum impact will be $1.5 million. What

Speaker: NA
Text: are you doing? You are stirring up a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: trouble about nothing.' But he erred on the

Speaker: NA
Text: side of caution and set aside $10 million in

Speaker: NA
Text: the original bill just in case the compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: was a little more-just in case the authority

Speaker: NA
