Text: had miscalculated. We have not paid out $85

Speaker: NA
Text: million, as was suggested by the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingsford Smith. We are moving towards

Speaker: NA
Text: $200 million. There was another claim just

Speaker: NA
Text: the other day. Lyle Squire has a third genera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion small family business which breeds cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: als and collects small marine fish for aquari-

Speaker: NA
Text: ums. They have been doing it for three gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erations and it has been deemed by the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to be

Speaker: NA
Text: totally ecologically sustainable. I was ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vised a couple of days ago that they are look-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing at a compensation package of $3.5 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion to compensate them for their loss-a

Speaker: NA
Text: small family business absolutely devastated.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have lost so many businesses because

Speaker: NA
Text: of this, and so many of them have been lost

Speaker: NA
Text: totally unnecessarily. Mitchell's Marine,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is owned by Wayne and Sally Bayne,

Speaker: NA
Text: is a marine retail outlet which has been suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessfully trading since 1984. The impact of

Speaker: NA
Text: the actions by the Great Barrier Reef Marine

Speaker: NA
Text: Park Authority resulted in their unit number

Speaker: NA
Text: of sales falling by almost 40 per cent in both

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial and recreational markets-they

Speaker: NA
Text: just went into freefall. This has resulted in

Speaker: NA
Text: staff reductions, downsizing of premises and

Speaker: NA
Text: slashing of costs. It means a once-valuable

Speaker: NA
Text: asset that has provided security for the own-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers' family and its future retirement has been

Speaker: NA
Text: unnecessarily and permanently damaged by a

Speaker: NA
Text: government department which is allowed to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide misinformation to government on

Speaker: NA
Text: which to base its decisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another one is Bill Izzard. The day after

Speaker: NA
Text: the rezoning he woke up to find that he had

Speaker: NA
Text: lost nearly 90 per cent of his available

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds. He was collecting a specific prod-

Speaker: NA
Text: uct which they call leader prawns. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: targeting the aquaculture industry. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: very successful and he was very specific in

Speaker: NA
Text: what he was targeting. He needed only a

Speaker: NA
Text: very narrow area from which to take his

Speaker: NA
Text: product. He was one of those who sat down

Speaker: NA
Text: and marked those areas-none of them on

Speaker: NA
Text: the reef. He said: ‘These are the areas I need.

Speaker: NA
Text: Without these areas my business will go

Speaker: NA
Text: broke.' This is where they took 90 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: his business. They wiped him out. It is just a

Speaker: NA
Text: disgrace. As Bill said, it was the straw that

Speaker: NA
Text: broke the camel's back and started the

Speaker: NA
Text: downhill spiral, sending dozens of family

Speaker: NA
Text: fishers like him to the wall. The industry has

Speaker: NA
Text: shrunk, investors have lost confidence and

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry has continued to lose experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: enced skippers and crews.

Speaker: NA
Text: Marlin Charters at Airlie Beach is another

Speaker: NA
Text: one. It has been successfully operating since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1989. Its owner, Ken Bryant, was another

Speaker: NA
Text: victim of the scam. He was told, ‘Tell us

Speaker: NA
Text: which locations are important to you and we

Speaker: NA
Text: will make sure that we leave them alone.' In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, the opposite happened and, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: stroke of a pen, much of the operating

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds were lost. Left with virtually no-

Speaker: NA
Text: where to operate, the business has suffered a

Speaker: NA
Text: 72 per cent drop in income. That has left the

Speaker: NA
Text: business absolutely devastated. I received an

Speaker: NA
Text: email from Ken the other day. He said: ‘I've

Speaker: NA
Text: had my business destroyed by RAP. I'm ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proximately $100,000 in debt and to date

Speaker: NA
Text: have been offered nothing in compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: or assistance. My life has been devastated by

Speaker: NA
Text: RAP, with no assistance or compensation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: need assistance not next week, not tomorrow,

Speaker: NA
Text: but now. I'm contemplating bankruptcy or,

Speaker: NA
Text: sadly, suicide.' That is the sort of impact it

Speaker: NA
Text: has had on the lives of so many people.

Speaker: NA
Text: MCLeod Engineering, a land based busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness, is another example that I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: highlight, because it demonstrates the flow-

Speaker: NA
Text: on effect for many onshore businesses as

Speaker: NA
Text: well. They are an iconic business which has

Speaker: NA
Text: been operating in the Cairns area for over 30

Speaker: NA
Text: years. They provide marine engineering ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices for both recreational and commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: services. The introduction of the rezoning by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Author-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity has seen their business halved. Staff lev-

Speaker: NA
Text: els have been reduced by 40 per cent and the

Speaker: NA
Text: owner is fighting to protect what is left of his

Speaker: NA
Text: once-thriving business. With a bleak future

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead, the owners are now left with no alter-

Speaker: NA
Text: native but to reassess their commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry as they oversee the unnecessary

Speaker: NA
Text: destruction of their life's work. I could go

Speaker: NA
Text: on. There have been dozens of these cases.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have got to say that I was very disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed that I was not listened to back in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2002 when the first tranche of this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: came through. I have to give credit to the

Speaker: NA
Text: then Minister for the Environment and Heri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tage, Senator Campbell, who did listen. He

Speaker: NA
Text: started the process of introducing the bill that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are talking to today and he was able to

Speaker: NA
Text: help us to gain some ground and to at least

Speaker: NA
Text: give some dignity, by trying to help them

Speaker: NA
Text: restructure, to some of those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: have lost so much. I also give credit to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Environment and Water Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources, Mr Turnbull. He and his office have

Speaker: NA
Text: been very helpful in trying to sort out these

Speaker: NA
Text: problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Kingsford Smith made

Speaker: NA
Text: reference to some individuals from the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side of politics that claim to have made some

Speaker: NA
Text: effort up there-but they were never heard of

Speaker: NA
Text: during the whole debate. We talk about Sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor MCLucas and others and about the previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous shadow environment minister-I know

Speaker: NA
Text: his name; it is Mr Albanese, but I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: sure of his seat-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Hat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton)-He is the member for Grayndler.

Speaker: Mr ENTSCH
Text: Yes, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Grayndler. They actually fed a lot of the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: ception that created this problem and made

Speaker: NA
Text: no effort at all to try to do anything to save

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation. He talks about ‘a forward-

Speaker: NA
Text: looking government' that would protect the

Speaker: NA
Text: industries and people depending on a healthy

Speaker: NA
Text: reef. What a load of nonsense! You do not

Speaker: NA
Text: see a forward-looking government on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side, I can assure you of that, when we

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about this. This was not about

Speaker: NA
Text: protecting the reef; this was all about push-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the lock-out views of the extreme greens.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, some sections of the bureauc-

Speaker: NA
Text: racy were captured by it and so many indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: viduals' healthy businesses that were very

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent on a healthy reef were destroyed

Speaker: NA
Text: unnecessarily. As I said at the beginning of

Speaker: NA
Text: my speech, had there been any issue as to

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainability then each and every owner of

Speaker: NA
Text: those businesses would have more than will-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly walked away from the industries in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved and started again, accepting that they

Speaker: NA
Text: could not afford to impact on what was their

Speaker: NA
Text: livelihood.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I am pleased to see these legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments coming through. I hope that by

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing these amendments through we do

Speaker: NA
Text: not allow this type of fiasco to occur again. I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that we can resolve the outstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: problems of so many of those businesses that

Speaker: NA
Text: are struggling to survive. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: has been very generous in dealing with this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue, but unfortunately in some cases mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing assessments has taken far too much time.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I can understand the complexities of

Speaker: NA
Text: some of these businesses, I am sure there

Speaker: NA
Text: was no understanding by their owners at the

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning, given the misinformation that was

Speaker: NA
Text: being provided by the bureaucracy at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time, of the changes. There was no way that

Speaker: NA
Text: they would have been able to appreciate their

Speaker: NA
Text: impact and the damage that was being done.

Speaker: NA
Text: On a final point, I refer to another matter

Speaker: NA
Text: raised by the member for Kingsford Smith. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was a little red herring, which was right up

Speaker: NA
Text: there with all the doom and gloom, about

Speaker: NA
Text: drilling on or around the Great Barrier Reef.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a perpetual chestnut. Every time

Speaker: NA
Text: when they run out of good ideas they slip

Speaker: NA
Text: this one in. The reality is that the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: rier Reef Marine Park is protected in a way

Speaker: NA
Text: that it has never ever been protected before

Speaker: NA
Text: and there is absolutely no risk whatsoever of

Speaker: NA
Text: it being drilled or impacted. There is legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in place that makes sure that will not and

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot happen. But it is all part of their scare

Speaker: NA
Text: tactics. When they have no ideas and they

Speaker: NA
Text: are looking at these ideological agendas that

Speaker: NA
Text: they try to push, they come out and push this

Speaker: NA
Text: nonsense about drilling on the reef, trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: frighten people. Those that know know it is

Speaker: NA
Text: absolute nonsense and there is no basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: fact whatsoever in it.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Text: Batman)

Speaker: NA
Text: (1.41 pm)-While it was a privilege to have

Speaker: NA
Text: been in the House to hear the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Leichhardt, I must say, as he has raised the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of drilling, that I would have thought,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the member for Leichhardt's electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: includes a huge slice of the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef, he would have raised practical prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems, such as the crown-of-thorns starfish,

Speaker: NA
Text: and talked about the need to give the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try up there greater assistance than it is cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently receiving from the government. He

Speaker: NA
Text: should have noted the huge challenge to the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry at this very point in time and not

Speaker: NA
Text: raised some futuristic debate about drilling

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Great Barrier Reef-but then he is not

Speaker: NA
Text: known for practical solutions to readily evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a great pleasure to speak to the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007. It is a very important bill. It is of criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal significance to one of my shadow portfo-

Speaker: NA
Text: lio responsibilities, tourism. We all appreci-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate its importance. To be fair to the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Leichhardt, he too understands the impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance of the tourism industry. It is a $75 bil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion industry that employs over half a million

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. It is a huge driver of jobs, espe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cially for young people, in Australia, espe-

Speaker: NA
Text: Bar- cially in regional communities. We appreci-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate that each year there are over two million

Speaker: NA
Text: visitors to the Great Barrier Reef, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: latest Access Economics report citing marine

Speaker: NA
Text: tourism directly related to the reef as being

Speaker: NA
Text: worth a huge $5.8 billion and employing

Speaker: NA
Text: 63,000 people. So the reef is exceptionally

Speaker: NA
Text: important not just to Queensland but also to

Speaker: NA
Text: our national economy. From Cooktown to

Speaker: NA
Text: Cairns, Townsville, Mackay and Gladstone,

Speaker: NA
Text: marine tourism is a significant export earner

Speaker: NA
Text: underpinning the area's economy and dwarf-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing other industries such as commercial fish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. It is second only to mining.

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition understands how impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant tourism is to the region, and this is why I

Speaker: NA
Text: stand here today to express concern over

Speaker: NA
Text: some aspects of the bill. Unfortunately, this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill essentially seeks to amend the act to

Speaker: NA
Text: plement in some instances key recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of the Uhrig review whose intent might

Speaker: NA
Text: be wrong. There are several key common-

Speaker: NA
Text: sense amendments proposed by the bill, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: there are also some potentially damaging

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects that could undermine the growth po-

Speaker: NA
Text: tential of Australia's tourism industry

Speaker: NA
Text: marine tourism sector in particular.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill makes the Minister for the Envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronment and Water Resources responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: any future decision to amend the zoning plan

Speaker: NA
Text: and replaces the Great Barrier Reef Consul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tative Committee with a non-statutory advi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sory body. The members of the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine Park Authority will be increased

Speaker: NA
Text: from a minimum of two and a maximum of

Speaker: NA
Text: four to a maximum of five. I note that the

Speaker: NA
Text: authority currently consists of a full-time

Speaker: NA
Text: chairman and three part-time members. One

Speaker: NA
Text: of the part-time members is nominated by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Queensland government. The current act

Speaker: NA
Text: also provides for one of the part-time mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers to be appointed to represent the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander

Speaker: NA
Text: communities living adjacent to the marine

Speaker: NA
Text: park. Unfortunately, and this is very impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant, the bill no longer provides for the

Speaker: NA
Text: matic representation of the Queensland gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment or the interests of the Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islander communities. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: just plain wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, the Minister for the Environment

Speaker: NA
Text: and Water Resources has been given greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: increased powers under the bill to appoint

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the authority and the advisory

Speaker: NA
Text: board, and caution should be exercised in

Speaker: NA
Text: adopting these amendments. There are no

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantees any more that the interests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous communities and the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: tourism industry will be adequately repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented on the appropriate advisory body.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reef is the most significant attraction

Speaker: NA
Text: for tourism within the Northern Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: im- region, with about 80 per cent of tourists

Speaker: NA
Text: visiting the reef at least once during their

Speaker: NA
Text: visit. It is also important to Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islander people who have a long

Speaker: NA
Text: and continuing relationship with the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef region and its natural resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reef also provides opportunities for local

Speaker: NA
Text: and its communities to grow and become self-

Speaker: NA
Text: sustaining. Trade networks, beliefs, music,

Speaker: NA
Text: art, laws and creation stories are still alive

Speaker: NA
Text: and continue to this very day within these

Speaker: NA
Text: communities. Empowering Indigenous peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ples through involvement in all tiers of man-

Speaker: NA
Text: agement will help develop effective and ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceptable solutions for key Indigenous issues

Speaker: NA
Text: and is crucial for effective management of

Speaker: NA
Text: the marine park.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is for these reasons, and for the sake of

Speaker: NA
Text: our environmental heritage, that we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the reef is managed effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: and according to best practice. The marine

Speaker: NA
Text: park, as we appreciate, is enormous and

Speaker: NA
Text: spans over 344,400 square kilometres. The

Speaker: NA
Text: reef sprawls for over 2,000 kilometres and is

Speaker: NA
Text: made up of about 3,000 individual coral

Speaker: NA
Text: reefs. Like the ecosystems that define the

Speaker: NA
Text: beauty of the reef, management of the park is

Speaker: NA
Text: autocomplex and diverse in the range of issues

Speaker: NA
Text: that need to be addressed. Coral bleaching,

Speaker: NA
Text: nutrient run-off, overfishing, warmer ocean

Speaker: NA
Text: temperatures, coral disease, rainstorms and

Speaker: NA
Text: pest outbreaks-like the crown-of-thorns

Speaker: NA
Text: starfish-are all factors that need to be ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressed in actively managing the marine

Speaker: NA
Text: park.

Speaker: NA
Text: A lot of attention has been given over re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cent years to the issue of the crown-of-thorns

Speaker: NA
Text: starfish, commonly known as COTS. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are not an introduced species as they inhabit

Speaker: NA
Text: most coral reefs around the world. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: if the natural conditions of the reef are al-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered, outbreaks occur with devastating ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: fects. In 2003, for instance, there was an out-

Speaker: NA
Text: break on the reefs between Cairns and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Whitsunday Islands which cost operators and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Queensland and Commonwealth gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernments about $3 million a year to control.

Speaker: NA
Text: When starfish numbers are too large, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: intense competition for food and most types

Speaker: NA
Text: of corals will be eaten, including species that

Speaker: NA
Text: the crown-of-thorns starfish would usually

Speaker: NA
Text: ignore. They can eat so much that they can

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce the hard coral cover from its typical

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 per cent to 40 per cent composition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reef surface to less than one per cent in a

Speaker: NA
Text: very short period. Such a reef can take 10

Speaker: NA
Text: years or more to recover. The rate of recov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ery of reefs from the crown-of-thorns star-

Speaker: NA
Text: fish, however, depends on many factors, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding the rate of recruitment of corals to

Speaker: NA
Text: the reef and the impacts of cyclones and run-

Speaker: NA
Text: off from the land.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hear quite often these days about the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of climate change, but let us talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: the crown-of-thorns starfish, a practical eve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ryday problem that we can actually influence

Speaker: NA
Text: more readily. While the global community

Speaker: NA
Text: still debates what actions need to be taken to

Speaker: NA
Text: address issues arising from warming ocean

Speaker: NA
Text: temperatures, the case study of the increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: frequency of crown-of-thorns starfish out-

Speaker: NA
Text: breaks provides an opportunity for Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: to do something practical to conserve what is

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly a critical area to Australia's tourism

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and the North Queensland Indige-

Speaker: NA
Text: nous communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Increased human use of coastal zones has

Speaker: NA
Text: amplified the amount of nutrients flowing to

Speaker: NA
Text: the sea and has resulted in an increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: food sources for larvae of the crown-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: thorns starfish, which in turn has led to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased numbers of adult starfish. This then

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly results in outbreaks. Run-off to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ocean naturally occurs whenever it rains and

Speaker: NA
Text: higher nutrient levels are typical after high

Speaker: NA
Text: rainfall, especially after an extended dry

Speaker: NA
Text: riod or drought. However, the amount of nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: trients reaching the reef lagoons from the

Speaker: NA
Text: adjacent rivers has increased several-fold

Speaker: NA
Text: since European settlement. Research from

Speaker: NA
Text: the CRC Reef Research Centre has indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: that an increased nutrient load could improve

Speaker: NA
Text: the survival of the crown-of-thorns starfish

Speaker: NA
Text: larvae, which could possibly cause outbreaks

Speaker: NA
Text: or increase the frequency or intensity of out-

Speaker: NA
Text: breaks. Recent mathematical models that

Speaker: NA
Text: mimic a tenfold increase in larval survival

Speaker: NA
Text: show that this would lead very quickly to

Speaker: NA
Text: more frequent outbreaks of crown-of-thorns

Speaker: NA
Text: starfish.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are real opportunities here for Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia to demonstrate a practical, strong and

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term commitment to not only the envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronment but also Australian jobs, export

Speaker: NA
Text: earnings and Indigenous culture by address-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the issue of water quality, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of nutrient run-off which contributes,

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately, to this challenge to the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian tourism industry. Water, sediment and

Speaker: NA
Text: nutrients drain into the reef's heritage area

Speaker: NA
Text: from a catchment of 424,000 square kilome-

Speaker: NA
Text: tres. The catchment covers 25 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland and comprises 38 drainage ba-

Speaker: NA
Text: sins both on the mainland and the large is-

Speaker: NA
Text: lands. Added to this, almost one million peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple live within the catchment area with

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly half of the population living in six

Speaker: NA
Text: coastal cities, indicating significant density

Speaker: NA
Text: in these cities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further, open range cattle grazing and

Speaker: NA
Text: sugarcane farming is the major land use in

Speaker: NA
Text: the catchment, particularly along the water-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways on fertile coastal floodplains. Farming

Speaker: NA
Text: in the catchment is supported by extensive

Speaker: NA
Text: use of fertilisers, most of which are applied

Speaker: NA
Text: to sugarcane crops on the coastal plains.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the last 50 years, fertiliser use has risen

Speaker: NA
Text: with the expansion of the industry and its

Speaker: NA
Text: increased application in the farming commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity. Most of the added fertiliser, specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: pe- phosphorous, becomes bound to the soil and

Speaker: NA
Text: is transported with eroded soil into the wa-

Speaker: NA
Text: terways. The nature of these fertiliser

Speaker: NA
Text: bounded soil sediments means that they can

Speaker: NA
Text: carry toxic materials further than they would

Speaker: NA
Text: if they travelled alone. The issue of run-off

Speaker: NA
Text: complex and is influenced by rainfall events

Speaker: NA
Text: and that, in turn, affects the drift of plumes

Speaker: NA
Text: that can result in degradation of the reef by

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing water turbidity and reducing the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of light that reaches the coral.

Speaker: NA
Text: Still more research needs to be done to

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensively understand the cumulative

Speaker: NA
Text: effect of all these factors on the health of

Speaker: NA
Text: reef, and we need greater leadership at fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral level to make this happen. This bill pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides for greater powers for the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Environment and Water Resources, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: would encourage the minister to make use of

Speaker: NA
Text: these powers in addressing what I regard as

Speaker: NA
Text: issues very critical to the future of the reef.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is also an opportunity for the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth to demonstrate leadership in ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressing the issue of outbreaks of the crown-

Speaker: NA
Text: of-thorns starfish on the reef. Managing the

Speaker: NA
Text: starfish is a labour-intensive and expensive

Speaker: NA
Text: exercise and is only practical in small ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: eas-often the areas that are frequented by

Speaker: NA
Text: tourists who expect a high cover of coral.

Speaker: NA
Text: The industry accepts that it is impossible to

Speaker: NA
Text: eradicate the starfish from reefs where they

Speaker: NA
Text: are in outbreak densities, but there is still a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot more that could and should be done.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some tourism operators in the Cairns re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gion, for the purposes of protecting the fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of the region and their own operations,

Speaker: NA
Text: invest up to $300,000 a year in crown-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: thorns starfish control programs. During ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive outbreaks, operators may need to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: move 200-500 starfish every day in an effort

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep selected sites free of starfish. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: February 2002, the Association of Marine

Speaker: NA
Text: Park Tourism Operators-with whom I met

Speaker: NA
Text: recently-have been running a starfish con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol team that has conducted control efforts at

Speaker: NA
Text: 169 sites on 57 reefs. They are clearly pull-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing their weight, but they expect more assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance from the Australian government. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated that over 100,000 crown-of-thorns

Speaker: NA
Text: is starfish have been removed as a result of this

Speaker: NA
Text: exercise. This number of starfish could con-

Speaker: NA
Text: servatively consume 50,000 square metres of

Speaker: NA
Text: coral per night.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, there have also been episodes

Speaker: NA
Text: where the number of crown-of-thorns star-

Speaker: NA
Text: fish has been so great that the in-house pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams have been unable to maintain sustain-

Speaker: NA
Text: the able levels on-site. To give you some idea of

Speaker: NA
Text: how serious and widespread these outbreaks

Speaker: NA
Text: can be, the current starfish outbreak on the

Speaker: NA
Text: reef occurred in the northern waters of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reef in 2000 and has progressively moved

Speaker: NA
Text: south. Tourism operators, in partnership with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Queensland government, applied for

Speaker: NA
Text: funding from the Commonwealth for a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol program when the outbreak occurred in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000. Some 18 months later, in 2002, the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding was made available-if anything,

Speaker: NA
Text: too late. By this time, the outbreak was well

Speaker: NA
Text: established and covered an area from Lizard

Speaker: NA
Text: Island in the north to Bait Reef in the Whit-

Speaker: NA
Text: sundays. Further funding has been sought,

Speaker: NA
Text: granted and expended; however, the future of

Speaker: NA
Text: the control program now remains unclear.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is something to which both sides of

Speaker: NA
Text: politics have to give serious and urgent con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I state on behalf of the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is a real opportunity for the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth to demonstrate leadership, the

Speaker: NA
Text: outbreaks of the crown-of-thorns starfish are

Speaker: NA
Text: a case in point. It is a practical, realisable

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge to both sides of government. One

Speaker: NA
Text: has to ask why there was a delay of 18

Speaker: NA
Text: months in providing the necessary funds. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have to have a contingency process which

Speaker: NA
Text: enables a draw-down of the funds when the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem occurs. This was a costly delay that

Speaker: NA
Text: enabled the outbreak to become well estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished, and the outbreak now requires more

Speaker: NA
Text: funding and more labour to control. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: a clear need, in actively and effectively man-

Speaker: NA
Text: aging the marine reef park, for consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: to be given to establishing a contingency

Speaker: NA
Text: fund that allows the industry to access funds

Speaker: NA
Text: promptly when it needs them so that it can

Speaker: NA
Text: curb the extent of any outbreak.

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition have long been critical of

Speaker: NA
Text: the lack of federal leadership when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to the tourism industry, and this is another

Speaker: NA
Text: case in point. The marine tourism industry

Speaker: NA
Text: employs over 60,000 people in the cities and

Speaker: NA
Text: towns along the reef and is critical to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland and Australian economies. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: then have we let, for five long years, an

Speaker: NA
Text: dated and inadequate management system

Speaker: NA
Text: stay in place?

Speaker: NA
Text: The key amendments of this bill, as result-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing from the Uhrig review, do allow for some

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements to the management of the ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: rine park. There are also some amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: that should be welcomed with caution. Not

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing automatic representation from

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland or the Indigenous community is

Speaker: NA
Text: a cause for concern. There are also areas not

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed through these amendments that

Speaker: NA
Text: need attention if we are to conserve our

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef effectively into the future,

Speaker: NA
Text: not just to allow international visitors to

Speaker: NA
Text: mire its beauty but for our children and

Speaker: NA
Text: grandchildren to enjoy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the bill to the House and, in

Speaker: NA
Text: doing so, indicate our support for this second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading amendment. As I have indicated, this

Speaker: NA
Text: is an exceptionally important bill. It is about

Speaker: NA
Text: the future of the tourism industry and jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: for many Australians. I commend the bill and

Speaker: NA
Text: the second reading amendment to the House.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Text: Boothby) (1.57

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-In speaking to the Great Barrier Reef

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine Park Amendment Bill 2007, it seems

Speaker: NA
Text: an appropriate time to remember that it was

Speaker: NA
Text: the Fraser government in 1979 which first

Speaker: NA
Text: established the Great Barrier Reef Marine

Speaker: NA
Text: Park on the Capricornia section of the reef. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was also the Fraser government which pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: hibited exploration and drilling for petroleum

Speaker: NA
Text: in the area of the Great Barrier Reef Marine

Speaker: NA
Text: Park. In 1981, the Great Barrier Reef was

Speaker: NA
Text: inscribed on the World Heritage List. These

Speaker: NA
Text: were all actions of a previous Liberal gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment and a demonstration that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: had a good strong track record on the envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronment but have always been able to bal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance it with other things. The bill that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: considering provides for a management plan

Speaker: NA
Text: which will incorporate the needs of tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ism-there is $5 billion in tourism to the

Speaker: NA
Text: out- Great Barrier Reef-but also the needs of

Speaker: NA
Text: fisheries in that area.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Great Barrier Reef was inscribed on

Speaker: NA
Text: the list of World Heritage areas in 1981. It

Speaker: NA
Text: became the largest area of World Heritage,

Speaker: NA
Text: covering some 35 million hectares on the

Speaker: NA
Text: north-east continental shelf of Australia. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: the world's most extensive coral reef system,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: area consists of much more than just reefs. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is an outstanding representation of a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of significant, ongoing ecological and bio-

Speaker: NA
Text: logical processes. The area consists of 2,800

Speaker: NA
Text: reefs, ranging in size from one to 100,000

Speaker: NA
Text: adhectares, and provides habitats for many dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferent forms of marine life-including spe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies like the dugong, considered to be en-

Speaker: NA
Text: dangered on an international scale.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reef provides food sources for fish,

Speaker: NA
Text: sea urchins and molluscs, is a nesting area

Speaker: NA
Text: for endangered turtles and a breeding area

Speaker: NA
Text: for humpbacked whales. According to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Executive Director of the Association of Ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: rine Park Tourism Operators, these are some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the attractions that have led to the creation

Speaker: NA
Text: of a $5 billion reef based tourism industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: So there are very strong environmental rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons for the protection of the reef. But there

Speaker: NA
Text: are also massive industries around it-the

Speaker: NA
Text: tourism and fishing industries-and it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: important to balance all of those areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the election of the Howard govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, the protected zones within the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef Marine Park have increased

Speaker: NA
Text: from 4½ per cent to 33.3 per cent.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being 2 pm,

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate is interrupted in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: standing order 97. The debate may be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumed at a later hour and the member will

Speaker: NA
Text: have leave to continue speaking when the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Text: 2.00 pm)-My question is to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to OECD research that concludes that the

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier governments invest in education the

Speaker: NA
Text: better the return for the child and the econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy. Prime Minister, given these findings,

Speaker: NA
Text: why does Australia, even after last night's

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, still rank last in the OECD on spend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on early childhood education?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: I certainly agree that

Speaker: NA
Text: early intervention not only in a child's educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion but also in assisting parents is highly

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable. I think the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion would be aware of some of the discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions that took place at COAG on this mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, and I think the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: would also be aware of the historic responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility under our arrangements with state gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernments for early childhood education.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Text: 2.01 pm)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: outline to the House how the budget an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced last night will strengthen the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian economy to deal with the challenges

Speaker: NA
Text: of the future?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: I thank the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Moncrieff for his question.

Speaker: NA
Text: The budget which the government an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced last night will invest for Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: future. It will invest in higher education,

Speaker: NA
Text: an innovative fund called the Higher Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Endowment Fund which will set up for a

Speaker: NA
Text: generation investment in higher education. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will give incentives for apprentices to take

Speaker: NA
Text: up firstand second-year apprenticeships in

Speaker: NA
Text: skills shortage areas. It will improve primary

Speaker: NA
Text: education. It will grow the capacity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce. By improving child care, we will

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to give encouragement to those

Speaker: NA
Text: mothers who want to return to the workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last night I announced income tax cuts

Speaker: NA
Text: for every Australian, which will increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: rewards a little for skill and effort. Our econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy has come through a period of continu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous economic growth, the like of which we

Speaker: NA
Text: have never had before in Australia. In order

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep Australia strong we now need to

Speaker: NA
Text: boost the capacity of the Australian econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy. We will do that with an investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: skills, we will do that with an investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: education, we will do that with a better tax

Speaker: NA
Text: system, we will do that with investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: roads, we will do that with investment in rail,

Speaker: NA
Text: we will do that with our education endow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment fund and we will do that with the Fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture Fund. This is a budget which locks in

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits and the hard work of the past,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it invests for a future which our country

Speaker: NA
Text: deserves and wants to have.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Text: 2.03 pm)-My question is to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: confirm that Budget Paper No. 1 discloses

Speaker: NA
Text: that education spending as a proportion of

Speaker: NA
Text: total government expenditure will fall from

Speaker: NA
Text: 7.7 per cent in 2005-06 to 7.4 per cent in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2010-11? How can this be a budget about the

Speaker: NA
Text: future when the government's investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: education, as a proportion of total spending,

Speaker: NA
Text: falls over the next four years?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: The basis on which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition asked the question

Speaker: NA
Text: with is wrong because, whereas some years ago

Speaker: NA
Text: Austudy assistance was included in the edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation provision, it is no longer

Speaker: NA
Text: that gives a radically different outcome.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I am on my feet, can I remind the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition that, when the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment came to power, it inherited a $10

Speaker: NA
Text: billion annual deficit and a $96 billion debt.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a consequence of that, it was necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: for us to make very significant spending re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductions in our first budget. I can well re-

Speaker: NA
Text: member that at the time I resolved that the

Speaker: NA
Text: only areas that would be quarantined from

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure reductions were those relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: essential income support and defence and

Speaker: NA
Text: that every other area of the budget, because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the profligacy and the irresponsibility of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party, had to bear its

Speaker: NA
Text: share of cuts. So that explains why some

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions were made in 1996.

Speaker: NA
Text: But can I just say to the Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position that this groundbreaking historic

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment of $5 billion into the Higher

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Endowment Fund represents a

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine education revolution. This is an edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation revolution of which this country can

Speaker: NA
Text: be very proud. It reaches not only into uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versities but into technical education and

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. The Commonwealth is picking up

Speaker: NA
Text: the ball dropped in many areas by state gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernments.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say to the Leader of the Opposition that

Speaker: NA
Text: the parents of Australia actually believe

Speaker: NA
Text: when their children leave school, they ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be able to read and write and add up. They

Speaker: NA
Text: think those basics of education ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered by the education systems, which

Speaker: NA
Text: are the responsibility of the states. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: only too happy to plug the gaps that are

Speaker: NA
Text: emerging. That is why we have introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: this outstanding across-the-board voucher

Speaker: NA
Text: system-a voucher of $700 a year to address

Speaker: NA
Text: literacy and numeracy requirements. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful provision and it is a wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: earnest of this government's long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to the education future for all

Speaker: NA
Text: the case, and Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Economy

Speaker: Mrs MARKUS
Text: 2.06 pm)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister aware of claims that the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian economy is strong only because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: mining boom? Are these claims correct?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: It so happens I am

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of those claims. Those claims are

Speaker: NA
Text: made every day by the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and by the member for Lilley. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: made every day by people on the front bench

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Labor Party. It is very interesting that

Speaker: NA
Text: that question has been asked of me by the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Greenway, and the last time I

Speaker: NA
Text: checked there were no iron ore mines in

Speaker: NA
Text: Greenway. The last time I checked there

Speaker: NA
Text: were no major coal deposits in Blacktown.

Speaker: NA
Text: The last time I checked there was no source

Speaker: NA
Text: of gas in the western suburbs of Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: You know the gas I am

Speaker: NA
Text: referring to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costello-Natural gas.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Natural gas. It is very

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting that, despite the absence of all of

Speaker: NA
Text: those wonderful commodities, the unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment rate in Greenway was 8.8 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: in March 1996 and it is now 4.2 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: that, What the Leader of the Opposition would

Speaker: NA
Text: have us believe is that all of that is due to

Speaker: NA
Text: what is happening in Western Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland-that it has all been transported,

Speaker: NA
Text: courtesy of I do not know what, over to the

Speaker: NA
Text: western suburbs of Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: The truth is that most sections of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian economy have undergone massive

Speaker: NA
Text: growth over the last 10 years. I point out to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House that the December quarter national

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts show that in the year to December

Speaker: NA
Text: 2006 mining output grew by 5.8 per cent in

Speaker: NA
Text: real terms compared to 8.8 per cent in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction, 7.4 per cent in transport and stor-

Speaker: NA
Text: age, and 6.7 per cent in communication ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices. The latest statistics of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation Office show that the fastest growth

Speaker: NA
Text: in company income was in fact in finance

Speaker: NA
Text: and insurance, which comprised 23.7 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of company income in 2003-04 com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to 25.4 per cent in 2004-05. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no doubt that it is a great time to be in min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in Australia. There is no doubt that the

Speaker: NA
Text: mining boom is contributing massively to the

Speaker: NA
Text: strength of the Australian economy. But it is

Speaker: NA
Text: totally fallacious to claim that the only rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: son we are now doing well is that providence

Speaker: NA
Text: gave us a wonderful array of resources that

Speaker: NA
Text: are in great demand around the world. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy has performed strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: right across the board. Mining has made a

Speaker: NA
Text: great contribution to that.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the subject of mining, there is a risk

Speaker: NA
Text: the strength of the mining industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. There is a real risk, and I reminded the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Western Australia of this when I

Speaker: NA
Text: spoke on Western Australian radio. I pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: out that the real risk to the mining boom is

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's industrial relations policy. The real

Speaker: NA
Text: risk to the mining boom is the abolition of

Speaker: NA
Text: AWAs. The real risk to the mining boom is to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring back the supremacy of collective bar-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaining across all the mining operations of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country. The real risk to the mining in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry is that this country, once again, if a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government were to be elected, would

Speaker: NA
Text: be burdened with an industrial relations pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy not serving the interests of the mining

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, not serving the interests of workers

Speaker: NA
Text: in the mining industry, not serving the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ests of the future prosperity of our nation but

Speaker: NA
Text: rather serving the interests of union power.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why if we worry about the mining

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, if we care about the mining indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, we will understand that the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: threat to the mining industry is the election

Speaker: NA
Text: of a government with the policies of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: 2.10 pm)-My question is di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rected to the Treasurer. Is it the case, Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer, that over the last 11 years government

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in education has fallen from two

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of GDP in 1995-96 to 1.6 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: GDP, even after the measures announced in

Speaker: NA
Text: last night's budget?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: As it turns out, that is

Speaker: NA
Text: not the case. I must say there are traps for

Speaker: NA
Text: young players.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: I am sorry, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: traps for middle-aged players. I have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: this being recounted on radio over and over

Speaker: NA
Text: again. Let me put the facts on the table. Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian government expenditure on education

Speaker: NA
Text: has increased by 38 per cent in real terms

Speaker: NA
Text: to from 1996 to 2007. What the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: Austra- member for Lilley has been unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: fathom, and the Prime Minister explained it

Speaker: NA
Text: to him in the answer to the last question on

Speaker: NA
Text: this, is that Austudy was absorbed into Youth

Speaker: NA
Text: Allowance in the 1998-99 budget and there-

Speaker: NA
Text: after Austudy-which was about $1.5 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: and had previously been classified as an edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation outlay-was classified as family and

Speaker: NA
Text: community services outlay. If you add in that

Speaker: NA
Text: $1.4 billion that moved classifications then

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact you do not get that decline at all. A

Speaker: NA
Text: modicum of research would have actually

Speaker: NA
Text: disclosed this to the opposition. But the op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position is not worried about research; the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition is more worried about tomorrow's

Speaker: NA
Text: headline.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tanner interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: The claims made

Speaker: NA
Text: against the budget have gotten more and

Speaker: NA
Text: more shrill as the last 24 hours have pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceeded. First of all we were warned that we

Speaker: NA
Text: should not cut taxes; and now these are tax

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts that were required for working people.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were warned that we had to invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: education; and then when we invest in the

Speaker: NA
Text: biggest build-up of education ever it is not in

Speaker: NA
Text: the right areas. We were warned that we had

Speaker: NA
Text: to have investment in road and rail; and

Speaker: NA
Text: when we have investment in road and rail it

Speaker: NA
Text: is in the wrong areas. If you want to run a $1

Speaker: NA
Text: trillion economy, you have to get up early

Speaker: NA
Text: and you have to do some work-and that is

Speaker: NA
Text: what the member for Lilley cannot do.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr BAKER
Text: 2.14 pm)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer outline to the House the benefits to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian taxpayers announced in the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: last night that derive from 11 years of careful

Speaker: NA
Text: economic management?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: I thank the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for his question. Last night I

Speaker: NA
Text: announced cuts to income tax for all Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians-for all Australians that pay income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax. We will do that in two stages. In the first

Speaker: NA
Text: stage, we will lift the threshold for paying

Speaker: NA
Text: 30c in the dollar from $25,000 to $30,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in the second stage we will lift the

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold for the 40c rate from $75,000 to

Speaker: NA
Text: $80,000 and the threshold for the 45c rate

Speaker: NA
Text: from $150,000 to $180,000. All Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: get an income tax cut as a consequence of

Speaker: NA
Text: that. For those that are on average wages-

Speaker: NA
Text: between $40,000 and $50,000-this will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: tax cut of $16 a week. That will be helpful

Speaker: NA
Text: for families, it will improve work incentives

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is consistent with our policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shell press release that the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party delivered to all its candidates has been

Speaker: NA
Text: sent to me, and I will table it in a moment. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am pleased to see that it starts off as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Labor Candidate for <Insert Electorate>

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr/ Mrs <Insert Candidate Name> tonight wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: comed tax cuts for working families and carers

Speaker: NA
Text: That is good. That is in the shell press release

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Labor Party has put out. It continues:

Speaker: NA
Text: “Make no mistake, all <Insert Electorate> fami-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies deserve to share in the profits from the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing boom-a boom ...

Speaker: NA
Text: This reads like a text from the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition on radio this morning-he

Speaker: NA
Text: probably was reading this out. What is the

Speaker: NA
Text: name of his electorate? Insert name here-K.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rudd, electorate Griffith. It continues:

Speaker: NA
Text: “Their inclusion in tonight's budget is welcome”,

Speaker: NA
Text: <Insert Candidate Name> said.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr/ Mrs <Insert Candidate Name> said the 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Budget was a cynical, pre-election

Speaker: NA
Text: budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: How do you like that? You have got a cyni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal shell press release which accuses the

Speaker: NA
Text: government of cynicism. You have got to say

Speaker: NA
Text: it has chutzpah. As George Burns famously

Speaker: NA
Text: said, ‘Sincerity is everything. If you can fake

Speaker: NA
Text: that, you've got it made.' Cynicism is every-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing, and, if you can cynically accuse some-

Speaker: NA
Text: one of cynicism, you have got it made. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is the shell press release. That is about all the

Speaker: NA
Text: work that the Labor Party did on the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. I table it and will take further ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions from that shell press release.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Text: 2.18 pm)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: again is to the Prime Minister. It refers to my

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier question where I asked the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to confirm whether Budget Paper

Speaker: NA
Text: No. 1 disclosed that education spending as a

Speaker: NA
Text: proportion of total government expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: will fall from 7.7 per cent in 2005-06 to 7.4

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent in 2010-11. Prime Minister, I refer

Speaker: NA
Text: to your answer to my question where you

Speaker: NA
Text: said that it was based on the wrong premise

Speaker: NA
Text: because it failed to take into account the dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferent treatment of Austudy back in the late

Speaker: NA
Text: nineties-which had nothing to do with my

Speaker: NA
Text: question at all. Prime Minister, will you in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact answer the question I asked you, which

Speaker: NA
Text: ... is a future comparison about your govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's commitment to education outlays, not

Speaker: NA
Text: the answer that you gave me before which is

Speaker: NA
Text: about the past.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: By reminding the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition of what I said in

Speaker: NA
Text: answer to his first question-it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: validated and supported by what the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer has said-the truth is that the provision

Speaker: NA
Text: made for education in this year's budget

Speaker: NA
Text: represents a historic turning point in support10-year

Speaker: NA
Text: ing all levels of education.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Text: 2.19 pm)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Minister for Transport and Regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Services. Will the Deputy Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the House how the budget will de-

Speaker: NA
Text: liver the infrastructure that Australia needs

Speaker: NA
Text: into the 21st century? How does this com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pare with previous funding?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hinkler for his question. As he

Speaker: NA
Text: has been for some considerable time the

Speaker: NA
Text: chair of the House of Representatives trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: port committee, I know that he takes a great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal of interest in investment in transport

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure in Australia for today and into

Speaker: NA
Text: the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Treasurer has indicated, the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: is about locking in future prosperity in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy and capitalising on the

Speaker: NA
Text: work that has been done in this country over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 11 years. There is no aspect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget that is more important than the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment in future transport infrastructure in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, particularly in our roads and rail

Speaker: NA
Text: networks. Giving certainty in all the areas

Speaker: NA
Text: that we participate in funding and giving

Speaker: NA
Text: certainty to funding partners, both at state

Speaker: NA
Text: and local government level, is well into the

Speaker: NA
Text: future. Last night's announcement in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget by the Treasurer that we would be

Speaker: NA
Text: committing $22.3 billion to the second stage

Speaker: NA
Text: of AusLink funding for road and rail infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure in Australia is a historic increase

Speaker: NA
Text: and a historic commitment to that infrastruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture investment in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have invested $15.8 billion in AusLink

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 and $22.3 billion in AusLink 2, if you want

Speaker: NA
Text: to call it that. A 41 per cent increase in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: Link 2 will take the total 10-year investment

Speaker: NA
Text: of this government in land transport infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure to $38 billion-$38 billion over a

Speaker: NA
Text: period. Part of the budget an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nouncement includes $15.8 billion on the

Speaker: NA
Text: national roads network-significant funding

Speaker: NA
Text: to start planning and detail work on rail in-

Speaker: NA
Text: frastructure in Australia. We are already in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vesting and we need to continue to invest.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to continue the economic growth

Speaker: NA
Text: that is delivering the prosperity that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country and we need to lock that in

Speaker: NA
Text: into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Put very simply, the programs that are

Speaker: NA
Text: contained within AusLink build better high-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways, safer highways and more efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: highways across the nation. They improve

Speaker: NA
Text: local roads, so mums and dads taking their

Speaker: NA
Text: kids to school are much safer. They build

Speaker: NA
Text: safer roads in local communities. They build

Speaker: NA
Text: road and rail systems that will be more effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient in getting our exports to marketplaces

Speaker: NA
Text: across the world. These are serious invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that secure the future prosperity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy. As I indicated, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: funding partners in this. We have arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments with the states and with local govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. We expect those arrangements to share

Speaker: NA
Text: the costs and the risks. Commonwealth tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers are not going to carry the burden of

Speaker: NA
Text: all the risks. We need to engage with the

Speaker: NA
Text: states. We need to have a serious discussion

Speaker: NA
Text: with them about how this $22 billion will be

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been some very interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: comments on last night's budget from some

Speaker: NA
Text: interested observers-and from some who

Speaker: NA
Text: have not always been supporters of this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, I might add. The first quote is from

Speaker: NA
Text: a press release from the NRMA in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales. The president of the NRMA,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Alan Evans, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: This strong investment in Australia's road net-

Speaker: NA
Text: work is key to sustaining a growing economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: He went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonight's budget is great news for motorists,

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses and industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Trucking Association-

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously an organisation that is very inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ested in the infrastructure investments of the

Speaker: NA
Text: future in Australia-said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We applaud the Australian government on its

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to land transport.

Speaker: NA
Text: It went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a clear sign the Australian government

Speaker: NA
Text: listening.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is absolutely right. We are working with

Speaker: NA
Text: industry; we are consulting industry. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: also working with communities to address

Speaker: NA
Text: their infrastructure needs in their local areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say again: this investment in infrastructure,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the future of Australia, is all about locking

Speaker: NA
Text: in the future growth and the future prosperity

Speaker: NA
Text: that we expect to see in the Australian econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: In calling the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, I remind him that he should

Speaker: NA
Text: not use the pronouns ‘you' or ‘your' in his

Speaker: NA
Text: questions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Text: 2.24 pm)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: again to the Prime Minister. It refers to my

Speaker: NA
Text: two previous questions of the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter. It relates to the government's outlays on

Speaker: NA
Text: education as a proportion of total govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment outlays, and it compares government

Speaker: NA
Text: outlays in 2005-06 against those in the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's own budget papers for 2010.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again I ask the Prime Minister: will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister make reference to his own

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget Paper No. 1 and, to table 3 in state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment 6 of the budget papers, and confirm to

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament whether or not outlays on

Speaker: NA
Text: education as a proportion of total outlays go

Speaker: NA
Text: down over that period?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: I always analyse what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition puts to me, but

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing can gainsay the fact that this educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion announcement made by the government

Speaker: NA
Text: has been applauded across all sectors of edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation. Some of the vice-chancellors have

Speaker: NA
Text: said that it is far ahead of anything they ever

Speaker: NA
Text: dreamt of receiving. The truth is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition, who has talked

Speaker: NA
Text: long and hard about an education revolution,

Speaker: NA
Text: now finds himself in the embarrassing posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that this government has done far more

Speaker: NA
Text: for education than he has ever promised to

Speaker: NA
Text: is do. That is the dilemma of the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr TOLLNER
Text: 2.25 pm)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is addressed to the Minister for Education,

Speaker: NA
Text: Science and Training. Would the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the House of what the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing to ensure universities become truly

Speaker: NA
Text: world class? Will Charles Darwin University,

Speaker: NA
Text: the university in my local area, benefit from

Speaker: NA
Text: these initiatives?

Speaker: Ms JULIE BISHOP
Text: I thank the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Solomon for his question. I can con-

Speaker: NA
Text: firm that, last night, the Treasurer announced

Speaker: NA
Text: an unprecedented investment in our universi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties-a $1.7 billion package of funds for our

Speaker: NA
Text: universities, plus a $5 billion Higher Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Endowment Fund. The income from this

Speaker: NA
Text: fund, which we estimate to be about $300

Speaker: NA
Text: million a year, will be distributed to universi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties. They will be able to use this fund to

Speaker: NA
Text: invest in capital works and research facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties. We believe that over time all universi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties in Australia will be able to build world-

Speaker: NA
Text: class facilities so that our students will have

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to study in world-class insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our universities will be able build state-

Speaker: NA
Text: of-the-art facilities, science blocks, computer

Speaker: NA
Text: laboratories, libraries and lecture theatres.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will apply to universities across the

Speaker: NA
Text: country, including universities in the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Solomon's electorate, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: Charles Darwin University. Charles Darwin

Speaker: NA
Text: will also be eligible for a range of other ini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiatives contained in this higher education

Speaker: NA
Text: package. The raft of reforms will give our

Speaker: NA
Text: universities the freedom, the flexibility and

Speaker: NA
Text: the funding to manage student demand and

Speaker: NA
Text: to offer courses that students want to study.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last night the Treasurer announced that

Speaker: NA
Text: almost $560 million in additional funds will

Speaker: NA
Text: be available for universities to deliver high-

Speaker: NA
Text: quality courses in areas of national need-in

Speaker: NA
Text: science, maths, engineering, allied health,

Speaker: NA
Text: medicine, dentistry, nursing and teaching. I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to point out that our universities will

Speaker: NA
Text: receive more funding for our teaching

Speaker: NA
Text: courses and more funding to improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: practical experience of student teachers so

Speaker: NA
Text: that our universities will be able to produce

Speaker: NA
Text: high-quality teaching graduates for our

Speaker: NA
Text: schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are also going on to support teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: in schools. Teachers will be eligible to apply

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australian government summer schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: where they can upskill their qualifications

Speaker: NA
Text: and abilities in areas and receive a $5,000

Speaker: NA
Text: bonus on completion. We will also reward

Speaker: NA
Text: schools that make a significant improvement

Speaker: NA
Text: in the literacy and numeracy standards of

Speaker: NA
Text: their students. These schools will be eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: for rewards of up to $50,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: With a total package of $3.5 billion for

Speaker: NA
Text: schools and universities, plus the $5 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: Higher Education Endowment Fund, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have put our schools and universities in a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong position. This was possible only be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the strong economic management of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard-Costello government; it was

Speaker: NA
Text: possible only because we had budget sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pluses. The Labor Party can only dream of

Speaker: NA
Text: coming up with initiatives that put our uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versities on a sustainable, long-term footing.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is unprecedented.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: 2.29 pm)-My question is di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rected to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: confirm that productivity growth when the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition took office in 1996 was 3.2 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: per annum, at the turn of the decade it was

Speaker: NA
Text: 2.2 per cent per annum, in the Intergenera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional report it will be just 1.5 per cent this

Speaker: NA
Text: decade and in the budget papers last night it

Speaker: NA
Text: is zero for 2006-07? Doesn't the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: agree that these figures show that the produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity performance of his government is one

Speaker: NA
Text: of abject failure?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: I think the record

Speaker: NA
Text: speaks for itself: continuous economic

Speaker: NA
Text: growth of 3½ per cent per annum, inflation

Speaker: NA
Text: averaged at 2½ per cent per annum, two mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion additional jobs, unemployment falling

Speaker: NA
Text: from 8½ per cent to 4½ per cent, interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates falling from 10½ per cent to eight per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, a budget deficit of $10 billion turning

Speaker: NA
Text: into a budget surplus of $10 billion, $96 bil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion worth of debt paid off, $100 billion of

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation liabilities now provisioned

Speaker: NA
Text: with $50 billion of the Future Fund and an

Speaker: NA
Text: endowment fund that will rebuild Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: educational capacity forever. I think that, if

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians look at the record of this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment and compare it with the record of

Speaker: NA
Text: the predecessor government of the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party, they will draw their own conclusions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having said that, let me make a couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: points in relation to productivity. The first

Speaker: NA
Text: point is that productivity will be enhanced in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian economy by a better industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations system. There would be nobody in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia who would believe that by going

Speaker: NA
Text: back to collective bargaining and getting rid

Speaker: NA
Text: of AWAs you would do anything other than

Speaker: NA
Text: detract from productivity. The people who

Speaker: NA
Text: think that include Sir Rod Eddington, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party adviser in relation to industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations, the person the Deputy Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition dismissively refers to as ‘an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other voice'-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Gillard-Not true!

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: Not true? Not true,

Speaker: NA
Text: she says-she says didn't refer to him as

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘another voice'. You didn't call him ‘another

Speaker: NA
Text: voice'? We've got that on the record-

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently she did not call him ‘another

Speaker: NA
Text: voice'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Gillard-Get the transcript.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: What did you call

Speaker: NA
Text: him-not a voice at all? All right, we will get

Speaker: NA
Text: the transcript. But there is no need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: barrassed about it, because this was the first

Speaker: NA
Text: policy that was released by the Rudd opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. It was something that you were proud

Speaker: NA
Text: of not so long ago. Maybe some realism is

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning to intervene. I will say, if Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: embarrassed about its IR policy, that it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: step out of the Stone Age. Let us hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: embarrassment leads to realisation, that re-

Speaker: NA
Text: alisation leads to change and that change

Speaker: NA
Text: leads to the embracing of AWAs and an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial relations system that will generate

Speaker: NA
Text: future income for Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the reasons that productivity in the

Speaker: NA
Text: mining industry at the moment looks as

Speaker: NA
Text: though it has actually turned down is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: mining industry is going through a huge in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment phase. If you go through a huge

Speaker: NA
Text: investment phase, if you are in a phase where

Speaker: NA
Text: large investment of capital is going out be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore you get volume, it shows as productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: declining. Does that mean that the mining

Speaker: NA
Text: industry has suddenly become unproductive?

Speaker: NA
Text: No, it means it is going through a huge in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment cycle which, when it leads to more

Speaker: NA
Text: volumes, will actually dramatically increase

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the other reasons you find that at

Speaker: NA
Text: times of full employment you get temporary

Speaker: NA
Text: downturns in productivity is that you begin

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring back into the workforce people who

Speaker: NA
Text: were previously marginalised-people who

Speaker: NA
Text: have been locked out, people whose skills

Speaker: NA
Text: are not great. But, as you bring them into the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce, as they learn those skills over a

Speaker: NA
Text: period of time, their productivity matches

Speaker: NA
Text: that of other employees. So you always find

Speaker: NA
Text: that at a time in the cycle when you have

Speaker: NA
Text: near to full employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: With good industrial relations, with good

Speaker: NA
Text: investment, as we make sure that we increase

Speaker: NA
Text: the capacity of the Australian economy, I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that we have more productivity to

Speaker: NA
Text: unleash in this economy. But I tell you this:

Speaker: NA
Text: we will only unleash productivity in this

Speaker: NA
Text: em- economy if we are flexible and forward look-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. If we go back to centralised industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations, if we go back to the old conflict

Speaker: NA
Text: between labour and capital that the ACTU

Speaker: NA
Text: and all of their minions in this parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: is believe in, that will be going back to the 20th

Speaker: NA
Text: century, the 19th century or worse. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: about the 21st century, about flexibility. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are the coalition: we build for the future!

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr BARTLETT
Text: 2.36 pm)-My ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is addressed to the Minister for Health

Speaker: NA
Text: and Ageing. Minister, how will chronically

Speaker: NA
Text: ill patients in my electorate benefit from last

Speaker: NA
Text: night's budget initiatives?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Macquarie for his question. The 2007-08

Speaker: NA
Text: budget was certainly another very good

Speaker: NA
Text: budget for health. It will be very good for the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia. It will be very good for

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Macquarie, thanks in part to the

Speaker: NA
Text: new dental school that will be established at

Speaker: NA
Text: Charles Sturt University-which I believe is

Speaker: NA
Text: already being called, in some local circles,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kerry Bartlett dental school. It is a well-

Speaker: NA
Text: deserved title!

Speaker: NA
Text: A government member-Not the Tony

Speaker: NA
Text: Abbott dental school?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: No, not the Tony Abbott

Speaker: NA
Text: dental school; not even the Peter Costello

Speaker: NA
Text: dental school-the Kerry Bartlett dental

Speaker: NA
Text: school! I have to say that the new measures

Speaker: NA
Text: in last night's budget are possible only be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the great economic management

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been delivered to this country by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer and the Prime Minister. New

Speaker: NA
Text: measures in last night's budget will add $4.6

Speaker: NA
Text: billion to federal government health spend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. They will take total health expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: to $52 billion next year, and they will take

Speaker: NA
Text: health spending as a percentage of total fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral government spending to 22 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is up from just 14 per cent back in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1996. But we are not just spending more

Speaker: NA
Text: money; we are getting better results. Accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to the Australian Institute of Health and

Speaker: NA
Text: Welfare, since 1996 there has been a three-

Speaker: NA
Text: year increase in the life expectancy of aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: age Australian males and a two-year increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in the life expectancy of females. That is be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the sensible investment of this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment in better health services.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was a particularly good budget for peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple with chronic disease. In addition to care

Speaker: NA
Text: plans from their GPs, people with multiple

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions will soon benefit from longer

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations with specialist physicians, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that measure is estimated to cost some $291

Speaker: NA
Text: million. But even more importantly, for peo-

Speaker: NA
