Text: ple with chronic conditions whose poor oral

Speaker: NA
Text: health is impacting on their general health,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is now greatly expanded access to

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare funded dentistry. Instead of just

Speaker: NA
Text: three consultations a year, under Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: those patients will be eligible for an initial

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation and up to $2,000 worth of sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sequent treatment a year.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are not relieving the states of their

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility for public dentistry but we will

Speaker: NA
Text: not leave people in health crisis. Many of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 650,000 people on those public dental wait-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing lists will be eligible for a team care plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: My message to them is this: the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government will not let you down. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute to the way the Treasurer has managed

Speaker: NA
Text: health that it was only after question time

Speaker: NA
Text: began that we finally heard from the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Gellibrand who, after two o'clock, finally

Speaker: NA
Text: surfaced with a press release that said: ‘Den-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal program lacks bite.' Well, I tell you what:

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare has a lot more bite than ever be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore; it has a lot more bite than it ever had

Speaker: NA
Text: when Labor was in charge. The Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government is proving by its actions, not just

Speaker: NA
Text: by its words, that it is the best friend-the

Speaker: NA
Text: very best friend-that Medicare has ever

Speaker: NA
Text: had.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: 2.40 pm)- Mr Speaker, my

Speaker: NA
Text: question is to the Prime Minister. How can

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister claim that this is an edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation budget when it has no plans to under-

Speaker: NA
Text: pin education through the rollout of a high

Speaker: NA
Text: speed broadband network? Does the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister believe that it is acceptable for chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren in countries like Singapore, Japan and

Speaker: NA
Text: Korea to have access to high-speed broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: band infrastructure for their education, when

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian children do not?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: I believe that high-speed

Speaker: NA
Text: broadband is important to the education fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of this country. I just do not believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian taxpayer should pay for some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing through raiding the Future Fund and

Speaker: NA
Text: plundering $2 billion from the budget which

Speaker: NA
Text: is available for enhancement of communica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions services in the Australian bush. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that that $4.7 billion should be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken-$2.7 billion from the Future Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: and $2 billion from rural people-to subsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dise commercial operations which ought, as

Speaker: NA
Text: an operation of market forces, provide the

Speaker: NA
Text: re- broadband that the Australian community

Speaker: NA
Text: needs. This is the Australian Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent of the great debates the British

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Party used to have about clause 4 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Constitution and whether you would re-

Speaker: NA
Text: nationalise a whole lot of industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I am on my feet, can I say that the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lilley asked me to validate the

Speaker: NA
Text: argument I made that this was an education

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. His leader had asked me some ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and invited me, and I have now had an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to look at the paper from which

Speaker: NA
Text: he quoted. It is a very revealing examination.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me read from under the title ‘Education',

Speaker: NA
Text: 6.10 of Budget Paper No. 1. Bear in mind

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Leader of the Opposition asked me

Speaker: NA
Text: two questions that were calculated to demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strate that expenditure on education, so far

Speaker: NA
Text: from rising, had actually fallen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: I see. To start with it

Speaker: NA
Text: was 7.5 and 7.4, but that 7.5 and 7.4 was not

Speaker: NA
Text: a percentage of GDP. It was not an attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: compare education spending from one year

Speaker: NA
Text: to the next; rather, they were percentages of

Speaker: NA
Text: aggregate government spending and made no

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance for the fact that expenditure in

Speaker: NA
Text: other areas may have increased at an even

Speaker: NA
Text: faster rate than education-such as expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture on defence and expenditure on family

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like the member for Lilley to

Speaker: NA
Text: leave question time with a feeling of tran-

Speaker: NA
Text: quillity and peace about the subject of educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I will quote from Budget Paper No. 1. It

Speaker: NA
Text: reads as follows, and I invite the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lilley and the member for Griffith to listen

Speaker: NA
Text: to this:

Speaker: NA
Text: Total expenses under the education function are

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated to increase by 9.0 per cent in real

Speaker: NA
Text: from 2007-08 to 2010-11, or 3.4 per cent annually

Speaker: NA
Text: on average. The major drivers of this growth are

Speaker: NA
Text: the significant new measures for schools and uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versities announced in the 2007-08 Budget ...

Speaker: NA
Text: This is specifically on the point that I know

Speaker: NA
Text: worries the member for Lilley; I know he

Speaker: NA
Text: worries about this. It goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Higher education funding is estimated to rise by

Speaker: NA
Text: about 9.7 per cent in real terms from 2007-08 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 2010-11 or 3.7 per cent annually on average.

Speaker: NA
Text: All I can conclude is that the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is being trickier than usual with

Speaker: NA
Text: his figures. The truth is that we have had an

Speaker: NA
Text: education revolution. The truth is that on the

Speaker: NA
Text: centrepiece-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Albanese- Mr Speaker, I rise on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. As you know, this question

Speaker: NA
Text: was about broadband. We know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister knows nothing about it and

Speaker: NA
Text: its relation to education-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Manager of Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition Business will resume his seat. He will

Speaker: NA
Text: recall that the question started off referring to

Speaker: NA
Text: education and then went to broadband. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister is in order.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: I am broadbanding my

Speaker: NA
Text: answer. I will repeat it because I think the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Grayndler may have missed it.

Speaker: NA
Text: This really is the thing that I know bugs the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition. They have been talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: education for the last four or five months.

Speaker: NA
Text: Everywhere they go: ‘Education revolution!'

Speaker: NA
Text: Everywhere they go: ‘The way forward is

Speaker: NA
Text: education.' That is absolutely right, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: way you go forward in education is in part to

Speaker: NA
Text: spend more money on it, which we are do-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. It is also to raise standards, which we are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing. It is also to acknowledge the profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sionalism of teachers in Australia, which we

Speaker: NA
Text: do. It is also to recognise the passion of par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents to make certain that our schools actually

Speaker: NA
Text: teach children how to read and write and add

Speaker: NA
Text: terms up. That is what the Australian public wants

Speaker: NA
Text: and that is what this education revolution

Speaker: NA
Text: will deliver.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: NA
Text: Miss JACKIE KELLY (2.46 pm)-My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is addressed to the Minister for De-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence. Would the minister outline to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House the impact of the budget on defence

Speaker: NA
Text: capability and the recruitment and retention

Speaker: NA
Text: of defence personnel?

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lindsay for her service to our country in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Australian Air Force and for now do-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a magnificent job looking after the main-

Speaker: NA
Text: stream Australians in Western Sydney, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Lindsay. The Treasurer last

Speaker: NA
Text: night, in ‘Locking in the gains, investing in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's future', announced the largest

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in defence investment over the past

Speaker: NA
Text: 30 years for a single budget. Last night it

Speaker: NA
Text: was announced by the Treasurer that defence

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure will increase by 10.6 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: over the next year, which will take it to $22

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. Over the last 11 years, since this

Speaker: NA
Text: government came to office, defence expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture has increased in real terms by 47 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. In fact, when this government came to

Speaker: NA
Text: office in 1996, the deficit inherited from

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party was almost as large as the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence budget in that year alone.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last night an additional $14 billion was

Speaker: NA
Text: committed by this government to defence

Speaker: NA
Text: over the next 10 years, investing not only in

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment but also in people, who are indeed

Speaker: NA
Text: our most important asset. The $2 billion an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced for recruiting and retention in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cludes, for example, a significant increase

Speaker: NA
Text: the home loan subsidy for Defence person-

Speaker: NA
Text: nel, both regulars and reservists. Whereas

Speaker: NA
Text: home loan subsidy was $136 a month for

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible diggers, it is now going to as much

Speaker: NA
Text: as $470 a month tax free. In addition to that,

Speaker: NA
Text: 18,000 nonofficers, the lower ranks in our

Speaker: NA
Text: military, will receive pay increases of up to

Speaker: NA
Text: We are also announcing that we will be

Speaker: NA
Text: going into partnership with schools and the

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector to drive apprenticeships and

Speaker: NA
Text: training in the Australian Defence Force.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will also be a significant increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: advertising to make sure that we not only

Speaker: NA
Text: focus on having a very visible presence for

Speaker: NA
Text: our three service uniforms in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community but also get back to promoting

Speaker: NA
Text: service in the Australian Defence Force on

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis of the values represented by the

Speaker: NA
Text: three uniforms. There is also an additional

Speaker: NA
Text: $100 million for cadets, and I encourage all

Speaker: NA
Text: parents-and my own son was in the Army

Speaker: NA
Text: Cadets-to do what they can where possible

Speaker: NA
Text: to get their kids into cadets. Another 1,000

Speaker: NA
Text: cadets will join as a consequence of this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to that, the Treasurer an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced $6 billion over the next 10 years for

Speaker: NA
Text: the acquisition of 24 FA18F Super Hornets,

Speaker: NA
Text: which will enable us to retire the F111 and

Speaker: NA
Text: safely transition to the Joint Strike Fighter in

Speaker: NA
Text: the next decade, and another $4 billion for

Speaker: NA
Text: spares and repairs-logistics so important to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that we do not get back to Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence force, where we ended up having to

Speaker: NA
Text: cannibalise FA18s on the ground to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: ones in the air flying. It is very important to

Speaker: NA
Text: this government that we never return to the

Speaker: NA
Text: days of the Australian Labor Party. It is very

Speaker: NA
Text: important that Australia has a cutting-edge

Speaker: NA
Text: high-end warfare fighting capability, whether

Speaker: NA
Text: it is antisurface ship or air combat, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time as preparing the Defence Force

Speaker: NA
Text: to for the next decade in security stabilisation,

Speaker: NA
Text: maritime border protection, counterterrorism

Speaker: NA
Text: the and security, and humanitarian relief in our

Speaker: NA
Text: region. This budget delivers on the economic

Speaker: NA
Text: dividend of the last 11 years and makes Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, its interests, its people and its values

Speaker: NA
Text: more secure on our borders, in our region

Speaker: NA
Text: and throughout the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Text: 2.50 pm)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: again to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister now confirm, firstly, that in 2005-

Speaker: NA
Text: 06 education outlays as a percentage of total

Speaker: NA
Text: government outlays stand at 7.7 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, according to the government's own

Speaker: NA
Text: papers; secondly, that in 2010-11 education

Speaker: NA
Text: outlays as a percentage of total government

Speaker: NA
Text: outlays in fact stand at 7.4 per cent of budget

Speaker: NA
Text: according to the government's own papers;

Speaker: NA
Text: and, finally, that 7.4 per cent is less than 7.7

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent? Prime Minister, haven't you simply

Speaker: NA
Text: got your answer to this question fundamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tally and totally wrong?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: No, because the answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to that question is that I confirm all of the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures in the budget paper, and those figures

Speaker: NA
Text: reveal that expenditure on education is going

Speaker: NA
Text: to increase in real terms very significantly

Speaker: NA
Text: over the next three or four years as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: the measures announced last night.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I think the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: is getting at is the proposition that, although

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been an increase in expenditure on

Speaker: NA
Text: education, in other areas of government ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penditure there may have been an even big-

Speaker: NA
Text: ger increase than has occurred in the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: education and, therefore, the percentages of

Speaker: NA
Text: total expenditure from one year might be

Speaker: NA
Text: lower than in a later year, or the other way

Speaker: NA
Text: around. That does not prove, as the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition is trying to allege, that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have cut government spending. The whole

Speaker: NA
Text: point of this tawdry exercise-and it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: tawdry exercise-by the Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position is to try to establish that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced spending on education. We have in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact done the complete reverse, and educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion spending is going to rise over the next

Speaker: NA
Text: four years by more than 3.5 per cent a year in

Speaker: NA
Text: real terms as a result of the measures an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced by the Treasurer last night.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say to the Leader of the Opposition: yes,

Speaker: NA
Text: I confirm these figures; yes, I confirm that

Speaker: NA
Text: from one year to the next, because there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be differential rates of increase in expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture, there may be a situation where a given

Speaker: NA
Text: area as a percentage of total outlays will fall

Speaker: NA
Text: from one year to the next without the real

Speaker: NA
Text: level of that expenditure falling at all. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is nothing remarkable about that, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition is just trying to be

Speaker: NA
Text: too clever by half.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Text: 2.53 pm)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, my question is addressed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Families, Community Services

Speaker: NA
Text: and Indigenous Affairs. Would the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the House how last night's budget

Speaker: NA
Text: will impact on Australian families, from

Speaker: NA
Text: Calamvale to Chelmer and in Annerley,

Speaker: NA
Text: Moorooka, Salisbury, Sunnybank and other

Speaker: NA
Text: places like those, around Australia? What has

Speaker: NA
Text: of been the response to these announcements?

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreton for his question. This budget un-

Speaker: NA
Text: ashamedly puts families at the centre of the

Speaker: NA
Text: priorities of the Howard government. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: an additional $4.5 billion commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian families over the next five years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, there are tax cuts for all Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians who are in the workforce. Those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are retired are getting their superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: tax free but high-income, self-funded retirees

Speaker: NA
Text: will get a tax cut. Beyond that, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken into account childcare costs, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: have dramatically reduced that burden on

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian families.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the member for Moreton, about 6,600

Speaker: NA
Text: families in the Moreton electorate will bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fit. For an average family on a low income

Speaker: NA
Text: with one child in care, that means about

Speaker: NA
Text: $20.50 less in the cost of child care as a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sult of the increase of 13 per cent in child-

Speaker: NA
Text: care benefit. The member for Moreton, along

Speaker: NA
Text: with all other honourable members, might

Speaker: NA
Text: like to tell families that are in child care that

Speaker: NA
Text: this year they will be able to claim two lots

Speaker: NA
Text: of childcare tax rebate. That means they will

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to claim up to $4,000 of their out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: pocket expenses between now and the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: the year. That is as a result of the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government listening to families who said

Speaker: NA
Text: they really appreciated childcare tax rebate,

Speaker: NA
Text: but they would like it to be a bit more

Speaker: NA
Text: timely-and the Howard government has

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have not forgotten those families who

Speaker: NA
Text: have disabled children. We have increased

Speaker: NA
Text: our spending by an additional $62 million to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist some 3,000 families to have their

Speaker: NA
Text: abled children, those kids with slightly

Speaker: NA
Text: higher needs, supported in child care. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that is a really important measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: For those in the bush, sometimes child

Speaker: NA
Text: care becomes quite marginal as far as viabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity is concerned. Regional and rural members

Speaker: NA
Text: on both sides of this House can go back and

Speaker: NA
Text: say that the Howard government is commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting an additional $43 million for those fami-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies so they can access a quality childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: place.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not always get positive comments

Speaker: NA
Text: from ACOSS, but on this particular occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: Lin Hatfield Dodds said she welcomes the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's initiatives on child care and

Speaker: NA
Text: education-the minister for education will be

Speaker: NA
Text: happy to hear that-which are targeted at

Speaker: NA
Text: low-income Australians; not those ‘ Mr Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: battlers' on one-quarter of a million dollars

Speaker: NA
Text: but the real battlers. ACOSS said that, rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than cutting taxes, they were looking for the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to invest in these sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: things-and that is why Lin Hatfield Dodds

Speaker: NA
Text: is right; we have actually cut taxes for those

Speaker: NA
Text: people and we have improved their access to

Speaker: NA
Text: child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are other important families that

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government has paid attention to:

Speaker: NA
Text: for example, older families. In the electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: of Moreton, some 11½ thousand older fami-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies will receive the one-off $500 bonus be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore 30 June this year to help them with their degree?

Speaker: NA
Text: out-of-pocket expenses.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Nelson interjecting-

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Text: Real money, as the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Defence said.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Swan-Does it exist?

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Text: It exists. I know the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lilley thought that the family tax

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement was not real. I can tell him that

Speaker: NA
Text: that was real. This is real. It will be appreci-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated by those families out there, who say that

Speaker: NA
Text: dis- the Howard government is listening and

Speaker: NA
Text: helping them share in the wealth of this na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that they contributed to. In the past, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government has given larger fami-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies-those who have been blessed with trip-

Speaker: NA
Text: lets or quadruplets-a bonus, whereby they

Speaker: NA
Text: got $3,000 for a family with triplets and just

Speaker: NA
Text: over $4,000 for a family with quadruplets.

Speaker: NA
Text: That used to cut out at when the children

Speaker: NA
Text: were six years of age but now it will go right

Speaker: NA
Text: through to 16 years of age or when the chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren turn 18, in their last year of education.

Speaker: NA
Text: It does not matter how old you are, it does

Speaker: NA
Text: not matter how many children you have, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it does not matter if you are struggling with

Speaker: NA
Text: the complexities of being a carer, the How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard government has listened to Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: families. We have shared the prosperity of

Speaker: NA
Text: this nation, and we have allowed everyone to

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit from the strength of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Text: 2.58 pm)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, my question is to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Education, Science and Training. Isn't it the

Speaker: NA
Text: case that last night's budget increased the

Speaker: NA
Text: student HECS contribution, effective from

Speaker: NA
Text: the January 2008, by more than $1,200 per year

Speaker: NA
Text: for new students studying accounting, eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomics or commerce? Doesn't this increase

Speaker: NA
Text: the student HECS contribution by nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: $200 million over the life of a three-year

Speaker: Ms JULIE BISHOP
Text: I can confirm that

Speaker: NA
Text: under a Howard government no accounting

Speaker: NA
Text: student will be paying $200 million for an

Speaker: NA
Text: accounting degree!

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members-Ha, ha!

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Members on my right!

Speaker: NA
Text: Order!

Speaker: Ms JULIE BISHOP
Text: Last night in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget the Treasurer announced in the $1.7

Speaker: NA
Text: billion higher education package that some

Speaker: NA
Text: $560 million in extra funding would be de-

Speaker: NA
Text: livered to universities for courses such as

Speaker: NA
Text: science and maths and engineering and allied

Speaker: NA
Text: health and medicine and dentistry. In maths

Speaker: NA
Text: and science there will be an increase of some

Speaker: NA
Text: $2,729 per place; in allied health, some

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,889; and in engineering, science and sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: veying and clinical psychology, $2,729. So

Speaker: NA
Text: all told, that is $560 million in increased

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for specific courses that are part of

Speaker: NA
Text: our national priorities. In the case of ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: counting and commerce, we have put that

Speaker: NA
Text: into the same category as law because that

Speaker: NA
Text: reflects the cost of delivery of that course,

Speaker: NA
Text: reflects the demand and it reflects the gross

Speaker: NA
Text: lifetime earnings of accounting graduates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Universities can decide for themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not there should be any change to

Speaker: NA
Text: the HECS.

Speaker: NA
Text: Vocational and Further Education

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Text: 3.00 pm)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Vocational and Further

Speaker: NA
Text: Education. Would the minister inform the

Speaker: NA
Text: House how the government has continued to

Speaker: NA
Text: invest substantially in vocational and further

Speaker: NA
Text: education? Minister, are there any alternative

Speaker: NA
Text: policies and what is the government's re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse?

Speaker: Mr ROBB
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowman for his question and for his very

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine interest in this area. I might begin

Speaker: NA
Text: with the alternative policies, because there I

Speaker: NA
Text: can be brief. In Labor's much touted Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Revolution document, on skills needs,

Speaker: NA
Text: the so-called skills crisis, and vocational and

Speaker: NA
Text: technical education the sum total of discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion was four lonely paragraphs-and not

Speaker: NA
Text: one idea amongst them. Yet the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lilley last night was out asserting that Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: had set the agenda on vocational and techni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal education. Fortunately, we have not

Speaker: NA
Text: waited for Labor to tell us what to do, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: can report for the benefit of the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lilley that in 1996 there were 1,500 people

Speaker: NA
Text: doing apprenticeships in his electorate. He

Speaker: NA
Text: can now go back and report to his electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: that today there are 4,280 people doing ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prenticeships-nearly a threefold increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 11 years. So we have done a lot. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have now spent around $3 billion a year

Speaker: NA
Text: compared with $1 billion 10 years ago when

Speaker: NA
Text: we took over office. That is a 99 per cent real

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in spending on vocational and tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nical education in the last 11 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet we have a rapidly ageing population

Speaker: NA
Text: and the experience of well over a decade of

Speaker: NA
Text: uninterrupted economic growth. This means

Speaker: NA
Text: it that we have further challenges. That is why

Speaker: NA
Text: last night we made a further substantial in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment of $668 million in vocational and

Speaker: NA
Text: further education. That adds to the $837 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion that we announced last November, just

Speaker: NA
Text: six months ago, for the Skills for the Future

Speaker: NA
Text: package. So, in total, in the last six months

Speaker: NA
Text: the government has announced $1.5 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: for technical and further education.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last night's announced initiatives were

Speaker: NA
Text: aimed at three things: improving the status,

Speaker: NA
Text: improving the opportunity, and raising the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of vocational and technical education

Speaker: NA
Text: across our workforce. Specifically the meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures included, in the trades areas facing a

Speaker: NA
Text: skills shortage, a tax-free $1,000 wage top-

Speaker: NA
Text: up to every firstand second-year apprentice

Speaker: NA
Text: under 30 years of age. On top of that, every

Speaker: NA
Text: firstand second-year apprentice, without

Speaker: NA
Text: age restriction, will get a fee voucher worth

Speaker: NA
Text: up to $500 a go towards their TAFE or other

Speaker: NA
Text: training fees. When you put that together

Speaker: NA
Text: with a trade scholarship, each firstand sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ond-year apprentice across the country in

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of trade skill shortage will get a total of

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,500 a year as a tax-free top-up for their

Speaker: NA
Text: wages and a $500 contribution towards their

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE fees-nearly $2,000, or up to $2,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: for every firstand second-year apprentice.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government also announced the es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tablishment of three more Australian techni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal colleges, one in southern Brisbane, one

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Sydney and one in northern Perth.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means that in the five largest cities we

Speaker: NA
Text: will have two technical colleges across the

Speaker: NA
Text: country to combine with the other 18 techni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal colleges in regional and other cities in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Furthermore, we announced nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: $60 million to develop fast track apprentice-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships. We have extended fee help to full fee

Speaker: NA
Text: paying students pursuing diploma and ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vanced diploma courses through the VET

Speaker: NA
Text: system and we have provided further assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance for our Indigenous community and for

Speaker: NA
Text: people with disabilities to enter the work-

Speaker: NA
Text: force. So, along with the tax cuts and the

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare and the superannuation initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: last night, these new measures will further

Speaker: NA
Text: expand our productive capacity at a time

Speaker: NA
Text: when the economy is at full stretch.

Speaker: NA
Text: Higher Education

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Text: 3.06 pm)-My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is again to the Minister for Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, Science and Training. Isn't it the case

Speaker: NA
Text: that the annual income stream of $300 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion from the Higher Education Endowment

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund for each of Australia's 38 universities

Speaker: NA
Text: would mean that each university would only

Speaker: NA
Text: receive, on average, an annual payment of $8

Speaker: NA
Text: million? Given that important teaching and

Speaker: NA
Text: research infrastructure like the medical re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search centre at the ANU in Canberra cost

Speaker: NA
Text: $125 million, how can the government claim

Speaker: NA
Text: that this will make up for 10 years of neglect

Speaker: NA
Text: of our universities?

Speaker: Ms JULIE BISHOP
Text: I thank the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Perth for his question. He obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: does not understand that the endowment

Speaker: NA
Text: fund is on top of what the Australian gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment already provides universities for

Speaker: NA
Text: capital works and research facilities. Last

Speaker: NA
Text: year alone the Australian government pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided over $240 million for capital and $460

Speaker: NA
Text: million for research facilities. What the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer announced last night is an endow-

Speaker: NA
Text: in ment fund that will be invested, with the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come from that endowment fund being dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributed to universities on top of what we

Speaker: NA
Text: already fund. This is an unprecedented level

Speaker: NA
Text: of investment in Australian universities. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party could only dream of

Speaker: NA
Text: such an initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Climate Change

Speaker: Mrs VALE
Text: 3.07 pm)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed to the Minister for the Environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and Water Resources. Would the minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter inform the House of the recent budget

Speaker: NA
Text: announcements to boost initiatives on cli-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate change and the environment? Are there

Speaker: NA
Text: any alternative approaches?

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Hughes for her question and acknowl-

Speaker: NA
Text: edge her very keen interest in environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: and water matters. Last night's budget con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinues the Howard government's record lev-

Speaker: NA
Text: els of environment spending. Over the last 11

Speaker: NA
Text: years the government has invested almost

Speaker: NA
Text: $20 billion to protect the environment and in

Speaker: NA
Text: the next year we have committed $4.3 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: in funding to tackle the pressing issues of

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change, water scarcity and natural

Speaker: NA
Text: resource management. At the centre of the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget-the environmental part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget-is the $10 billion National Plan for

Speaker: NA
Text: Water Security.

Speaker: NA
Text: Water scarcity is a global problem. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are many countries facing water scarcity

Speaker: NA
Text: problems as severe as Australia's. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: country in the world which has a comprehen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive national plan to tackle water scarcity

Speaker: NA
Text: like Australia does. It is thanks to the leader-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship of the Prime Minister, the leadership of

Speaker: NA
Text: this government, that we have that $10 bil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion plan, that we have a coordinated effort

Speaker: NA
Text: that is capable of restoring efficiency to our

Speaker: NA
Text: irrigation systems, restoring environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: flows. That $10 billion plan has been wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: comed around Australia and admired around

Speaker: NA
Text: the world, but it is still not enjoying the sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port of the Labor government in Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the grassroots level, saving water and

Speaker: NA
Text: setting an example of using water efficiently,

Speaker: NA
Text: is vital. We have committed-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Gillard interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Deputy Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition is warned!

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: $200 million towards

Speaker: NA
Text: community water grants. These provide the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to save a considerable amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: water, but far more importantly than that-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Gillard interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The deputy leader has

Speaker: NA
Text: been warned.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: they provide the op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity for schoolchildren and communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties to understand how water can be saved

Speaker: NA
Text: and preserved. On climate change, the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian government, once again, is showing

Speaker: NA
Text: global leadership. In the budget we provide

Speaker: NA
Text: for our global initiative on forests and cli-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate. This is the first substantial national

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to attack the global problem of

Speaker: NA
Text: deforestation. The opposition like to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about global warming but they will not rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ognise that it is a global problem. A tonne of

Speaker: NA
Text: CO2 that goes into the atmosphere in China

Speaker: NA
Text: does as much damage as a tonne of CO2 that

Speaker: NA
Text: goes into the atmosphere here. We are tack-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling that globally with our global initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: on forests and climate.

Speaker: NA
Text: At home, we are genuinely doubling the

Speaker: NA
Text: solar panel rebate. We all remember that the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kingsford Smith said he was

Speaker: NA
Text: doubling the rebate, but he did not know that

Speaker: NA
Text: double meant twice as much. That is sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: important. Two times four equals eight. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have doubled the rebate from $4 a watt and a

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum of $4,000 to $8 a watt and a

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum of $8,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Gillard interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: will resume his seat. I have continually

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn to the attention of the Deputy Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition that she should not be in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terjecting. She has been warned. She ignores

Speaker: NA
Text: that warning. She will remove herself from

Speaker: NA
Text: the chamber under standing order 94(a).

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Lalor then left the cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Hughes asked me to consider alternative

Speaker: NA
Text: policies. There are no alternative policies on

Speaker: NA
Text: water from the opposition. The $10 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: national plan had no counterpart in the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party's repertoire. When it was announced

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Kingsford Smith said-and I

Speaker: NA
Text: was sitting right here, listening to him in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tently-‘It's Labor Party policy.' I could not

Speaker: NA
Text: find it, and neither could he. He had as much

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty proving that misstatement as he did

Speaker: NA
Text: with the solar panel rebate. The opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: policy on climate change is a unilateral 60

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent reduction in emissions in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: by 2050. It proposes to do that regardless of

Speaker: NA
Text: what the rest of the world does. If the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Kingsford Smith had read the IPCC

Speaker: NA
Text: report published recently, he would be aware

Speaker: NA
Text: of the lengthy discussion on the problems of

Speaker: NA
Text: one country imposing restrictions and the

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon emissions just leaking over to other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. There would be no gain to the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. There would be massive economic

Speaker: NA
Text: loss in that country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Global warming needs a global solution.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are committed to a global solution and

Speaker: NA
Text: we are working towards it. We are not going

Speaker: NA
Text: to devastate the Australian economy in a fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tile, ideological gesture that is more about

Speaker: NA
Text: gratifying the prejudices of the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingsford Smith and his colleagues than

Speaker: NA
Text: achieving the outcomes the world needs.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Mr Speaker, I ask that fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE:

Speaker: NA
Text: ADDITIONAL ANSWERS

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: Higgins-Treasurer)

Speaker: NA
Text: (3.13 pm)- Mr Speaker, I seek the indul-

Speaker: NA
Text: gence of the chair to add to an answer.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The minister may pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceed.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: In the course of mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a statement about productivity and the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of AWAs in the mining industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Leader of the Opposition claimed

Speaker: NA
Text: that she had never called Sir Rod Eddington

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘another voice'. She claimed that in parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I want to table the Australian of Fri-

Speaker: NA
Text: day, 4 May 2007-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Albanese- Mr Speaker, I raise a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order. This is an abuse; this is not adding

Speaker: NA
Text: to an answer.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Manager of Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition Business will resume his seat. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer has sought indulgence to add to an

Speaker: NA
Text: answer and he has the call. I call the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: which quotes Ms Gil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lard saying the following:

Speaker: NA
Text: I am happy to talk to Rod about ... but that would

Speaker: NA
Text: just be another voice in the voices we've got in

Speaker: NA
Text: the business community.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Treasurer will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sume his seat. The Manager of Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: Business on another point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Albanese-He is responding to an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terjection, Mr Speaker, and it is entirely out

Speaker: NA
Text: of order.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Manager of Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition Business will resume his seat. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer has sought to add to an answer. He

Speaker: NA
Text: is in order. I call the Treasurer.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: That is a direct quote

Speaker: NA
Text: of Ms Gillard referring to Sir Rod Eddington

Speaker: NA
Text: as ‘another voice' from the front page of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian, 4 May 2007, and I table it.

Speaker: NA
Text: DOCUMENTS

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House) (3.15 pm)-Documents are tabled as

Speaker: NA
Text: listed in the schedule circulated to honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members. Details of the documents will

Speaker: NA
Text: be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings

Speaker: NA
Text: and I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House take note of the following

Speaker: NA
Text: documents:

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment, Workplace Relations and Work-

Speaker: NA
Text: force Participation-Standing Committee-

Speaker: NA
Text: Report-Shifting gears: Employment in the

Speaker: NA
Text: automotive components manufacturing indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try-Government response.

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration Act 1958-Section 486O-Assessment

Speaker: NA
Text: of detention arrangements-Government re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse to the Commonwealth Ombudsman's

Speaker: NA
Text: statements-Personal identifiers 126/07 to

Speaker: NA
Text: Surveillance Devices Act 2004-Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Ombudsman's reports on inspection of surveil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lance device records for the period 1 July to 31

Speaker: NA
Text: December 2006 (Australian Crime Commission,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Federal Police).

Speaker: NA
Text: Telecommunications (Interception and Access)

Speaker: NA
Text: Act-Report for 2005-06.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: journed.

Speaker: NA
Text: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: I have received a letter

Speaker: NA
Text: from the honorable member for Lilley pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posing that a definite matter of public impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance be submitted to the House for discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The inadequacy of the 2007 Budget to secure

Speaker: NA
Text: future economic prosperity by addressing the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation's long term challenges of flagging produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity growth and dangerous climate change.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call upon those members who approve of

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed discussion to rise in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than the number of members re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired by the standing orders having risen in

Speaker: NA
Text: their places-

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Lilley) (3.16 pm)-It is my

Speaker: NA
Text: privilege to support this matter of public im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance on the failure of the 2007 budget to

Speaker: NA
Text: secure future economic prosperity by ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressing the nation's long-term challenges of

Speaker: NA
Text: flagging productivity growth and climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change. I want to start by thanking the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer for doing something that Labor has

Speaker: NA
Text: been doing for a very long period. For a long

Speaker: NA
Text: time, Labor has been talking about education

Speaker: NA
Text: and climate change, two issues which go to

Speaker: NA
Text: the very heart of our economic prosperity

Speaker: NA
Text: and our survival as a nation, two issues

Speaker: NA
Text: which are absolutely central to the future of

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Education is central to boosting productiv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity in Australia, and lifting productivity is

Speaker: NA
Text: way we can guarantee rising living standards

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond the mining boom. The recent Inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: generational report delivered that message

Speaker: NA
Text: as well-that lifting productivity is the key

Speaker: NA
Text: to future wealth creation beyond the mining

Speaker: NA
Text: boom. We all know that two key elements of

Speaker: NA
Text: lifting productivity are education and modern

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. They are absolutely central.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are just as central as climate change,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has to be addressed in an absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive way. If we do not address

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change, future prosperity will be

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened. So thank you, Treasurer, for in-

Speaker: NA
Text: serting two words which were not in last

Speaker: NA
Text: year's budget speech-productivity and cli-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate change. Those two words were missing

Speaker: NA
Text: completely-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Downer-Three words: productive,

Speaker: NA
Text: climate, change. You are supposed to be the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Treasurer!

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Two concepts, three words,

Speaker: NA
Text: both concepts missing from last year's

Speaker: NA
Text: budget speech. In fact, climate change has

Speaker: NA
Text: never appeared in any of the Treasurer's 11

Speaker: NA
Text: budget speeches. We know this government

Speaker: NA
Text: has disinvested in education over 11 years,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that proves that productivity has not

Speaker: NA
Text: been central to the government's agenda dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing those 11 long years. Labor says it is time

Speaker: NA
Text: our nation started using the budget to invest

Speaker: NA
Text: in the future of the nation, rather than simply

Speaker: NA
Text: using it to buy the government's way back

Speaker: NA
Text: into power. So why are education and cli-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate change now the centrepiece of this

Speaker: NA
Text: year's budget? It is pretty clear: it is politics,

Speaker: NA
Text: clear and simple. We have a stale, reactive,

Speaker: NA
Text: slow-on-the-uptake government which has

Speaker: NA
Text: decided to give itself an extreme makeover.

Speaker: NA
Text: Watching the Treasurer trying to give himself

Speaker: NA
Text: an extreme makeover is extremely humor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous. It is not very comfortable. The Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: is not comfortable talking about climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change and he most certainly is not comfort-

Speaker: NA
Text: the able talking about education. He is trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: camouflage the government's complacency

Speaker: NA
Text: on these key issues, which is driving a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: mood for change in the community. The

Speaker: NA
Text: community sees this government as being

Speaker: NA
Text: stuck in the past, complacently relying on the

Speaker: NA
Text: commodity boom rather than putting in place

Speaker: NA
Text: a reform program to lift productivity and to

Speaker: NA
Text: create wealth beyond the mining boom. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is why we say this budget is a re-election

Speaker: NA
Text: budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most certainly it is not a reform budget. It

Speaker: NA
Text: does not take a rocket scientist to see what

Speaker: NA
Text: has been happening here. Kevin Rudd has

Speaker: NA
Text: offered a vision for the future, a package of

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms that will prepare our economy for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future challenges we will face. This vi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion is striking a chord with the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community after 11 years of a government

Speaker: NA
Text: that is simply stuck in the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costello thinks he is a very clever boy.

Speaker: NA
Text: He knows that Labor's vision for the future

Speaker: NA
Text: is striking a chord so he is scrambling to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: invent himself before this year's election. All

Speaker: NA
Text: of a sudden, the language Labor have been

Speaker: NA
Text: using constantly appears in the Treasurer's

Speaker: NA
Text: words. His budget is about securing the fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture. Who has been talking about that? His

Speaker: NA
Text: budget contains huge reforms. Who has been

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about this? When Labor announced

Speaker: NA
Text: our education revolution, it struck a chord,

Speaker: NA
Text: and next thing we have the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: calling for an education revolution. Why?

Speaker: NA
Text: Because this government has been threatened

Speaker: NA
Text: electorally. It has not moved because there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a fundamental problem in our economy; it

Speaker: NA
Text: has moved because the election is around the

Speaker: NA
Text: corner and there is a very strong mood for

Speaker: NA
Text: change in the Australian community.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need reform. Despite rivers of gold

Speaker: NA
Text: flowing from the mining boom in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: years, this government has not been invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in the nation's capacity. Economic re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form and productivity growth have faltered

Speaker: NA
Text: on this Treasurer's watch. Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: growth has fallen from 3.2 per cent to 2.2 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent in the latest productivity cycle. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: fallen even lower since then.

Speaker: NA
Text: This slowdown has seen us slip further

Speaker: NA
Text: behind the productivity leaders in an increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly competitive global environment. In

Speaker: NA
Text: comparative terms, we have now almost

Speaker: NA
Text: completely lost the productivity gains asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciated with the economic reforms imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mented over the 1980s and 1990s. Of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: as we demonstrated in question time, the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget papers reveal that our flagging pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity growth is not expected to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: anytime soon. In fact, the forecasts on page

Speaker: NA
Text: 1-5 of Budget Paper No. 1 reveal zero pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity growth in 2006-07 and declining

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity growth at the end of the next

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: If this is a budget that is about the future,

Speaker: NA
Text: that is designed to lift the productive capac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity of the economy, why does the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: forecast declining productivity growth? Why

Speaker: NA
Text: does it forecast that? In fact, in the Intergen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erational report released last month, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government revised down its projection of

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity growth over this decade from

Speaker: NA
Text: 1.7 per cent to just 1.5 per cent. This is less

Speaker: NA
Text: than half the rate of productivity growth

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved over the 1990s. So this government

Speaker: NA
Text: has a poor record.

Speaker: NA
Text: We as a nation need to urgently turn

Speaker: NA
Text: around our flagging productivity growth if

Speaker: NA
Text: we are to build prosperity for the future and

Speaker: NA
Text: to build it beyond the mining boom, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: why this country urgently needs an education

Speaker: NA
Text: revolution. We welcome the education initia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives in this budget; they are a useful contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution after 11 years of disinvestment. But

Speaker: NA
Text: with the best global conditions in over 30

Speaker: NA
Text: years, and the windfall from the mining

Speaker: NA
Text: boom, the government should have already

Speaker: NA
Text: built a world-class education system. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, they have not been doing that.

Speaker: NA
Text: These budget papers show that expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture as a percentage of GDP has fallen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, no matter how much you try to

Speaker: NA
Text: drag a dead cat across the figures you pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented in question time, it has fallen. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: fallen over 11 years. Even with the new

Speaker: NA
Text: spending in this budget, education spending

Speaker: NA
Text: will fall as a proportion of the total budget

Speaker: NA
Text: over the forward estimates. That was demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strated comprehensively during question

Speaker: NA
Text: time in the questioning of the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Leader of the Opposition. We are slip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ping behind our competitors. Overall, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's investment in education as a propor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of GDP ranks behind 17 other OECD

Speaker: NA
Text: economies, including Poland, Hungary and

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand.

Speaker: NA
Text: So whilst these budget measures are wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: come, while they are useful, they are a long

Speaker: NA
Text: way from the education revolution needed to

Speaker: NA
Text: secure our future. Just consider this compari-

Speaker: NA
Text: son: this budget commits $3.5 billion to its

Speaker: NA
Text: education and skills package over four years.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is roughly the same amount committed

Speaker: NA
Text: in one-off pre-election payments to go out in

Speaker: NA
Text: the next eight weeks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costello-Are you against them?

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: We are absolutely for them,

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer. Most notably, the budget fails to

Speaker: NA
Text: invest in high-quality universal preschool

Speaker: NA
Text: education for all four-year-olds, to give them

Speaker: NA
Text: the best start possible. As we know, Labor is

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to a $450 million package to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide play based learning for all four-year-

Speaker: NA
Text: olds. Labor has also committed up to $200

Speaker: NA
Text: million for 260 new childcare centres on

Speaker: NA
Text: school sites.

Speaker: NA
Text: We welcome the measures on apprentices,

Speaker: NA
Text: but there is nothing in this package which

Speaker: NA
Text: shows that the government comprehends the

Speaker: NA
Text: magnitude of the challenge before us and the

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of the education revolution we require

Speaker: NA
Text: if we are to deal with declining productivity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has established its Higher

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Endowment Fund. That is a wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: come initiative because the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: neglected this area for too long, but its way

Speaker: NA
Text: of paying for it is interesting. Its way of

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for it undermines the government's case

Speaker: NA
Text: against Labor's national plan for high-speed

Speaker: NA
Text: broadband. The government is proposing to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for this measure by taking part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus that would otherwise have gone to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Future Fund. And, just as the education

Speaker: NA
Text: endowment is an investment, so is Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: high-speed broadband initiative. The Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer simply can't have it both ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: That brings us to broadband. We saw in

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament during question time that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister simply does not get broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: band. He does not comprehend how impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant broadband is for lifting productivity in

Speaker: NA
Text: this economy and that this country urgently

Speaker: NA
Text: needs a solution so that we can get high-

Speaker: NA
Text: speed broadband to all Australians. Its im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance to business and to families is simply

Speaker: NA
Text: not comprehended by this Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: That brings us to tax cuts, because the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts in this budget are welcome. They do

Speaker: NA
Text: start to tackle some of the worst disincen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives to workforce participation. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer will well recall, it has been Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House that has been making the case

Speaker: NA
Text: constantly for taxation reform to ease the

Speaker: NA
Text: high effective marginal tax rates which have

Speaker: NA
Text: been hitting second-income earners, who are

Speaker: NA
Text: predominantly women. All of a sudden, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is another conversion from the Treasurer. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has discovered part-time workers, he has

Speaker: NA
Text: finally discovered they are women and he

Speaker: NA
Text: has finally discovered that they, too, deserve

Speaker: NA
Text: an incentive, like everybody else in the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: system. Of course, that has taken 11 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we certainly welcome these tax cuts, and

Speaker: NA
Text: we also welcome the fact that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: staged, because to stage them will minimise

Speaker: NA
Text: the risk of inflationary pressures. But these

Speaker: NA
Text: tax cuts do not even hand back all the addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional tax that the government is collecting as

Speaker: NA
Text: a consequence of the mining boom. Despite

Speaker: NA
Text: the tax cuts, the government will still collect

Speaker: NA
Text: paymore than $10 billion more in income taxes,

Speaker: NA
Text: excluding company taxes, from 2007-08 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009-10 than originally anticipated before

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a high-taxing, high-spending gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment. What is important here is a stable

Speaker: NA
Text: macroeconomic environment. Labor is

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to disciplined fiscal policy. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are committed to running budget surpluses

Speaker: NA
Text: over the medium term, to not increasing tax

Speaker: NA
Text: as a proportion of GDP and to meeting our

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments by reprioritising spending in

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget and cutting out waste.

Speaker: NA
Text: That brings us to climate change, because

Speaker: NA
Text: there is not a comprehensive program that

Speaker: NA
Text: this country needs being put in place to com-

Speaker: NA
Text: bat climate change. We know that the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer is a well-known climate change sceptic.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know the record of the Prime Minister;

Speaker: NA
Text: we know the record of the industry minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know the view of the Treasury-that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government does not get it when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: combating climate change and dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: problems in water. The government simply

Speaker: NA
Text: does not get this, and we know that from the

Speaker: NA
Text: speech given by Treasury Secretary Ken

Speaker: NA
Text: Henry over a month ago. He blew the whistle

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Treasurer, he blew the whistle on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister and he blew the whistle on

Speaker: NA
Text: the cabinet about their inattention

Speaker: NA
Text: change and water problems and their central

Speaker: NA
Text: importance to wealth creation in this com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity. That whistle was well and truly

Speaker: NA
Text: blown by the government's chief economic

Speaker: NA
Text: adviser, who pinged them for what they

Speaker: NA
Text: are-completely irresponsible when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to dealing with one of the most serious issues

Speaker: NA
Text: which goes to the heart of future economic

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity, job creation and environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainability.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why we do not have an emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: trading scheme. That is why we do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: a serious response to renewable energy. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is why we do not have a serious response to

Speaker: NA
Text: demand management. All of these things are

Speaker: NA
Text: missing, but no doubt they will come-and

Speaker: NA
Text: why? Because Labor under Kevin Rudd and

Speaker: NA
Text: Peter Garrett, and also the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Grayndler, have been putting out compre-

Speaker: NA
Text: hensive plans to combat dangerous climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change. We have left the government for

Speaker: NA
Text: dead and they are so embarrassed that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to be forced to follow in the

Speaker: NA
Text: months ahead. It will be really exciting to

Speaker: NA
Text: watch the backflips and the U-turns and so

Speaker: NA
Text: on.

Speaker: NA
Text: That brings us finally to where this econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy should be going. The Treasurer would

Speaker: NA
Text: have us all believe that the economic reform

Speaker: NA
Text: process starts and ends with him. The reality

Speaker: NA
Text: is that much of our current wealth owes a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: to the reforms implemented by the Hawke

Speaker: NA
Text: and Keating governments. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: quote an eminent authority on this: the Sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: retary of the Treasury-the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: pre-eminent economic adviser. This is what

Speaker: NA
Text: he had to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: That macro performance owes much to decades

Speaker: NA
Text: of reform that have improved monetary, fiscal and

Speaker: NA
Text: structural policy frameworks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Much of our recent macroeconomic and fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: success is based on past reforms, assisted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of trade. A significant proportion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: to climate latter may be transitory.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Secretary of the Treasury is warning all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians that the government is not pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared for the future beyond the mining boom

Speaker: NA
Text: and has not put in place the essential reforms

Speaker: NA
Text: required to lift productivity and create wealth

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond the mining boom. That is the warn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing from the Secretary of the Treasury; it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: damning indictment of the performance of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Treasurer and the performance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government. During this time, a

Speaker: NA
Text: time of plenty, it has been raining gold bars.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been substantial increases in na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional income. Why haven't we taken the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to create a First-World, first-

Speaker: NA
Text: class education and training system so we

Speaker: NA
Text: can compete in our region and become even

Speaker: NA
Text: more prosperous and wealthy? Why has the

Speaker: NA
Text: government not done that? Because it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been complacent, tired and stuck in the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: Higgins-Treasurer)

Speaker: NA
Text: (3.31 pm)-Members will recall a former

Speaker: NA
Text: National Secretary of the ALP, Gary Gray,

Speaker: NA
Text: complaining that Labor was increasingly

Speaker: NA
Text: relying on what he called ‘white-bread poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticians' who were coming into parliament-

Speaker: NA
Text: people who had no real experience outside of

Speaker: NA
Text: politics and were bland and insubstantial.

Speaker: NA
Text: That criticism that Gary Gray made, without

Speaker: NA
Text: naming whom he had in mind, was made in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to Mr Swan, the member for Lilley,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Mr Smith, the member for Perth-two

Speaker: NA
Text: people who came into this parliament out of

Speaker: NA
Text: the ALP machine and had experience in fo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cus groups and polling but never really had

Speaker: NA
Text: any great interest in policy or, indeed, what

Speaker: NA
Text: makes economic policy work.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you wanted a demonstration of that

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism that Gary Gray made of the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Lilley, you would have seen it in the

Speaker: NA
Text: speech that he just made-completely insub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantial, offering nothing except rhetorical

Speaker: NA
Text: lines, the kind of rhetorical lines that he

Speaker: NA
Text: would have got a focus group to put together

Speaker: NA
Text: and then retailed around to the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: as lines to use in relation to the budget. The

Speaker: NA
Text: focus group that he obviously got together

Speaker: NA
Text: was the source of this media release, which

Speaker: NA
Text: just about says it all in terms of the depth

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking of the member for Lilley. I guess

Speaker: NA
Text: just about every word that he used in that

Speaker: NA
Text: speech came from this press release in one

Speaker: NA
Text: form or another. The press release itself came

Speaker: NA
Text: from the focus group, and it illustrates really

Speaker: NA
Text: how insubstantial Labor has now become in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to economic policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Normally in a budget reply a shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer would stand up and say: ‘These

Speaker: NA
Text: will be the macro effects of what you did and

Speaker: NA
Text: this is why they are wrong. Maybe the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget surplus, instead of being one per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of GDP, should have been 0.1 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: GDP or maybe it should have been two per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. This is what we think about the eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic forecast. Your economic forecast for

Speaker: NA
Text: growth of 3¾ per cent is wrong because we

Speaker: NA
Text: think household consumption will not be as

Speaker: NA
Text: strong as you are saying, or we think that net

Speaker: NA
Text: exports will detract from growth to a larger

Speaker: NA
Text: degree. Here's what we think about your in-

Speaker: NA
Text: flation forecast. We think that, given pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: arising out of the drought or given pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: arising from international oil prices-

Speaker: NA
Text: because we do not agree with those assump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions-your inflation target will be wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: Here's what we would have done on tax cuts.

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe that you have cut tax too far

Speaker: NA
Text: down the scale or too far up the scale or you

Speaker: NA
Text: haven't cut it enough. You should have

Speaker: NA
Text: changed the mix to move tax cuts off income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax and maybe put them on business tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: Here's what we think you should have had

Speaker: NA
Text: your investment in. We don't think an en-

Speaker: NA
Text: dowment fund is the right way to go because

Speaker: NA
Text: it is a capital fund. We would have gone with

Speaker: NA
Text: recurrent funding; we would have gone for

Speaker: NA
Text: the current amount. Mr Speaker, here's what

Speaker: NA
Text: an alternative government would do.'

Speaker: NA
Text: But you will never hear that from the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lilley. You will never hear it

Speaker: NA
Text: because I do not think he has ever really un-

Speaker: NA
Text: derstood the nature of economic policy in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and he certainly has not done the

Speaker: NA
Text: of work. To him it is a question of getting a fo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cus group, running a line and moving on be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore anybody actually scratches for things

Speaker: NA
Text: that are substantive underneath. He is some-

Speaker: NA
Text: body who is quite voluble, but there is never

Speaker: NA
Text: any substance behind it. There was never

Speaker: NA
Text: actually any substance in his reply. In all of

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget replies I have heard from five

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow treasurers now, that would be the

Speaker: NA
Text: weakest without question. We had Gareth

Speaker: NA
Text: Evans, Simon Crean, Bob MCMullan and

Speaker: NA
Text: Mark Latham, but I do not think I have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: a weaker budget reply than the one we have

Speaker: NA
Text: just heard. I think we can deal with it pretty

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly.

Speaker: NA
Text: He welcomed the Higher Education En-

Speaker: NA
Text: dowment Fund, he welcomed the tax cuts

Speaker: NA
Text: and the fact that they were staged and he

Speaker: NA
Text: welcomed the apprenticeships. He welcomed

Speaker: NA
Text: those measures that are going to be done be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore 30 June, so everything that was done

Speaker: NA
Text: was right. I do not think there was anything

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government did that he said was

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong, but I think the essence of it was that

Speaker: NA
Text: we should have spent more in every area of

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget and ended up with a bigger sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: plus. I think that was the outcome: ‘You

Speaker: NA
Text: should have cut tax, spent more in every area

Speaker: NA
Text: of the budget and ended up with a bigger

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus.' Why didn't I think of that for a pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal? We should have spent more on educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, we should have spent more on skills,

Speaker: NA
Text: we should have spent more on climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change, we should have spent more on the

Speaker: NA
Text: environment, we should have cut tax and we

Speaker: NA
Text: should have had more left over.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the kind of thing that you would

Speaker: NA
Text: try and get away with at an ALP branch

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting as a machine man, but every now

Speaker: NA
Text: and then you are confronted with facts. The

Speaker: NA
Text: fact of the matter is that, when you are man-

Speaker: NA
Text: aging a $240 billion budget, there are more

Speaker: NA
Text: demands than can possibly be funded. Some-

Speaker: NA
Text: times you have to be able to say no. Manag-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a federal budget requires a bit of

Speaker: NA
Text: strength; you have to be able to say no and

Speaker: NA
Text: sometimes you have to be able to say no to a

Speaker: NA
Text: minister. Sometimes you have to be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: say no to a whole government. Sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: you have to make very hard choices if you

Speaker: NA
Text: want to get a particular outcome, and when

Speaker: NA
Text: you want to get that particular outcome it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not enough to convene a focus group and ask

Speaker: NA
Text: for a slick line or an insubstantial criticism.

Speaker: NA
Text: actually takes hard assessment and hard

Speaker: NA
Text: work.

Speaker: NA
Text: The place where Australia is now did not

Speaker: NA
Text: just drop out of the sky. It was not as if a

Speaker: NA
Text: cloud was suddenly unleashed on Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: or, as he said, ‘Oh, gold bars just started

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on Australia.' If the member for Lilley

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks that about economic management, it

Speaker: NA
Text: illustrates how ill equipped he is for the great

Speaker: NA
Text: role of being in government. If he believes-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I do not think he believes it for a mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-that you balance a budget, reform a

Speaker: NA
Text: tax system, improve industrial relations, pay

Speaker: NA
Text: off $96 billion worth of debt or set up a Fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture Fund and it is all just some kind of fluke

Speaker: NA
Text: then he is less prepared for government than

Speaker: NA
Text: I suspect many of us, even in our worst

Speaker: NA
Text: nightmares, thought would have been the

Speaker: NA
Text: case.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the things that the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lilley said in his speech is that of course

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor is committed to budget surpluses.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why would he say that? The focus groups

Speaker: NA
Text: would have said, ‘You've got to show that

Speaker: NA
Text: you're committed to balanced budgets.' It is

Speaker: NA
Text: easily said. Anybody can say that, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: would ask him this question: as an adviser to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party and a Labor Party staffer in

Speaker: NA
Text: all those years when Labor were in govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment between 1990 and 1996 when they ran

Speaker: NA
Text: consecutive budget deficits, if he was so

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to surpluses why weren't there

Speaker: NA
Text: any? I think it is a fair question: why weren't

Speaker: NA
Text: there any?

Speaker: NA
Text: For the sake of the record I think we ought

Speaker: NA
Text: not to actually listen to the words, we ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to listen to the deeds, because in 1990-91 the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government deficit was 2.8 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of GDP. In 1991-92, it was 3.9 per cent; in

Speaker: NA
Text: cent; in 1994-95, 1.9 per cent; and in 1995-

Speaker: NA
Text: 96, one per cent. So that is six straight defi-

Speaker: NA
Text: It cits, the highest of which was four per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of GDP. If we had had a deficit of four per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of GDP in the budget I brought down

Speaker: NA
Text: last night it would have been $40 billion. We

Speaker: NA
Text: had a budget surplus of $10 billion. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: had had a budget deficit of four per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: rain- GDP, it would have been a $50 billion turn-

Speaker: NA
Text: around, a $40 billion deficit.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, in the mind of the member for Lilley,

Speaker: NA
Text: what you actually do in government is not

Speaker: NA
Text: the important thing; what is important is

Speaker: NA
Text: what the focus groups demand that you do,

Speaker: NA
Text: and you reassure them without actually get-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting into the substantive policy debate. I

Speaker: NA
Text: guess the illustration that brought this home

Speaker: NA
Text: to me more than any other was when this

Speaker: NA
Text: government increased family benefits with

Speaker: NA
Text: an annual $600 payment and announced that

Speaker: NA
Text: we would pay a $600 lump sum in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: each child where the family was entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: family tax benefit. The member for Lilley

Speaker: NA
Text: decided that that payment should be abol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ished. His leader, Mark Latham, said to him,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘How do we explain that we're taking $600 a

Speaker: NA
Text: year away from families?' The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lilley said: ‘Tell them it's not real. Tell

Speaker: NA
Text: they never had a $600 payment, so when you

Speaker: NA
Text: take it away they won't notice it.' This is of

Speaker: NA
Text: course what you would learn as a machine

Speaker: NA
Text: politician. When you are on weak ground,

Speaker: NA
Text: claim that black is white, repeat it often

Speaker: NA
Text: enough and you will get people to believe it.

Speaker: NA
Text: You could not fool the Australian public;

Speaker: NA
Text: they knew they were getting $600 as I said-

Speaker: NA
Text: it went into their bank accounts. It could be

Speaker: NA
Text: spent, it could be drawn out, it could be ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: changed for milk and bread, and the line that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was not real did not gel with reality. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course it turned into a disaster during the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004 election.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to say something briefly about pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity because I was saying this in the

Speaker: NA
Text: course of question time today. What would

Speaker: NA
Text: you be doing if you wanted to boost produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity in Australia? I think investing in

Speaker: NA
Text: schools will boost productivity in the longer

Speaker: NA
Text: term because, if you invest in skills and you

Speaker: NA
Text: train more apprentices, you get more people

Speaker: NA
Text: into the labour force with higher skills. Over

Speaker: NA
Text: the course of time, you would expect that to

Speaker: NA
Text: lift capacity. Of course, you have to bear in

Speaker: NA
Text: mind that an apprentice will take four years

Speaker: NA
Text: to train and the apprentice then has to go into

Speaker: NA
Text: the workforce. I think we have something

Speaker: NA
Text: like 160,000 apprenticeships at the moment,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is some kind of record in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that will give you benefits in the long

Speaker: NA
Text: term; there is no doubt about that.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, if you really want to unlock key pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity benefits, you should do it in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the existing workforce-not just the

Speaker: NA
Text: future workforce, not just in five or 10 years

Speaker: NA
Text: time, but the existing workforce. I have no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that if you improve industrial relations,

Speaker: NA
Text: if you allow employers and employees to

Speaker: NA
Text: directly agree on AWAs, that will be a much

Speaker: NA
Text: more productive industrial relations system

Speaker: NA
Text: in each and every factory, shop, business and

Speaker: NA
Text: company in Australia. But, of course, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party are against that. If you do not

Speaker: NA
Text: them want to take my word for it, you could take

Speaker: NA
Text: the word of the former Governor of the Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: serve Bank, Ian Macfarlane. In his testimony

Speaker: NA
Text: before the House of Representatives shortly
