Speaker: NA
Text: before he ceased being governor, he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The biggest thing in this area-

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity-

Speaker: NA
Text: is industrial relations reform. There must be a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of things that still can be done.

Speaker: NA
Text: What did the Reserve Bank Governor say?

Speaker: NA
Text: The biggest area is industrial relations re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form. What is the major plank of Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial relations policy? To get rid of

Speaker: NA
Text: AWAs. So the Labor Party would have you

Speaker: NA
Text: believe, on one hand, that they are critical of

Speaker: NA
Text: the government about productivity and, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the other hand, that they want to abolish the

Speaker: NA
Text: key thing that can drive it. So how would

Speaker: NA
Text: you reconcile those two positions-that you

Speaker: NA
Text: allegedly want to increase productivity and,

Speaker: NA
Text: at the same time, abolish the key thing that

Speaker: NA
Text: would drive it? You do precisely what you

Speaker: NA
Text: did in relation to the $600 payment. You

Speaker: NA
Text: deny the obvious and you repeat over and

Speaker: NA
Text: over again that it is not real, that it does not

Speaker: NA
Text: occur, that it does not happen. Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: needs more than focus-group-driven glib

Speaker: NA
Text: cliches. What we need is real policy. What

Speaker: NA
Text: the government delivered last night was real

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. It is the biggest investment that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has ever had. We are going to lock in

Speaker: NA
Text: the gains. We are going to invest for the fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture. This is the economic path forward and

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition will lead it. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr TANNER
Text: Melbourne) (3.46 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Seven weeks ago the Treasurer stood up at

Speaker: NA
Text: the dispatch box and suddenly became hys-

Speaker: NA
Text: terical. He screamed, he shouted, he went red

Speaker: NA
Text: in the face, he frothed at the mouth, he

Speaker: NA
Text: cursed, he ranted like an old preacher at an

Speaker: NA
Text: AA meeting. We were almost expecting a

Speaker: NA
Text: round of ‘Away, away with rum by gum.'

Speaker: NA
Text: You could say that he does this often,

Speaker: NA
Text: was a particularly spectacular performance-

Speaker: NA
Text: and, by the sound of his rather ponderous

Speaker: NA
Text: and soporific contribution today, he is proba-

Speaker: NA
Text: bly still recovering. Why was it that he be-

Speaker: NA
Text: came so hysterical? What was the cause of

Speaker: NA
Text: this outburst of red-facedness, hysteria and

Speaker: NA
Text: ranting? The answer is: Labor's broadband

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal.

Speaker: NA
Text: This proposal includes drawing on $2.7

Speaker: NA
Text: billion of Telstra shares, one telecommunica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions asset held by the government in escrow

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Future Fund, in order to invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: ating the national broadband network that

Speaker: NA
Text: this nation desperately needs and the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government has totally failed to deliver. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer described this as shameful eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic vandalism, robbery and burglary. He

Speaker: NA
Text: said it was the most economically irrespon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible thing that Labor has said in 11 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fortunately the commentators dismissed this

Speaker: NA
Text: hysteria as total rubbish and last night, in

Speaker: NA
Text: effect, the Treasurer and the government

Speaker: NA
Text: completely surrendered. They vacated the

Speaker: NA
Text: field on this assertion that Labor's broadband

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal is economically irresponsible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why? Because they have effectively done

Speaker: NA
Text: the same thing that Labor was proposing to

Speaker: NA
Text: do with respect to prospective future invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. But they have doubled it. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken what would otherwise have been Fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture Fund assets of $5 billion plus the earn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings that would accrue from that between

Speaker: NA
Text: now and the end of next year, which effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively adds up to double what Labor's com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment involved. But in true hypocritical

Speaker: NA
Text: preacher style the Treasurer is still trying

Speaker: NA
Text: pretend he is pure. So in the budget speech,

Speaker: NA
Text: the same speech where he announced this $5

Speaker: NA
Text: billion drawdown on the Future Fund, he

Speaker: NA
Text: also said, ‘But we won't be like those irre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible Labor people who propose to draw

Speaker: NA
Text: down $2.7 billion.' Let us run through the

Speaker: NA
Text: quote to make it clear exactly what we are

Speaker: NA
Text: but this dealing with. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: If you rob capital or earnings from the Future

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund, taxpayers will have to make up the differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence. You are passing our bills, our obligations,

Speaker: NA
Text: from our generation to the next. This will limit

Speaker: NA
Text: their future. We will strongly oppose any irre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible attempt to raid this national investment

Speaker: NA
Text: for cheap political advantage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Six weeks ago, in the Australian Financial

Speaker: NA
Text: Review, the Minister for Finance and Ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ministration said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly this year's surplus and next year's sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: cre- plus will be going into the Future Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: So where did this $5 billion for the Higher

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Endowment Fund come from? It

Speaker: NA
Text: came from this year's surplus-the same

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus that, according to Senator Minchin,

Speaker: NA
Text: was destined for the Future Fund. Whichever

Speaker: NA
Text: way you look at it, however you play with

Speaker: NA
Text: words-as he sought to do in his press re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lease defending himself this afternoon-that

Speaker: NA
Text: $5 billion was halfway out the door, heading

Speaker: NA
Text: towards the Future Fund. He grabbed it and

Speaker: NA
Text: said: ‘We're going to have a Higher Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Endowment Fund. This isn't going into

Speaker: NA
Text: the Future Fund.' So the preacher has gone

Speaker: NA
Text: out and got legless. He is wandering around

Speaker: NA
Text: looking for some alcoholics to convert and

Speaker: NA
Text: lecture about the virtues of abstinence. Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: supports the Higher Education Endowment

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund. It is a reasonable idea. But we should

Speaker: NA
Text: not get carried away with it, as the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and Treasurer have done, because it

Speaker: NA
Text: is only going to deliver approximately $300

Speaker: NA
Text: million of, one would hope, new money to

Speaker: NA
Text: the higher education sector each year. A lot

Speaker: NA
Text: to more needs to be done, but that is not a bad

Speaker: NA
Text: start.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the one thing we can take out of this is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the debate about Labor's broadband pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal is over. Not only is the proposal good

Speaker: NA
Text: in the national interest from the point of view

Speaker: NA
Text: of getting that broadband network built; it is

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely responsible financially. But yet again

Speaker: NA
Text: there is virtually nothing in this budget to

Speaker: NA
Text: tackle that chronic productivity problem of

Speaker: NA
Text: our falling behind the rest of the developed

Speaker: NA
Text: world in access to high-speed broadband.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government have now conceded not

Speaker: NA
Text: only that Labor's proposition is good and

Speaker: NA
Text: sound from a communications point of view

Speaker: NA
Text: and a productivity point of view but also that

Speaker: NA
Text: the financing proposal is entirely reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able-because they are doing exactly the

Speaker: NA
Text: same thing with respect to the headline an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nouncement in this year's budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a sense that encapsulates the entire

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, a budget built on preaching absti-

Speaker: NA
Text: nence and practising incontinence; that is the

Speaker: NA
Text: entire budget of 2007. Yes, there are many

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives that we support, such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Higher Education Endowment Fund. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: of them we designed, so why wouldn't we

Speaker: NA
Text: support them? But the wider picture is dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferent. The wider picture is of a government

Speaker: NA
Text: that is complacently cruising on the minerals

Speaker: NA
Text: boom, handing out money every way it can

Speaker: NA
Text: to try to ensure its re-election while not

Speaker: NA
Text: vesting for the future of Australia and for

Speaker: NA
Text: future living standards of our kids and not

Speaker: NA
Text: investing for increasing productivity to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that we stay at the forefront of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world's nations. When the sun is shining you

Speaker: NA
Text: make hay. That is not what this government

Speaker: NA
Text: is doing and that is not what the budget is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing; it fails the future test.

Speaker: NA
Text: We welcome the education initiatives that

Speaker: NA
Text: are in the budget, but they are, in overall

Speaker: NA
Text: terms, relatively modest-a good first step.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are good snapshots but they are a long

Speaker: NA
Text: way from being the whole picture. And the

Speaker: NA
Text: government could not help themselves: they

Speaker: NA
Text: had to whack in a little sting in the tail on

Speaker: NA
Text: HECS; they had to slug students on the way

Speaker: NA
Text: through. They had to revert to type and hit

Speaker: NA
Text: accounting, business and commerce students

Speaker: NA
Text: with a big HECS slug, because they could

Speaker: NA
Text: not help themselves. Even though they are

Speaker: NA
Text: trying desperately to look like they care

Speaker: NA
Text: about education-they want to improve in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment in education because Kevin Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: has put the issue squarely at the forefront of

Speaker: NA
Text: the national agenda-on the way through

Speaker: NA
Text: they could not help themselves: they had to

Speaker: NA
Text: slug students.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to examine what has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: tackled in this budget. We need to look at

Speaker: NA
Text: what has not actually occurred. There is very

Speaker: NA
Text: little on vocational education in the middle

Speaker: NA
Text: of a skills crisis. There are a few modest ini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiatives with respect to climate change, the

Speaker: NA
Text: most striking of which is about adapting to

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change, getting used to it-not doing

Speaker: NA
Text: something about it, not acting, not leading

Speaker: NA
Text: the world as Australia should be doing, not

Speaker: NA
Text: contributing to a global solution. Early

Speaker: NA
Text: childhood education is critical to the future

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities of all children but there is ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: fectively nothing. And, as I said, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing on broadband.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then, if you look at the wider estimates,

Speaker: NA
Text: the wider projections as to where the nation's

Speaker: NA
Text: in- economy is heading, you see productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: the effectively at zero and very ordinary produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity figures projected for the future. As to

Speaker: NA
Text: export growth, they have finally given up on

Speaker: NA
Text: all of the outrageous, exaggerated export

Speaker: NA
Text: projections that they have put over the past

Speaker: NA
Text: few years when they have kept saying we are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to get eight per cent or nine per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: growth but it turns out to be two per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are backing that down to five. That

Speaker: NA
Text: makes you really worry about what the out-

Speaker: NA
Text: come and the reality will ultimately be in the

Speaker: NA
Text: next few years if they are pulling their pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: jections down like that, particularly when the

Speaker: NA
Text: projections indicate that the current account

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit is expected to blow out to six per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: again.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployment is expected to rise; job

Speaker: NA
Text: creation is expected to fall. It is also impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant to look at the wider macrofiscal position

Speaker: NA
Text: to lay to rest once and for all the suggestion

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is a fiscally conservative, ‘small

Speaker: NA
Text: government' focused, economic-managing

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Fifty-three billion dollars in

Speaker: NA
Text: additional money has rained down on the

Speaker: NA
Text: government since December. The estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: for the four years have $53 billion more than

Speaker: NA
Text: what was available in the equivalent esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates in December. They have spent the lot.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have used the lot, some on tax cuts and

Speaker: NA
Text: an awful lot on spending, and they have

Speaker: NA
Text: managed to throw in an additional $4-odd

Speaker: NA
Text: billion of spending at the end of this finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial year, the one that is about to close, not to portance-

Speaker: NA
Text: mention the $5 billion that has been put in

Speaker: NA
Text: there for the Higher Education Endowment

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund. We are getting to the point where we

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to see more new spending initia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives at the end of a budget than we see at the

Speaker: NA
Text: start. In the financial year that is about to

Speaker: NA
Text: end, the new spending initiatives that were

Speaker: NA
Text: announced in the 2006 budget for the 2006-

Speaker: NA
Text: 07 year were worth about $4 billion. The

Speaker: NA
Text: new spending initiatives for the 2006-07 fi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nancial year announced in the 2007 budget

Speaker: NA
Text: are also about $4 billion, even if you exclude

Speaker: NA
Text: the one-off capital investment in the higher

Speaker: NA
Text: education fund. This is a very peculiar ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to accounting.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been virtually no serious effort

Speaker: NA
Text: to gain savings, to cut expenditure and to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that we have rigorous controls on

Speaker: NA
Text: government spending. A lot more money has

Speaker: NA
Text: been handed out to departments such as

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury and Finance without even any

Speaker: NA
Text: process attached to them as to what they are

Speaker: NA
Text: supposed to be for. The Melbourne Cricket

Speaker: NA
Text: Club has got another $10 million to add to

Speaker: NA
Text: the $15 million it got last year for its mu-

Speaker: NA
Text: seum, and so the list goes on.

Speaker: NA
Text: The drunken preacher is having a wild

Speaker: NA
Text: time. He is handing out free advice on absti-

Speaker: NA
Text: nence in between swigs of his flagon. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: passing the flagon around and he is having a

Speaker: NA
Text: great time because he has a lot to drink. The

Speaker: NA
Text: worry is, though, that it will be our kids who

Speaker: NA
Text: get the hangover, because when this nation

Speaker: NA
Text: was in a position of enormous good for-

Speaker: NA
Text: tune-of great fortune with huge revenues

Speaker: NA
Text: coming in to the government from the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing boom-what did the government do?

Speaker: NA
Text: They squandered it and they are continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: to squander it. Don't be fooled by the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are trying to look as if they are do-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing something, because this budget fails the

Speaker: NA
Text: future test. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Text: Moncrieff) (3.57 pm)-I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to rise on this matter of public im-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Jen-

Speaker: NA
Text: kins)-Member for Moncrieff, is your mi-

Speaker: NA
Text: crophone on?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Murphy-We're not missing any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing!

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! The

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lowe is not helping. The Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Clerk will start the clock again. I will call the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Moncrieff now that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: sorted that out.

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have worked out what the problem is: the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Melbourne actually put the mi-

Speaker: NA
Text: crophone operator to sleep. That is a new

Speaker: NA
Text: record. In the six years that I have been in

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament I have never actually seen a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the opposition put a console op-

Speaker: NA
Text: erator to sleep. Congratulations to the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Melbourne! It is a new record to the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Melbourne: not only was he so

Speaker: NA
Text: boring and his speech so devoid of any fact

Speaker: NA
Text: but he actually managed to give it in such a

Speaker: NA
Text: monotonous way that he sent one of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sole operators to sleep. My heart is with the

Speaker: NA
Text: console operator. But for the fact that I am

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to sit in this chamber and have to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: attention, I would have liked to have fallen

Speaker: NA
Text: asleep as well, although I would have had

Speaker: NA
Text: some sort of recurring nightmare as I heard

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Melbourne drone on and on

Speaker: NA
Text: and on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Notwithstanding that, I am very pleased to

Speaker: NA
Text: stand up to speak on the MPI that is before

Speaker: NA
Text: the chamber today. I was fascinated by one

Speaker: NA
Text: small part of what the member for Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne had to say in the topsy-turvy Tanner

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to economics. We have got the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Melbourne coming to the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: patch box saying, ‘You know what: Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: and the coalition are as one when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Future Fund and investment in broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: band.' What we know from topsy-turvy Tan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ner economics is that they say it is okay to

Speaker: NA
Text: have money in the Future Fund and to take

Speaker: NA
Text: that money from the Future Fund and go off

Speaker: NA
Text: and spend it, because that is the same thing

Speaker: NA
Text: as having money in the Future Fund and then

Speaker: NA
Text: establishing an additional endowment fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, what are we actually talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about?

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Melbourne is saying that,

Speaker: NA
Text: if you have $100 in a savings account and

Speaker: NA
Text: you take out $50 and go and spend it, it is the

Speaker: NA
Text: same principle that members of the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: have put forward. What are the coalition do-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing? They have put $100 in a savings ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: count and are now opening a second savings

Speaker: NA
Text: account and putting in an additional $50.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to the Australian Labor Party, to

Speaker: NA
Text: have $100 in one savings account and $50 in

Speaker: NA
Text: a second savings account is apparently the

Speaker: NA
Text: same as having $100 in an account, with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawing $50 and spending it. That is what

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Melbourne said to the cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber this afternoon, and it is for that very

Speaker: NA
Text: son that the Australian Labor Party is abso-

Speaker: NA
Text: lutely laughable when it comes to having the

Speaker: NA
Text: discipline or economic sense to manage the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer said today that you cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: trust Labor when it comes to managing Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's trillion dollar economy because it is

Speaker: NA
Text: just too important. We know that the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers for Lilley and Melbourne have both

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly demonstrated that, when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: having discipline, to rolling up the sleeves,

Speaker: NA
Text: getting up early and doing the work required

Speaker: NA
Text: to manage Australia's trillion dollar econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy, the Labor Party just do not have it. If

Speaker: NA
Text: you want proof positive, the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: would ruin the Australian economy with not

Speaker: NA
Text: only their talk of $600 ‘not being real

Speaker: NA
Text: money' but also their comment that having

Speaker: NA
Text: one savings account and starting a second

Speaker: NA
Text: savings account is the same as taking money

Speaker: NA
Text: out of a savings account. It beggars belief.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hear from the Australian Labor Party that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is the same thing; it is not even remotely

Speaker: NA
Text: similar!

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Labor Party's proposition

Speaker: NA
Text: on broadband-and we heard much talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about broadband from both the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lilley and the member for Melbourne-is

Speaker: NA
Text: very clear, and it is nothing like what this

Speaker: NA
Text: government is doing with the endowment

Speaker: NA
Text: fund. The Australian Labor Party's approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Future Fund is to say, ‘We will extract

Speaker: NA
Text: money from the Future Fund and spend it.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Their initial approach was that $2.7 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: was going to be used on broadband rollout-

Speaker: NA
Text: which, incidentally, the Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party were going to steal from the Future

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund. That $2.7 billion smash and grab was

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be used to invest in a network that

Speaker: NA
Text: two private operators in Australia are looking

Speaker: NA
Text: at rolling out themselves. Not only have we

Speaker: NA
Text: got the Australian Labor Party smashing and

Speaker: NA
Text: grabbing from the future savings of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian generations; we have them investing that

Speaker: NA
Text: reamoney in a broadband network that two pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate operators are lining up to roll out today.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the Australian Labor Party's ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government has turned around and

Speaker: NA
Text: said, ‘We quarantined the money in the Fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture Fund.' We do not want the burden of

Speaker: NA
Text: retirees in the future-service men and

Speaker: NA
Text: women from Australia's defence forces, and

Speaker: NA
Text: public servants. We are building up retire-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment savings for them in the Future Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: to We do not want future generations of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians to have to shoulder that burden, so we

Speaker: NA
Text: will start making provision today. The Future

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund is a savings account that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: opened today to provide for all of our tomor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rows, and we have done it again with the

Speaker: NA
Text: endowment fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: The $5 billion visionary endowment fund

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Treasurer announced last night will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that, in perpetuity, Australian univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sities have access to capital to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia can have world-class and first-class

Speaker: NA
Text: research institutions and teaching facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: and a whole spate of new initiatives available

Speaker: NA
Text: to our tertiary education sector. We can have

Speaker: NA
Text: world-class facilities that will ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian kids in the future can be not only

Speaker: NA
Text: among the best in our region but among the

Speaker: NA
Text: best in the world, with access to the very best

Speaker: NA
Text: technology and the very best teaching facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties at our universities. That is what this

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment has set up under the $5 billion en-

Speaker: NA
Text: dowment fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the Labor Party's response to

Speaker: NA
Text: that? They say that they support it, but in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: they would approach it by stealing more

Speaker: NA
Text: money out of the Future Fund. The Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party's approach is not to create additional

Speaker: NA
Text: savings but to spend even more money. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know that the Australian Labor Party's ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to the budget is really distilled down

Speaker: NA
Text: to a couple of basic elements. Their criticism

Speaker: NA
Text: has been that we have not spent enough as a

Speaker: NA
Text: government, so they say, ‘Spend more

Speaker: NA
Text: money.' The other criticisms that have come

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Australian Labor Party are that the

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus was not big enough and that we

Speaker: NA
Text: should have saved more money. Spend more

Speaker: NA
Text: money; save more money-that is all we

Speaker: NA
Text: hear from the Australian Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we get to the issue of our environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, it is important to recognise that this

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition government is proposing to spend

Speaker: NA
Text: $19 billion on Australia's environment over

Speaker: NA
Text: the next four years-$19 billion of invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in Australia's environment and those of

Speaker: NA
Text: our surrounding neighbours. A key plank of

Speaker: NA
Text: this government's approach to combating the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect of climate change is to look at some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the source problems affecting climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change. We know that one of the key issues

Speaker: NA
Text: is deforestation that is taking place around

Speaker: NA
Text: the world. I am proud to be a part of a gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment that is working with poorer nations

Speaker: NA
Text: around the world and with some of our near

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbours to put in place incentives to try to

Speaker: NA
Text: stop them from cutting down trees-a very

Speaker: NA
Text: good initiative. It is the kind of initiative that

Speaker: NA
Text: will have a long-term benefit for our nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a world-leading initiative that the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Melbourne was talking about earlier.

Speaker: NA
Text: This country is leading and setting an exam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple for the world. We are doing it by focus-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing not only within Australia but also on our

Speaker: NA
Text: govnear neighbours, and saying to them, ‘We

Speaker: NA
Text: will work with you. We will create an incen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive so that we do not end up with vast hec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tares of deforested land because you have

Speaker: NA
Text: people in your countries who are chopping

Speaker: NA
Text: down trees faster than we can plant them

Speaker: NA
Text: here.' That is the kind of world leadership

Speaker: NA
Text: that I am pleased to be part of.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the single biggest, most glaring er-

Speaker: NA
Text: rors that we have seen from the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party is their standing up and saying it

Speaker: NA
Text: has been raining gold bullion for this How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard government. We hear the Australian La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor Party say, ‘It's all just a coincidence; it's

Speaker: NA
Text: all just a fluke.' The reality is that the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Labor Party have stood opposed to every

Speaker: NA
Text: major reform measure that this government

Speaker: NA
Text: has tried to introduce since 1996. The Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labor Party stood opposed to tax re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form. The Australian Labor Party stood op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed to waterfront reform. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party stood opposed to the tax reform

Speaker: NA
Text: that took place under the GST. The Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Labor Party even opposed tax cuts for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians in the previous budget. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party's record. When it

Speaker: NA
Text: came to industrial relations reform-for ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample, unfair dismissal laws-the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party opposed that as well, and they

Speaker: NA
Text: are opposing Work Choices now. On every

Speaker: NA
Text: single front, the Australian Labor Party have

Speaker: NA
Text: stood opposed to the initiatives this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has undertaken, the kinds of initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: that have delivered in spades to the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian people-that have kept our budget in the

Speaker: NA
Text: black, got unemployment down to a 30-year

Speaker: NA
Text: record low and delivered the dividend that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian people enjoyed last night in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer's speech.

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: Prospect) (4.07 pm)-Last

Speaker: NA
Text: week Australia had a very eminent visitor, a

Speaker: NA
Text: respected commentator on globalisation, the

Speaker: NA
Text: author of one of the world's best-selling

Speaker: NA
Text: books in recent times-Thomas Friedman,

Speaker: NA
Text: the author of the book The World is Flat. He

Speaker: NA
Text: met with the Prime Minister, he met with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition and he addressed a

Speaker: NA
Text: big dinner in Sydney-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hockey interjecting-

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: The minister was at the

Speaker: NA
Text: dinner and they may have met individually.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hockey interjecting-

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: They met individually; I

Speaker: NA
Text: am glad to hear it. The minister and several

Speaker: NA
Text: other ministers were at the dinner, as were

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow ministers, and we heard about Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Friedman's views on what makes a success-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful nation in this difficult time around the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. An interesting quote has been brought

Speaker: NA
Text: to my attention. Thomas Friedman says this:

Speaker: NA
Text: Money, jobs, and opportunity in the flat world

Speaker: NA
Text: will go to the countries with the best infrastructo

Speaker: NA
Text: ture, the best education system that produces the

Speaker: NA
Text: most educated work force, the most investor-

Speaker: NA
Text: friendly laws, and the best environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last night's budget fails the Thomas Fried-

Speaker: NA
Text: man test because it fails the future test-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hockey interjecting-

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: and the minister knows it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister knows that last night was an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other squandered opportunity from a gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment which is riding the mining boom,

Speaker: NA
Text: taking the Chinese dividend, and refusing to

Speaker: NA
Text: invest and prepare Australia for the downturn

Speaker: NA
Text: which will inevitably come in this nation. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a government which is ignoring the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity gap which has not only existed but

Speaker: NA
Text: has been rising under this government for

Speaker: NA
Text: several years; a government which ignores-

Speaker: NA
Text: and has ignored for 11 years-the need for a

Speaker: NA
Text: massive reinvestment in Australia's educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion system. At five minutes to midnight, five

Speaker: NA
Text: months before an election, they suddenly

Speaker: NA
Text: rediscover the need to invest in education.

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, it is not enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not enough to catch up. Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: to do better than that. A catch-up is wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: come-we welcome some of the funds going

Speaker: NA
Text: to education in last night's budget-but a

Speaker: NA
Text: catch-up is not enough. And the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people will not be fooled by a cynical and

Speaker: NA
Text: cunning budget at five minutes to midnight

Speaker: NA
Text: which finally recognises the need to invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: education. It does not go far enough-on any

Speaker: NA
Text: measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was in the budget lockup yesterday and I

Speaker: NA
Text: thought, ‘I'll look up the early childhood

Speaker: NA
Text: measures; I'll find out how much new money

Speaker: NA
Text: is going into early childhood.' And I looked

Speaker: NA
Text: and I looked and I looked through the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: papers, locked away in the room-not one.

Speaker: NA
Text: Every respected economic commentator in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world says that one of the best ways to

Speaker: NA
Text: invest in a nation's future is to invest early-

Speaker: NA
Text: invest in early childhood education; to

Speaker: NA
Text: take people in their first two or three years

Speaker: NA
Text: and give them the best possible start in life.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why Labor has committed to a mul-

Speaker: NA
Text: timillion-dollar early childhood investment

Speaker: NA
Text: plan. Yet there was not one word on that in

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget. I thought, ‘Maybe the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will try to catch up; maybe they will

Speaker: NA
Text: respond,' but there was not one word on that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's overall investment in educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is 5.8 per cent of GDP-behind 17 other

Speaker: NA
Text: OECD nations. That is not changed by this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. We are behind Hungary-still behind

Speaker: NA
Text: them. We are behind Poland. We are still

Speaker: NA
Text: behind New Zealand. We are still behind 17

Speaker: NA
Text: other OECD nations when it comes to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment in education. As the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Perth pointed out in question

Speaker: NA
Text: time, we welcome the $5 billion Higher

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Endowment Fund. That means an

Speaker: NA
Text: average allocation between Australia's 38

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education institutions of about $8 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion. Now, that is welcome. But let us not kid

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves that that is enough. Let us not kid

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves that that is going to make up for

Speaker: NA
Text: the backlog of investment in capital infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure in universities in this nation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government are kidding themselves that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: enough, but it simply is not.

Speaker: NA
Text: I looked through the budget papers for

Speaker: NA
Text: higher investment in broadband funding. I

Speaker: NA
Text: looked and I looked and I looked-not one

Speaker: NA
Text: word; not one cent. And then, in question

Speaker: NA
Text: time, I realised why: it is because the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment just does not get it. We got up here

Speaker: NA
Text: and we pointed out the connection between

Speaker: NA
Text: education and broadband. We pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: that children in regional areas need access

Speaker: NA
Text: high-speed broadband to help them with

Speaker: NA
Text: their education-and there was laughter from

Speaker: NA
Text: the other side; guffaws of laughter at the

Speaker: NA
Text: connection being made by this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House between education and broadband.

Speaker: NA
Text: They just do not get it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Moncrieff

Speaker: NA
Text: called Labor's plan to invest in a broadband

Speaker: NA
Text: network for this nation ‘theft'. He used all

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of other pejoratives to describe Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: plans. He does not get it. And nobody on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side of the House seems to get the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nection between the need to connect 98 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the Australian people to broadband,

Speaker: NA
Text: the need to increase broadband speeds by 40

Speaker: NA
Text: times, and the impact that will have on Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's education outcomes. But we get it.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr HARTSUYKER
Text: Cowper) (4.13

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-I certainly disagree most strongly with

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposition put by the member for Pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: pect that the budget fails what he calls ‘the

Speaker: NA
Text: Friedman test' in preparing this country for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future, because nothing could be further

Speaker: NA
Text: from the truth. We have heard nothing from

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition-up until recently-other

Speaker: NA
Text: than hot air and rhetoric.

Speaker: NA
Text: An unusual thing happened at the ALP

Speaker: NA
Text: conference. We saw a couple of things start-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to occur. We saw the Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position make it pretty clear that he takes the

Speaker: NA
Text: vote of the Australian people for granted. We

Speaker: NA
Text: also saw the Leader of the Opposition cast

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt on the ability of someone of a particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar chronological age to function at a high

Speaker: NA
Text: level in this community. If you went to a fo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cus group and asked them the question: ‘If

Speaker: NA
Text: someone is a certain age, does that mean

Speaker: NA
Text: they cannot run a country or they cannot run

Speaker: NA
Text: a major corporation?' they would tell you

Speaker: NA
Text: very strongly that they certainly can. And

Speaker: NA
Text: there is very strong objection to that notion

Speaker: NA
Text: put by the Leader of the Opposition that if

Speaker: NA
Text: you grew up in the era of black-and-white

Speaker: NA
Text: to television you are somehow less worthy to

Speaker: NA
Text: hold high office than if you were a child of

Speaker: NA
Text: the era of colour television.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also saw at the ALP conference a shift

Speaker: NA
Text: from hot air and rhetoric to their first piece

Speaker: NA
Text: of black-letter policy. We saw them move

Speaker: NA
Text: away from the rivers of milk and honey and

Speaker: NA
Text: the endless discussion of warmth and light to

Speaker: NA
Text: put out a policy. What was it? An industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations policy. Was it going to build pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity? I think not. Was it going to take

Speaker: NA
Text: this country forward? I think not. The first

Speaker: NA
Text: piece of black-letter policy that they brought

Speaker: NA
Text: out did not take this country forward but, in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, took it back some 20 years. We got to

Speaker: NA
Text: the point where Labor were going to produce

Speaker: NA
Text: this piece of policy that would bring us back

Speaker: NA
Text: to the great old days of centralised wage

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. They were going to make reforms they

Speaker: NA
Text: were going to turn back AWAs. We know-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I see the Minister for Employment and

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations at the table, and he cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly knows-that AWAs provide more

Speaker: NA
Text: flexibility for employers to come up with

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements with their employees to maxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mise the production and productivity of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. And to take away a major element

Speaker: NA
Text: of the growth of this nation, through taking

Speaker: NA
Text: away AWAs, can hardly be setting up this

Speaker: NA
Text: country for growth and taking this country

Speaker: NA
Text: forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: We saw the folly in Labor's first venture

Speaker: NA
Text: into policy when they had to review their

Speaker: NA
Text: own policy some five times within 10 days.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition must

Speaker: NA
Text: be embarrassed by what is considered by

Speaker: NA
Text: most commentators as an absolutely woeful

Speaker: NA
Text: foray into detailed policy. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: believes that greater flexibility is greater

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity, but Labor want to introduce

Speaker: NA
Text: union rule by good old team ACTU, that

Speaker: NA
Text: great bastion of flexibility. If you want to

Speaker: NA
Text: look at productivity you have to look no

Speaker: NA
Text: ther than the commercial building industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: where we hear of reductions in cost in com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercial building of some 20 to 30 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: through fewer industrial disputes, through

Speaker: NA
Text: less intimidation and thuggery on work sites

Speaker: NA
Text: and through improved work practices.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is Labor's response to this improved

Speaker: NA
Text: flexibility, improved productivity and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced cost on commercial building sites?

Speaker: NA
Text: They want to abolish the Australian Building

Speaker: NA
Text: and Construction Commission. They want to

Speaker: NA
Text: go back to good old team ACTU. Bring back

Speaker: NA
Text: union thuggery, revitalise union power: ‘We

Speaker: NA
Text: want to have the crane drivers running the

Speaker: NA
Text: construction sites again, deciding what goes

Speaker: NA
Text: up the building and what comes down. We

Speaker: NA
Text: want to have the crane drivers holding up the

Speaker: NA
Text: job, costing tens of thousands of dollars in

Speaker: NA
Text: prolongation costs.' That is the response of

Speaker: NA
Text: fixthe Labor Party to improved productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been brought about by these sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: changes. It is the peak of hypocrisy for Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: to talk of productivity growth, when the first

Speaker: NA
Text: policy that they bring out takes this country

Speaker: NA
Text: back 20 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: This budget has introduced a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: measures that will drive this country for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward. This government is very much on the

Speaker: NA
Text: leading edge of improved productivity. You

Speaker: NA
Text: are a very backward-looking opposition. You

Speaker: NA
Text: have no real solutions, apart from hot air and

Speaker: NA
Text: rhetoric. We have seen you on climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change. It is all warm and fuzzy, but there is

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing beneath that never-ending rhetoric

Speaker: NA
Text: that you put out. This government is taking

Speaker: NA
Text: this country forward in an economically re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible way and the people of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: see through your-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Jen-

Speaker: NA
Text: kins)-Order! The time allotted for this dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion has concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: BUSINESS

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: North Sydney-Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: fur- for Employment and Workplace Relations

Speaker: NA
Text: and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Public Service) (4.18 pm)-On behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the House, Mr Abbott, I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That standing order 31 (automatic adjournment

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House) be suspended for the sitting on

Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday, 10 May 2007 and at that sitting, after

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition completes his reply

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Budget speech, the House automatically

Speaker: NA
Text: stand adjourned until 12.30 p.m. on Monday, 21

Speaker: NA
Text: May 2007 unless the Speaker or, in the event of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Speaker being unavailable, the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, fixes an alternative day or hour of meet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: STANDING ORDERS

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Jen-

Speaker: NA
Text: kins)-In calling the next order of the day, I

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to indicate that there was a minor proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: essing error in the way in which the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared on the Notice Paper. In relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed standing order 190(e), the words

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘at 6 pm' should not have appeared.

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: North Sydney-Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Employment and Workplace Relations

Speaker: NA
Text: and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Public Service) (4.19 pm)-On behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the House, Mr Abbott, I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That unless otherwise ordered, standing orders

Speaker: NA
Text: Nos 190(e) and 192 be as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: 190 (e) The Committee shall stand adjourned

Speaker: NA
Text: on completion of all matters referred to it, or may

Speaker: NA
Text: 4.00 pm Committee and

Speaker: NA
Text: approx 6.00 pm

Speaker: NA
Text: The meeting times of the Main Committee are

Speaker: NA
Text: change. Additional meetings may be scheduled

Speaker: NA
Text: other than Thursdays by agreement between the Whips.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: Grayndler) (4.19 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor supports this amendment to standing

Speaker: NA
Text: orders, which would allow the Main Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee to sit on Monday until all business

Speaker: NA
Text: before it is concluded instead of requiring a

Speaker: NA
Text: motion to extend. The amendment to stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing order 192 clarifies that the priority of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Main Committee on Mondays is committee

Speaker: NA
Text: and delegation reports. It is extraordinary,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, that we have a motion before the

Speaker: NA
Text: be adjourned on motion moved without notice by

Speaker: NA
Text: any Member-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Committee do now adjourn.

Text: 192 Main Committee's order of business

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) If the Committee meets on a Wednesday or

Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday the normal order of business is set

Speaker: NA
Text: out in figure 4.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) The Committee shall meet, if required, on a

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting Monday from 4 pm to 6 pm to con-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: and delegation reports and these orders of the

Speaker: NA
Text: day shall have priority over other business,

Speaker: NA
Text: unless otherwise ordered.

Text: am business and/or am business and/or

Text: committee and committee and

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation delegation

Speaker: NA
Text: reports reports

Speaker: NA
Text: Adjournment

Speaker: NA
Text: debate

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation reports

Speaker: NA
Text: and/ or Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment business

Speaker: NA
Text: approx 1.00 pm approx 1.00 pm

Speaker: NA
Text: fixed by the Deputy Speaker and are subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: if required. Adjournment debates can occur on days

Speaker: NA
Text: House this afternoon to extend the sitting of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Main Committee. Whilst we in the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party are certainly happy to facilitate the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Main Committee to consider business,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is surprising because the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: not been prioritising business at all. Indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the last sitting, just six weeks ago, the

Speaker: NA
Text: week before parliament rose, the Main Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee barely had any business to consider at

Speaker: NA
Text: all. On the Wednesday, all we had was a se-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries of three-minute statements from mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers and on the Thursday it did not sit at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing could better illustrate the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: this government is short of ideas, it is short

Speaker: NA
Text: of legislation, it is out of touch and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: of time. Nothing could better illustrate that

Speaker: NA
Text: fact. The Leader of the House, the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Warringah, never does his job. He gets

Speaker: NA
Text: other people to do it for him. He cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: bothered moving motions that are appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ately moved by the Leader of the House in

Speaker: NA
Text: this chamber. He simply gets his colleague-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin-Where is he?

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: He's out jogging. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is where he usually is at this time of the day.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a government-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hockey- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: on a point of order. If the Manager of Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition Business wants to engage in a debate

Speaker: NA
Text: about the fitness of the Leader of the House,

Speaker: NA
Text: I am happy to engage in a debate about that,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I would like to hear him come back to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Main Committee order of business.

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing orders 190(e) and 192-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Jen-

Speaker: NA
Text: kins)-The minister will resume his seat,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I am sure the member for Grayndler will

Speaker: NA
Text: be relevant to the question before the House.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: I certainly will. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: not surprising that government ministers are

Speaker: NA
Text: embarrassed. They are embarrassed by their

Speaker: NA
Text: own performance-embarrassed about ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tending the sittings of the Main Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: when there is no legislation before the Main

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee to consider. It is extraordinary.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can remember back to previous times

Speaker: NA
Text: before elections in 2004, 2001 and 1998. The

Speaker: NA
Text: House was full of legislation. There was a

Speaker: NA
Text: battle of ideas. What do we see from this

Speaker: NA
Text: government? This is a government that is out

Speaker: NA
Text: of ideas and out of legislation. Indeed, the

Speaker: NA
Text: only legislation that it has before this House

Speaker: NA
Text: to consider tends to be legislation amending

Speaker: NA
Text: its own legislation, such as Work Choices,

Speaker: NA
Text: because it has got the fundamentals of its

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation wrong. Surely the first step should

Speaker: NA
Text: be ensuring that the Main Committee does

Speaker: NA
Text: not sit vacant like it did during the last ses-

Speaker: NA
Text: out sion. The government is putting the cart be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the horse. You actually need some legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation before you expand the sittings of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Main Committee. This is in contrast to the

Speaker: NA
Text: solid legislative agenda that Labor has been

Speaker: NA
Text: outlining all year on climate change, on ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressing our water crisis, on broadband and

Speaker: NA
Text: on education. I would encourage the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment to actually refer the private mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber's bill that we have to ratify the Kyoto

Speaker: NA
Text: protocol, for example, to the Main Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee for full debate and then have a vote on it

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than sitting on this legislation and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: fusing to allow votes in this chamber or

Speaker: NA
Text: proper debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very clear, and we saw it again today

Speaker: NA
Text: when he was asked a question about the fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of education, that the prime minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: response is all about the past. His response

Speaker: NA
Text: was all about the 1990s-when we were

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about the budget here and through the

Speaker: NA
Text: forward estimates years to 2010-11. So we

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome the opportunity to have more de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate and we will be engaging in it. But we

Speaker: NA
Text: say to the government: if you are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase sitting times and make these

Speaker: NA
Text: changes then let us have more debate on the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy differences, which are stark, in this

Speaker: NA
Text: election year: the policy differences on ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressing our skills crisis, on addressing infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure, on the education revolution, on

Speaker: NA
Text: providing broadband, on addressing climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change and the water crisis, on addressing all

Speaker: NA
Text: these issues-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hockey-And industrial relations.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: and on making sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have a fair workplace relations sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem for Australia. What I would like to de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate as well is the failure of this government,

Speaker: NA
Text: when it comes to industrial relations, to ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress the issue of those workers from Tristar

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate. This government sat on its

Speaker: NA
Text: hands. I asked questions of the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter last year. We had a delegation, a busload,

Speaker: NA
Text: of workers from Tristar down here and the

Speaker: NA
Text: government refused to see them. It only no-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticed that this was an issue when Alan Jones

Speaker: NA
Text: and other people in the media took it up. The

Speaker: NA
Text: minister asked for a debate on these issues

Speaker: NA
Text: but he does not like hearing-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hockey-I rise on a point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only is the member factually incorrect

Speaker: NA
Text: but the matter is actually before the courts. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would urge the member to bear in mind that,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the matter is before the courts, we

Speaker: NA
Text: should not prejudice the court proceedings

Speaker: NA
Text: with debate.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! The

Speaker: NA
Text: chair is in the invidious position of not

Speaker: NA
Text: knowing at what stage the legal proceedings

Speaker: NA
Text: are. If there are matters before the court, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would hope that the member for Grayndler

Speaker: NA
Text: recognises that and couches his words in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the House of Representatives Prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: I assure you, Mr Dep-

Speaker: NA
Text: uty Speaker, that I certainly do. What is not

Speaker: NA
Text: before the courts is the fact that I asked

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of the Prime Minister and the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister dismissed them out of hand. What is

Speaker: NA
Text: not before the courts is the fact that a busload

Speaker: NA
Text: of workers from Tristar came here last year. I

Speaker: NA
Text: asked a question while they were in the gal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lery and the government refused to see them.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a fact. That is not before the courts;

Speaker: NA
Text: that is an absolute fact. The minister opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: said that he wanted more time in the Main

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee and in this chamber to talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial relations. He suggested that. I took

Speaker: NA
Text: it up. The first time I did there were objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, points of order and attempts to shut

Speaker: NA
Text: down debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hockey interjecting-

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: I will continue to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about Tristar, as I have been doing now for

Speaker: NA
Text: more than a year.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member will refer his remarks through

Speaker: NA
Text: the chair. The minister might assist by ceas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to interject.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: I believe that I have a

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility to represent those people, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause they were not going to get any repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentation from the other side. The fact is that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are prepared to support this motion ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tending the time of sittings for the Main

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee. We are prepared to facilitate

Speaker: NA
Text: these debates. We are prepared to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: every opportunity is taken to talk about the

Speaker: NA
Text: forward-looking agenda that Kevin Rudd and

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor are pursuing. I commend the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House. I suggest to the government

Speaker: NA
Text: and, through the minister, to the absent

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the House that to fill in this time in

Speaker: NA
Text: future we would be quite happy to debate the

Speaker: NA
Text: pieces of legislation that we have sitting on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Notice Paper, because that legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: represents the fact that we are ready to gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Australia into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: quesfirstly, to endorse the remarks of the Man-

Speaker: NA
Text: ager of Opposition Business in the House. I

Speaker: NA
Text: observe, like he did, that normal practice is

Speaker: NA
Text: of course that these changes to standing or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ders, which affect every member of this

Speaker: NA
Text: place, are moved by the Leader of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: or, in his absence, the Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. There is nothing particularly wrong

Speaker: NA
Text: with a minister introducing these changes.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, one does assume that he would at

Speaker: NA
Text: least explain to the House what the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: were. I find it a tad ironic that he took a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order on relevance about changes to stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing orders that he did not understand or was

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to explain to the House. Be that as it

Speaker: NA
Text: may, these are a minor but significant change

Speaker: NA
Text: because they allow what is effectively a pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate members' Monday in the Main Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee to parallel what is in the chamber should

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislative load be such that government

Speaker: NA
Text: bills can be debated on that sitting Monday.

Speaker: NA
Text: Priority of course is given to private mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers' business.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have seen increasing changes to what

Speaker: NA
Text: is actually being done in the Main Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee. This enhances the role and the impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance of the Main Committee. Like the Man-

Speaker: NA
Text: ager of Opposition Business, I certainly hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government has a legislative pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram which in fact would enable the Main

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee to be fully utilised and afford

Speaker: NA
Text: members the opportunity to debate legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. The minister at the table said that he

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to have a debate on industrial rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. I was wondering, for my own edifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, when the new legislation that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: announced will come in and when we will

Speaker: NA
Text: have that opportunity to debate those

Speaker: NA
Text: changes. Will he allow a full debate without

Speaker: NA
Text: it being truncated?

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: That the following order of the day, govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment business, be discharged: Child Support Leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation Amendment Bill 2004: Second reading-

Text: Resumption of debate.

Text: That the House grants leave for the report by

Speaker: NA
Text: Program, 24 May 1978, to be produced in pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceedings in the Federal Court of Australia in the

Text: case Collins v. Northern Territory of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in any subsequent proceedings.

Text: presented.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the bill be considered imme-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS'

Speaker: NA
Text: AFFAIRS LEGISLATION

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: MEASURES) BILL 2007

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: Jagajaga) (4.34 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (One-off Payments

Speaker: NA
Text: and Other 2007 Budget Measures) Bill 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: provides a one-off, non-taxable bonus pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of $500 to each person qualified for

Speaker: NA
Text: utilities allowance or seniors concession al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance on budget night. Labor supports this

Speaker: NA
Text: one-off bonus payment to these concession

Speaker: NA
Text: card holders because they certainly deserve

Speaker: NA
Text: this money, and many of them are struggling

Speaker: NA
Text: to make ends meet. The bill will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: $500 before the end of this financial year to

Speaker: NA
Text: all age pensioners and to those self-funded

Speaker: NA
Text: retirees earning less than $50,000 for singles

Speaker: NA
Text: or $80,000 for couples combined.

Speaker: NA
Text: We certainly support this initiative. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know that there have been significant in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases in the cost of living, and I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that, when all members of parliament are out

Speaker: NA
Text: in our shopping centres talking with con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents, they hear on a regular basis how

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult it is for seniors, in particular, to

Speaker: NA
Text: make ends meet given the ongoing rises in

Speaker: NA
Text: food prices. In the last quarter, in March

Speaker: NA
Text: prices rose by 4.6 per cent. This was particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly due to increases in fruit prices, which

Speaker: NA
Text: rose by almost 15 per cent. It is not surpris-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that we often hear from seniors in our

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates about how difficult it is for them

Speaker: NA
Text: to manage. The price of petrol and other very

Speaker: NA
Text: important utilities and basics that people

Speaker: NA
Text: need just to manage from week to week have

Speaker: NA
Text: also risen.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also know that our seniors provide the

Speaker: NA
Text: backbone for many of the voluntary organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sations in our community and spend a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: their own money, especially on petrol, going

Speaker: NA
Text: to help out those in even greater need in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community, visiting and providing support

Speaker: NA
Text: for the very aged and for others who are on

Speaker: NA
Text: their own. This $500 payment will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: that extra bit of help that I am sure the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipients will appreciate. The payment will

Speaker: NA
Text: also go to those of service pension age re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceiving, as I mentioned, the utilities allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance or the seniors concessional allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: and to those receiving the mature age allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance, the widows allowance and the partner

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance. All of those people will receive

Speaker: NA
Text: the payment before the end of June.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill also provides payments to a wide

Speaker: NA
Text: range of carers. We know that in many cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances they too are working extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: hard to care for their loved ones. A payment

Speaker: NA
Text: of $1,000 will be made to carers who are

Speaker: NA
Text: currently receiving the carer payment. Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipients of the carer allowance will receive a

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of $600 for every eligible care re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceiver. In addition to the $600 carer allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance bonus, recipients of the carer allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: who also receive the wife pension or the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment of Veterans' Affairs partner service

Speaker: NA
Text: pension will receive a payment of $1,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: The last three budgets have provided similar

Speaker: NA
Text: one-off lump sum bonuses to eligible carers.

Speaker: NA
Text: We certainly welcome these payments be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause we know that, as with seniors, many

Speaker: NA
Text: carers are finding it difficult to make ends

Speaker: NA
Text: food meet-and, of course, it is very hard for

Speaker: NA
Text: them to find time to be able to earn any

Speaker: NA
Text: money. We know that they also have signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant extra costs because of their caring re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure that I speak for all members of

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament when I say that many carers feel

Speaker: NA
Text: that their work is undervalued. I think people

Speaker: NA
Text: often feel that way because, in the vast ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: jority of cases, their work is carried out be-

Speaker: NA
Text: hind closed doors, in people's homes. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think they feel that they are well under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stood. Also, an increasing number of women

Speaker: NA
Text: aged between 35 and 54-often called the

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘sandwich generation'-are being asked to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide most of the care needed by their

Speaker: NA
Text: children and by frail older people who are,

Speaker: NA
Text: most often, related to them. We do have a

Speaker: NA
Text: rapidly ageing population in Australia, so we

Speaker: NA
Text: can only expect that the number of people

Speaker: NA
Text: who will need to be cared for in this way will

Speaker: NA
Text: increase. There are about 2.6 million carers

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. I hope that the support that this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill will provide to them will give them the

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition that they deserve and that bit of

Speaker: NA
Text: extra relief to help them meet the heavy load

Speaker: NA
Text: that they carry.

Speaker: NA
Text: A major study done in 2006, called the

Speaker: NA
Text: AMP.NATSEM study, found that the average

Speaker: NA
Text: carer is $5,600 worse off each year compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with someone with no caring responsibilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also know that one in every seven Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians is providing primary or informal care

Speaker: NA
Text: for an older frail relative or one with a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability. As I mentioned before, most of that

Speaker: NA
Text: burden is still falling on women. The report

Speaker: NA
Text: also goes into the expectation that these re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibilities will increase as the population

Speaker: NA
Text: ages. This will happen at the same time that

Speaker: NA
Text: we see an increase in the need for women to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate in the workforce, which is also

Speaker: NA
Text: related to the ageing of the population. The

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities that those women will have

Speaker: NA
Text: to carry-workforce responsibilities and car-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing responsibilities for their children and

Speaker: NA
Text: ageing parents-are likely to increase. We

Speaker: NA
Text: also know that carers are more often than not

Speaker: NA
Text: family members and that it is often the case

Speaker: NA
Text: that the carer is an elderly person them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. I certainly know from my own fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily's circumstances that that can be an enor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mous responsibility as well as a very heavy

Speaker: NA
Text: load. Carers are doing this day in and day

Speaker: NA
Text: out-and often during the night as well when

Speaker: NA
Text: it involves the support of someone who is

Speaker: NA
Text: frail or ill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also contains a number of meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures to support veterans and war widows and

Speaker: NA
Text: widowers, and I want to go through each of

Speaker: NA
Text: those. Schedule 5 of the bill will make one-

Speaker: NA
Text: off payments on 1 January 2007 to Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian former prisoners of war in Europe or

Speaker: NA
Text: their surviving widows. We certainly wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: come this initiative. I notice that the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow minister is at the table, and he will

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly endorse my remarks that this pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is long overdue. Unfortunately, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government left these Australian prisoners of

Speaker: NA
Text: war from Japan and Korea out of the first

Speaker: NA
Text: two ex gratia payments in 2001 and 2004. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am pleased to see that that oversight has now

Speaker: NA
Text: been rectified.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also increase the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: funeral benefit from $1,000 to $2,000 for

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible veterans under the Veterans' Enti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tlements Act 1986. Once again, we welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: this initiative. We know-my colleague at

Speaker: NA
Text: the table is very well aware of this-that the

Speaker: NA
Text: funeral benefit has been a longstanding con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern in the veterans community, and this ini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiative is certainly a step in the right direc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also increase the veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: disability pension for special rate and inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediate rate recipients by $50 and $25 a

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight respectively from 3 July 2007. This

Speaker: NA
Text: will benefit around 29,600 veterans who re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive either the special rate or the intermedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate rate of disability pension because their

Speaker: NA
Text: injuries or diseases related to war or defence

Speaker: NA
Text: service on behalf of Australia limit their

Speaker: NA
Text: earning capacity. Once again, we welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: this catch-up payment. It was needed to ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress the erosion of these pensions that, un-

Speaker: NA
Text: der the Howard government, has occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: since 1997. It is unfortunate that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment has not taken this opportunity to fix

Speaker: NA
Text: the indexation of these pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: By contrast-and this is a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: contrast between the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Labor opposition-Labor has already

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to properly indexing these pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions in the same way that the age pension is

Speaker: NA
Text: indexed. I call on the government to follow

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's lead to make sure that these people

Speaker: NA
Text: do not fall behind in the way they have over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last few years. It is unfortunate that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government did not include extreme dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ablement adjustment pension recipients in

Speaker: NA
Text: this catch-up budget. As I am sure everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House knows, these veterans fought in

Speaker: NA
Text: World War II, Korea and Malaya and suffer

Speaker: NA
Text: from severe disabilities. Unfortunately, it

Speaker: NA
Text: seems that once again they have been ig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nored by the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: War widows who claim a pension follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the death of their spouse will now re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive an additional three months to claim a

Speaker: NA
Text: backdated war widow's pension. Once again,

Speaker: NA
Text: we think this is a good move. From 1 July

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007, war widows who claim the pension

Speaker: NA
Text: within six months of their spouse's death will

Speaker: NA
Text: have their pension backdated to the time of

Speaker: NA
Text: death, recognising that the death of a spouse

Speaker: NA
Text: in this situation is extremely difficult. This

Speaker: NA
Text: provision gives our war widows time to

Speaker: NA
Text: come to terms with all the things they need

Speaker: NA
Text: to do following a very painful and difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: event.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor have been calling on the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to address the erosion of our most se-

Speaker: NA
Text: verely disabled war veterans pensions. I want

Speaker: NA
Text: to inform the House about the dimension of

Speaker: NA
Text: the loss that these pensioners have faced be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the government's refusal to properly

Speaker: NA
Text: index their pensions. Over the last 10 years,

Speaker: NA
Text: because these pensions are only linked to

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in the cost of living, there has in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact been a drop of over $70 a fortnight in

Speaker: NA
Text: the value of the special rate disability pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. That is a very substantial amount for

Speaker: NA
Text: people dependent upon a pension. Similarly,

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been an erosion in the value of the

Speaker: NA
Text: extreme disablement adjustment and inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediate pensions. Once again, I say to the

Speaker: NA
Text: government that, although we do support

Speaker: NA
Text: what is in this bill, it really is

Speaker: NA
Text: the long-term problem of indexation of these

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions is addressed. It is only by address-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the long-term problem and making sure

Speaker: NA
Text: we have proper indexation that veterans will

Speaker: NA
Text: be given the certainty that the value of their

Speaker: NA
Text: payments will be maintained and the dignity

Speaker: NA
Text: of their circumstances will be respected.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, I am very pleased we have indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated that, if we are successful at the next

Speaker: NA
Text: election, a Rudd Labor government will

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that our most severely disabled

Speaker: NA
Text: war veterans will have their pensions ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: justed to take account of not just the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: living but also the standard of living. A La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor government will make sure that these

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans will no longer have to depend on

Speaker: NA
Text: the government delivering the sorts of ad

Speaker: NA
Text: hoc, catch-up payments that we are debating

Speaker: NA
Text: today. If Labor is successful at the next elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, future increases that account for both

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in the cost of living and the stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dard of living will be automatic under Labor.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indexation is the only long-term solution to

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain the true value of veterans pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1997, when the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: indexed a range of other pensions, they left

Speaker: NA
Text: out the above general rate disability pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions. Since that time there has been an ero-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of the value of these pensions compared

Speaker: NA
Text: to pensions in the broader community-for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, in 1997 the special rate disability

Speaker: NA
Text: pension represented 46.3 per cent of male

Speaker: NA
Text: total average weekly earnings. On the most

Speaker: NA
Text: recent figures available, it now represents

Speaker: NA
Text: only 42.9 per cent. The government provided

Speaker: NA
Text: only partial indexation in 2004, and that was

Speaker: NA
Text: in response to sustained protest from the vet-

Speaker: NA
Text: eran community. Unfortunately, it was only a

Speaker: NA
Text: bandaid solution, and tonight we are debat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing another catch-up rather than a long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: solution. We certainly do not want to treat

Speaker: NA
Text: our most severely disabled war veterans in

Speaker: NA
Text: this way. Labor wants to give war veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: high time that security for the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: To be very specific about what we intend

Speaker: NA
Text: to do: if we are successful at the next elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, Labor will restore the value of the spe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial rate disability pension, the intermediate

Speaker: NA
Text: rate and the extreme disablement adjustment

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions by indexing the whole of these pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions to movements in male total average

Speaker: NA
Text: weekly earnings or the consumer price index,

Speaker: NA
Text: whichever is greater. This will benefit more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 43,000 war veterans with disabilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: On current projections, over the first four

Speaker: NA
Text: years after implementation, the recipients of

Speaker: NA
Text: these pensions will be $1,700 better off, with

Speaker: NA
Text: their pensions building to $30 a fortnight

Speaker: NA
Text: more than they would otherwise have been.

Speaker: NA
Text: The announcement certainly concerns the

Speaker: NA
Text: most severely disabled of our war veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: They include those who fought and served in

Speaker: NA
Text: conflicts including World War II, Korea, Ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: laya, Vietnam, the Gulf War, East Timor, Iraq

Speaker: NA
Text: and Afghanistan. Unfortunately, we are al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready seeing veterans from Iraq and Af-

Speaker: NA
Text: ghanistan needing assistance. As of Decem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber 2006, eight soldiers who served in Af-

Speaker: NA
Text: ghanistan and two from Iraq would be af-

Speaker: NA
Text: fected by Labor's commitment. I certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: hope we are able to deliver that increase as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of being successful at the next elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I am sure everybody here knows, our

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans have paid a very high price for their

Speaker: NA
Text: service to our country, and this really is

Speaker: NA
Text: about fixing an injustice. Once again, I want

Speaker: NA
Text: to give credit to our shadow minister. A lot

Speaker: NA
Text: people at my recent Anzac Day service at the

Speaker: NA
