Text: repatriation hospital in Melbourne said to me

Speaker: NA
Text: how grateful they were for the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Bruce has been willing to

Speaker: NA
Text: listen and to convince our colleagues about

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance of this measure. I know how

Speaker: NA
Text: much it is appreciated by veterans. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that would apply not just to people in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate but to people right around Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I just want to say in summary that we

Speaker: NA
Text: support these payments. We think that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are very important and we want them to get

Speaker: NA
Text: into the hands of the carers, seniors and vet-

Speaker: NA
Text: erans as quickly as possible. However, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunate, given that the bill has been

Speaker: NA
Text: brought in so quickly, that the financial im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pact statement contained in the explanatory

Speaker: NA
Text: memorandum does not give any indication of

Speaker: NA
Text: departmental costs associated with the pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. I would just say to the minister that

Speaker: NA
Text: when he is summing up this debate-we ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously do not want to hold up the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion; we think it is very important-these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters nevertheless need to be dealt with

Speaker: NA
Text: properly, because the parliament needs to

Speaker: NA
Text: know about these costs. In this bill, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: also very wide powers given to the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to make administrative arrangements for

Speaker: NA
Text: these payments by legislative instruments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Once again, I think these issues need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: properly explained when the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: comes into the parliament. I will finish by

Speaker: NA
Text: reiterating Labor's strong support for these

Speaker: NA
Text: payments. We know that, for many seniors,

Speaker: NA
Text: carers and veterans, life is pretty tough. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: hard for them to make ends meet, and I know

Speaker: NA
Text: any support will be very gratefully received.

Speaker: Mr FAWCETT
Text: Wakefield) (4.53 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to address the Social Security and Veter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (One-

Speaker: NA
Text: off Payments and Other 2007 Budget Meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures) Bill 2007, which deals with a very im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant issue for our community. When I

Speaker: NA
Text: of have sent out surveys or stood for long peri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ods of time in shopping centres and spoken

Speaker: NA
Text: to people, I have been given consistent feed-

Speaker: NA
Text: back from seniors in our community, who

Speaker: NA
Text: talk to me about the various situations they

Speaker: NA
Text: find themselves in. The thing that strikes me

Speaker: NA
Text: is that there are a range of situations. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: spoken in this House before about the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that some seniors are doing very well, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly those who own their own homes in

Speaker: NA
Text: areas that do not have high council rates and

Speaker: NA
Text: where they have access to public transport et

Speaker: NA
Text: cetera, but there are some-perhaps those in

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing Trust homes who do not have ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess to public transport or those with very

Speaker: NA
Text: high council rates-who, for the same given

Speaker: NA
Text: income, really struggle to put food on the

Speaker: NA
Text: table. I think it is important that at this time,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the budget, we look at any measures we

Speaker: NA
Text: can to make sure that we have the fairest and

Speaker: NA
Text: most equitable distribution of some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth that this nation is enjoying to those

Speaker: NA
Text: who have gone before us and helped to build

Speaker: NA
Text: this nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The older Australians bonus of $500 is

Speaker: NA
Text: payable to every person over pension age

Speaker: NA
Text: who is eligible for the utilities allowance or

Speaker: NA
Text: the seniors concession allowance on budget

Speaker: NA
Text: night this week. For DVA pensioners this

Speaker: NA
Text: also includes age, invalidity or partner ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice pensioners over pension age, and Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth seniors health card holders and

Speaker: NA
Text: gold card holders over pension age. These

Speaker: NA
Text: are one-off payments but they are non-

Speaker: NA
Text: taxable and they are not classed as income.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those are important things, because some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the feedback I have had from people is that

Speaker: NA
Text: they have appreciated rises in pensions be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore but particularly those in Housing Trust

Speaker: NA
Text: properties have noted that some of that-in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, a substantial amount-gets taken away

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Housing Trust. So those people are

Speaker: NA
Text: not as well off as we would have intended by

Speaker: NA
Text: giving them a rise in their pensions. By tak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this approach of a bonus-as we look at

Speaker: NA
Text: things like the utilities allowance-we have

Speaker: NA
Text: ensured that it does not come into the equa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion when things like house trust rents are

Speaker: NA
Text: calculated. So the people who are receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: this bonus are actually getting the opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity to use the entire bonus for the purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: that they want to in their own households.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether that is to pay off bills, to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: things around the home or to do other things,

Speaker: NA
Text: the entire amount is available to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the electorate of Wakefield, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: some 15,000 aged pensioners in receipt of

Speaker: NA
Text: the utilities allowance who will receive this

Speaker: NA
Text: $500, and there are nearly 1,200 seniors in

Speaker: NA
Text: receipt of the senior concession allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: who will receive it as well. So well over

Speaker: NA
Text: 16,000 seniors in Wakefield will receive this

Speaker: NA
Text: $500, which is one way that this government,

Speaker: NA
Text: through its responsible economic manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, can share the wealth that this country

Speaker: NA
Text: is currently generating.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other people whom I interact with on

Speaker: NA
Text: a regular basis are in groups such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Elizabeth Special School-the parents there

Speaker: NA
Text: who care for children with special needs-

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Northern Carers Network, including

Speaker: NA
Text: Maria Ross, who runs that organisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are people who care for the elderly and

Speaker: NA
Text: those with disabilities or chronic illnesses.

Speaker: NA
Text: They invest a huge amount in some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: most frail and needy in our community, and

Speaker: NA
Text: we cannot begin to thank them enough for

Speaker: NA
Text: that. The carer bonuses, which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: paid now for the fourth year in a row, are just

Speaker: NA
Text: a small way in which the government recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nises the invaluable work that these people

Speaker: NA
Text: do.

Speaker: NA
Text: As in previous years, this year the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment will provide a lump sum payment to

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible carers who were in receipt of the

Speaker: NA
Text: carer payment or the carer service pension

Speaker: NA
Text: and/or the carer allowance and those in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceipt of the wife pension or the DVA partner

Speaker: NA
Text: service pension who also receive carer al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance on budget night this year. In Wake-

Speaker: NA
Text: field's case, nearly 4,400 people are in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceipt of carers allowance. They will receive

Speaker: NA
Text: that $600 bonus. Over 1,000 people who are

Speaker: NA
Text: in receipt of the carer payment will also re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive it. So nearly 5,500 people who are car-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers-who are giving of their time, energy

Speaker: NA
Text: with and compassion to care for those around

Speaker: NA
Text: them-are recognised in a small but signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant way through this measure, which I wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: come.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also welcome the opposition's support

Speaker: NA
Text: for these measures. It is encouraging to see

Speaker: NA
Text: that they also see the benefit of it, but I am

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhat bemused by their comments about

Speaker: NA
Text: the measures that we have taken to support

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans. As someone who served for over

Speaker: NA
Text: 22 years in the armed forces I am very aware

Speaker: NA
Text: of the needs of veterans. Certainly one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: large issues that have been brought to my

Speaker: NA
Text: attention time and again by the TPI organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is the matter of the indexation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: income or compensation aspects. This gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment has chosen to increase the special

Speaker: NA
Text: rate by $50 a fortnight and the intermediate

Speaker: NA
Text: rate by $25 a fortnight, with effect from July

Speaker: NA
Text: this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that the opposition has welcomed

Speaker: NA
Text: that, but, at the same time, they criticise it

Speaker: NA
Text: and say how good their plan is. But I notice

Speaker: NA
Text: that their plan, announced by Mr Rudd, looks

Speaker: NA
Text: at commencing indexation, which would

Speaker: NA
Text: build over a four-year period to a sum of $30

Speaker: NA
Text: per fortnight. The previous speaker was say-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing just before that, under their plans veter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ans would be better off by some $1,700. Un-

Speaker: NA
Text: der our plan, because the $50 comes into

Speaker: NA
Text: effect from July this year and is not incre-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentally built over four years, TPI pension-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers will be better off by over $5,000. When

Speaker: NA
Text: you compare those two schemes, it is fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: clear that we have taken a step that optimises

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefit to these veterans who have served

Speaker: NA
Text: our country, with immediate effect from July

Speaker: NA
Text: this year. I certainly welcome that move. I

Speaker: NA
Text: also welcome the moves in terms of funeral

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits, although personally I am disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed they were not greater, and I welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that war widows now have a longer

Speaker: NA
Text: period in which to register their claims for

Speaker: NA
Text: the new pension once their husband or wife

Speaker: NA
Text: dies from a war-related cause.

Speaker: NA
Text: The important thing that has come out of

Speaker: NA
Text: this is that this government is able to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: these support measures to people who have

Speaker: NA
Text: gone before us in our community because its

Speaker: NA
Text: good economic management has led to more

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue. Why is there more revenue? It is

Speaker: NA
Text: because there are more people in work, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause business has been encouraged and be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause there has been investment in this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try. We have seen revenue go up, which has

Speaker: NA
Text: given the government more options to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide for carers, for our seniors, for education,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the environment, for infrastructure and

Speaker: NA
Text: for defence. Because of good economic

Speaker: NA
Text: management, we are able to do the important

Speaker: NA
Text: things that a government should do.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am glad to see that the opposition have

Speaker: NA
Text: supported these measures. I am disappointed,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, that over the last 10 years they

Speaker: NA
Text: have not supported the measures that have

Speaker: NA
Text: led to this economic outcome. When we

Speaker: NA
Text: came to office in 1996, there was $96 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: of debt, resulting in $8½ billion of interest

Speaker: NA
Text: having to be paid every year. There were

Speaker: NA
Text: deficits year after year, which meant there

Speaker: NA
Text: was no capacity to provide this sort of sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port to a range of people with a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: needs in our community. So, whilst I am glad

Speaker: NA
Text: they support these measures, I am disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed they have not supported the eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic measures over the years that have led

Speaker: NA
Text: to us having the economic capacity to share

Speaker: NA
Text: the wealth of this nation not only across port-

Speaker: NA
Text: folio areas but, importantly, with our seniors,

Speaker: NA
Text: our carers and our veterans, to whom we owe

Speaker: NA
Text: an enormous debt of gratitude.

Speaker: Mr GRIFFIN
Text: Bruce) (5.02 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to welcome the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment (One-off Payments and Other 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget Measures) Bill 2007 and to make

Speaker: NA
Text: some brief points today, particularly relating

Speaker: NA
Text: to the veterans and ex-services community. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will focus on two or three points and I will

Speaker: NA
Text: pick up on a couple of points that my friend

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Wakefield made on the way

Speaker: NA
Text: through-they were not bad points, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to further clarify our position with re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect to indexation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will start off with the compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: payments under schedule 5 for certain World

Speaker: NA
Text: War II internments. Under this schedule, the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill will make one-off payments of $25,000

Speaker: NA
Text: to former Australian prisoners of war in

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe or to their surviving widows as at 1

Speaker: NA
Text: January 2007. Labor welcomes this ex gratia

Speaker: NA
Text: payment. This is a long overdue initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: that addresses an injustice that left these

Speaker: NA
Text: prisoners out of two previous ex gratia pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2001 the Howard government made a

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of $25,000 to former Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: prisoners of war in Japan. At this stage there

Speaker: NA
Text: was much criticism that they had left out the

Speaker: NA
Text: POWs of Europe and Korea. The govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment ignored the criticism at this time. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004, after the Clarke review, they finally

Speaker: NA
Text: made a payment to former Australian prison-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers of war in Korea. Again they were criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cised for leaving out Australian prisoners of

Speaker: NA
Text: war in Europe. Finally, six years and two

Speaker: NA
Text: elections after the original announcement,

Speaker: NA
Text: these former prisoners or their surviving

Speaker: NA
Text: widows are getting what is duly owed to

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Until now, the government argued that the

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions experienced by the POWs in

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe did not warrant this payment. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, one thing should be made very clear,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that is that prisoners of war interned in

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe did suffer, and they suffered consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: erably. Returned POWs reported a lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate medical care and facilities; an

Speaker: NA
Text: inadequate diet; inappropriate washing facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties; sleeping quarters infested with lice and

Speaker: NA
Text: vermin; confinement in small spaces without

Speaker: NA
Text: toilet facilities, food and water whilst being

Speaker: NA
Text: transported; physical abuse from their cap-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors; forced marches; slave labour; being

Speaker: NA
Text: shot or abused when caught trying to escape;

Speaker: NA
Text: and being shackled. In addition, POWs were

Speaker: NA
Text: subjected to the extreme cold of European

Speaker: NA
Text: winters while lacking rations. The Ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: Prisoners of War Association of Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: argued that breaches of the Geneva conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion varied between regions, while other

Speaker: NA
Text: breaches relating to security, rations, medical

Speaker: NA
Text: matters, transport and shackling were more

Speaker: NA
Text: systematic and clearly the policy of the Ger-

Speaker: NA
Text: man high command. Labor congratulates the

Speaker: NA
Text: government on finally correcting this injus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice and fully supports this worthwhile initia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive. I would like to particularly congratulate

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister because I know that he has been

Speaker: NA
Text: interested in this issue since he became the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister. I give him credit for being able to

Speaker: NA
Text: steer this action through at this budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will talk briefly about some other mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters. Under schedule 6 there are amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: to increase funeral benefits. The bill will in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease the maximum funeral benefit for eli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gible veterans under the Veterans' Entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments Act 1986 from $1,000 to $2,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, Labor congratulates the government

Speaker: NA
Text: on this initiative. There has been a longstand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing concern within the veterans community

Speaker: NA
Text: about the low level of this benefit in com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parison to the benefit allowed under the Mili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary Rehabilitation and Compensation Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004. This goes some way to addressing this

Speaker: NA
Text: discrepancy and is a positive step in the right

Speaker: NA
Text: direction. It certainly is an issue that is raised

Speaker: NA
Text: with me regularly within the veterans com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity as something that they see as being

Speaker: NA
Text: quite inequitable. I know that many in the

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans community will not feel this has

Speaker: NA
Text: gone far enough. I understand their position

Speaker: NA
Text: on that. It is something that we will look at,

Speaker: NA
Text: but at this stage I congratulate the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on taking action with this initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next item I would like to discuss is

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendments under schedule 7 to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: the rates of certain pensions. Under this

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule the bill will increase the veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: disability pension for special rate and inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediate rate recipients by $50 and $25 re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spectively per fortnight from 3 July 2007.

Speaker: NA
Text: This measure will benefit around 29,600 vet-

Speaker: NA
Text: erans who receive either the special rate or

Speaker: NA
Text: the intermediate rate of disability pension

Speaker: NA
Text: because their injuries or diseases, related to

Speaker: NA
Text: war or defence service on behalf of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia, limit their earning capacity. This was a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter which the member for Wakefield

Speaker: NA
Text: spoke about earlier. He sought to contrast his

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of our position on this issue

Speaker: NA
Text: with the government's and to focus on cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain aspects of that. I will go to that matter

Speaker: NA
Text: briefly. I make it very clear at this stage

Speaker: NA
Text: we completely support the payments that are

Speaker: NA
Text: being made through this process.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to make my argument on this issue

Speaker: NA
Text: clear: there has been a significant erosion as

Speaker: NA
Text: a result of incomplete indexation for those

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans under the special rate disability

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, the intermediate rate pension and the

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely disabled adjustment pension over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 11 years. It dates back to when the

Speaker: NA
Text: government itself created a situation where

Speaker: NA
Text: we had male total average weekly earnings

Speaker: NA
Text: or CPI, whichever is the greater, for the age

Speaker: NA
Text: pension and a number of other pensions but

Speaker: NA
Text: it left these pensions on CPI increases. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is an argument for it. It is an argument which

Speaker: NA
Text: was not accepted by the veterans community,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is an argument which has been debated

Speaker: NA
Text: with a good deal of heat, passion and anger

Speaker: NA
Text: within the veterans community over the last

Speaker: NA
Text: decade. It was reconsidered as part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Clarke review, and the government made

Speaker: NA
Text: some changes with respect to splitting the

Speaker: NA
Text: payment in two. But I think it is fair to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that, although that addressed part of the is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sue, it actually created a good deal more

Speaker: NA
Text: concern and in fact incensed elements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans community on the basis that it was

Speaker: NA
Text: not seen to be fair, reasonable or just in the

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we have seen under that erosion

Speaker: NA
Text: over the last 10-plus years now is-

Speaker: NA
Text: depending on whom you talk to-an impact

Speaker: NA
Text: of somewhere between $70 and $92-plus a

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight for someone on the special rate dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability pension. So it is significant; there is

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely no doubt about that. Over that

Speaker: NA
Text: period, we have seen no catch-up payment,

Speaker: NA
Text: none at all, to address the issue of that ero-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. There was one catch-up payment-if

Speaker: NA
Text: you could call it that-one adjustment. That

Speaker: NA
Text: related to the implementation of the GST.

Speaker: NA
Text: Essentially, as many lower income earners

Speaker: NA
Text: were receiving some additional compensa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to make up for the costs of the GST,

Speaker: NA
Text: that there was a small increase. But, in the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: text of the erosion of the value, this is the

Speaker: NA
Text: first time. We are talking 12 budgets to actu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally see some action. To put that into per-

Speaker: NA
Text: spective, $50 in one hit sounds great-it

Speaker: NA
Text: sounds fantastic; it sounds significant-but it

Speaker: NA
Text: pen- is just over $4, $4.17 or thereabouts, per

Speaker: NA
Text: budget if you add it up over time. When you

Speaker: NA
Text: put it in that perspective, it is significant but

Speaker: NA
Text: there is still a long way to go.

Speaker: NA
Text: The position that I have taken on this is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sue, and it was announced recently, related to

Speaker: NA
Text: indexation, which we sought to put forward

Speaker: NA
Text: as policy-in fact, the member for Wakefield

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned it-because that has been the

Speaker: NA
Text: principal demand from right across the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: service organisations and the veterans com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity. Indexation is required to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is certainty, dignity and justice in the

Speaker: NA
Text: payments that they receive and to halt the

Speaker: NA
Text: erosion.

Speaker: NA
Text: On from that, there has been the issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: that erosion and the impact of dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: that erosion-the question of a catch-up

Speaker: NA
Text: payment. The position that I have put with

Speaker: NA
Text: respect to that issue is very clearly this: La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor stood ready to accept and to support any

Speaker: NA
Text: payment that the government came forward

Speaker: NA
Text: with which actually dealt with the issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: that catch-up, because we knew and we be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that, as that erosion occurred under this

Speaker: NA
Text: government, this government has the respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility to deal with it and to bring forward a

Speaker: NA
Text: measure to compensate those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: missed out as a result of that erosion.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Wakefield made a point

Speaker: NA
Text: about the value of our proposal-probably

Speaker: NA
Text: best estimated over a period of four years

Speaker: NA
Text: from introduction-being something like

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,700 net and $30 per fortnight at the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: that four-year period and that that is there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore significantly less than what the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment proposes with $50 a fortnight now,

Speaker: NA
Text: which will add up to something like five

Speaker: NA
Text: grand. The point is this: that is something

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government needed to do because of

Speaker: NA
Text: its neglect over the last decade. Labor sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port that payment going forward. Ours is

Speaker: NA
Text: additional to that and ours remains additional

Speaker: NA
Text: to that, so let us be in no doubt about the

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances here. The government has done

Speaker: NA
Text: what the government had to do, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: government had let the whole system go to

Speaker: NA
Text: seed. We have said that we will endorse that

Speaker: NA
Text: payment and will then further increase it by

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing indexation. It has taken 12 budg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ets for a catch-up payment. When will the

Speaker: NA
Text: next one be-in another 12 budgets? How

Speaker: NA
Text: much greater will the difference be over that

Speaker: NA
Text: period of time?

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact of the matter is that these people

Speaker: NA
Text: need certainty, they deserve certainty, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: will give them certainty after the next elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by ensuring that there is no further ero-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. We will restore indexation so it is there

Speaker: NA
Text: for all these people who have been affected.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the important thing about our policy

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is the difference between us and the

Speaker: NA
Text: government on this issue. We fully support

Speaker: NA
Text: this as part recompense for what went

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong, but we want to try to set up a system

Speaker: NA
Text: into the future that means we will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: coming back here in five, 10 or 12 years time

Speaker: NA
Text: once again saying, ‘Here's a payment to

Speaker: NA
Text: make up for what you've lost over the last

Speaker: NA
Text: decade.' I think that is a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: point.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have to say, though, that that is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: way the minister saw it. When the details of

Speaker: NA
Text: our announcement came out, Minister Bill-

Speaker: NA
Text: son was quoted in the Herald Sun in an arti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cle by Neil Wilson entitled ‘Labor's plan

Speaker: NA
Text: wins veterans'. The article reads in part:

Speaker: NA
Text: But Veterans Affairs Minister Bruce Billson

Speaker: NA
Text: slammed the measure as a “cobbled together me-

Speaker: NA
Text: dia stunt”.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Billson said it would take until 2012 for

Speaker: NA
Text: disabled veterans to achieve any real benefit.

Speaker: NA
Text: He then went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: They say this is about equity but it is illogical.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is inconsistent and unprincipled in ignoring

Speaker: NA
Text: 100,000 other people on lesser degrees of disabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity pension ...

Speaker: NA
Text: cirI will just pick up on a couple of points. In

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of it being a ‘cobbled together media

Speaker: NA
Text: stunt', we can always debate the issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: when these things are announced. Let me

Speaker: NA
Text: make it very clear that I, and Labor, have

Speaker: NA
Text: been working on this policy for quite some

Speaker: NA
Text: time. I have been talking about this issue in

Speaker: NA
Text: speeches at veterans congresses all over this

Speaker: NA
Text: country for more than 12 months. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been saying that this is an issue that is under

Speaker: NA
Text: serious consideration. Senior people within

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-service organisations in this country can

Speaker: NA
Text: confirm that. They know because I and oth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers have been talking to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am joined today by the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cowan. I know he has an in-depth under-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing of this issue and his knowledge has

Speaker: NA
Text: been of great assistance to me in trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: come to grips with what is in many ways a

Speaker: NA
Text: very complex issue. This is not something

Speaker: NA
Text: that has just occurred overnight. A lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: work has gone into it, and therefore I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: think it can be considered to be a ‘cobbled

Speaker: NA
Text: together media stunt'. The minister also said

Speaker: NA
Text: that it would take until 2012 for disabled

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans to achieve any real benefit. Again,

Speaker: NA
Text: that is just not true. Under our proposal, the

Speaker: NA
Text: first indexation point after our first budget

Speaker: NA
Text: will be September 2008. The difference be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween MTAWE and CPI will be paid at that

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The point in relation to the $30 is that that

Speaker: NA
Text: is what we estimate the likely cap to be over

Speaker: NA
Text: the four-year period of the forward estimates,

Speaker: NA
Text: but people will be getting money as they be-

Speaker: NA
Text: come entitled to it, under the CPI versus

Speaker: NA
Text: MTAWE adjustment, every six months. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact, the minister is wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the issue of equity, the minister is say-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing it is illogical and inconsistent. He men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned the issue of the 100,000 other people

Speaker: NA
Text: on lesser degrees of disability pension. What

Speaker: NA
Text: he is talking about is people on varying rates

Speaker: NA
Text: of disability as a result of general rate dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability pensions. Again, this is a complex

Speaker: NA
Text: area and I will not take the time of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: to go through it in detail. But I will say a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of things. Firstly, in respect of general

Speaker: NA
Text: rate disability pension I do not wish to deni-

Speaker: NA
Text: grate in any way the disabilities that many

Speaker: NA
Text: people have, but the key issue normally in

Speaker: NA
Text: the consideration between general rate dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability pension and special rates and inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediate rates is the recipient's capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: work. Secondly, the minister's own press

Speaker: NA
Text: release with respect to the catch-up payment

Speaker: NA
Text: is interesting. I will go to what he said to

Speaker: NA
Text: justify why special rate and intermediate rate

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners got this catch-up payment but

Speaker: NA
Text: nobody else did. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The special rate takes into account incapacity

Speaker: NA
Text: from war or defence caused disabilities that

Speaker: NA
Text: are so great that a veteran cannot undertake any

Speaker: NA
Text: employment totalling more than eight hours per

Speaker: NA
Text: week. The intermediate rate takes into account

Speaker: NA
Text: incapacity from war or defence caused disabilities

Speaker: NA
Text: that alone are so great that a veteran cannot un-

Speaker: NA
Text: dertake any employment other than on a part-time

Speaker: NA
Text: or intermittent basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is exactly the case. The point is that, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the paper, the minister accuses Labor of be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing illogical and inconsistent with respect to

Speaker: NA
Text: this particular difference, yet he himself has

Speaker: NA
Text: used this definition as a basis for citing why

Speaker: NA
Text: certain groups have got this payment and

Speaker: NA
Text: certain groups have not. I think the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was right in the budget press release, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: think he was wrong in the newspaper article.

Speaker: NA
Text: In those circumstances, he ought to have an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other hard look at his position on this issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an issue of real and ongoing concern

Speaker: NA
Text: within the veteran community and it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: going to go away. The reason it is not going

Speaker: NA
Text: to go away is that, once again, whether it be

Speaker: NA
Text: July 2007, July 2008, July 2009 or July

Speaker: NA
Text: 2010, the fact is that the erosion will con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue. Six months after the $50 is paid the

Speaker: NA
Text: erosion will continue-and it will keep go-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. People will be left to come back, cap in

Speaker: NA
Text: hand, just before the election after next, to

Speaker: NA
Text: seek some recompense, some catch up, in a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation which is not fair, not justified, not

Speaker: NA
Text: dignified and not something that these peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple deserve to be put through.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to pick up on another couple of is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sues under the bill. Under schedule 8 there

Speaker: NA
Text: are amendments relating to the backdating of

Speaker: NA
Text: war widow and widower payments. Under

Speaker: NA
Text: this schedule the bill will allow war widows

Speaker: NA
Text: who claim a war widows pension following

Speaker: NA
Text: the death of their spouse an additional three

Speaker: NA
Text: months to claim a backdated pension. From

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 July 2007, war widows who claim the pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion within six months of their spouse's

Speaker: NA
Text: death will have their pension backdated to

Speaker: NA
Text: the time of death. Labor supports this meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: alone ure. This is a worthwhile reform that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been requested and pushed hard by organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions such as Legacy and the War Widows

Speaker: NA
Text: Guild. This reform owes a lot to their hard

Speaker: NA
Text: work. I congratulate them and I also con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulate the government on taking this ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: The sacrifice by our nation's war widows

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be underestimated. They have had to

Speaker: NA
Text: suffer the consequences of our nation's wars

Speaker: NA
Text: much more acutely than the rest of the popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation and they deserve everything they can

Speaker: NA
Text: get. The only thing that concerns me about

Speaker: NA
Text: this reform is the number of widows who,

Speaker: NA
Text: prior to this reform, would have been finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cially disadvantaged by not submitting their

Speaker: NA
Text: application within three months. The esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mated cost of this measure suggests that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are a high number of widows who

Speaker: NA
Text: could be classified within this category. But

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a worthwhile and positive reform and

Speaker: NA
Text: it has the full support of Labor.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under schedules 1 and 2 of the bill, which

Speaker: NA
Text: provide for one-off payments to older Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians, each person who qualified

Speaker: NA
Text: ties allowance or seniors concession allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance on budget night will receive a one-off,

Speaker: NA
Text: non-taxable bonus payment of $500. In ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: fect, this will provide $500 before the end

Speaker: NA
Text: the financial year to all age pensioners and

Speaker: NA
Text: self-funded retirees earning less than

Speaker: NA
Text: $50,000 for singles or $80,000 for couples

Speaker: NA
Text: combined. This measure is expected to affect

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 286,000 veterans and war

Speaker: NA
Text: widows. Our nation owes a lot to our veter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ans and war widows and Labor fully sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports this payment being made. To be eligi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble for this payment a veteran or war widow

Speaker: NA
Text: will need to have been of age pension age or

Speaker: NA
Text: service pension age on budget night and be

Speaker: NA
Text: in receipt of an income support payment that

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifies them for utilities allowance or hold

Speaker: NA
Text: a Commonwealth seniors health card or De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment of Veterans' Affairs gold card

Speaker: NA
Text: which qualifies them for seniors concession

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance. Labor fully supports this meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure. It is hoped that this payment will help

Speaker: NA
Text: ease the burden that cost of living increases

Speaker: NA
Text: are having on our veterans and war widows.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under schedules 3 and 4 of the bill, which

Speaker: NA
Text: provide for one-off payments to carers, a

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of $1,000 will be made to carers

Speaker: NA
Text: who receive carer payment. Recipients of

Speaker: NA
Text: carer allowance will receive a payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: $600 for each eligible care receiver. In

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the $600 carer allowance bonus, re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipients of carer allowance who also receive

Speaker: NA
Text: wife pension or the Department of Veteran's

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs partner service pension will receive

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of $1,000. The last three budgets

Speaker: NA
Text: have provided similar one-off lump-sum bo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuses to eligible carers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The health of many veterans is often

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained, to a substantial degree, by their

Speaker: NA
Text: partners in their role as carers. There are 2.5

Speaker: NA
Text: million carers in Australia who look after

Speaker: NA
Text: family members or friends who have a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability, a mental illness, a chronic condition

Speaker: NA
Text: for utilior are frail aged.

Speaker: NA
Text: Carers make a great contribution to our

Speaker: NA
Text: society and to the economy more broadly by

Speaker: NA
Text: caring for their loved ones, who may other-

Speaker: NA
Text: of wise be taken out of the community. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated that carers save the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy approximately $20 billion annually.

Speaker: NA
Text: They do this by providing unpaid work. Car-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers clearly contribute a great deal to the

Speaker: NA
Text: wellbeing of our veterans and to those in the

Speaker: NA
Text: broader community who may require assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance in their daily lives. For these carers this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure will be very welcome and it is fully

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by federal Labor. However, I

Speaker: NA
Text: should add that, over the last couple of years,

Speaker: NA
Text: the system for payment of this allowance has

Speaker: NA
Text: not always run perfectly. I urge the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments involved to ensure that all carers who

Speaker: NA
Text: are eligible to receive this payment receive it

Speaker: NA
Text: on time. Our carers should not have to go

Speaker: NA
Text: chasing the government for this payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: By and large, Labor supports this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, and I wish it a speedy passage to the

Speaker: NA
Text: other place.

Speaker: Mr EDWARDS
Text: Cowan) (5.21 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: also support the Social Security and Veter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (One-

Speaker: NA
Text: off Payments and Other 2007 Budget Meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures) Bill 2007. While I will not speak for

Speaker: NA
Text: too long, so as not to delay it, I want to make

Speaker: NA
Text: addisome points. Firstly, I want to compliment

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Bruce, Alan Griffin, who

Speaker: NA
Text: came in after the last election as the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for veterans' affairs. He has moved

Speaker: NA
Text: a around Australia in a very energetic way,

Speaker: NA
Text: consulting with the veterans community. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has been to groups that I have not even heard

Speaker: NA
Text: of, and I have been heavily involved with the

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans community for some time. Right

Speaker: NA
Text: across the length and breadth of Australia he

Speaker: NA
Text: has listened and spoken to them as he has

Speaker: NA
Text: consulted with them. I think our policy on

Speaker: NA
Text: indexation which was announced the other

Speaker: NA
Text: day-it is just one policy and there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: others before the election-is a very good

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, being well reasoned and well consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered as a response to concerns put to us by

Speaker: NA
Text: the veterans community. I compliment Alan

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Leader of the Australian Labor Party,

Speaker: NA
Text: Kevin Rudd, on their response to this issue,

Speaker: NA
Text: an issue which has been going on for a long

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not want to criticise the government,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I do want to make one little point. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: Alan Griffin's response to this budget has

Speaker: NA
Text: been very gracious. He has been very posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive and very objective. I did look for a little

Speaker: NA
Text: bit more from the Minister for Veterans' Af-

Speaker: NA
Text: fairs when our policy was announced. I

Speaker: NA
Text: thought the minister's response was very

Speaker: NA
Text: juvenile. He knows that this issue of indexa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has been an issue of contention in the

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans community for a long time. That we

Speaker: NA
Text: moved to address it was a good initiative,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I think the minister could have and

Speaker: NA
Text: should have recognised this. The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has come to the portfolio at a fortuitous time,

Speaker: NA
Text: at a time leading up to an election when the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is flush with money. The gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment know they have got a difficult elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in front of them and they are prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: spend money. So I wish that the minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: response could have been a little more ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture and a little more gracious. I will always

Speaker: NA
Text: speak critically of the minister when I think

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a need to, but, like this morning, I

Speaker: NA
Text: will also compliment him when there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: need to.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have had a number of emails following

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget and the announcement of our pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy just a few days ago. I want to thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam Veterans Federation of Australia for

Speaker: NA
Text: the tremendous work that they have done

Speaker: NA
Text: over a long period of time. This particular

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-service organisation is not always in fa-

Speaker: NA
Text: vour with government or opposition. It puts

Speaker: NA
Text: first and foremost the welfare of its members

Speaker: NA
Text: as its top priority, it is fearless in prosecuting

Speaker: NA
Text: the objects and aims of its membership and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is fearless in the way it goes about advocat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for and supporting its members. Some-

Speaker: NA
Text: times it stands on individuals' toes, but it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: good ESO and I simply wish there were a

Speaker: NA
Text: few more ESOs and individuals out there in

Speaker: NA
Text: the veterans community who could take a

Speaker: NA
Text: leaf from its book.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to thank the federation for the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that it put out a press release today thanking

Speaker: NA
Text: both the government and the opposition for

Speaker: NA
Text: their responses to veterans issues. Its mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers are not happy, and I understand why

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not happy. They are not happy with

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that this payment of $50 falls some

Speaker: NA
Text: $42 short of what they have lost since 1997

Speaker: NA
Text: when indexation was taken away from the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension, and they make that point. But, by

Speaker: NA
Text: the same token, they congratulate the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment on making this payment. They also

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate the Australian Labor Party on

Speaker: NA
Text: their policy of indexation. I think it is impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant for the veterans community when they

Speaker: NA
Text: argue for something, even if they do not get

Speaker: NA
Text: all that they want, to at least acknowledge it.

Speaker: NA
Text: They do not have to tug their forelock or

Speaker: NA
Text: anything like that, but sometimes it helps to

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge that there has been at least

Speaker: NA
Text: some movement, which I think encourages

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers and shadow ministers and other

Speaker: NA
Text: members of parliament to be more enthusias-

Speaker: NA
Text: tic in the way that they respond in addressing

Speaker: NA
Text: some of these issues. I want to congratulate

Speaker: NA
Text: Tim MCCombe and Graham Walker from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam Veterans Federation. As I said, I

Speaker: NA
Text: think they do a great job.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have had a number of other emails. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: not going to refer to them all. I want to refer

Speaker: NA
Text: to one particular email because I think its

Speaker: NA
Text: writer makes some good points. It has come

Speaker: NA
Text: from a fellow by the name of Ron King. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has this to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Well we have been thrown the keep quite

Speaker: NA
Text: crumbs again. What a disgrace to the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: of the day. We have been treated as the poor sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: onds compared to the other benefits given to other

Speaker: NA
Text: groups.

Speaker: NA
Text: He makes two particular points that are the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis for these comments. Firstly, he says:

Speaker: NA
Text: We look at the funeral allowance of $2000.

Speaker: NA
Text: That buys the plot. Where is the rest of the costs

Speaker: NA
Text: coming from?

Speaker: NA
Text: This once again is discrimination compared to

Speaker: NA
Text: the MRCA funeral benefits. Surely a Veteran of

Speaker: NA
Text: any war is entitled to the dignity of leaving this

Speaker: NA
Text: world in a respected manner. The new grant for

Speaker: NA
Text: burial is not good enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is an improvement-we all acknowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: that. We appreciate it and we thank the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment for it. But the point he makes is a

Speaker: NA
Text: good one. Under the military compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme the grant available for a funeral

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit is some $4,890, just under $5,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that the grant for a funeral under the

Speaker: NA
Text: military compensation scheme is just under

Speaker: NA
Text: $5,000, why is a similar grant under the Vet-

Speaker: NA
Text: erans' Entitlements Act only $2,000? That

Speaker: NA
Text: does not make sense to me, and I would

Speaker: NA
Text: really like the minister or someone else in

Speaker: NA
Text: the government to tell me why this differen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiation exists. Once again this will be a bone

Speaker: NA
Text: of contention. Mr King goes on to say this:

Speaker: NA
Text: The $50 hand out to the TPI is a small catch

Speaker: NA
Text: of the fallout from years of neglect.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Veteran community, once again they

Speaker: NA
Text: have missed the point here, and that is the SR-

Speaker: NA
Text: special rate-

Speaker: NA
Text: pension needs to have a decent means of quarterly

Speaker: NA
Text: adjustment. Not just crumbs thrown at the will of

Speaker: NA
Text: a Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: This point is well made, and I want to finish

Speaker: NA
Text: on this note. Not only have Labor addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: the issue of indexation; we have also sought

Speaker: NA
Text: to take the funding of veterans pensions out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the political arena. Our policy of indexa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion means that it will happen on a regular

Speaker: NA
Text: basis and that it will not be subject to the

Speaker: NA
Text: whim of the government of the day, nor to

Speaker: NA
Text: the whim of the minister of the day.

Speaker: NA
Text: For some 10 years the veteran community

Speaker: NA
Text: has suffered because of a political decision

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by the Howard government back in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1997. The government have now repaid to

Speaker: NA
Text: the veterans who are on these entitlements

Speaker: NA
Text: about half of that which they have taken

Speaker: NA
Text: away from them over that period. But they

Speaker: NA
Text: have made, in my view, a major mistake.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have left this issue fairly and squarely

Speaker: NA
Text: in the political arena. Who is to say, should

Speaker: NA
Text: this government be returned, that they will

Speaker: NA
Text: not do the same thing in the future to the vet-

Speaker: NA
Text: eran community-that is, screw them finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cially and not provide them with the regular

Speaker: NA
Text: indexation to which they are entitled to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that their pensions retain the value that

Speaker: NA
Text: they should in the community? Who is to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that they simply will not screw the veteran

Speaker: NA
Text: community again and not allow any in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases for a period and then, when they face

Speaker: NA
Text: a difficult election, when they know that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are coming from behind, when they know

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are on the nose, suddenly throw a

Speaker: NA
Text: handful of money at them and say, ‘Look,

Speaker: NA
Text: here's some money, we are looking after

Speaker: NA
Text: you; support us'? I hope that the veteran

Speaker: NA
Text: community see through this. I hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government might reconsider their policy

Speaker: NA
Text: up and the fact that they have short-changed

Speaker: NA
Text: every TPI veteran in this nation by some $42

Speaker: NA
Text: and that they might give some serious con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration to taking this issue out of the po-

Speaker: NA
Text: litical forum.

Speaker: NA
Text: I conclude by saying that I am very disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed that those on EDAs, who are some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most disabled veterans in Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: are some of the most disabled people in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community, will not benefit from this budget

Speaker: NA
Text: at all. I think that is a shame. That decision

Speaker: NA
Text: will ensure that the EDA community contin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ues to suffer a lack of fairness. I commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill.

Speaker: Mr WILKIE
Text: Swan) (5.31 pm)-I rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak on the Social Security and Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs Legislation Amendment (One-off

Speaker: NA
Text: Payments and Other 2007 Budget Measures)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2007 and to add my comments to those

Speaker: NA
Text: of the shadow minister, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce, and the shadow parliamentary secre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary, the member for Cowan. Before I com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mence specific comments on this bill, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to say that the way veterans are

Speaker: NA
Text: treated by their country is a measure of the

Speaker: NA
Text: quality of a nation. Those men and women

Speaker: NA
Text: who served Australia in the forces deserve

Speaker: NA
Text: our highest praise and they deserve their

Speaker: NA
Text: rifices to be recognised and applauded by all

Speaker: NA
Text: of us. It upsets and disturbs me when I hear

Speaker: NA
Text: of veterans who are suffering difficulties in

Speaker: NA
Text: accessing the pensions and the support ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices which they are due. Every single one of

Speaker: NA
Text: us has a duty to ensure that the systems

Speaker: NA
Text: which administer the pensions and benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: which veterans receive are efficient in deliv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ering those services. Sadly, this is not always

Speaker: NA
Text: the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I congratulate the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Families, Community Services and Indige-

Speaker: NA
Text: nous Affairs on the increase in pensions con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in this bill, I would have dearly liked

Speaker: NA
Text: to have seen the government do much more

Speaker: NA
Text: for veterans. Every Anzac Day and Remem-

Speaker: NA
Text: brance Day we bow our heads to pray and

Speaker: NA
Text: say, ‘Lest we forget.' As we honour those

Speaker: NA
Text: who served, we should never forget the obli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gation we have to all of our returned service

Speaker: NA
Text: men and women to ensure that the programs

Speaker: NA
Text: in place for them and their families are well

Speaker: NA
Text: funded and efficiently delivered.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said earlier, a country can be judged

Speaker: NA
Text: by the way it treats its veterans. While suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessive Australian governments have recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nised the obligation of all of us to veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: through the payment of pensions and bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits, I am concerned that we have allowed the

Speaker: NA
Text: situation to drift and that now our veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: are under immense financial pressure. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate there are a number of very active

Speaker: NA
Text: RSL clubs, which I have the privilege of vis-

Speaker: NA
Text: iting on a regular basis. Most of these clubs

Speaker: NA
Text: have members who are TPIs and disabled

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans on pensions. I often hear dreadful

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts of the experiences of these veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: in making ends meet with the current levels

Speaker: NA
Text: of income that their pensions provide. There-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, I support the measures in this bill which

Speaker: NA
Text: provide additional income.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, more is needed. That is why the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition and the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for veterans' affairs, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: sac- Bruce, have announced a major policy

Speaker: NA
Text: change to provide tangible improvements to

Speaker: NA
Text: the lives of our disabled veterans which

Speaker: NA
Text: would be in addition to the measures con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in this bill. Labor would increase

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits for our nation's most severely dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: abled war veterans by restoring the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: the special rate disability pension, TPI and

Speaker: NA
Text: TTI, intermediate rate and the extreme dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ablement adjustment pensions by indexing

Speaker: NA
Text: all of these pensions to movements in male

Speaker: NA
Text: total average weekly earnings or the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer price index, whichever is the greater.

Speaker: NA
Text: This policy change will affect more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 43,000 war veterans with disabilities and is

Speaker: NA
Text: budgeted to cost $61 million. In the first four

Speaker: NA
Text: years after implementation of this change,

Speaker: NA
Text: the recipients of these pensions will be

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,700 better off, with their pensions build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to $30 a fortnight more than they would

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise have been, not including the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes that are announced in this bill. So

Speaker: NA
Text: they would be far better off even than that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's proposal concerns the most se-

Speaker: NA
Text: verely disabled of our war veterans. They

Speaker: NA
Text: include those who fought and served in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: flicts including World War II, Korea, Ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: laya, Vietnam, the Gulf War, East Timor, Iraq

Speaker: NA
Text: and Afghanistan. We are already seeing vet-

Speaker: NA
Text: erans from Iraq and Afghanistan needing

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance. Already eight soldiers who served

Speaker: NA
Text: in Afghanistan and two from Iraq would be

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible under Labor's proposal for these

Speaker: NA
Text: enhanced arrangements and, therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: higher pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard from many individuals and

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of the veteran community

Speaker: NA
Text: about the importance of this issue. In 1997,

Speaker: NA
Text: when the Howard government indexed a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of other pensions, they left out the

Speaker: NA
Text: above general rate disability pensions. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: that time there has been an erosion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of these pensions compared to other

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions. For example, in 1997 the special

Speaker: NA
Text: rate disability pension represented 46.3 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of male total average weekly earnings.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the most recent figures available, it now

Speaker: NA
Text: represents only 42.9 per cent. If the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government had not squibbed the issue in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1997, these pensions would now be between

Speaker: NA
Text: $70 and $90 a fortnight higher. The Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government provided only partial male total

Speaker: NA
Text: average weekly earnings indexation in 2004

Speaker: NA
Text: after sustained protests from the veteran

Speaker: NA
Text: community. We should never be in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: where our veterans have to scream out in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to be treated fairly. In a decent and fair

Speaker: NA
Text: society with a reasonably good government,

Speaker: NA
Text: it should automatically happen that these

Speaker: NA
Text: people get looked after. In fact, what was

Speaker: NA
Text: done in 2004 was merely a bandaid solution

Speaker: NA
Text: that failed to fully address the problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: I welcome the government's budget an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nouncement that it will increase the veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: special rate disability pensions by $25 and

Speaker: NA
Text: $50 respectively. But this is window dressing

Speaker: NA
Text: at best. It further demonstrates the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's reluctance to fully acknowledge the

Speaker: NA
Text: sacrifices of our veterans who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: incapacitated as a result of their service to

Speaker: NA
Text: our country. These men and women did not

Speaker: NA
Text: ever fail us, but the government repays them

Speaker: NA
Text: by sticking a new bandaid over the old one,

Speaker: NA
Text: hoping the old one will go away. Without the

Speaker: NA
Text: indexation Labor has proposed, we will be

Speaker: NA
Text: revisiting this issue time and time again as

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans entitlements fail to keep up with the

Speaker: NA
Text: growth of other pensions. There has been no

Speaker: NA
Text: other issue that has been the subject of

Speaker: NA
Text: greater, sustained and more passionate con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern in the veterans community over the last

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 years than this one.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not just a concern that affects peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple in Western Australia-this issue affects

Speaker: NA
Text: people right across Australia. In fact, I was

Speaker: NA
Text: just talking with the prior member for Brad-

Speaker: NA
Text: don, Sid Sidebottom, before I came down

Speaker: NA
Text: here. A very high number of these people

Speaker: NA
Text: live in the area that he previously repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented, and he is very passionate about the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that this issue needs to be dealt with and

Speaker: NA
Text: commends Labor on its initiative of trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: index pensions into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our disabled veterans have paid a very

Speaker: NA
Text: high price for their service to our country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst the measures announced in this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: help restore some balance, they can only be

Speaker: NA
Text: effective if they include the measures rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommended by this side of the House. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: about fixing an injustice. Labor has listened

Speaker: NA
Text: to our nation's veterans, and it is time the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition did the same. I commend the bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House but, again, I urge the government

Speaker: NA
Text: to implement Labor's initiative for proper

Speaker: NA
Text: indexation of these pensions and to give

Speaker: NA
Text: these people the respect and income they

Speaker: NA
Text: deserve in the future.

Speaker: Ms HALL
Text: Shortland) (5.39 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to start my contribution to this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate on the Social Security and Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs Legislation Amendment (One-off

Speaker: NA
Text: Payments and Other 2007 Budget Measures)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2007 by endorsing the comments of the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous speaker. In doing so, I recognise the

Speaker: NA
Text: fine contribution of all our veterans. I ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge the fact that this government has

Speaker: NA
Text: not treated them fairly and that the change

Speaker: NA
Text: that is in this legislation we are debating to-

Speaker: NA
Text: night is just a very small measure, a very

Speaker: NA
Text: small step towards what should be done for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to acknowledge the work

Speaker: NA
Text: of the shadow minister and the proposal that

Speaker: NA
Text: he has put forward. I would like to state my

Speaker: NA
Text: full support for the policy and program that

Speaker: NA
Text: he has announced. It is only through full in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dexation that we will truly be looking after

Speaker: NA
Text: our disabled veterans-people who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been prepared to put their lives on the line

Speaker: NA
Text: for our country. But tonight I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: direct my contributions to other areas of the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate, as the area of veterans has been so

Speaker: NA
Text: ably covered by the three previous speakers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Firstly, I would like to say that the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes have my 100 per cent support. My

Speaker: NA
Text: only comment is: this is too little too late.

Speaker: NA
Text: And there are so many people out there who

Speaker: NA
Text: are hurting that the government should be

Speaker: NA
Text: condemned for allowing a situation to de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velop where we have a large number of peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple in our community who are going without

Speaker: NA
Text: on a daily basis, whilst they cynically come

Speaker: NA
Text: in, in the shadow of an election, and throw

Speaker: NA
Text: out one-off payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not want my words to speak for the

Speaker: NA
Text: hurt that is being felt in the community;

Speaker: NA
Text: rather, I thought I would allow the words of

Speaker: NA
Text: my constituents to say what has been hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pening to them and just how hard they are

Speaker: NA
Text: finding it. The letter that I am going to start

Speaker: NA
Text: with will demonstrate to the parliament very

Speaker: NA
Text: graphically just how important this $500 will

Speaker: NA
Text: be to one pensioner in the electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Shortland. This constituent is a lady for

Speaker: NA
Text: whom I have written some letters in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to the increased costs in the PBS, and she

Speaker: NA
Text: talks about new increases and cutbacks. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will come in on her letter at the point where

Speaker: NA
Text: she says:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... it is a sad, sick & sorry joke that we only

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive $500 per fortnight-which covers [prescrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions] & yesterday I had to pay $26.40 for my

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnightly necessities-so little food till next

Speaker: NA
Text: pension day.

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘... so little food till next pension day'.

Speaker: NA
Text: I had a fire in my flat (stove & range hood are to

Speaker: NA
Text: be replaced, thank the Lord), and this added to

Speaker: NA
Text: my stress-I am having counselling for shock,

Speaker: NA
Text: trauma, emotional exhaustion & “shot to smither-

Speaker: NA
Text: eens nerves” ...

Speaker: NA
Text: That is just a disgrace. She has been rejected

Speaker: NA
Text: by charities and she has been begging for

Speaker: NA
Text: money, just to pay for the necessities of daily

Speaker: NA
Text: life. No matter what she does, nothing seems

Speaker: NA
Text: to help. She says:

Speaker: NA
Text: It is quite disgusting & deplorable that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government have taken away our rights & not

Speaker: NA
Text: [given] us more money to meet our increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: costs as our pensions shrink-no integrity, diplo-

Speaker: NA
Text: macy or dignity left & these ever increasing in-

Speaker: NA
Text: sults are totally unacceptable, “beyond the pale”,

Speaker: NA
Text: NOT Australian and leave everything to be de-

Speaker: NA
Text: sired.

Speaker: NA
Text: She goes on a little more in her letter about

Speaker: NA
Text: her problems. She talks about how she has

Speaker: NA
Text: tried to secure food vouchers and how she is

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to manage to get her stove and other

Speaker: NA
Text: whitegoods fixed, and asks me to give her a

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution. And, of course, I will help her

Speaker: NA
Text: out. But I think it is very sad that, in our so-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciety, we have a situation where people are

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering in that way. She is just someone's

Speaker: NA
Text: mum, an ordinary pensioner, who is doing it

Speaker: NA
Text: hard. And I know that she will really wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: come the $500 that she will be eligible for.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it should never have gone on that long.

Speaker: NA
Text: She should never have been in a situation

Speaker: NA
Text: where she was forced-forced-to write a

Speaker: NA
Text: begging letter like that to a member of par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have recently surveyed my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: What came out very clearly in those surveys

Speaker: NA
Text: was the battle that pensioners are having on a

Speaker: NA
Text: day-to-day basis to survive. The three most

Speaker: NA
Text: reimportant issues relate to increased petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: prices-and the impact that has on their abil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity to survive-health and dental costs. In

Speaker: NA
Text: this particular survey my constituent said,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Pensions do not cover increases of daily

Speaker: NA
Text: living.' The next one refers to the price of

Speaker: NA
Text: petrol and how the price of everything in life

Speaker: NA
Text: is increasing. I have another one in which

Speaker: NA
Text: they refer to the impact that petrol prices

Speaker: NA
Text: have had on their ability to pay for things.

Speaker: NA
Text: This demonstrates how much this $500 bo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nus is needed. I would now like to quote a

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner in my electorate: ‘I only go to doc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors when it is absolutely urgent because I

Speaker: NA
Text: can't find the $52 I need to pay the doctor.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Another one wrote, ‘High price of fruit and

Speaker: NA
Text: vegetables-inflation rate is a joke.' Another

Speaker: NA
Text: constituent wrote: ‘With two living on a pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion'-and I think this is a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: comment-‘it only takes one illness on top

Speaker: NA
Text: of a chronic illness to wreck the budget.' And

Speaker: NA
Text: from another constituent:

Speaker: NA
Text: The pension will only stretch so far then savings

Speaker: NA
Text: and superannuation have to be used-once they

Speaker: NA
Text: have run out-who knows?

Speaker: NA
Text: I will not read the next one because it is quite

Speaker: NA
Text: critical of the government, and I think I have

Speaker: NA
Text: adequately made my point. I wholeheartedly

Speaker: NA
Text: embrace the fact that money is going to our

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners. But I do implore the government

Speaker: NA
Text: to be a little kinder, a little more aware

Speaker: NA
Text: is not only when an election is called but at

Speaker: NA
Text: all times that pensioners are doing it hard.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very pleased to see in this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government have rectified a problem

Speaker: NA
Text: that arose a few years back when they failed

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay $25,000 to veterans who were prison-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers of war in Europe during World War II,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet they paid $25,000 to those veterans who

Speaker: NA
Text: were interred in Japanese prison camps. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think this rectifies a mistake that occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: back then. It caused great division within the

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans community. I support that inclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: in the budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: One thing I am very upset about is that

Speaker: NA
Text: disability support pensioners have been ig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nored. To demonstrate the impact this has

Speaker: NA
Text: had, I would like to refer to three people who

Speaker: NA
Text: rang my office today. For the benefit of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Families, Community Services

Speaker: NA
Text: and Indigenous Affairs, we have had a num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of phone calls in our office today from

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are very disturbed about that.

Speaker: NA
Text: One young girl does some volunteer work in

Speaker: NA
Text: my office. She had a brain tumour and had it

Speaker: NA
Text: removed. She is quite disabled. She has a

Speaker: NA
Text: lovely personality and tries very hard. But

Speaker: NA
Text: she was so angry that she is not to be treated

Speaker: NA
Text: in the same way that aged pensioners and

Speaker: NA
Text: retirees are. She feels that her needs are just

Speaker: NA
Text: as great, and she feels that a stigma is at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tached to the fact that she is not being

Speaker: NA
Text: granted the same one-off payment that other

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners are. The second person I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to refer to is a man who rang my office.

Speaker: NA
Text: He was in tears. He cried to my staff member

Speaker: NA
Text: for four or five minutes. My staff member

Speaker: NA
Text: found it very difficult to handle. My con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituent's parting comment was, ‘What's the

Speaker: NA
Text: point in going on? I may as well top myself.'

Speaker: NA
Text: I am quite concerned about that person, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: am hopeful that I will be able to get in touch

Speaker: NA
Text: with him later tonight.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government have ignored a group of

Speaker: NA
Text: that it people who probably have higher medical

Speaker: NA
Text: needs and higher expenses than ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners and have refused to extend the

Speaker: NA
Text: one-off payment to them. I received another

Speaker: NA
Text: phone call in my office from a woman who

Speaker: NA
Text: asked us to send her a membership form to

Speaker: NA
Text: join the Labor Party. She was so upset that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government had decided that they would

Speaker: NA
Text: not extend the one-off payment to people on

Speaker: NA
Text: the disability support pension. Therefore, I

Speaker: NA
Text: have increased the number of branch mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers by one because of the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: inaction.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no way I will oppose this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. It contains too little, it has come too

Speaker: NA
Text: late, particularly in areas relating to veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased about the funeral benefit being

Speaker: NA
Text: increased. It has been an issue that veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: have been most concerned about for a period

Speaker: NA
Text: of time. But I implore the government to

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt the policy as outlined by the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister. It is a good policy and it recognises

Speaker: NA
Text: the needs of veterans. I hope the government

Speaker: NA
Text: finds a place in its heart to look after those

Speaker: NA
Text: people whom it has chosen to ignore in this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. It should realise that there are many

Speaker: NA
Text: people who need the government's assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance, not just the ones it hopes to bribe on

Speaker: NA
Text: the eve of an election.

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Text: Longman-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Families, Community Services and Indige-

Speaker: NA
Text: nous Affairs and Minister Assisting the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs) (5.51

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-I would like to thank all the members

Speaker: NA
Text: who have participated in the debate on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (2007 Measures No. 1) Bill 2007, but quite

Speaker: NA
Text: frankly some of the comments that have just

Speaker: NA
Text: come from the other side are so disgraceful

Speaker: NA
Text: that they do not actually warrant being

Speaker: NA
Text: thanked. The fact is that not once in 13 years

Speaker: NA
Text: did the Labor Party pay a bonus to any pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner. There was a good reason for that-

Speaker: NA
Text: because what they did was to actually mort-

Speaker: NA
Text: gage the future of those same peoples'

Speaker: NA
Text: grandchildren and children. They asked them

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay for their wanton expenditure as an

Speaker: NA
Text: incompetent government and did not give

Speaker: NA
Text: them a damn cent. Yet the members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition have the hide to come in here, one

Speaker: NA
Text: after another, and be so pious as to presume

Speaker: NA
Text: that this government somehow has left

Speaker: NA
Text: somebody out. I say to the member opposite:

Speaker: NA
Text: tell this to your constituents about disabili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties-that I went to the ministerial council

Speaker: NA
Text: recently with all of the state and territory

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers and I put on the table this offer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Hall interjecting-

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Text: You, Madam, should lis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ten and take this back. What we offered-

Speaker: NA
Text: and what you, Madam, should tell your con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents-to the states was that the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government, over and above-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bowen- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: on a point of order. Remarks should be ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressed through you not directly to the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. AM

Speaker: NA
Text: Somlyay)-The minister will address his

Speaker: NA
Text: comments through the chair.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Hall- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. The minister should refer to a

Speaker: NA
Text: member by their electorate not by any other

Speaker: NA
Text: title.

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Text: I say to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member, and I mean this quite sincerely:

Speaker: NA
Text: would you please go back to your disabled

Speaker: NA
Text: constituent-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bowen- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: on a point of order. The minister is clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: flouting your ruling.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order.

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Text: I say to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member who sits opposite that, when negoti-

Speaker: NA
Text: ating the next five-year agreement with the

Speaker: NA
Text: states and territories about the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth-state disability agreement, I put it to

Speaker: NA
Text: the state and territory ministers that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth would again enter into a

Speaker: NA
Text: five-year agreement with the same funding

Speaker: NA
Text: plus $400 million indexation. Then, to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the unmet need for supported accommoda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and respite care, we asked each state and

Speaker: NA
Text: territory to come back to the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: with an individual plan to address the needs

Speaker: NA
Text: of people with disabilities. I said, ‘Come

Speaker: NA
Text: back to us with a plan that will deliver places

Speaker: NA
Text: for supported accommodation and respite

Speaker: NA
Text: care and the Commonwealth will consider

Speaker: NA
Text: each of those plans on a dollar-for-dollar

Speaker: NA
Text: basis.' I put that directly to those ministers.

Speaker: NA
Text: What they did at that meeting was to adjourn

Speaker: NA
Text: the meeting, caucus outside for 10 minutes,

Speaker: NA
Text: come back inside, read a written statement

Speaker: NA
Text: and close the meeting without further com-

Speaker: NA
