Text: ment. It was a reprehensible piece of behav-

Speaker: NA
Text: iour by people who are supposed to be repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting those people most vulnerable in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community. Every single one of those people

Speaker: NA
Text: was a Labor minister. The offer we put was

Speaker: NA
Text: then put again in writing, asking the state

Speaker: NA
Text: territory governments to bring a plan forward

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Commonwealth so that we could fund

Speaker: NA
Text: the need for supported accommodation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Hall- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. Whilst I find what the minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter has to say most interesting, I raise the

Speaker: NA
Text: point of relevance in relation to the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion we are debating today.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter's contribution is relevant. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order.

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Text: We are dealing with the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of one-off payments to carers who look

Speaker: NA
Text: after people with disabilities. Given the

Speaker: NA
Text: comments of the honourable member oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: site, this could not be more pertinent to the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of helping people with disabilities-

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been totally neglected by state

Speaker: NA
Text: premiers and ministers. I wrote to each of the

Speaker: NA
Text: state ministers. Not one of them has re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponded. So I wrote again today to the state

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers and said, ‘You have one month to

Speaker: NA
Text: put an offer on the table of how you will

Speaker: NA
Text: meet, as states and territories, the responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility of providing respite care and supported

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation for people with disabilities;

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Commonwealth will consider a dol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar-for-dollar funding arrangement.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth will not run away

Speaker: NA
Text: from the needs of people with disabilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: We will not hide behind the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: states have failed these people miserably; we

Speaker: NA
Text: will stand up for them. We should be trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to do this in a way which is bipartisan with

Speaker: NA
Text: state and territory governments. Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Della Bosca wrote to some Liberal senators,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I got the letters. He said, ‘Why doesn't

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth enter into a dollar-for-

Speaker: NA
Text: dollar arrangement like we did for young

Speaker: NA
Text: people in nursing homes.' That is the exact

Speaker: NA
Text: point I made to his disabilities minister. So

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Della Bosca from New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, your own home state, agrees. All we

Speaker: NA
Text: and want is for people to get on and actually do

Speaker: NA
Text: something positive. So can you please take

Speaker: NA
Text: that back? I would be delighted if you would.

Speaker: NA
Text: The members opposite made a lot of the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that pensioners do not have enough

Speaker: NA
Text: money. If it had not been for the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth introducing twice-yearly indexation

Speaker: NA
Text: and linking the aged pension to not only CPI

Speaker: NA
Text: but also wages, because wages have gone up

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 per cent under this government, pension-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers today would be $66.20 a fortnight worse

Speaker: NA
Text: off on the single rate. That is how much bet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter they are off per fortnight on the single

Speaker: NA
Text: rate as a result of our decision to formally

Speaker: NA
Text: link it to 25 per cent of MATWE. The Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party never did that. We are providing not

Speaker: NA
Text: only those additional income streams every

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight but also, because the economy has

Speaker: NA
Text: been run in a strong and responsible way and

Speaker: NA
Text: because we want people who are no longer

Speaker: NA
Text: in the workforce to be able to participate in

Speaker: NA
Text: the wealth of this nation, $1,000 for couples

Speaker: NA
Text: and $500 for individuals. Yet those opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: come in here and whinge. It did not happen

Speaker: NA
Text: in 13 years of Labor government. My bet is

Speaker: NA
Text: that, with their irresponsible way of running

Speaker: NA
Text: an economy, it would not happen if they

Speaker: NA
Text: were ever re-elected.

Speaker: NA
Text: These measures today go to the heart of a

Speaker: NA
Text: compassionate government providing sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port when you can afford it directly to those

Speaker: NA
Text: who need it the most. For argument's sake,

Speaker: NA
Text: let us remember the $25,000 one-off com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pensation payment paid to our civilian and

Speaker: NA
Text: war internees interned by enemy forces in

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe and our veterans who were prisoners

Speaker: NA
Text: of war. This followed on from the heartfelt

Speaker: NA
Text: and warmly appreciated $25,000 paid previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously to those who were POWs of the Japa-

Speaker: NA
Text: nese. You and I both know very well, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause I know that both of our electorates

Speaker: NA
Text: have very large veterans communities, that

Speaker: NA
Text: this will be welcomed not only directly by

Speaker: NA
Text: those individuals but also by the wider com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity. They know the pain that those peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple went through, and that pain and suffering

Speaker: NA
Text: has been recognised in this very practical

Speaker: NA
Text: way.

Speaker: NA
Text: The one-off payments, as I have said, are

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible. They are responsible because it

Speaker: NA
Text: is money that the government has not had to

Speaker: NA
Text: borrow. Running a strong economy with two

Speaker: NA
Text: million more Australians in work, and there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore fewer outgoings in the form of welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, and not having to pay $8.5 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: in interest on accumulated debt that the lot

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite ran up when they were in govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment means that that is money you can re-

Speaker: NA
Text: turn to people who need it. I know that many

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate and in the electorates of all

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members, regardless of which

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the chamber they come from, will

Speaker: NA
Text: greatly appreciate these payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill also increases, through the Veter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ans' Entitlements Act 1986, the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of funeral benefit payable from

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,000 to $2,000. The doubling of that bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fit will be a great comfort to, and the contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution to the funeral will be greatly appreci-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated by, family members. I applaud the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Veterans' Affairs for the wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: work that he has done since he has taken

Speaker: NA
Text: over this portfolio in being able to secure,

Speaker: NA
Text: through this budget, an intermediate rate dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability payment in the Veterans' Entitlements

Speaker: NA
Text: Act-an increase of $25 per fortnight-and

Speaker: NA
Text: an increase of $50 per fortnight in the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of the special rate disability pension.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will extend the maximum period for back-

Speaker: NA
Text: dating of war widows or widower pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: from three to six months in certain circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances, and the backdating rules will ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that those dependants or veterans who are

Speaker: NA
Text: not automatically eligible for the war wid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ows or widower pension are not financially

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged during such a difficult time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Carers really are the unsung heroes, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure that is one thing both sides of this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber will always agree on. Nothing cuts

Speaker: NA
Text: more to the quick, particularly when you sit

Speaker: NA
Text: and talk with older carers, than their fear of

Speaker: NA
Text: what will occur when they themselves are

Speaker: NA
Text: too frail and aged to look after their children.

Speaker: NA
Text: These people have given so much of their

Speaker: NA
Text: lives for the ones they care for-and they are

Speaker: NA
Text: only the older ones. There are also younger

Speaker: NA
Text: carers who have responsibility way beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: their years. We all applaud what they do.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not, as some members so glibly put,

Speaker: NA
Text: something done in an election year. For the

Speaker: NA
Text: fourth consecutive year we have been in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position to be able to make a $1,000 one-off

Speaker: NA
Text: payment for those receiving, on the 8 May,

Speaker: NA
Text: either a social security carer payment or a

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans carer service pension. Carers receiv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the non-means-tested allowance in addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to either wife pension or veterans part-

Speaker: NA
Text: ner service pension will also get the $1,000

Speaker: NA
Text: one-off payment. Any carer receiving the

Speaker: NA
Text: carer allowance will be paid a separate $600

Speaker: NA
Text: one-off payment for all eligible care receiv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know from personal experience, from

Speaker: NA
Text: talking to these people, how much they ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: preciate that and I am just so pleased that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has been in a position-because

Speaker: NA
Text: we have a strong economy and for the rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons we have outlined of people being back

Speaker: NA
Text: in work and not having to put this money

Speaker: NA
Text: into paying off debt-where those people

Speaker: NA
Text: will benefit. I hope that we are in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: in future years to be able to continue these

Speaker: NA
Text: measures so that the money can make a dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference in being able to perhaps buy some

Speaker: NA
Text: little luxury or pay off some debt like the car

Speaker: NA
Text: repair bills that come in for people who do

Speaker: NA
Text: not have the capacity-because the love and

Speaker: NA
Text: compassion they have for those they care for

Speaker: NA
Text: does not give them the time to do so. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: what being in government is really all about.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is about having an economy that allows

Speaker: NA
Text: you to deliver those dividends to everyone

Speaker: NA
Text: and to deliver them in such a way that peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple's lives can be improved. It is not just

Speaker: NA
Text: those in the workforce who get the tax cuts

Speaker: NA
Text: and the improvements in wage increases.

Speaker: NA
Text: Everyone in a just society gets to benefit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only do I commend this bill to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House but also I appeal to all those opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: to talk to their state and territory colleagues

Speaker: NA
Text: and to listen to what the federal government

Speaker: NA
Text: has put on the table here-the offer to help

Speaker: NA
Text: people with disabilities in the most substan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial way by giving us a plan on how to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide the right sort of supported accommoda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and appropriate respite care. The Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth has made a commitment straight

Speaker: NA
Text: to them, looking them in the eye and in writ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, that we will consider each of those state

Speaker: NA
Text: plans on a dollar-for-dollar basis. The Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth is very proud of what it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to do in this bill, which is a measure of

Speaker: NA
Text: the success of the nation. The provisions are

Speaker: NA
Text: greatly appreciated by those people who may

Speaker: NA
Text: not be able to directly contribute through the

Speaker: NA
Text: tax system any more or through their work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing lives but who have done so in the past

Speaker: NA
Text: and who have done so to the best of their

Speaker: NA
Text: ability. As a result, today they share in

Speaker: NA
Text: cessful economy, of which we should all be

Speaker: NA
Text: rightly proud. I commend the bill to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Message from the Governor-General rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommending appropriation announced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Text: Longman-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Families, Community Services and Indige-

Speaker: NA
Text: nous Affairs and Minister Assisting the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs) (6.05

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: SUPERANNUATION LAWS

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT (2007 BUDGET CO-

Speaker: NA
Text: CONTRIBUTION MEASURE)

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed.

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: Prospect) (6.06 pm)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation Laws Amendment (2007

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget Co-contribution Measure) Bill 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks approval for a one-off additional gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment contribution to the superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts of those people who made eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions in the 2005-06 income year, as

Speaker: NA
Text: announced in last night's budget. This legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation will effectively double the government

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution for those who have already

Speaker: NA
Text: made voluntary contributions in the 2005-06

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year. The cost is estimated at $1.1

Speaker: NA
Text: billion, with most payments being made in

Speaker: NA
Text: this financial year at a cost of $990 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor is supporting this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The co-contribution scheme grants a $1.50

Speaker: NA
Text: government contribution for a $1.00 em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployee contribution, capped at a maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: government payment of $1,500. The current

Speaker: NA
Text: a sucscheme allows the maximum government co-

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution of $1,500 to be paid up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: income threshold of $28,000 and phasing

Speaker: NA
Text: down at a rate of 5c for every dollar of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come above the threshold and then com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely phasing out at $58,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Up until 1987, the benefits of superannua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion generally flowed to only 40 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the workforce-in the main, middleand

Speaker: NA
Text: high-income earners. The majority of lowto

Speaker: NA
Text: middle-income earners-often people in

Speaker: NA
Text: casual and part-time occupations such as

Speaker: NA
Text: retail, hospitality and transport, of which

Speaker: NA
Text: over 60 per cent were women-did not re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive superannuation payments. It is one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most abiding and proud achievements of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hawke and Keating governments that

Speaker: NA
Text: that is no longer the case. Labor introduced a

Speaker: NA
Text: compulsory superannuation scheme using

Speaker: NA
Text: the principle of basic fairness to spread su-

Speaker: NA
Text: perannuation coverage to all employees earn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing more than $450 a month. This represents

Speaker: NA
Text: not just a critical social policy but also

Speaker: NA
Text: important economic policy. One of the big-

Speaker: NA
Text: gest challenges that was facing this nation in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1980s and 1990s was how to lift our sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings rates, and the superannuation scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: was a huge addition to the national effort to

Speaker: NA
Text: do that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Savings is no longer the issue that it was

Speaker: NA
Text: in the 1980s and 1990s. Today there is in

Speaker: NA
Text: excess of $1 trillion in superannuation sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings, which has been overwhelmingly driven

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Superannuation Guarantee-the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form of the last Labor government. The gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment now pretend to be friends of super-

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation. They vigorously opposed these

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms at the time. They criticise us for op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posing some of their measures and say that

Speaker: NA
Text: they supported all of our good reforms in the

Speaker: NA
Text: eighties and nineties. They supported some

Speaker: NA
Text: of them but they did not support superannua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: The one-off increase in the legislation that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are discussing tonight does deserve some

Speaker: NA
Text: comment. The one-off increase represents a

Speaker: NA
Text: rebuff to my honourable friend the Assistant

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, who in a splash-as I recall, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: a front page splash-in the Australian earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: in the year sought an ongoing expansion of

Speaker: NA
Text: the scheme for those up to 45 years of age. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was not a one-off payment but an ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion for many years to come-a major

Speaker: NA
Text: addition. This is not what we saw in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. The Assistant Treasurer, unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nately, was clearly rebuffed in the Expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture Review Committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: The co-contribution scheme is supported

Speaker: NA
Text: by Labor and will be continued if Labor are

Speaker: NA
Text: successful in winning office later this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: We support any sensible and reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: measure to increase the superannuation sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings of Australians and, as such, we support

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill. However, there are a couple of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: consistencies that we feel duty bound to

Speaker: NA
Text: point out. Yesterday in the Australian, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: a very morning of the budget, there was a drop-a

Speaker: NA
Text: conveniently leaked article-which de-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed the impending announcement as:

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a way ... to help ... encourage younger people

Speaker: NA
Text: to invest in superannuation ...

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us call this measure for what it is. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: an important addition to the superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: savings of low-income earners. We accept

Speaker: NA
Text: that. That is why we are supporting it. But let

Speaker: NA
Text: us not pretend that it is something that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not. Let us call it what it is. It is not an en-

Speaker: NA
Text: couragement for people to put more money

Speaker: NA
Text: into superannuation. If that is what it is, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be prospective not retrospective. We

Speaker: NA
Text: would be saying: ‘If you put in more money

Speaker: NA
Text: in the coming financial year, we'll match it

Speaker: NA
Text: to a greater level than we have in the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: We'll double our matching.' But that is not

Speaker: NA
Text: what this is.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ciobo-Yes, it is.

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: I look forward to hearing

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Moncrieff tell us

Speaker: NA
Text: how it is and why the Chief Executive of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Superannuation Funds Associa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is wrong. Tell us why Philippa Smith is

Speaker: NA
Text: incorrect. I will not be able to stay in the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber to hear it, but I will be listening in.

Speaker: NA
Text: Philippa Smith said:

Speaker: NA
Text: There was disappointment because it was only a

Speaker: NA
Text: one-off for past contributions ... the budget had

Speaker: NA
Text: missed an opportunity to change savings behav-

Speaker: NA
Text: iour.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further, she said:

Speaker: NA
Text: This initiative rewards individuals who accessed

Speaker: NA
Text: the co-contribution a year ago, but it is difficult to

Speaker: NA
Text: see how it will encourage younger people to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vest in their retirement future going forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure the honourable member for Mon-

Speaker: NA
Text: crieff will take up a substantial part of his 20

Speaker: NA
Text: minutes explaining why the Australian Su-

Speaker: NA
Text: perannuation Funds Association is wrong. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure that we will see the headlines in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian tomorrow: ‘Ciobo attacks Smith'.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not the member for Perth-and what is

Speaker: NA
Text: Tony's seat?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ciobo-Casey.

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: and not the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Casey. It is Philippa Smith, from the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Superannuation Funds Association. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are prepared to support this legislation. It

Speaker: NA
Text: adds to the savings of lowand middle-

Speaker: NA
Text: income earners-and that is a good thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are prepared, as a responsible opposition,

Speaker: NA
Text: to say when the government does a good

Speaker: NA
Text: thing. We are prepared to say that we will

Speaker: NA
Text: support this bill and vote for it. But let us not

Speaker: NA
Text: pretend and let us not get high and mighty

Speaker: NA
Text: and say that this is a great reform which is

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging more savings when it is not. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: an addition to savings that have already been

Speaker: NA
Text: made and, on that basis, we will support it.

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Text: Moncrieff) (6.12 pm)-I am

Speaker: NA
Text: very pleased to add my support to the Super-

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation Laws Amendment (2007 Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: Co-contribution Measure) Bill 2007 and to

Speaker: NA
Text: address the previous speaker's comments.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an important bill. It is one day after

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of the budget and the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is already delivering on its prom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ises. Last evening the Treasurer spoke of the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of making sure that younger gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erations of Australians in particular are in-

Speaker: NA
Text: centivised to provide for their retirement. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know that we have an ageing population in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. We know in Australia, as in many

Speaker: NA
Text: other Western democracies around the world,

Speaker: NA
Text: that those aged 65 and over will represent an

Speaker: NA
Text: increasingly larger percentage of our total

Speaker: NA
Text: population base. One of the most fundamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal things that the government can do to ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress the ageing of the population is to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that, as much as possible, it encourages

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians to provide for their retirement.

Speaker: NA
Text: One key way in which the Howard gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment and particularly the Treasurer, Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Costello, have done this is through the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's co-contribution scheme for super-

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation contributions. Australia is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: garded as having one of the finest superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuation and savings systems in the world. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am even happy to pay credit to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party for the introduction of compul-

Speaker: NA
Text: sory superannuation. They had the idea and it

Speaker: NA
Text: was supported by us when we were in oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition. The coalition supported the idea be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause we saw it as a beneficial reform. So I

Speaker: NA
Text: am happy to acknowledge that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party started this process.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we have in Australia is a situation

Speaker: NA
Text: whereby we have been facilitating, over a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of years now, the increasing transfer

Speaker: NA
Text: of wealth into people's retirement savings

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts in the form of superannuation. And

Speaker: NA
Text: that is a very good thing because, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: population ages, we will increasingly see the

Speaker: NA
Text: need for Australians to draw down, in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of an annuity, a lump sum payment or some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing like that-either of the two or some

Speaker: NA
Text: combination thereof-their retirement sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings. The simple fact is that, with an ageing

Speaker: NA
Text: population, the more we can encourage peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple to provide for their retirement, the better

Speaker: NA
Text: off the nation will be. The co-contribution is

Speaker: NA
Text: one very meaningful and important initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: of this government that has helped to facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tate people to place money into their retire-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment savings accounts to provide for their

Speaker: NA
Text: retirements so that they are not all drawing

Speaker: NA
Text: on the public purse.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we know is that, as the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: population ages, and as the percentage of

Speaker: NA
Text: those aged 65 and over grows, there will be-

Speaker: NA
Text: come a bigger draw-down on the public

Speaker: NA
Text: purse. And with more people moving into

Speaker: NA
Text: retirement, and more people drawing down

Speaker: NA
Text: on the public purse, there will be fewer peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple in the labour force who will be paying

Speaker: NA
Text: the taxes that will be used to fund the draw-

Speaker: NA
Text: down. That really, in essence, is the reason

Speaker: NA
Text: we need to incentivise and encourage people

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide for their retirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: The co-contribution-as I mentioned, an

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative of Peter Costello and this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-is particularly targeted at rewarding

Speaker: NA
Text: the effort of lower and middle income Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians in providing for their retirements. We

Speaker: NA
Text: did say that we took the initiative to intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce the co-contribution because we particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly wanted those on lower and middle in-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to make sure that they are also recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nising the power of compound interest and

Speaker: NA
Text: recognising the power that comes from them

Speaker: NA
Text: providing for their retirements in a more

Speaker: NA
Text: meaningful way. Certainly, a nine per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution, at the minium level, is a start,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it is not enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker Somlyay, I acknowl-

Speaker: NA
Text: edge that you and I sit on the House of Rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentatives Economics Committee, which

Speaker: NA
Text: undertook an inquiry into the superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: savings of generations X and Y. As I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, we

Speaker: NA
Text: found that there does need to be incentive. A

Speaker: NA
Text: payment like this is particularly important as

Speaker: NA
Text: well for women, because a large number of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian women transition into and out of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian workforce. Particularly at

Speaker: NA
Text: those times when, for example, many would

Speaker: NA
Text: choose to stay at home to raise a family and

Speaker: NA
Text: not be in paid employment, the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution does play an important role in

Speaker: NA
Text: helping to boost the superannuation sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings-especially for women, for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: who may be undertaking part-time work. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: for that reason that this is a very good initiaParty

Speaker: NA
Text: tive and one that I am very pleased to sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill that is moving through the House

Speaker: NA
Text: this evening, which I am certain will be

Speaker: NA
Text: passed given that the opposition is also sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porting it, recognising it to be a very good

Speaker: NA
Text: decision by this government-I am sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: is why the opposition is supporting it-will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that we top up superannuation savings

Speaker: NA
Text: that are being made. So, for those people

Speaker: NA
Text: who have already made a voluntary contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to their superannuation, and received a

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,500 top-up from the Australian govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, this bill will ensure that they receive

Speaker: NA
Text: an additional $1,500 on top of that again.

Speaker: NA
Text: That means that, for the $1,000 they have

Speaker: NA
Text: invested, they are receiving a $3,000 top-up

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Australian government. That clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: is an incentive to make voluntary contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. It is that simple: if you receive a return

Speaker: NA
Text: of three to one then that is an incentive to be

Speaker: NA
Text: doing what you are doing. Whether it is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: spective or retrospective is really neither

Speaker: NA
Text: here nor there. The fact is that those who

Speaker: NA
Text: have taken advantage of the co-contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: stand to gain the most. This additional

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,500 top-up that can be received will go a

Speaker: NA
Text: long way to ensuring that there is more

Speaker: NA
Text: money in the accounts of those Australians,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially lower and middle income earning

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, who have made the decision to

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntarily make contributions towards their

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation. This comes at a cost of some

Speaker: NA
Text: $1.1 billion. That is for the time frame speci-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied, which was for the last financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I listened with great interest to the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Labor Party, because what I heard from

Speaker: NA
Text: the shadow parliamentary secretary was that

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact more should have been done. I heard

Speaker: NA
Text: the shadow parliamentary secretary. Basi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally, if you read between the lines of what

Speaker: NA
Text: he said, his statement was that this is a good

Speaker: NA
Text: idea, and that is why the Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: is supporting it, but we should have

Speaker: NA
Text: made it prospective, we should be ensuring

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is a three to one contribution for all the

Speaker: NA
Text: years in the forward estimates. This is again

Speaker: NA
Text: the problem that we have with the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party. We recognise that this is a good

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution. We recognise that it creates

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive. That is why the Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party says there should be even more of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the problem we have as a government is

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are fiscally disciplined. If there is

Speaker: NA
Text: one fault that we have as a government it is

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are fiscally disciplined and we make

Speaker: NA
Text: tough decisions about what is good, what is

Speaker: NA
Text: achievable, what is affordable and what is

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable. This $1.1 billion that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is pouring in to help these lower and

Speaker: NA
Text: middle income earning Australians will pay

Speaker: NA
Text: big dividends for those people, especially

Speaker: NA
Text: those at the lower end of the age spectrum,

Speaker: NA
Text: who have made contributions-big divi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dends indeed, when it comes to their retire-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Labor Party, I take it from

Speaker: NA
Text: the comments of the shadow parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: secretary, is obviously of the view that its

Speaker: NA
Text: policy will be for there to be a three-to-one

Speaker: NA
Text: ratio going forward. I take it that is the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party's position. I take it that the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party's position-perhaps the policy that is

Speaker: NA
Text: being announced by Labor-is for there to

Speaker: NA
Text: be a three-to-one contribution from this point

Speaker: NA
Text: forward. I look forward, if that is what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party is going to do, to seeing that

Speaker: NA
Text: announcement. But I suspect that that is not

Speaker: NA
Text: actually the Labor Party's policy. It is just

Speaker: NA
Text: another case, like the hollow drum beating,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Labor Party banging on and

Speaker: NA
Text: basically saying that we should have done

Speaker: NA
Text: more. We have done a lot-we have now

Speaker: NA
Text: tipped in another $1.1 billion-but the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party still says, ‘You should've done more.' I

Speaker: NA
Text: look forward to seeing the Labor Party's an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nouncement of policy. I look forward to

Speaker: NA
Text: hearing that the Labor Party's co-

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution will in fact be $3 on a prospec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive basis. I am sure many people would be

Speaker: NA
Text: interested in a policy like that. It is just a

Speaker: NA
Text: case, of course, of these things being costed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am proud to be part of a government that

Speaker: NA
Text: has done more for Australian superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: than any other government. And it is not just

Speaker: NA
Text: the co-contribution that I am referring to

Speaker: NA
Text: now; it is the fact that this government, in

Speaker: NA
Text: last year's budget, introduced the simplified

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation reforms. These simplified

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation reforms, which the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Labor Party took nearly six months to

Speaker: NA
Text: agree to, will make a very big difference.

Speaker: NA
Text: The abolition of tax on withdrawals from a

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation fund means so much to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians that it is extraordinary to think that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party would have taken

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly six months to agree.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that the Assistant Treasurer is walk-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing into the chamber. I know he worked tire-

Speaker: NA
Text: lessly for months to try to get the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party on board with this government's

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms. I know the Assistant Treasurer kept

Speaker: NA
Text: as much pressure as he possibly could on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party, who dragged their

Speaker: NA
Text: feet every step of the way before finally, af-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter about six months, agreeing to support this

Speaker: NA
Text: government's very sound, reasonable, wise

Speaker: NA
Text: and sustainable reforms that made superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuation exceptionally simplified and, most

Speaker: NA
Text: importantly, delivered in spades to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian people.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have to say that for my constituents on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Gold Coast the simplified superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms were welcomed with open arms.

Speaker: NA
Text: They knew these were vital reforms. They

Speaker: NA
Text: welcomed them. It was music to their ears,

Speaker: NA
Text: as this government provided further incen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives for Australians to ensure that they pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided for their superannuation. Like many of

Speaker: NA
Text: my constituents I was very disappointed that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party took six months

Speaker: NA
Text: to agree to these very sound proposals. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: very pleased that they may have learned a

Speaker: NA
Text: lesson from that. And I am pleased that

Speaker: NA
Text: within a day of the budget being announced

Speaker: NA
Text: they are now on board with this additional

Speaker: NA
Text: co-contribution that the government has an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced. I commend the bill to the House in

Speaker: NA
Text: a resounding way.

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Text: Gorton)

Speaker: NA
Text: (6.24 pm)-Can I firstly correct the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments made by the member for Moncrieff

Speaker: NA
Text: with respect to his reference to the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker, the member for Prospect. The mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Prospect is the shadow Assistant

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer. I am sure he will want to take that

Speaker: NA
Text: up with the member for Moncrieff at a later

Speaker: NA
Text: date.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also indicate to the member for Mon-

Speaker: NA
Text: crieff and the House that Labor's concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: about the policy being retrospective rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than prospective is an issue. You cannot sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gest, as the government is suggesting, that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is an incentive to encourage younger

Speaker: NA
Text: people to invest in superannuation if the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount is paid after the investment has al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready been made. Therefore, it is wrong to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that the one-off payments made already

Speaker: NA
Text: in 2005-06 will encourage young people to

Speaker: NA
Text: save. It would make more sense to say to

Speaker: NA
Text: young people, ‘If you make a voluntary con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribution from a certain date then we will

Speaker: NA
Text: match this.' This would then be classified as

Speaker: NA
Text: an incentive, as you would be encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: bonuses for extra contributions made in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future. But the government has chosen to

Speaker: NA
Text: give the bonus payment for contributions

Speaker: NA
Text: already made. There were a number of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerns I had with the contribution by the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Moncrieff. The two I have al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready mentioned are axiomatic, wrong

Speaker: NA
Text: statements, and I thought I would correct

Speaker: NA
Text: them for his benefit.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also say to the House that we support the

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation Laws Amendment (2007

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget Co-contribution Measure) Bill 2007.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a bill that provides a one-off additional

Speaker: NA
Text: government co-contribution into the super-

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation accounts of those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: made eligible contributions in 2005-06. We

Speaker: NA
Text: support, in principle, the co-contribution.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation will effectively double the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's co-contribution for those who

Speaker: NA
Text: have already made voluntary contributions in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 2005-06 year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will just reiterate the co-contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. The scheme grants a $1.50 govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment contribution for a $1 employee volun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary contribution, capped at a maximum gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment payment of $1,500. The current

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme allows a maximum government co-

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution of $1,500 to be paid up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: income threshold of $28,000, phasing down

Speaker: NA
Text: at a rate of 5c for every dollar of income

Speaker: NA
Text: above the threshold and completely phasing

Speaker: NA
Text: out at $58,000 per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: The original policy of co-contribution was

Speaker: NA
Text: announced by the then Keating Labor gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment in 1995. It was to be a compulsory

Speaker: NA
Text: three per cent government scheme for all

Speaker: NA
Text: employees, phased in between 1996 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 2002, delivering an extra $4.6 billion per

Speaker: NA
Text: year-in 1996-dollar values-when fully

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented. It was to build on Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: compulsory nine per cent superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee, initially introduced at three per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent in 1987. Twenty years ago, almost to the

Speaker: NA
Text: day, a Labor government introduced compul-

Speaker: NA
Text: sory superannuation into this country and

Speaker: NA
Text: was opposed by the coalition. We understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that the coalition parties supported the prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple of super, but they did not support the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation that was proposed by the then

Speaker: NA
Text: government to ensure that lowerand mid-

Speaker: NA
Text: dle-income families had proper retirement

Speaker: NA
Text: savings. Indeed, there has been resistance by

Speaker: NA
Text: government with respect to superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: for many a year. Indeed, the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: when he was Treasurer in the 1970s and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1980s, did not support a scheme that would

Speaker: NA
Text: provide superannuation to employees. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was no suggestion by any coalition govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment preceding the Hawke-Keating govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that there would be superannuation,

Speaker: NA
Text: and there was resistance by those parties, in

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition, to Keating's proposal to intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce superannuation.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we are going to consider the superannu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation scheme and some of the add-ons that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government suggests-and which Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: supports-we should put the superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: debate in context and remind the government

Speaker: NA
Text: and the people of Australia that it was a La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor government that introduced the super

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme, with resistance from coalition par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties. Indeed, it is such good public policy to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that lowand middle-income families

Speaker: NA
Text: are able to secure their retirement that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult, even for a government that opposes

Speaker: NA
Text: such policies, to change. So it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that, along with Medicare, the compul-

Speaker: NA
Text: sory superannuation scheme introduced by

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor governments preceding the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government's election in 1996, have not been

Speaker: NA
Text: altered adversely to affect lowand middle-

Speaker: NA
Text: income families. But there is no doubt that

Speaker: NA
Text: that government has failed to continue pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding a contribution that will ensure the

Speaker: NA
Text: security of low-and middle-income families

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. There has been no support for

Speaker: NA
Text: the initial scheme to have a 15 per cent con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribution that would provide the security for

Speaker: NA
Text: lowand middle-income families in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. That is a personal disappointment; I

Speaker: NA
Text: ported the scheme that was put together.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think people should remember how that

Speaker: NA
Text: came about. I think people are quite ready to

Speaker: NA
Text: forget, if they are not reminded, how super-

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation came about in this country. It cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly was not initiated by the mob on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side. Indeed, there was resistance by

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition parties at the time. Let us re-

Speaker: NA
Text: member that the first compulsory contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion component was introduced in 1987 by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Keating government in consultation with

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and unions. As the government likes

Speaker: NA
Text: to remind us, there were occasions in which

Speaker: NA
Text: wages were suspended or suppressed to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that other benefits would flow on to

Speaker: NA
Text: working families and the nation as a whole.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recalling the 1987 legislation, we should

Speaker: NA
Text: be reminded that people forwent a wage in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease to commence the first stages of what

Speaker: NA
Text: has become one of the most amazing na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional retirement schemes in the world. In

Speaker: NA
Text: December last year the amount of money

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australians invested in superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: passed the $1 trillion mark. That is $1,000

Speaker: NA
Text: billion under super funds management, or

Speaker: NA
Text: $50,000 for every man, woman and child in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country. Whilst we support the add-on

Speaker: NA
Text: that has occurred today, it is important to

Speaker: NA
Text: place this debate in the context of the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that, without some bold initiatives by a for-

Speaker: NA
Text: surprisward-thinking government, this scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be there to add on to. If we had

Speaker: NA
Text: had to wait for the Prime Minister when he

Speaker: NA
Text: was Treasurer in the eighties or if we had

Speaker: NA
Text: listened to the opposition during the Hawke-

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating period there would not be this na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional retirement scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is also important to note that this

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme has ensured more security for low-

Speaker: NA
Text: and middle-income families in this nation as

Speaker: NA
Text: a result of the benefits of the funds. Looking

Speaker: NA
Text: at why there has been 15 years of consecu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive economic growth, the trillion dollars

Speaker: NA
Text: amassed by super funds has underpinned

Speaker: NA
Text: sup- such economic prosperity. We should note

Speaker: NA
Text: that it fuels the stock market, it encourages

Speaker: NA
Text: business investment and it builds on an un-

Speaker: NA
Text: precedented bank of national savings. Along

Speaker: NA
Text: the way it has potentially transformed re-

Speaker: NA
Text: tirement for cashed-up baby boomers, shift-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing reliance away from the age pension and

Speaker: NA
Text: providing higher living standards. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: things should be remembered when we de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate this bill. This bill is just a brick that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been put on top of the Empire State Building.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not a major reform, but we do support it.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will actually provide some benefit to

Speaker: NA
Text: young people and people who have already

Speaker: NA
Text: placed money into superannuation funds, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is important to place the debate in

Speaker: NA
Text: the context of why we have such a good na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional retirement scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also want to place on the record what

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was like in the late eighties, when

Speaker: NA
Text: we did not have this scheme to reform. As

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Prospect indicated, the ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: jority of workers did not receive superannua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. My parents and many of their friends

Speaker: NA
Text: were not in a superannuation scheme. They

Speaker: NA
Text: did not work in the public sector; they were

Speaker: NA
Text: not managers or working in senior positions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst in the factories in which they worked

Speaker: NA
Text: their senior managers would have been in

Speaker: NA
Text: receipt of superannuation, in that period my

Speaker: NA
Text: parents and others like them were not in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceipt of any superannuation benefit. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: such a critical issue for lowand middle-

Speaker: NA
Text: income families because they do not always

Speaker: NA
Text: have the capacity to save in the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: higher income families do; they do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: the wherewithal to put away a lot of money

Speaker: NA
Text: because they are expending it on goods and

Speaker: NA
Text: services required for their families. They

Speaker: NA
Text: not in the position that higher income earners

Speaker: NA
Text: are. People in the eighties were looking for

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes that would provide them future as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistance. Unfortunately for my parents and

Speaker: NA
Text: people of that age, they probably did not

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit as much as those who have come

Speaker: NA
Text: after them. Those people born in the late for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties, the fifties and the sixties have been

Speaker: NA
Text: greater beneficiaries of the reforms of the

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation scheme in the Hawke-

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating period. I am glad to see that this

Speaker: NA
Text: government has realised it is a scheme worth

Speaker: NA
Text: amending, reforming and improving wher-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever it can.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I am concerned, and I am sure Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: is concerned, that we did not go further with

Speaker: NA
Text: the nine per cent. Whilst these one-off pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments can, if the money is given after the

Speaker: NA
Text: investment is made, create an incentive for

Speaker: NA
Text: people to invest in their retirement savings,

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst these one-off payments are okay and

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst these co-contribution efforts have in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased the likelihood of people saving,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I think is a good thing, it is a shame

Speaker: NA
Text: we have not gone beyond the nine per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: since it was promised in 1995. It was some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that we should have proceeded with as

Speaker: NA
Text: a nation, but we failed to do so. Having said

Speaker: NA
Text: that, it is a remarkable thing that we now

Speaker: NA
Text: find ourselves with more than $1,000 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars in our national retirement savings

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important to note that the effort today

Speaker: NA
Text: is a rather meagre one in the context of the

Speaker: NA
Text: entire area of superannuation, but it is sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported by Labor. It will benefit a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people, but I think the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment could have gone further in tackling it

Speaker: NA
Text: since its election to its first term in 1996. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think the government was ideologically

Speaker: NA
Text: predisposed to support a compulsory super-

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation scheme. That is unfortunate, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause we would have found many more mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lions of Australians better off had the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: are ernment chosen to continue on with the good

Speaker: NA
Text: work of the Hawke and Keating govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, which created this scheme in the first

Speaker: NA
Text: place.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to reinforce the concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: that were expressed by the Chief Executive

Speaker: NA
Text: Officer of the Association of Superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: Funds of Australia, Ms Philippa Smith, who

Speaker: NA
Text: stated, ‘There was disappointment because it

Speaker: NA
Text: was only a one-off for past contributions'-

Speaker: NA
Text: as I have already indicated, the concern that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was not really creating a genuine incentive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, she went on to say that ‘the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: had missed an opportunity to change savings

Speaker: NA
Text: behaviour'. I think those comments are apt.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a bill that we can support, but it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: bold. It does not deliver what it really should

Speaker: NA
Text: be delivering. In the end, it is something that

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor will support, but Labor just thinks it

Speaker: NA
Text: falls short of the mark of what is required for

Speaker: NA
Text: our superannuation scheme in this country.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Dickson-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Revenue and Assistant Treasurer) (6.38

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-in reply-I would like to thank all of

Speaker: NA
Text: the members who have taken part in the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate on the Superannuation Laws Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment (2007 Budget Co-contribution Meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure) Bill 2007. This bill will further boost

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation savings by doubling the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment superannuation co-contribution pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to lowand middleincome earners in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of eligible contributions made in the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2005-06 year-for example, if a person was

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise eligible for a co-contribution of

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,500 for the 2005-06 year, they will now

Speaker: NA
Text: receive an extra co-contribution of $1,500 so

Speaker: NA
Text: that the total contribution for that year would

Speaker: NA
Text: be $3,000. This rewards eligible lowto

Speaker: NA
Text: middle-income Australians who have saved

Speaker: NA
Text: for their retirement and builds on the already

Speaker: NA
Text: successful government co-contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme and the significant improvements to

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation that the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: made through the recent simplified superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuation reforms.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government introduced the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution scheme in 2003-04. It then in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased the co-contribution from $1 to $1.50

Speaker: NA
Text: in 2004-05 and raised the upper income

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold from $40,000 to $58,000. From 1

Speaker: NA
Text: July 2007, eligibility for the co-contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme will be extended to the self-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed, and the income thresholds will be

Speaker: NA
Text: indexed each year in line with growth in

Speaker: NA
Text: wages. Over 2.7 million co-contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: payments worth approximately $2 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: have already been paid under the scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: This measure will increase payments under

Speaker: NA
Text: this scheme to $3.1 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only way that this government has

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to afford such a generous scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide support to lowand middle-

Speaker: NA
Text: income earners is because it has run a suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessful economy. This policy would never

Speaker: NA
Text: have been contemplated by the Labor Party,

Speaker: NA
Text: because during their term in government

Speaker: NA
Text: they ran up $96 billion of debt and required

Speaker: NA
Text: $8½ billion a year to service that debt. If a

Speaker: NA
Text: government is servicing $8½ billion in inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: est payments each year, it could never con-

Speaker: NA
Text: template providing support to lower income

Speaker: NA
Text: earners with this sort of policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The co-contribution scheme builds, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: said earlier, on the superannuation reforms

Speaker: NA
Text: that we announced in the last budget and that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have built on since that time. It will set

Speaker: NA
Text: up the next generation, those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: will be facing the threats of the ageing of the

Speaker: NA
Text: population in this nation, and it will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: people with a greater capacity to enjoy a bet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter lifestyle in retirement. It will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: them with an opportunity also to be sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported by the taxpayer, if they have not saved

Speaker: NA
Text: enough through their superannuation,

Speaker: NA
Text: through the age pension system. But this is a

Speaker: NA
Text: system which has worked well. It is only

Speaker: NA
Text: affordable because of the good economic

Speaker: NA
Text: management of the Howard government. It

Speaker: NA
Text: only remains affordable whilst the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: is well managed. The system, like most in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place, would be under threat if the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party were to be returned to power, because

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not have the skills to run a trillion-

Speaker: NA
Text: dollar economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: In closing, can I just provide by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: example two or three electorates where this

Speaker: NA
Text: has provided real outcomes to lowand mid-

Speaker: NA
Text: dle-income earners. I will start with the

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful electorate of Dickson in the state

Speaker: NA
Text: of Queensland. In that electorate, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: 9,537 lowand middle-income earners who

Speaker: NA
Text: stand to benefit from this measure-those

Speaker: NA
Text: people who would not otherwise have had an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to accumulate and to compound

Speaker: NA
Text: this money to help them in their retirement.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second one which I think is also relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: as part of today's debate is the electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Griffith, where 9,849 low-

Speaker: NA
Text: and middle-income earners will benefit from

Speaker: NA
Text: the measure. In the electorate of the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Lilley, there are 12,154 lowand middle-

Speaker: NA
Text: income earners. It should be the responsibil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity of the member for Lilley and the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Griffith to explain to their respective

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates why the Labor Party would have

Speaker: NA
Text: no hope of continuing this policy in govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-because they would again not be in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position economically to afford such a policy

Speaker: NA
Text: to help lowand middle-income earners re-

Speaker: NA
Text: tire more comfortably than they otherwise

Speaker: NA
Text: would be able to. I commend the bill to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Message from the Governor-General rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommending appropriation announced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Dickson-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Revenue and Assistant Treasurer) (6.43

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE

Speaker: NA
Text: PARK AMENDMENT BILL 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. IR

Speaker: NA
Text: Causley)-The original question was that

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill be now read a second time. To this

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Kingsford Smith

Speaker: NA
Text: has moved as an amendment that all words

Speaker: NA
Text: after ‘That' be omitted with a view to substi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tuting other words. The question now is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the words proposed to be omitted stand part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the question.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Text: Boothby) (6.44

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-Since the election of the Howard gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, protected zones within the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef Marine Park have increased

Speaker: NA
Text: from 4½ per cent of the marine park to one-

Speaker: NA
Text: third of it, adding almost 5,000 square kilo-

Speaker: NA
Text: metres of protected areas. To do this required

Speaker: NA
Text: management of all the different stakeholders,

Speaker: NA
Text: considering their points of view and support-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing fishermen and others who rely on the

Speaker: NA
Text: marine area for their income with a compre-

Speaker: NA
Text: hensive and uncapped structural adjustment

Speaker: NA
Text: package. There is still more to be done, with

Speaker: NA
Text: a reef water quality action plan currently

Speaker: NA
Text: being implemented. In last night's budget

Speaker: NA
Text: speech the Treasurer announced that another

Speaker: NA
Text: $14.2 million over four years from the Natu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ral Heritage Trust would be used to compre-

Speaker: NA
Text: hensively monitor and report on the water

Speaker: NA
Text: quality and ecosystem health of the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef Lagoon. The aim is to address

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the biggest current threats to reef

Speaker: NA
Text: health-the run-off of sediment and other

Speaker: NA
Text: undesirable nutrients into the reef lagoons.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have mentioned, there are many con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderations that must be made when examin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the future of the reef. The Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill 2007 has

Speaker: NA
Text: been introduced by the Minister for the Envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronment and Water Resources for the pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose of amending the Great Barrier Reef

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine Park Act 1975 to include recommen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dations made in the 2006 review of the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. The au-

Speaker: NA
Text: thority was set up with specific responsibili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties to protect the marine park while consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ering the interests that compete for how the

Speaker: NA
Text: park should be utilised. In particular, a pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary function of the authority is to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations on declaring areas for in-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusion in the marine park and for what uses

Speaker: NA
Text: these should be zoned. It also serves a further

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose in managing and promoting Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth-state relations and assisting co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operative arrangements for the environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental management of the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef region.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the key amendments being intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced in this bill will serve to carefully ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: amine the effects of any draft zoning plan

Speaker: NA
Text: through the preparation of a report on the

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental, economic and social values

Speaker: NA
Text: of the area with which the plan is concerned;

Speaker: NA
Text: increase from one month to three months the

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum amount of time for the acceptance

Speaker: NA
Text: of public comment on draft zoning plans;

Speaker: NA
Text: and repeal section 37 of the act, in response

Speaker: NA
Text: to one of the recommendations of the 2006

Speaker: NA
Text: review. The proposed amendment to section

Speaker: NA
Text: 37 will ensure that any zoning plan cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: amended for at least seven years and that a

Speaker: NA
Text: report on the progress of the plan must be

Speaker: NA
Text: tabled every five years. This will ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits of zoning accrue, provide a suit-

Speaker: NA
Text: able period for the ecosystem to flourish and

Speaker: NA
Text: give certainty to businesses to adapt to the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the government is also aware that

Speaker: NA
Text: maintaining and protecting the environment

Speaker: NA
Text: is not just a local issue. The effect that coral tage.

Speaker: NA
Text: bleaching disease is having on some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: healthiest reefs within the marine park has

Speaker: NA
Text: long been a concern for researchers. Just yes-

Speaker: NA
Text: terday, researchers suggested that rising

Speaker: NA
Text: ocean temperatures may be a driver of dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ease outbreaks on the Great Barrier Reef.

Speaker: NA
Text: This highlights the need for broad thinking-

Speaker: NA
Text: the need to think globally in order to address

Speaker: NA
Text: a national concern. As a nation, Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: contributes only 1.46 per cent of global

Speaker: NA
Text: greenhouse gas emissions. While there is

Speaker: NA
Text: much that can be done to cut our contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, we will achieve far more through coop-

Speaker: NA
Text: erative projects with other nations in our re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gion. One example is the Asia-Pacific part-

Speaker: NA
Text: nership for clean technology and develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Another solution is the Global Initia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive on Forests and Climate. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: will provide almost $200 million to look at

Speaker: NA
Text: reforestation in South-East Asia. This is an

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative that Australia is leading. The How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard government recognises that greenhouse

Speaker: NA
Text: gas emissions and climate change are serious

Speaker: NA
Text: issues which require a whole range of practi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal responses and cannot be properly ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressed without the cooperation of our

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbours.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government has invested billions of

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars in environmental programs and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search, and the evidence shows that this is a

Speaker: NA
Text: sound investment in our nation's future. By

Speaker: NA
Text: 2010 the greenhouse gas emissions from de-

Speaker: NA
Text: forestation will be 45 per cent of their 1990

Speaker: NA
Text: levels. Further, since 1990 more than 1.1

Speaker: NA
Text: million hectares of new forests have been

Speaker: NA
Text: planted, with the expected result being that

Speaker: NA
Text: 21 million tonnes of carbon dioxide will be

Speaker: NA
Text: removed from the atmosphere each year by

Speaker: NA
Text: 2010. Over the last 10 years, $2 billion has

Speaker: NA
Text: been spent to combat climate change. This

Speaker: NA
Text: will see Australia being able to meet or, in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, better the greenhouse targets set out in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kyoto protocol, as recently outlined by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for the Environment and Heri-

Speaker: NA
Text: Much has been made over this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's decision not to ratify Kyoto, but our

Speaker: NA
Text: long-held view that climate change must be

Speaker: NA
Text: treated as a global challenge incorporating

Speaker: NA
Text: the world's biggest greenhouse gas emitters

Speaker: NA
Text: has been supported by the findings of the

Speaker: NA
Text: latest report by the Intergovernmental Panel

Speaker: NA
Text: on Climate Change, which was released last

Speaker: NA
Text: Friday. The government understands the

Speaker: NA
Text: need to find a balance between environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental management and economic concerns.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have demonstrated this with our course

Speaker: NA
Text: of action to deal with climate change and

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill 2007. We have sought to

Speaker: NA
Text: implement changes recommended by the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2006 review and to ensure the responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: management and conservation of one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world's greatest marine parks.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Great Barrier Reef is an Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: icon. It was listed as a World Heritage Area

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Fraser government in 1981. It con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributes something like $5 billion to the tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ism industry and it is a resource for all Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: Grayndler) (6.50 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: I rise to speak on the Great Barrier Reef Ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: rine Park Amendment Bill 2007. Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House would know that I have a long-

Speaker: NA
Text: held interest in the protection and conserva-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the Great Barrier Reef-a true Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian treasure and icon. It is this interest

Speaker: NA
Text: that drives me to make one critical point: no

Speaker: NA
Text: number of amendments to legislation that

Speaker: NA
Text: impacts on the Great Barrier Reef will save

Speaker: NA
Text: this national treasure without immediate ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by the federal government on climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change. While we have inaction, there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be no saving the Great Barrier Reef. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: ample evidence to show that rising global

Speaker: NA
Text: water temperatures are increasing the inci-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence of bleaching events and coral diseases.

Speaker: NA
Text: The IPCC was clear in its conclusion that

Speaker: NA
Text: rising temperatures are linked to greenhouse

Speaker: NA
Text: gases being pumped into the atmosphere by

Speaker: NA
Text: human activity. In its Fourth Assessment

Speaker: NA
Text: Report, released in April, the IPCC stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: Significant loss of biodiversity is projected to

Speaker: NA
Text: occur by 2020 in some ecologically-rich sites,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the Great Barrier Reef and Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Wet Tropics ....

Speaker: NA
Text: Ongoing coastal development and population

Speaker: NA
Text: growth in areas such as Cairns and south-east

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland (Australia) and Northland to Bay of

Speaker: NA
Text: Plenty (New Zealand), are projected to exacerbate

Speaker: NA
Text: risks from sea level rise and increases in the se-

Speaker: NA
Text: verity and frequency of storms and coastal flood-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing by 2050.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we do not significantly reduce our green-

Speaker: NA
Text: house output, we could see the complete col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lapse of the reef in our lifetime. The evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence is abundant but so are the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government climate change sceptics and cli-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate change apologists. We have just heard

Speaker: NA
Text: from one, who stated that Australia was on

Speaker: NA
Text: track to meet our Kyoto protocol target.

Speaker: NA
Text: Firstly, it is unlikely that Australia will meet

Speaker: NA
Text: our generous target. Secondly, the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who say that never acknowledge that in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is one of only three countries

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the world that were given a gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erous figure, increasing their greenhouse gas

Speaker: NA
Text: emissions based on 1990 levels. If you take

Speaker: NA
Text: away the decisions by the Queensland and

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales governments to end broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: scale land clearing, you see our greenhouse

Speaker: NA
Text: gas emissions have spiralled, increasing by

Speaker: NA
Text: over 20 per cent since 1990. Our greenhouse

Speaker: NA
Text: gas emissions are on track, according to the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's own figures, to increase sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantially up to the year 2020. The govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment conveniently ignores the fact that it

Speaker: NA
Text: signed the Kyoto protocol because it had

Speaker: NA
Text: such a generous target and said that it would

Speaker: NA
Text: be, to quote the Prime Minister, ‘a win for

Speaker: NA
Text: the environment and a win for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia only retreated from that posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-and joined with the United States in

Speaker: NA
Text: isolating ourselves from global action-after

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States made that decision. By

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia being outside of the global system,

Speaker: NA
Text: we do not have a say at the table in the post-

Speaker: NA
Text: 2012 system. I have attended the last two UN

Speaker: NA
Text: framework convention conferences which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been held in conjunction with the first

Speaker: NA
Text: and seventh international conferences of the

Speaker: NA
Text: parties to the Kyoto protocol, in Montreal

Speaker: NA
Text: and Nairobi. At those conferences Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: does not get a say in the very significant

Speaker: NA
Text: meetings taking place regarding the structure

Speaker: NA
Text: and scope of the second commitment period

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Kyoto protocol for post-2012. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be a critical agreement as to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the world can agree that we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce our greenhouse gas emissions as in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dividuals, as communities, as nations and as

Speaker: NA
Text: a global community. The structure which

Speaker: NA
Text: drives that change is the Kyoto protocol. The

Speaker: NA
Text: embarrassing performances by the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Environment and Water Resources in

Speaker: NA
Text: describing Australia as a global leader is ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: traordinary, to say the least, and offensive to

Speaker: NA
Text: many, because the evidence that we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: take action is there. The evidence is also

Speaker: NA
Text: there that it is not a case of whether you put

Speaker: NA
Text: the environment or the economy first. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: the case that in order to sustain our economic

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity we must have a sustainable envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronment and we must take action on climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just this week further research conducted

Speaker: NA
Text: by an international team of scientists-from

Speaker: NA
Text: the University of North Carolina, the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Research Council Centre of Excellence

Speaker: NA
Text: for Coral Reef Studies, James Cook Univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity and the Australian Institute of Marine

Speaker: NA
Text: Science-who are working on Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef has revealed a ‘highly

Speaker: NA
Text: significant relationship', to quote their

Speaker: NA
Text: port, between coral disease and warmer

Speaker: NA
Text: ocean temperatures. The researchers state

Speaker: NA
Text: their results suggest that climate change

Speaker: NA
Text: could be increasing the severity

Speaker: NA
Text: the ocean, leading to a decline in the health

Speaker: NA
Text: of marine ecosystems and the loss of the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources and services that humans derive

Speaker: NA
Text: from them. The Great Barrier Reef is esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mated to contribute $5.4 billion and 68,000

Speaker: NA
Text: local jobs to the Australian economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Worldwide, coral reefs support more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 200 million people. The evidence is over-

Speaker: NA
Text: whelming, yet the federal government's re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse is underwhelming. For more than 11

Speaker: NA
Text: long years the Howard government has been

Speaker: NA
Text: complacent and has comfortably sat back

Speaker: NA
Text: and watched while the Great Barrier Reef

Speaker: NA
Text: has been threatened. It has done that because

Speaker: NA
Text: of an ideological view that is based upon

Speaker: NA
Text: scepticism as to whether climate change is

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed human induced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consider the best-case scenario which has

Speaker: NA
Text: been outlined in many reports. In February

Speaker: NA
Text: 2006, the CSIRO report Climate change im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pacts on Australia and the benefits of early

Speaker: NA
Text: action to reduce global greenhouse gas emis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions highlighted that, even if all greenhouse

Speaker: NA
Text: gas emissions ceased today, the earth would

Speaker: NA
Text: still be committed to an additional warming

Speaker: NA
Text: of between 0.2 and one degree Celsius by the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of the century. The current momentum of

Speaker: NA
Text: the world's fossil fuel economy precludes the

Speaker: NA
Text: elimination of greenhouse gas emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: over the near term. So it is clear that future

Speaker: NA
Text: global warming is likely to be well over one

Speaker: NA
Text: degree Celsius. Left unchecked, human

Speaker: NA
Text: greenhouse gas emissions will increase sev-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral-fold over the 21st century. The CSIRO

Speaker: NA
Text: report states that Australia's annual average

Speaker: NA
Text: temperatures are projected to increase by

Speaker: NA
Text: between 0.4 and two degrees Celsius above

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990 levels by the year 2030 and by between

Speaker: NA
Text: one degree and six degrees Celsius by 2070.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, if we limit future increases in at-

Speaker: NA
Text: re- mospheric CO2 to 550 parts per million, we

Speaker: NA
Text: would reduce 21st century global warming to

Speaker: NA
Text: an estimated 1.5 to 2.9 degrees Celsius. This

Speaker: NA
Text: would effectively avoid the more extreme

Speaker: NA
Text: of disease in climate changes.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is widely accepted that a target of a 60

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions by 2050 is required to stabilise CO2

Speaker: NA
Text: emissions to 550 parts per million. In Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia we have a government that refuses to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gage in discussion about greenhouse gas

Speaker: NA
Text: emissions targets. What does this scepticism

Speaker: NA
Text: mean for the Great Barrier Reef? Even in a

Speaker: NA
Text: best-case scenario that we can limit CO2 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 550 parts per million, the consequences are

Speaker: NA
Text: devastating. A less than one degree Celsius

Speaker: NA
Text: rise in temperature would mean that 60 per

Speaker: NA
