Text: cent of the Great Barrier Reef could be regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly bleached. A one-degree or two-degrees

Speaker: NA
Text: temperature rise would mean 58 to 81 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the Great Barrier Reef is bleached

Speaker: NA
Text: every year and a twoto three-degrees tem-

Speaker: NA
Text: perature rise would mean that 97 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Great Barrier Reef would be bleached

Speaker: NA
Text: every year. We need a plan to address these

Speaker: NA
Text: issues, we need targets for greenhouse gas

Speaker: NA
Text: emission reductions and we need the eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic instruments that would drive the move

Speaker: NA
Text: to clean energy, which is why we need a na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional emissions trading scheme. We need

Speaker: NA
Text: bold energy initiatives such as those pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed by Labor's solar, green energy and

Speaker: NA
Text: water renovations plan for Australian house-

Speaker: NA
Text: holds that will save families money on their

Speaker: NA
Text: energy and water bills and help the environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. We need to ratify the Kyoto protocol.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need a substantial increase in our manda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory renewable energy target.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, climate change is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: only threat to the health and long-term sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: vival of the Great Barrier Reef. It is difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: to believe that oil drilling and exploration

Speaker: NA
Text: can still occur on or near the reef. I have in-

Speaker: NA
Text: troduced a private member's bill that is still

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Notice Paper that would stop this oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: curring. My colleague the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingsford Smith has moved an amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking support for the Great Barrier Reef

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine Park (Protecting the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef from Oil Drilling and Exploration)

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill. It was 1983 when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke Labor government acted to prohibit

Speaker: NA
Text: drilling anywhere in the Great Barrier Reef

Speaker: NA
Text: region by extending the borders of that re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gion east to Australia's exclusive economic

Speaker: NA
Text: zone. Our legislation would remove the

Speaker: NA
Text: threat posed by exploration and mining both

Speaker: NA
Text: on and near the reef. The Howard govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has never ruled out oil drilling east of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, the very

Speaker: NA
Text: area our bill seeks to protect. If the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government is serious about protecting the

Speaker: NA
Text: reef, it will support the passage of Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: bill through the parliament. This bill would

Speaker: NA
Text: protect not only the reef's extraordinarily

Speaker: NA
Text: diverse ecosystem but also the livelihoods of

Speaker: NA
Text: 200,000 Queenslanders and a tourism indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try worth billions of dollars annually.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rather than take practical and long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: action against climate change, the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government entertains absurd ideas to protect

Speaker: NA
Text: the Great Barrier Reef. In the collection of

Speaker: NA
Text: absurd ideas, perhaps the worst was the plan

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Minister for Small Business and Tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ism to put a shadecloth over the Great Bar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rier Reef-a bizarre and impractical proposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from a government looking for political

Speaker: NA
Text: cover to hide the fact that it has no plan to

Speaker: NA
Text: tackle climate change. We need to reduce our

Speaker: NA
Text: greenhouse pollution, not publicly brain-

Speaker: NA
Text: storm absurd ideas. The minister, Fran Bai-

Speaker: NA
Text: ley, was topped on this proposal by the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Tangney who wants to put a

Speaker: NA
Text: shadecloth in outer space to combat global

Speaker: NA
Text: warming. Dr Jensen, the member for Tang-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney, said in the Commonwealth of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament:

Speaker: NA
Text: After all, we have heard about aerosols and global

Speaker: NA
Text: dimming. Or what about some sort of shadecloth

Speaker: NA
Text: put in orbit? In that way we could actually tailor

Speaker: NA
Text: the area of the shadecloth and adjust it according

Speaker: NA
Text: to the energy balance.

Speaker: NA
Text: A completely whacky proposal from a gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment member who is one of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: always put up to debate climate change in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House. One of the government's key

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change experts is the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Tangney, who supports putting a shadecloth

Speaker: NA
Text: into orbit along with putting nuclear reactors

Speaker: NA
Text: all around the coast of Australia-an abso-

Speaker: NA
Text: lutely extraordinary proposal. Whilst the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Tangney calls himself a scientist,

Speaker: NA
Text: the plan for a giant intergalactic shadecloth

Speaker: NA
Text: in outer space does not constitute serious

Speaker: NA
Text: scientific discussion on climate change.

Speaker: NA
Text: When you look at the government's spokes-

Speaker: NA
Text: people-the member for Tangney with his

Speaker: NA
Text: outer space shadecloth; the minister for tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ism, a frontbencher, with her plan for a

Speaker: NA
Text: shadecloth to protect the Great Barrier Reef;

Speaker: NA
Text: and a Prime Minister who does not think that

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change exists and is sceptical but still

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to impose 25 nuclear reactors on the

Speaker: NA
Text: coastal areas and urban communities of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia-it is little wonder that you see this

Speaker: NA
Text: government has no credibility when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to climate change.

Speaker: NA
Text: It keeps going right to the top of this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, because a couple of weeks ago the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister opened-well, he did not

Speaker: NA
Text: quite open it because it has been shut

Speaker: NA
Text: down-the new Lucas Heights reactor in

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney. They went ahead with the grand

Speaker: NA
Text: opening anyway, because the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to promote and use what is a medical

Speaker: NA
Text: research facility that has broad support to

Speaker: NA
Text: promote his narrow agenda on nuclear reac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors. There, at the opening, the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter said that the Lucas Heights reactor was

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Australian icon'-an icon, along with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Harbour Bridge and the Opera House. This

Speaker: NA
Text: was the third Sydney icon-not the Rocks,

Speaker: NA
Text: not the Blue Mountains, not Bondi Beach

Speaker: NA
Text: and the pavilion, not Balmoral, not Taronga

Speaker: NA
Text: Park Zoo, not all these great Sydney icons;

Speaker: NA
Text: this was the icon. Well, I say to the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister: ‘We do have an icon, in Far North

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, and that is the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef'-the largest, most pristine, continuous

Speaker: NA
Text: coral reef archipelago on earth; our treasured

Speaker: NA
Text: natural icon, which is some 18 million years

Speaker: NA
Text: old. And it is astonishing that the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment still has not placed the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef on Australia's National Heritage List.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister's scepticism is getting in

Speaker: NA
Text: the way of good policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I conclude with this point: we do need to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect the Great Barrier Reef. I want future

Speaker: NA
Text: generations to have the opportunity that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have had to see this marvellous natural won-

Speaker: NA
Text: der. I also want the economic benefit that

Speaker: NA
Text: comes through jobs, and income to Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result of the Great Barrier Reef's pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence. But unless we have action on climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change we will not be able to save the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef. That is a practical demonstra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of why we need to move away from this

Speaker: NA
Text: government's scepticism and have a gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, one led by Kevin Rudd, which ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tually understands that climate change is a

Speaker: NA
Text: great challenge for our generation, and is

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to do something about it-is pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to take the action that is required.

Speaker: Mr MURPHY
Text: Lowe) (7.09 pm)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975,

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill 2007 amends, has served its

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose extremely well, and remains a fun-

Speaker: NA
Text: damentally sound piece of legislation. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: time of its enactment, the government of the

Speaker: NA
Text: day stated, ‘The protection of our unique

Speaker: NA
Text: barrier reef is of paramount importance to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and to the world.' Like any other

Speaker: NA
Text: an good piece of legislation, the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park Act 1975 has, over time,

Speaker: NA
Text: been successful at giving effect to the public

Speaker: NA
Text: policy considerations underpinning it. We

Speaker: NA
Text: need not look any further for evidence of this

Speaker: NA
Text: than the many achievements of the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the

Speaker: NA
Text: international recognition, in 1981, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: conservation value of the Great Barrier Reef

Speaker: NA
Text: following its inscription on the World Heri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tage List.

Speaker: NA
Text: There can be no doubt that the act has

Speaker: NA
Text: stood the test of time as an exemplary de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fender of marine management and conserva-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Nonetheless, the act has now been in

Speaker: NA
Text: place for over 30 years and many lessons

Speaker: NA
Text: have been learnt from the challenges of the

Speaker: NA
Text: past. The manifest integrity of the act-and

Speaker: NA
Text: the general acceptance of that integrity by

Speaker: NA
Text: the stakeholders which it serves-is essential

Speaker: NA
Text: if the act is to have any hope of safeguarding

Speaker: NA
Text: the interests of the Great Barrier Reef well

Speaker: NA
Text: into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report of the review of the Great Bar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 identified

Speaker: NA
Text: numerous concerns about the inadequacy of

Speaker: NA
Text: the processes in place for engaging with

Speaker: NA
Text: stakeholders-as well as concern that deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions under the act were not being conveyed

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly enough to those stakeholders. The

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of the Great Barrier Reef Ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: rine Park Zoning Plan 2003, with its consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: erable scale and scope, affected many com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munities and stakeholders. Perhaps better

Speaker: NA
Text: than any other chapter in the act's history,

Speaker: NA
Text: this example demonstrated the tension often

Speaker: NA
Text: felt by many stakeholders in the decision-

Speaker: NA
Text: making process. Whether for valid reasons or

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise, many stakeholders disagreed with

Speaker: NA
Text: the scientific basis of the zoning plan, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered the processes to be biased and felt

Speaker: NA
Text: that it failed to consider the impacts on indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: viduals and communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the final criticism ought to be lev-

Speaker: NA
Text: elled directly at the Howard government for

Speaker: NA
Text: ignoring repeated warnings from the Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland fishing industry about flaws in socio-

Speaker: NA
Text: economic assessment processes, the other

Speaker: NA
Text: criticisms are symptomatic of the inherent

Speaker: NA
Text: weaknesses in the act. The review panel ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ecutive summary recognised this when it

Speaker: NA
Text: noted that:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... an effective relationship with recreational

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial fishing stakeholders is lacking. To an

Speaker: NA
Text: extent, such tensions between the Authority and

Speaker: NA
Text: affected stakeholders were inevitable in view of

Speaker: NA
Text: the substantial change to zoning arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed.

Speaker: NA
Text: And said:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... the Review Panel is of the view that

Speaker: NA
Text: esses for engagement with all stakeholders can be

Speaker: NA
Text: improved.

Speaker: NA
Text: The processes involved in the 2003 zoning

Speaker: NA
Text: plan should be considered with a view to

Speaker: NA
Text: learning lessons for the future. Managing the

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative uses of the marine park, and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponding to the long-term protection needs

Speaker: NA
Text: of the future will become much more chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenging in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The integrity of the act and the integrity of

Speaker: NA
Text: processes that allow conservation to coexist

Speaker: NA
Text: with reasonable marine park use-and the

Speaker: NA
Text: general acceptance of that integrity by stake-

Speaker: NA
Text: holders-depends on practices that: are

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly scientific, are thoroughly transparent,

Speaker: NA
Text: engage with stakeholders, are clearly under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stood, and assess the social and economic

Speaker: NA
Text: impacts of any changes affecting the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef. That is why I welcomed a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view into the act to:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... improve the performance of the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park Authority, its office holders and

Speaker: NA
Text: its accountability frameworks.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is also the reason why I am generally sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: portive of the measures in this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the bill is by no means perfect-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I will come to that later-it is certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: not as bad as many of us had feared at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time of the review's announcement by the

Speaker: NA
Text: former Minister for the Environment and

Speaker: NA
Text: Heritage. The review into the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park Act came against a back-

Speaker: NA
Text: drop of a National Party push to abolish the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority

Speaker: NA
Text: and give full control to the minister. No

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt the abolition of the authority has only

Speaker: NA
Text: and been avoided because of the intense cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign from members on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber and the resulting public outrage.

Speaker: NA
Text: The review also came against a backdrop of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government gutting the inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendence of other key environmental agen-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies such as the Australian Greenhouse Of-

Speaker: NA
Text: the proc- fice-have we forgotten?-the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Oceans Office and the Australian Heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: The review also came against the back-

Speaker: NA
Text: drop of the Howard government's use of no-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions such as ‘accountability' and ‘best cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: porate practice' as powerful rhetorical weap-

Speaker: NA
Text: ons but then acting in a venal manner that

Speaker: NA
Text: made a mockery of those very notions. Who

Speaker: NA
Text: could forget the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation Amendment Bill 2006? When

Speaker: NA
Text: announcing plans to restructure the board of

Speaker: NA
Text: the ABC under the guise of implementing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Uhrig report, the Review of corporate gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernance of statutory authorities and office

Speaker: NA
Text: holders, many held hopes of genuine reform.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many held hopes of a restructure that would

Speaker: NA
Text: result in an open and transparent process for

Speaker: NA
Text: making appointments to the ABC board, ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointments based on merit and free of politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal patronage. We all know how wrong we

Speaker: NA
Text: were, and we will rectify that on the election

Speaker: NA
Text: of a Rudd Labor government.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are not trifling matters that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissed when considering the substance of

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill before us today. The backdrop I have

Speaker: NA
Text: just provided is most relevant to several mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters of concern in the Great Barrier Reef Ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: rine Park Amendment Bill 2007. As I have

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned, it is true that there are many

Speaker: NA
Text: sons we can learn from the execution of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act over the

Speaker: NA
Text: last 30 years. However, it is true that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are still many lessons we can learn from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government's approach over the last

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 years to so-called improvements in ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: countability and performance frameworks of

Speaker: NA
Text: statutory authorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: At face value, the bill does fulfil the

Speaker: NA
Text: jectives the member for Wentworth has set

Speaker: NA
Text: out. At face value, the bill strengthens gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernance arrangements, transparency and ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: countability. This is particularly so for the

Speaker: NA
Text: zoning plan processes. There will be far

Speaker: NA
Text: greater engagement with stakeholders in the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of new zoning plans which

Speaker: NA
Text: regulate the use of the marine park. A system

Speaker: NA
Text: will be in place which better balances and

Speaker: NA
Text: manages the diverse and competing interests

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in any proposed zoning plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments to section 32 of the act will

Speaker: NA
Text: increase the minimum public comment pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: riod for draft zone plans from one month to

Speaker: NA
Text: three months. Proposed sections 34 and 35

Speaker: NA
Text: will make the zone planning process more

Speaker: NA
Text: transparent, with comprehensive information

Speaker: NA
Text: being made available to stakeholders. The

Speaker: NA
Text: process will be built on principles that must

Speaker: NA
Text: consider robust scientific and socioeconomic

Speaker: NA
Text: information. These principles, and a report

Speaker: NA
Text: considering the environmental, economic

Speaker: NA
Text: and social values of an area, must be made

Speaker: NA
Text: available to communities, users of the marine

Speaker: NA
Text: park and other interested persons and organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sations. It is pleasing to see that a compre-

Speaker: NA
Text: hensive socioeconomic assessment is neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary prior to making any changes to zoning.

Speaker: NA
Text: The disinterest and indolence shown by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government to repeated warn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings from the Queensland fishing industry

Speaker: NA
Text: that inadequate attention had been provided

Speaker: NA
Text: to the social and economic impacts of zoning

Speaker: NA
Text: plans is staggering. Perhaps this is being

Speaker: NA
Text: lesgenerous. Some would say the attention paid

Speaker: NA
Text: was perfunctory. The initial failure to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider the social and economic implications of

Speaker: NA
Text: zoning plans for the commercial fishing in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry is, at best, regrettable. However, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government's need to review and

Speaker: NA
Text: upgrade its fishing industry structural ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: justment packages on four separate occasions

Speaker: NA
Text: was embarrassing and a sign of incompe-

Speaker: NA
Text: obtence. It has been the cause of much frustra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for stakeholders, and it has unfairly sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: jected the integrity of the act itself to unnec-

Speaker: NA
Text: essary scrutiny. For the government's sake,

Speaker: NA
Text: we all hope this embarrassment can be

Speaker: NA
Text: avoided in future as a result of the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments contained in this bill, although there

Speaker: NA
Text: can be no panacea for incompetence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed sections 53 and 54 will establish

Speaker: NA
Text: a periodic Great Barrier Reef outlook report

Speaker: NA
Text: that provides a regular and reliable means of

Speaker: NA
Text: assessing performance in the long-term pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: tection of the Great Barrier Reef. The peer

Speaker: NA
Text: review assessment will include an analysis of

Speaker: NA
Text: the condition of the ecosystem and the long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term outlook for the reef. The outlook report

Speaker: NA
Text: may be used during any review of a zoning

Speaker: NA
Text: plan which is currently in place. So as to al-

Speaker: NA
Text: low the consequences of an existing zoning

Speaker: NA
Text: plan to take full effect on the ecosystem,

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to or reviews of zoning plans

Speaker: NA
Text: may only take place after seven years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The requirement that significant amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments may only be made to zoning plans

Speaker: NA
Text: after seven years leads me to a concern that

Speaker: NA
Text: pressing issues which may be identified in an

Speaker: NA
Text: outlook report, which is prepared every five

Speaker: NA
Text: years, may not be acted upon for a further

Speaker: NA
Text: two years. Notwithstanding this minor con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern, there can be no doubt that the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments have ostensibly been drafted for a

Speaker: NA
Text: proper purpose. At face value, the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments improve transparency and account-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability and strengthen the governance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is in no small part because the health

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Great Barrier Reef is to be regularly

Speaker: NA
Text: reported on, and considerations of changes in

Speaker: NA
Text: future planning and zoning arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: will appear to be undertaken in a robust and

Speaker: NA
Text: transparent manner. However, as with any

Speaker: NA
Text: reform of a statutory authority by the How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard government, it would be prudent to

Speaker: NA
Text: scratch the surface of the proposals because

Speaker: NA
Text: the devil is often in the detail. Superficiality

Speaker: NA
Text: has always been a strength of the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, but it is often the motives behind its

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals that can leave a lot to be desired.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is no exception.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I would not be prepared to throw

Speaker: NA
Text: the baby out with the bathwater, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: elements of this bill which all members

Speaker: NA
Text: should have serious concerns about. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef advisory board, which

Speaker: NA
Text: will be structured to provide the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Environment and Water Resources with

Speaker: NA
Text: specific advice relating to marine park pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: tection and use, will comprise appointments

Speaker: NA
Text: hand-picked by the minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Outlook reports, which will be structured

Speaker: NA
Text: to regularly provide the minister and the pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic with information about the health of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef, will be drafted by an au-

Speaker: NA
Text: thority whose members have been appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the minister. The outlook report will be

Speaker: NA
Text: peer-reviewed by persons who the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks have the necessary qualifications to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake the task.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill does not give any indication as to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the bona fides or qualifications of

Speaker: NA
Text: those undertaking the peer review of an out-

Speaker: NA
Text: look report will be subjected to public scru-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiny, because there is no indication as to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the peer review itself is public or

Speaker: NA
Text: confidential. The principles upon which a

Speaker: NA
Text: zoning plan is based are, in the final analysis,

Speaker: NA
Text: approved by the minister alone. Furthermore,

Speaker: NA
Text: any decision to amend a zoning plan will rest

Speaker: NA
Text: not with the authority but with the minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister may retort that any decision to

Speaker: NA
Text: amend a zoning plan will be based on the

Speaker: NA
Text: outlook report and advice received by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, we cannot easily forget the

Speaker: NA
Text: backdrop to this bill, which I identified ear-

Speaker: NA
Text: lier. The Howard government has drafted this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill against a backdrop of government mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers seeking to abolish the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park Authority, against a back-

Speaker: NA
Text: drop of damaging the independence of other

Speaker: NA
Text: key environmental agencies and against a

Speaker: NA
Text: backdrop of using rhetorical weapons of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form and restructure to make political ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointments to statutory authorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the present government there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been an appalling tradition of politicising

Speaker: NA
Text: board appointments and elements of the bu-

Speaker: NA
Text: reaucracy. Who could forget the frank and

Speaker: NA
Text: fearless advice received by the government

Speaker: NA
Text: on such matters as ‘children overboard',

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘weapons of mass destruction' and ‘AWB

Speaker: NA
Text: kickbacks to Saddam Hussein's regime'?

Speaker: NA
Text: In the best spirit of Christian charity, if

Speaker: NA
Text: one accepts that the government has not lied

Speaker: NA
Text: about these appalling incidents then one can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not forgive the government for its incompe-

Speaker: NA
Text: tence on those matters. It is clear the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government does not tolerate criticism well.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a tragedy that many agencies and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: partments have become shells of their former

Speaker: NA
Text: selves because some members of the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment do not want to hear of any evil or

Speaker: NA
Text: see any evil-even if the agency knows the

Speaker: NA
Text: evil exists. This backdrop should not allow

Speaker: NA
Text: us to fall for the government's disingenuous

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to employ shallow words to give

Speaker: NA
Text: soothing assurances that there are the neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary checks and balances on the minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: powers under this act.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Au-

Speaker: NA
Text: thority, as I have already mentioned, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: comprised of members stacked by the minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter. The outlook report will in turn be drafted

Speaker: NA
Text: by this authority. The outlook report will be

Speaker: NA
Text: peer-reviewed by individuals stacked by the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister. Zoning plans will be amended by

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister. Zoning plan principles will be

Speaker: NA
Text: determined by the minister. Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef advisory board will be

Speaker: NA
Text: stacked by the minister. Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government should not feign surprise at the

Speaker: NA
Text: concentration of power in the hands of the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister and nor should members of the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment feign surprise that one of the few

Speaker: NA
Text: structures in place that could have provided a

Speaker: NA
Text: check on the minister's powers will be abol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ished by this bill. The bill no longer provides

Speaker: NA
Text: for automatic representation on the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister has already noted that the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill encompasses the outcomes of the 2003

Speaker: NA
Text: Uhrig report, the Review of the corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: governance of statutory authorities and of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice holders. In defence of the abolition of

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland government representation on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Author-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity, the minister may cite the following con-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusion from that report:

Speaker: NA
Text: The review does not support representational

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments to governing boards as representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional appointments can fail to produce independgiven

Speaker: NA
Text: ent and objective views.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, assuming Mr Uhrig's conclusions

Speaker: NA
Text: are correct, it is interesting to note that his

Speaker: NA
Text: findings on the matter only made up one

Speaker: NA
Text: page of a 133-page report. It is important to

Speaker: NA
Text: note that Mr Uhrig also made the comment

Speaker: NA
Text: that ‘there are no universally accepted struc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tures and practices that constitute good gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernance'.

Speaker: NA
Text: The choice of governance model for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be formulaic but should be driven

Speaker: NA
Text: by the objectives of the authority. Guidance

Speaker: NA
Text: can be taken on this point from the executive

Speaker: NA
Text: summary of the Review of the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park Act. It notes, inter alia, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I quote:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... many points of intersection in both policy and

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation that apply to the Marine Park and sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rounding area, which require the two govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to work closely together.

Speaker: NA
Text: The review continues:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... officeholders should not be representational

Speaker: NA
Text: but appointed for their relevant expertise, with

Speaker: NA
Text: one member being nominated by the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Government ...

Speaker: NA
Text: In light of the need for effective collabora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion between the Commonwealth and Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland governments, this bill ought to have

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed for the Queensland government to

Speaker: NA
Text: be automatically represented on the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: have thought that that would be the mini-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum requirement. This, to some degree at

Speaker: NA
Text: least, would also have installed an independ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent voice on the authority which could keep

Speaker: NA
Text: a check on the minister's sweeping powers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given the health of the Great Barrier Reef,

Speaker: NA
Text: and bearing in mind that it is at a crossroads,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is more vital now than ever before for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide frank, fearless and independent ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice to the minister. This is particularly so

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister's propensity to dismiss

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental advice which is extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: pertinent for the long-term survival of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef.

Speaker: NA
Text: The issue of climate change is the largest

Speaker: NA
Text: single challenge confronting the Great Bar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rier Reef. Despite overwhelming evidence to

Speaker: NA
Text: this effect, the government remains unre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pentant in its determination to sabotage ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: forts to reduce emissions. Reports that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef is facing extinction be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the effects of climate change have

Speaker: NA
Text: amounted to nothing. It is a disgrace that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has ignored UN reports which

Speaker: NA
Text: predict the beginning of the end of the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef within 13 years. Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the public are entitled to ask: why has the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government ignored assessments by

Speaker: NA
Text: the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Cli-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate Change? Why has it ignored Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: Ove Hoegh-Guldberg of the Australian Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search Council Centre of Excellence for

Speaker: NA
Text: Coral Reef Studies? Why has it ignored Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian climate change expert Dr Geoff Love?

Speaker: NA
Text: And why has it ignored warnings from Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: Nicholas Stern?

Speaker: NA
Text: While the oceans have been a convenient

Speaker: NA
Text: dumping ground for our waste, the effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: all of this carbon dioxide upon the ocean

Speaker: NA
Text: waters is beginning to have serious conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quences, because carbon dioxide when dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: solved in water forms a weak acid. The Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef is not only under threat from

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing water temperatures that cause

Speaker: NA
Text: coral bleaching but also, it now appears, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: sieged by increasing ocean acidity. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: breathtakingly hypocritical for the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to suggest that ‘the Australian government

Speaker: NA
Text: has remained committed to the long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: protection of the Great Barrier Reef' when

Speaker: NA
Text: the government will not seriously address

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns that a three-degree rise in tempera-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture could bleach 97 per cent of the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef and that coral reef communities

Speaker: NA
Text: will be replaced by algal communities by

Speaker: NA
Text: 2030. The government has now cynically

Speaker: NA
Text: announced, four months before an election,

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives which will placate the growing

Speaker: NA
Text: anger of Australians. But we know what

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Howard government really

Speaker: NA
Text: think about the threat of climate change.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are climate change sceptics. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: thrown the precautionary principle out the

Speaker: NA
Text: window. Some members opposite believe-

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed one has openly stated-that climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change is an issue for ‘trendy coffee sippers'.

Speaker: NA
Text: What a disgrace.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has not only spread mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: information about the consequences of

Speaker: NA
Text: global warming, particularly for the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef, but also deliberately taken a

Speaker: NA
Text: wrecking ball to the international commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity's attempts to establish a treaty to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the volume of greenhouse gas emissions. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has tried in vain to turn the debate about cli-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate change into a mutually exclusive

Speaker: NA
Text: choice between environmental protection

Speaker: NA
Text: and job protection. This is nonsense. The

Speaker: NA
Text: destruction of the Great Barrier Reef from

Speaker: NA
Text: the effects of climate change directly puts at

Speaker: NA
Text: risk 200,000 jobs in a $4.3 billion tourism

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. While some members opposite sit

Speaker: NA
Text: back and ridicule scientists from home and

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad as ‘trendy coffee sippers', the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef and many tourism jobs are

Speaker: NA
Text: slowly facing destruction as a result of their

Speaker: NA
Text: inaction. This is a scandalous and disgraceful

Speaker: NA
Text: situation. It is vital that the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park Authority be given every

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to provide independent advice to

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister, and it is important that this ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice is taken heed of. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: 7.30 pm, I propose the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: Lalor) (7.29 pm)-Today

Speaker: NA
Text: during question time the Treasurer was asked

Speaker: NA
Text: a question by the shadow Treasurer about the

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity performance of this nation. As

Speaker: NA
Text: you would no doubt recall, the last thing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer actually wanted to talk about was

Speaker: NA
Text: the productivity performance of this nation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: can understand why the Treasurer would

Speaker: NA
Text: rather say anything or do anything than an-

Speaker: NA
Text: swer in a straightforward fashion a question

Speaker: NA
Text: about this nation's productivity because, if he

Speaker: NA
Text: were to answer that question in a straight-

Speaker: NA
Text: forward fashion, he would have to admit that

Speaker: NA
Text: the productivity record of this country under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government is a track record of

Speaker: NA
Text: failure.

Speaker: NA
Text: As we know, this government frequently

Speaker: NA
Text: comes into this chamber and makes all sorts

Speaker: NA
Text: of assertions about productivity and about its

Speaker: NA
Text: connection with its extreme industrial rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions laws. But what we know from the facts

Speaker: NA
Text: is that productivity under this government is

Speaker: NA
Text: in deeply concerning territory. Indeed, for

Speaker: NA
Text: the first six months following the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mencement of this government's extreme

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial relations laws, productivity in this

Speaker: NA
Text: nation went backwards. It is presently at a

Speaker: NA
Text: staggeringly low 1.5 per cent compared to an

Speaker: NA
Text: historical average of 2.3 per cent, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: very budget papers the Treasurer launched

Speaker: NA
Text: with such a flourish last night confirm that

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity will plummet again from the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of the next financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can well understand that the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: would rather stand at the dispatch box con-

Speaker: NA
Text: juring up any form of distraction than answer

Speaker: NA
Text: in a straightforward way a question about

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity-because he has no answer. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the course of the Treasurer clutching for dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tractions at the dispatch box today, he made

Speaker: NA
Text: the following statement. He was talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about Labor's industrial relations policy. He

Speaker: NA
Text: preferred to talk about that than deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity issues, and he said in the course

Speaker: NA
Text: of talking about the policy:

Speaker: NA
Text: The people who think that include Sir Rod Ed-

Speaker: NA
Text: dington, the Labor Party adviser in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial relations, the person the Deputy Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition dismissively refers to as ‘an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other voice'-

Speaker: NA
Text: At that stage I responded-and I do apolo-

Speaker: NA
Text: gise to you, Mr Speaker, for interjecting on

Speaker: NA
Text: that occasion-by interjecting, ‘Not true!'

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer's statement is not true in two

Speaker: NA
Text: respects. Firstly, I object to the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer has described Sir Rod Edding-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton. Of course, Sir Rod Eddington is a noted

Speaker: NA
Text: member of Australia's business community

Speaker: NA
Text: with a formidable history in Australian busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness. He is a former British Airways chief

Speaker: NA
Text: executive who now sits on boards including

Speaker: NA
Text: Rio Tinto and News Corporation. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed by the Labor leader Mr Rudd in

Speaker: NA
Text: February as the chair of Labor's business

Speaker: NA
Text: advisory panel. I believe the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer described Sir Rod Eddington

Speaker: NA
Text: today was inappropriate in this House. Be-

Speaker: NA
Text: yond that, the Treasurer today suggested in

Speaker: NA
Text: his answer, avoiding the question about pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity, that I had dismissively referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Rod Eddington. That is completely un-

Speaker: NA
Text: true. The newspaper article that the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: tabled to try to prove his spurious claims

Speaker: NA
Text: quotes me in the following terms:

Speaker: NA
Text: Last night, however, Ms Gillard said it would

Speaker: NA
Text: be “very unfair in any way to say I was

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissive” of Sir Rod's contribution to Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I did object to that; I do object to that. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Rod Eddington is an important person in the

Speaker: NA
Text: business community, he is an important ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: viser for Labor, I value the discussions I have

Speaker: NA
Text: had with him, I look forward to more discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions with him and I think it is inappropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Treasurer made remarks in those

Speaker: NA
Text: terms in the parliament today.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it is not candour that we expect from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government when we stand in

Speaker: NA
Text: this parliament. We do not get it, we do not

Speaker: NA
Text: see it on matters like this and we do not see it

Speaker: NA
Text: on matters of public policy in this nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the areas in which the least candour is

Speaker: NA
Text: shown is industrial relations, where this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is now pretending that it has a new

Speaker: NA
Text: policy which would make a difference to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian families. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Stanley Thomas Crisp

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Text: Moreton) (7.35

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-As unfortunately often has been the

Speaker: NA
Text: case in recent months, I wish tonight to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cord the passing of a great Australian. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: it is important that, as individual members of

Speaker: NA
Text: this place, we take time to pay tribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: people who maybe are not making a name

Speaker: NA
Text: for themselves in the daily news, who are not

Speaker: NA
Text: on the television every night and who are not

Speaker: NA
Text: necessarily seeking any attention but just

Speaker: NA
Text: getting on with the job. Tonight I lament the

Speaker: NA
Text: passing of Stanley Thomas Crisp, British

Speaker: NA
Text: Empire Medal winner, Centenary Medal

Speaker: NA
Text: winner, Australian Active Service Medal

Speaker: NA
Text: recipient 1945-75 with Clasps ‘Malaysia'

Speaker: NA
Text: and ‘Vietnam', General Service Medal with

Speaker: NA
Text: Clasp ‘Malay Peninsula', Vietnam Medal,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Service Medal 1945-75 with

Speaker: NA
Text: Clasp ‘Far Eastern Strategic Reserve', Long

Speaker: NA
Text: Service and Good Conduct Medal, Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Defence Medal, Pingat Jasa Malaysia

Speaker: NA
Text: Medal and Returned from Active Service

Speaker: NA
Text: Badge. Stan Crisp achieved the rank of Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Petty Officer within the Royal Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy-a ‘20-year man' and someone who

Speaker: NA
Text: saw active service in the Malaya confronta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and also from 1966-71 served Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia's interests in Vietnam. In more recent

Speaker: NA
Text: times Stan Crisp found other ways to serve

Speaker: NA
Text: our country and our local community. From

Speaker: NA
Text: 1995 Stan Crisp was the Secretary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Yeronga-Dutton Park sub-branch of the RSL.

Speaker: NA
Text: He was made a life member of the Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland RSL. For 12 years he was the pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner welfare officer of the Yeronga-Dutton

Speaker: NA
Text: Park sub-branch and a qualified Justice of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Peace.

Speaker: NA
Text: I take the time to mention Stan Crisp,

Speaker: NA
Text: cause he was a fundamentally decent man

Speaker: NA
Text: whom, sadly, we lost on Sunday after what

Speaker: NA
Text: seemed to be a short battle with cancer. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was just 78 years of age. Stan was fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: with a great deal of determination to make

Speaker: NA
Text: the Anzac Day ceremonies at both Gair Park

Speaker: NA
Text: and, indeed, at the Ekibin Memorial Park,

Speaker: NA
Text: Cracknell Road. I know that Stan was des-

Speaker: NA
Text: perate to be at both ceremonies, but his

Speaker: NA
Text: health made it impossible. Ken Railton, the

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-president of Yeronga-Dutton Park sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: branch, was not sure on Anzac Day whether

Speaker: NA
Text: Stan would actually see the day out, but in

Speaker: NA
Text: Stan's typical style he fought on.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that Ken and the new president,

Speaker: NA
Text: Tony Robinson, and all members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Yeronga-Dutton Park subbranch will miss

Speaker: NA
Text: Stan. His straight-talking, right up and down

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to things was something that left an

Speaker: NA
Text: indelible mark on me as the local member,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I am very grateful for everything he did.

Speaker: NA
Text: Stan told me quite a few years ago, ‘You

Speaker: NA
Text: need to get a bit of Navy into you, son; you

Speaker: NA
Text: need to get a bit of Navy experience.' When

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity came up for me, under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Defence Force parliamentary pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram, to join the ranks of the defence forces

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Middle East and to go and see for my-

Speaker: NA
Text: self what our troops were doing over there, I

Speaker: NA
Text: took it. So just a few weeks ago Stan was

Speaker: NA
Text: very much in my conversation. When I was

Speaker: NA
Text: on the HMAS Toowoomba, I said, ‘I'm look-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing forward to getting back and talking to

Speaker: NA
Text: Stan and saying, “Well, I've got a bit of

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy in me”.' When I spoke to the chief

Speaker: NA
Text: petty officers onboard the HMAS

Speaker: NA
Text: Toowoomba, I knew the style of man that

Speaker: NA
Text: Stan was because, again, we are seeing that

Speaker: NA
Text: in the contemporary chief petty officers, the

Speaker: NA
Text: able seamen and all of the senior officers on

Speaker: NA
Text: board the Toowoomba.

Speaker: NA
Text: Stan Crisp would be proud of the work

Speaker: NA
Text: that is being done by his counterparts today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Defence Force personnel are mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: being friends every day as we work with our

Speaker: NA
Text: Iraqi counterparts to secure a long, lasting

Speaker: NA
Text: peace and freedom that are underpinned by a

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy of the Iraqi people's choosing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Stan served on ships such as the Sydney, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cootumundra, the Melbourne, the Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: borough, the Vampire, the Yarra, the Voy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ager, the Quickmatch, the Parramatta and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Vendetta. Stan's 20 years of service in

Speaker: NA
Text: illuniform in Australia, which he completed in

Speaker: NA
Text: June 1972, was only surpassed by the service

Speaker: NA
Text: he gave to Australia and particularly to the

Speaker: NA
Text: local community, which centres around the

Speaker: NA
Text: Yeronga-Dutton Park RSL and, indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: Yeronga Services Club, following his retire-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I say on behalf of Stan's wife and fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily and all of his mates at the Yeronga Ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices Club and the Yeronga-Dutton Park

Speaker: NA
Text: RSL, ‘Thanks very much, Stan.' (Time ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Text: Cunningham) (7.39 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: take the opportunity this evening to address

Speaker: NA
Text: what no doubt will shape up to be a very im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant debate in this country in the run-up to

Speaker: NA
Text: the election, and that is the future of educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and its role in improving the productiv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity and the long-term prosperity of the na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I want to address the claim by the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment that the budget announcements by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer prove that the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: its own education revolution underway. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge that claim-I hope fairly signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantly, because there is so much that could

Speaker: NA
Text: be said-in the few minutes available to me.

Speaker: NA
Text: The centrepiece of the government's claim

Speaker: NA
Text: on education is the $5 billion university en-

Speaker: NA
Text: dowment fund. No doubt that is a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative, but it hardly addresses the issue

Speaker: NA
Text: university places and access and equity for

Speaker: NA
Text: university students. This fund will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: capital amounts of money-although obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously not a great deal if it is only $300 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion a year-and money for research facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties. That money is welcome, but it does not

Speaker: NA
Text: address the real challenge facing the great

Speaker: NA
Text: majority of students who find that it is the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of living that really creates a problem

Speaker: NA
Text: for them in completing their university stud-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies. Indeed, with Wollongong University in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate, I am constantly made aware

Speaker: NA
Text: by uni students of the struggle to balance

Speaker: NA
Text: their study and their work requirements and

Speaker: NA
Text: that they really have no other option but to

Speaker: NA
Text: work. Often many of them carry a full work-

Speaker: NA
Text: load on top of trying to complete their stud-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies. So, while this centrepiece item no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: is welcome, it will hardly address the issues

Speaker: NA
Text: of making sure that many of our young peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple are able to access and complete univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity study.

Speaker: NA
Text: The sad thing about the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals in the budget under education,

Speaker: NA
Text: where they are trying to claim that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: gazumped Labor, is that there was nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: about preschool education. Having a back-

Speaker: NA
Text: ground in both education and juvenile jus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice, I am profoundly aware of the impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance of the formative years for young peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple in both their social development and their

Speaker: NA
Text: educational development. Labor has commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ted itself to providing 15 hours of preschool

Speaker: NA
Text: education a week for all four-year-old chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren in order to provide them with the solid

Speaker: NA
Text: foundation they will need when they start

Speaker: NA
Text: school. There is absolutely nothing more

Speaker: NA
Text: important that you could do than to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure, as much as you can, that every kid who

Speaker: NA
Text: starts school starts from a level playing field.

Speaker: NA
Text: The capacity to access the pre-reading and

Speaker: NA
Text: pre-numeracy type skills that you get in

Speaker: NA
Text: those programs is absolutely vital. There was

Speaker: NA
Text: of nothing at all from the government in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget about preschool education. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: completely missed the point that early inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: vention programs in all sorts of areas, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly in education, can make a profound

Speaker: NA
Text: difference to the long-term learning of young

Speaker: NA
Text: people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then we come to the schools sector. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have a new commitment to an old pilot,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the tutorial voucher scheme. We all

Speaker: NA
Text: remember what a great success that scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: was! Indeed, I remember young people in

Speaker: NA
Text: my area who had not passed the 2003

Speaker: NA
Text: benchmark test being told that they had a

Speaker: NA
Text: voucher, yet many of them did not get that

Speaker: NA
Text: voucher until after they had sat the 2005 test.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rather than the government extending that

Speaker: NA
Text: program, I personally think it would be far

Speaker: NA
Text: better to use that money to provide literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: and numeracy support in schools, as Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: has proposed in its education revolution pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram; that would have been a better option.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the government is going to run this priva-

Speaker: NA
Text: tised version, it should at least ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities and services are there to be

Speaker: NA
Text: vided to the young people who need them

Speaker: NA
Text: and it should not leave parents as disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed as they were under the pilot.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, there is the great initiative for

Speaker: NA
Text: technical education. As long as I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: here, the government has been telling us that

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor people are far too wrapped up in uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity education and that they do not underSydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: stand how important vocational education is.

Speaker: NA
Text: What was the big loser in this budget? It

Speaker: NA
Text: vocational education and training. The best

Speaker: NA
Text: the government could manage were three

Speaker: NA
Text: new ATCs, when it does not even have the

Speaker: NA
Text: current promised crop up and running. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: that are up and running are not even filling

Speaker: NA
Text: their quotas for students. The students that

Speaker: NA
Text: are in them, by and large, are missing out

Speaker: NA
Text: employers; they cannot even get people to

Speaker: NA
Text: take them on for their work component. So

Speaker: NA
Text: let us throw some more money at something

Speaker: NA
Text: that is struggling to survive,

Speaker: NA
Text: budget provides a very weak response to the

Speaker: NA
Text: needs for education to develop productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: for the future. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Cook Electorate: Proposed Desalination

Speaker: Mr BAIRD
Text: Cook) (7.45 pm)-I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to draw the attention of the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: further negligent policy making by the New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales government in relation to its

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed desalination plant on the Kurnell

Speaker: NA
Text: Peninsula. My electorate of Cook is to be the is enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: home of this proposed plant, and just a few

Speaker: NA
Text: days ago the arrangements for its construc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion became public knowledge. The state

Speaker: NA
Text: government is effectively going to dig

Speaker: NA
Text: trenches down the middle of the Sutherland

Speaker: NA
Text: Shire and run pipes for the carriage of water

Speaker: NA
Text: from Botany Bay to the inner suburbs of

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney. These arrangements are very bad

Speaker: NA
Text: news for Sutherland Shire residents. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: being used as nothing more than a thorough-

Speaker: NA
Text: fare for the water supplies of inner Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: pro- The plans have confirmed what most of us

Speaker: NA
Text: feared about a desalination plant in Kurnell.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only will the plant's construction cause

Speaker: NA
Text: mass disruptions to shire residents over a

Speaker: NA
Text: two-year period; it will also contribute to the

Speaker: NA
Text: further decline of Botany Bay-all this for a

Speaker: NA
Text: plant which will produce a relatively small

Speaker: NA
Text: volume of water for the inner suburbs of

Speaker: NA
Text: Sutherland Shire residents have a long his-

Speaker: NA
Text: was tory of doing their bit for the benefit of

Speaker: NA
Text: greater Sydney, but the desalination plant is

Speaker: NA
Text: taking our generosity too far. The lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: community consultation about the construc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of this plant, especially at local council

Speaker: NA
Text: level, has been entirely inadequate. When

Speaker: NA
Text: residential driveways are blocked, local car

Speaker: NA
Text: on parks and parklands begin to close and noise

Speaker: NA
Text: levels from the pipe's construction reach se-

Speaker: NA
Text: vere levels, the shire will be fully aware of

Speaker: NA
Text: the raw deal we got from the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: as it is. This Wales government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst residents will be inconvenienced

Speaker: NA
Text: by these disruptions, a larger concern for us

Speaker: NA
Text: all is the permanent environmental damage

Speaker: NA
Text: the desal plant will cause to Kurnell and

Speaker: NA
Text: Plant Botany Bay. The environment in this region,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is of course the landing site of Captain

Speaker: NA
Text: Cook and the birthplace of our modern na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, has suffered enough damage over the

Speaker: NA
Text: years through overdevelopment and sand

Speaker: NA
Text: mining. Surely now is the time to say enough

Speaker: NA
Text: The desal pipelines outlined in these plans

Speaker: NA
Text: will stretch eight kilometres from Kurnell to

Speaker: NA
Text: Kyeemagh. In order to lay these pipelines I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand a four-metre deep trench will be

Speaker: NA
Text: dug across the bottom of Botany Bay. More

Speaker: NA
Text: than a million cubic metres of sand will be

Speaker: NA
Text: dug from the floor in an eight kilometre arc.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst most of this sand will be used as

Speaker: NA
Text: backfill, this process will have a detrimental

Speaker: NA
Text: effect on our bay. The most recent environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental study of the effects of the desal plant

Speaker: NA
Text: on the environment tells us that Botany Bay

Speaker: NA
Text: will lose a further 2.6 hectares of seagrass.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst this only amounts to approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: one per cent of the Botany Bay area, it shows

Speaker: NA
Text: us that, rather than finding ways of preserv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the environment in our region, the New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales government feels that it is okay

Speaker: NA
Text: to just take a little more. And what will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: place this seagrass? Eight kilometres of pipe-

Speaker: NA
Text: lines, covered in concrete. Kurnell is of

Speaker: NA
Text: course a place of major historical signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cance, but it is also an environmentally

Speaker: NA
Text: noteworthy site. It is home to a variety of

Speaker: NA
Text: rare birds and marine life and is a Ramsar

Speaker: NA
Text: site. I still wonder what effect the 750 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion litres of hot concentrated brine will have

Speaker: NA
Text: on this wildlife once it is sent off the coast

Speaker: NA
Text: Kurnell every day.

Speaker: NA
Text: The desalination plant is strongly opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: by many constituents in my electorate. After

Speaker: NA
Text: watching several weeks of solid coastal rain

Speaker: NA
Text: lost out to sea, many of us are wondering

Speaker: NA
Text: why the New South Wales government is

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to invest a small amount of the $1.8

Speaker: NA
Text: billion being spent on the plant in other wa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter saving strategies. As announced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer last night, the Australian govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is offering substantial initiatives to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: courage people to install rainwater tanks in

Speaker: NA
Text: their homes. The message is clear for all ju-

Speaker: NA
Text: risdictions responsible for the provision or

Speaker: NA
Text: management of water resources: we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: catch and use more rain. This is an obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: and sensible solution. It is a solution far su-

Speaker: NA
Text: perior to digging up suburbs to send desali-

Speaker: NA
Text: nated seawater halfway across Sydney. Fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: thermore, it is an environmentally sustain-

Speaker: NA
Text: able approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: The desalination plant was a major issue

Speaker: NA
Text: for shire residents in the recent New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales state election. With the election now

Speaker: NA
Text: over I call upon the New South Wales gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment to cancel the construction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: desalination plant in Kurnell. I ask that they

Speaker: NA
Text: revisit more effective strategies in water

Speaker: NA
Text: management that are more environmentally

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Ms GRIERSON
Text: Newcastle) (7.49

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-I cannot pass up this opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a closer look at what this budget has

Speaker: NA
Text: offered for education. Having spent three

Speaker: NA
Text: decades of my career as a teacher, a demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: stration teacher, a curriculum consultant and

Speaker: NA
Text: a principal, and over a quarter of a century as

Speaker: NA
Text: a parent-as many people here have-of

Speaker: NA
Text: children passing through education systems,

Speaker: NA
Text: I have a special interest, just like the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian people.

Speaker: NA
Text: So what did the budget offer? Early learn-

Speaker: NA
Text: of ing? A best start in life? Some early interven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion programs for children? Some medical

Speaker: NA
Text: checks to make sure they start school prop-

Speaker: NA
Text: erly? Nothing. For primary school education

Speaker: NA
Text: all I could see was a $700 voucher system

Speaker: NA
Text: for parents to put towards private tuition. It

Speaker: NA
Text: sounds good but there was nothing for sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port teachers for children with learning diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culties, nothing extra for school counsellors

Speaker: NA
Text: to do those diagnostic assessments and no

Speaker: NA
Text: funds for special literacy programs or nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: meracy programs. For those sorts of ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proaches, which allow each child to have

Speaker: NA
Text: greater individual attention and support,

Speaker: NA
Text: there was nothing at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am waiting to see what is in this $700

Speaker: NA
Text: voucher system that can make sure children

Speaker: NA
Text: actually benefit and to stop people making

Speaker: NA
Text: close private arrangements like nominating

Speaker: NA
Text: an accommodating friend or relative as a

Speaker: NA
Text: tutor and then pocketing the money and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: nying a child an opportunity. What about

Speaker: NA
Text: those tutors who do not deliver value for

Speaker: NA
Text: money, who do not understand the special

Speaker: NA
Text: needs of students? They will do very well,

Speaker: NA
Text: thank you very much, but the students are

Speaker: NA
Text: not at the centre of this decision. Apparently,

Speaker: NA
Text: that is not the government's concern-as

Speaker: NA
Text: long as the cheque is in the mail in an elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion year, as long as those flagpoles have

Speaker: NA
Text: flags flying and as long as chaplains are

Speaker: NA
Text: there to provide some sort of support, we

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently do not really need to worry about

Speaker: NA
Text: child-centred learning.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps secondary schools are benefiting.

Speaker: NA
Text: But there is not much there at all. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: $5,000 bonus for teachers who complete-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I quote the minister from question time

Speaker: NA
Text: today-‘the government's summer school'.

Speaker: NA
Text: It sounds a bit like the Bart Simpson ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach, doesn't it-write 100 times on the

Speaker: NA
Text: blackboard: ‘AWAs are good, unions are

Speaker: NA
Text: bad.' That is a real concern. What does a

Speaker: NA
Text: government summer school look like? Per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps it is individual schools that need to say

Speaker: NA
Text: what professional development and training

Speaker: NA
Text: would benefit their students, not a govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment summer school. It sounds exceedingly

Speaker: NA
Text: like Big Brother.

Speaker: NA
Text: At this stage little is known about the

Speaker: NA

Text: Budget 2007-08

Speaker: Mr BARTLETT
Text: Macquarie) (7.54

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-It is really quite disappointing to see

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite scratching around, trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to find something negative to say about a

Speaker: NA
Text: budget that has been received overwhelm-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly in a positive way and that contains a

Speaker: NA
Text: vast number of positive initiatives. It locks in

Speaker: NA
Text: our prosperity, continues our strong track

Speaker: NA
Text: record of sound economic management and

Speaker: NA
Text: invests for the future. Yet we have to go

Speaker: NA
Text: through this charade where members oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: site try to find something negative for the

Speaker: NA
Text: sake of negativity.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is much I would like to say about

Speaker: NA
Text: the strengths of this budget generally but I

Speaker: NA
Text: will save it for the debate on the appropria-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions bill. Tonight I would like to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: about some aspects regarding education that

Speaker: NA
Text: are of particular interest to me. The member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Newcastle has referred to the funding

Speaker: NA
Text: announcement of a dental school for Charles

Speaker: NA
Text: Sturt University. I am delighted to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: assistant minister at the dispatch box. The

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Parkes has worked with me and

Speaker: NA
Text: a number of other colleagues, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Riverina and Senator Nash, to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring this proposal to fruition. Last night, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget, the Treasurer announced $65

Speaker: NA
Text: million for a dental school for Charles Sturt

Speaker: NA
Text: University. This is an initiative that will

Speaker: NA
Text: vide long-term solutions to the dental crisis

Speaker: NA
Text: that affects New South Wales, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: regional New South Wales. This proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: includes $54.5 million for the establishment

Speaker: NA
Text: of the dental school itself, $4 million for

Speaker: NA
Text: dent accommodation and $6.6 million over

Speaker: NA
Text: four years for the places for training in the

Speaker: NA
Text: dental schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: The structure is that the undergraduate

Speaker: NA
Text: preclinical and clinical work will be done at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Orange and Wagga campuses. For the

Speaker: NA
Text: graduate years-years 4 and 5-clinics will

Speaker: NA
Text: be established in Bathurst, Albury and

Speaker: NA
Text: Dubbo. This proposal that will cover vast

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of central western and western New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales that area suffering so badly. The

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal is that there will be 240 dental

Speaker: NA
Text: places in the pipeline and students will begin

Speaker: NA
Text: studying in 2009. Three years later there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be an anticipated 30 graduates a year in oral

Speaker: NA
Text: health and related oral health sciences. Then

Speaker: NA
Text: two years after that there will be the start of a

Speaker: NA
Text: stream of 30 graduates in dentistry each year

Speaker: NA
Text: from these clinical schools in this university.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a quality proposal. I want to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulate Charles Sturt University on the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of work that they put into building

Speaker: NA
Text: this proposal and for their research and hard

Speaker: NA
Text: work. They put in the hard yards.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was obvious, when this proposal was

Speaker: NA
Text: brought to me and to my colleagues, that it

Speaker: NA
Text: was worth supporting. This proposal is a

Speaker: NA
Text: win-win situation. Firstly, it provides extra

Speaker: NA
Text: education places in regional New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, in the central west of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, which is a part of the state in which I

Speaker: NA
Text: am very interested. It provides improved,

Speaker: NA
Text: increased, expanded educational opportuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties for young people in this part of the state.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, it directly adds to the supply of

Speaker: NA
Text: dental services because in years 4 and 5

Speaker: NA
Text: those students will be under very close su-

Speaker: NA
Text: pervision working in those clinical facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: in Bathurst, Dubbo, Orange, Wagga and Al-

Speaker: NA
Text: probury, directly providing both public and pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate dental services in those areas of great

Speaker: NA
Text: need. Thirdly, and perhaps most signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantly, this project will address the dental

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis at its root source, and that is an inade-

Speaker: NA
Text: stuquate supply of dentists. By increasing the

Speaker: NA
Text: supply of dentists, we will be addressing the

Speaker: NA
Text: key issues that affect the shortage of dental

Speaker: NA
Text: services right throughout the state.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a quality proposal. I want to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulate everyone involved. I want to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulate Charles Sturt University Vice-

Speaker: NA
Text: Chancellor Professor Ian Goulter. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate Marge Bollinger and the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee of volunteers that were behind this. I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to congratulate and thank my col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues on assisting me in this project.
